fields.headline: Sven passes test as Lennon loses trial by fury
fields.trailText: Eriksson's is a symbolic recruitment, an appointment that breaks the narrow nationalistic bigotry from which Neil Lennon is currently suffering.
fields.body:
Five minutes before kick-off against Spain on Wednesday night and Sven-Goran Eriksson faced the toughest moment of his career. Standing in the Villa Park dug-out, all he could see were cameras trained on him, waiting for the most crucial test yet of his eligibility as England manager: the singing of the national anthem.

Would he join in? Did he know any of that embarrassing second verse about keeping uppity Scots in check? Or was he going to fry in the arc lights like a footballing John Redwood, vaguely moving his lips in a desperate approximation of its plodding doggerel?

As we have come to expect in the short period of his tenure, Eriksson was too smart to fall for that trick. An hour or two of preparatory cramming and he clearly knew more of the words than either of the Nickys, Barmby and Butt. As the photoflashes lit up round him, and he remembered the bit about sending her victorious, Eriksson couldn't help but smile that wry smile of his. How funny it was, a regiment of photographers trying to catch him out. It is good that Eriksson thought it was funny.

As a newcomer to this country, he doesn't yet find the excesses cluttering his job intimidating; he still finds them ridiculous. But the implication of what was going on there was anything but funny. Because what was being gathered was ammunition for a nasty little nationalistic war in waiting.

Had Eriksson's team lost, those shots would already have been fired, serving as evidence that as a foreigner he isn't up to the job. But never mind, he will lose one day, the pictures can wait. Defeat is when they will strike, those for whom the pragmatic solution to England's coaching problem that Eriksson represents will never, ever be acceptable. England for the English and by the English is their credo. And it is by no means a theory merely confined to the flabby-jowelled lager monsters in Hackett polo shirts who attach themselves to the England side. There are plenty in the press who feel that way and are waiting their moment.

Meanwhile as Sven faced his snapper squad, a couple of hundred miles west, Neil Lennon, too, was undergoing a trial of his loyalty. Except Lennon was doing anything but smiling through it. Because, this being Northern Ireland, the verdict had long since been decided. The moment the player signed for Celtic he was finished with those who believe they are upholding the cultural integrity of their nation.

Despite being an ecumenical club even when Rangers were strictly Protestant, in certain Ulster eyes Celtic represent the third prong on a devil's trident alongside the Pope and the IRA. Even though Lennon had pledged himself to Northern Ireland, when he could just as easily have turned out for the Republic (anyone born on the island of Ireland qualifies), signing for the Bhoys immediately made him suspect. A traitor, a fifth columnist, a pariah.

Just to remind him of the verdict meted out for his crime, the words "Neil Lennon RIP" were daubed on a wall in his home town, next to a cartoon representation of a lynching. Lennon did his best this week, made all the right noises about how he only wanted to play for his country and how he wasn't interested in politics. But still he was booed to the rafters by elements of the home support on Wednesday night. He left for Scotland before the end of the match, doubtless under police instruction, intimidated out of the land of his birth like hundreds before him, not sure if he wants to play there again.

The irony of scaring off their best player is lost on the kind of nationalistic blockhead who reckons the ethnic purity of their team is far more important than winning occasionally. And such thinking is by no means confined to Belfast. This week, the International Herald Tribune carried a front page report on the growing problem of racism in football. Linking the trial of the four Leeds United players on charges of assaulting an Asian student with the ugly booing of black players in Italy, the paper painted a picture for its American audience of a European sport riven with prejudice and cheapened by intolerance.

It would be nice to say the paper was wrong, that the fact England fielded as many black players as white on Wednesday against Spain meant our national game was some kind of cheery melting-pot love-in of a sport. But then you look at what happened to Lennon on the same evening. And you realise football - particularly international football - is a game which, because of the easy comparisons with other nations it provides through competition, will always be prone to the attention of bigots.

Which is why, in a sense, Eriksson's is such a symbolic recruitment, an appointment that breaks narrow nationalistic convention. And the longer he keeps winning, the more people will agree.

webTitle: Fulham aim for the high life

fields.headline: Fulham aim for the high life
fields.trailText: The granting of planning permission for the redevelopment of Craven Cottage into a 30,000-seat stadium takes Mohamed al Fayed's dream of Premiership football a step closer to reality.
fields.body:
With hangovers still pounding after the local council granted planning permission for the redevelopment of Craven Cottage into a 30,000-seat stadium, Fulham fans may not be relishing a weekend of significant meetings at the top of the First Division.

Following Watford's visit to Birmingham last night and Blackburn's game with West Bromwich Albion this afternoon, Jean Tigana's side host second-place Bolton tomorrow. Not that the skirmishes beneath them should overly concern the Cottagers - fast becoming black-and-white specks disappearing over the Nationwide horizon - who can open a 15-point lead at the top.

"No one's taking anything for granted that we will be playing Premiership football next season, but Tuesday's decision on the stadium takes my dream a step closer to reality," said the Fulham chairman Mohamed al Fayed, who will bankroll the £70m redevelopment project. "It's brilliant news. A lot of people have put a lot of time into this so we are thrilled. It's such an important decision."

Work will begin on Craven Cottage at the end of next season, with Fulham seeking a groundshare for the 2002-03 campaign; neighbours Queens Park Rangers and Chelsea appear the likeliest candidates. But if, as seems inevitable, the Cottagers win promotion this season, the Premiership will briefly boast terraces once again.

"We are allowed that during the first year after promotion, so hopefully our fans will be watching top-flight football from standing terraces," confirmed Al Fayed.

The party atmosphere at tomorrow's game should not be dampened either by Fulham's inability to beat Bolton at home since 1986 - such trivia means little since the Al Fayed revolution - or the loss of the England Under-21 midfielder Sean Davis with a thigh injury. The visitors, who trailed after just 10 seconds in the reverse fixture at the Reebok Stadium and eventually lost 2-0, will be without their suspended defensive duo John O'Kane and Kevin Nolan, while Ricardo Gardner is doubtful with a head injury.

"Bolton's season hinges on their games against us and Blackburn in the FA Cup," said the Fulham defender Kit Symons, who has stepped into the breach left by the long-term absence of the club captain Chris Coleman with a broken leg.

"So much is in place now," added Fayed. "We have a manager capable of taking us and moulding us into a great club and for whom players want to play. Jean Tigana joined us on the understanding that he would have all the backing from me to build a great club. He will. In years to come I want Fulham FC to be up there alongside Man United, Arsenal and Liverpool. It's a huge task, but it's within our grasp. This is an incredibly exciting time for us."

webTitle: Busby's philosophy lives on at Old Trafford

fields.headline: Busby's philosophy lives on at Old Trafford
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor meets the United coach who helped giants grow.
fields.body:
There is an old philosophy at Manchester United - who face Leeds United at Elland Road this morning - that has been passed down through the coaching staff since Jimmy Murphy's days nurturing the Busby generation. Potential, it is drummed into the young players, should be nothing more than a temporary condition, the prelude to greatness.

With this in mind a decade or so ago, Eric Harrison called a number of meetings with the brightest prospects from his youth team. One by one, he assured them that if they maintained their focus it would not be long before they were playing for the first team and, beyond that, winning international honours.

"I went round all of them separately, the Neville brothers, David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Nicky Butt and Paul Scholes," he says. "Call me very lucky or very good. I've never done anything like that en masse but these boys were so good it was frightening. You just had to look at the standard of training to know we were on the brink of something special. Ryan was already in the first team and the rest were queuing up behind him. I didn't have to be a rocket scientist."

To many observers he may be just another face in the background but inside Old Trafford, with a seventh title in nine years now a formality, Harrison's contribution could never be understated. From boys to adults, youthful exuberance to assured maturity, the nucleus of his 1992 FA Youth Cup-winning side - "my boys" - not only forms the hub of Sir Alex Ferguson's all-conquering team, but, if Wednesday's game against Spain is an accurate gauge, the solid fulcrum of Sven-Goran Eriksson's England plans.

"I can still remember when Mark Hughes, Paul Ince and Andrei Kanchelskis were sold and people were saying the boss was raving bonkers. Everyone thought he had gone mad, didn't they? But he knew what he was doing, he knew all right," he says.

"I had been banging on his door every day: 'When are these kids going to get their chance?' So in the end he got rid of three established players to create some room for the ones coming through. It was a masterstroke, really."

Harrison's role at Old Trafford may now be confined to the odd scouting mission - since last season he has been working with Mark Hughes and the Wales national squad - but for the foreseeable future the legacy of his "dream team" makes it difficult to see how United can be dethroned, certainly in the next five years.

"I genuinely believe every one of these young players wants to remain here. This team will get even better," says Harrison. "They want to be the best-ever United team and the only way they can do that is by sticking together. OK, it will be a nervy time when the manager leaves but everything is in place for his successor, whether it be Steve McClaren, a foreigner or whoever."

 Eric Harrison's autobiography, The View from the Dugout, is available from The Parrs Wood Press, price £8.95

webTitle: Hartson the terroriser aims to frighten opponents

fields.headline: Hartson the terroriser aims to frighten opponents
fields.trailText: Roy Collins talks to Coventry's hope for salvation about games, goals and his dodgy knee.
fields.body:
John Hartson knows he has caused much amusement in football circles in the past 12 months as a player with a most unusual passing problem. He is incapable, so it would seem, of passing a routine medical.

Even Coventry City, who signed him from Wimbledon just over three weeks ago, could not give his right knee a bill of health clean enough to satisfy their insurers, which is how they came up with the ingenious plan to pay a £15,000 instalment for every game he plays, rising to a maximum £500,000.

But, if the rest of football has been doubled up in laughter, the disappointments of the past year have caused real pain for Hartson, most poignantly when his proposed transfer to Rangers fell through last September. In fairness he never hinted that he wanted to leave Wimbledon when they were relegated from the Premiership last season.

He has been the victim of modern football's ruthless financial structure, in which the Premiership clubs commandeer a vastly unequal slice of the TV millions. He says: "When Wimbledon went down, it became obvious the club's Norwegian owners wanted me off the wage bill. In the end they were panicking, thinking: 'He's failed three medicals, we're not going to get any money for him.' And Terry Burton, the manager was reluctant to play me because he knew I would probably be on my way.

"No disrespect to Tottenham but I wasn't too upset when they pulled out of a deal last April because I'd just had an operation and wasn't really ready for them. But I was devastated when Rangers decided not to go ahead. I'd pulled out of a Wales game to fly up there and there were hundreds of supporters to meet me. I said to my missus, bloody hell, I fancy this and I was so ready for a new culture, a new environment, that I agreed terms straight away."

Hartson took out his frustration on some of the Nationwide First Division's whipping boys, scoring twice against both Sheffield Wednesday and Huddersfield on his next two appearances, which also said much for his professionalism. Earlier this season a move to Charlton was also mooted but the asking price of £5m was so high as to exclude negotiation.

To add to his frustration Hartson insists that the battles of his wounded knee have been greatly exaggerated. He says: "There must be something that comes up on a scan which frightens the doctors but I don't think any footballer's knee would be a pretty sight. A heck of a fuss has been made about my knee but it's perfectly okay and I have more niggles with my ankles, thighs and hamstrings."

He does not want to shout about that too loudly. But because of his previous disappointments he admits that, when he arrived for his medical at Coventry, he felt nervous. The compromise over money finally allowed the move to be completed and Hartson overlooked Coventry's precarious league position because of his respect for the manager Gordon Strachan.

Hartson was robbed of a debut goal against his former club West Ham which was disallowed for a phantom foul but scuffed one in against Charlton last week which would have delighted Coventry, if only because such a messy effort suggested that the rub of the green might finally be going their way.

He says: "I'm sure Ian Rush got a few of those in his time. And I know I will score goals, I always have at all my clubs. I'm not one of those forwards who gets the ball in space and thinks, oh no, I'm not sure I'll put this away. If I get the chances, I'll score."

Strachan said he signed Hartson as he wanted someone on his team sheet who frightens opponents. As everyone knows, Hartson managed to frighten even his team-mates with that infamous incident at West Ham involving Eyal Berkovic.

He says: "I probably frighten the gaffer because he's only 5ft 3in. But I take his words as a compliment. When I see the names of Sol Campbell or Ugo Ehiogu on a team sheet, I say to myself, 'I'm going to have a game today, I am going to have a battle.'"

On his way back to London from training the other day, Hartson was approached by a Coventry fan in a service station who said he thought it was unfair that there was so much pressure on him. Hartson, though, believes the pay-as-he-plays deal removes all the pressure.

It would have been far heavier, he says, had Rangers or Spurs made him a £7m player. He has felt the weight of his fee at all his clubs he says - at Arsenal he was a £2.5m teenager, West Ham took him off them for £3.5m and Wimbledon paid a club record £7.5m.

On that basis Coventry have got a bargain. And after his experience of relegation last season Hartson might be able to advise his Coventry team-mates on potential pratfalls.

He is reluctant to tempt fate by making that most dangerous of assessments, that his new team are too good to go down. But as evidence of the quality in the squad he points to the absentees on the training pitch this week caused by international demands. He himself was training with Wales in La Manga, where he also managed to swing a few clubs to maintain his golf handicap of eight.

If his team-mates can provide the ammunition, he is confident he can score the goals that will allow Coventry to extend their 34-year stay in the top flight. He says: "I can't produce miracles and I'm not Roy Of The Rovers. I can't beat 10 men and then knock the ball past the keeper. But I'll give 100% effort on the field and the training pitch and I'll get my share of goals."

If Coventry do go down, he will probably find himself at a club where his wages are again unsustainable. But should he rescue them, he may yet realise his dream of playing at Ibrox. He says: "I'm not the sort to lie awake at night saying please come back in for me, Rangers. But you never say never in football."

Age 25

League debut Luton 1 Nottm Forest 2, Aug 1993

International debut Bulgaria 3 Wales 1, March1995

Caps 20 Goals 2

Club Fee Games Goals

Luton - 63 13

Arsenal £2.5m 71 17

West Ham £5m 73 33

Wimbledon £7.5m 57 21

Coventry Paid per game 2 1

fields.headline: Transfer talks in deadlock
fields.trailText: Fifa and Uefa have told the European Commission that unlesss it changes its position on players who break contracts and compensation for small clubs, there can be no deal on the future of the transfer system.
fields.body:
Hopes of reaching agreement on the future of the transfer system have hit a major stumbling block after Fifa and Uefa warned that unless the European Commission changes its position on two crucial areas there can be no deal.

The two contentious issues are the length of sporting sanctions players who unilaterally break contracts should face and the amount of compensation small clubs should receive for developing players aged 23 and under.

Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive, has written to the Swedish prime minister Goran Persson, the current European Union president, criticising EU officials and warning him that unless they change their position football as a whole could be damaged and that a deal over the transfer system will not be reached.

Aigner wrote: "There can be no further compromises on this issue if we are to protect the fabric of our sport.

"We are now at the end of the road and fearful of the final outcome if the commission continue to dig their heels in on these fundamental items.

"We have found the commission officials almost impossible to deal with because of their unwillingness to accept the specific needs of the grassroots of the game and their total lack of understanding of how the development of players takes place."

Football and commission officials were hoping to finalise details of a new transfer system on Monday but a final outcome is unlikely to be announced next week.

The two sides have been locked in negotiations for the last six months after the commission ruled that the transfer system had to be amended to comply with European labour laws.

Regarding sanctions on players who break contracts, Fifa/Uefa want to see them banned for a minimum of one year. Under the new system, there would be two transfer windows and the commission is insisting that if a player breaks a contract he should only be banned from one transfer window to the next. Fifa/Uefa feel that this is not long enough.

Aigner wrote: "We believe this could be extremely disruptive to domestic and European club competitions with the potential of distorting those competitions at a crucial stage of their development."

The commission also wants to limit the amount of compensation small clubs should receive for finding and developing players who then move on to bigger clubs.

Commission officials yesterday refused to comment on the contents of Aigner's letter but insisted that they were optimistic that a solution could be reached.

The Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger, one of the most outspoken voices on the need to ensure contract stability in football, said yesterday: "I believe football needs stability to survive. You can only build a team with stability so I have tried to fight for that."

webTitle: Overworked O'Leary employs a little Kiddology

fields.headline: Overworked O'Leary employs a little Kiddology
fields.trailText: David O'Leary has taken a step back from the pressures of managing Leeds United by appointing Brian Kidd as head coach in time for today's encounter with his former employers Manchester United.
fields.body:
David O'Leary yesterday took a step back from the pressures of being Leeds United manager with the appointment of Brian Kidd as head coach 24 hours ahead of today's lunchtime encounter with Manchester United.

"I've never had a first-team coach before," O'Leary said. "I've done all the coaching and now with Brian it will give me a break because this job is a lot of hard work. My day is 24 hours - now it might come down to 23."

O'Leary insisted that the timing of the appointment of Sir Alex Ferguson's former assistant was a "coincidence". The pair fell out after criticisms of Kidd in Ferguson's autobiography two years ago.

Kidd, who was youth-development coach at Elland Road, said: "I am looking forward to working with the outstanding group of players we have here. It is a great challenge."

Paul Gascoigne returns his battered and bruised body to the front line this afternoon. The former England midfielder is expected to be on the substitutes' bench as Everton search for points at home to Newcastle United.

Although the 33-year-old has fully recovered from the thigh and hernia problems which have laid him low for the past four months, he will undergo the 23rd operation of his career this summer when he has a metal plate removed from the arm he broke while playing for Middlesbrough on Valentine's Day last year.

Crystal Palace have signed Arsenal's Matthew Upson, 21, and Ipswich's Slovenian international full-back Amir Karic on a month's loan. Both are included in the squad to play Preston North End at Selhurst Park this afternoon.

West Ham hope to complete the signing of the Everton midfielder Stephen Hughes in time to give him his debut in Wednesday's London derby against Chelsea.

Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson believes Kieron Dyer could be out for up to five months. The 22-year-old will undergo an operation on his shin today and will have further surgery in a fortnight's time.

Internazionale will have to play their next two European home games away from the San Siro after Uefa punished them for crowd trouble which halted play five minutes before the end of their 2-0 defeat by Alaves last week.

St Etienne, fighting relegation, have had a seven-point deduction reimposed by the federal appeals commission of the French League for their role in the false passports affair. After hearing St Etienne's appeal against a six-point penalty, the commission ordered that the original penalty of seven points, which had been reduced on a previous appeal, should be reinstated.

Toulouse, who were awarded three points for their losing match against St Etienne on appeal, will lose those points.

webTitle: Festa's fear of a Boro nightmare

fields.headline: Festa's fear of a Boro nightmare
fields.trailText: Dominic Fifield finds the Italian centre-back defiant as relegation looms.
fields.body:
Gianluca Festa has had a traumatic week. Having tasted defeat under Terry Venables' stewardship for the first time last Saturday, the Middlesbrough defender pranged his flash sports car on the way to training. Now, with relegation fears shivering across frozen Teesside, he has the thankless task of informing his two young children that their summer holidays are not to be spent in the Sardinian sun but a stuffy classroom attempting to vault the unlikeliest of language barriers.

"They've been over here so long, the problem is that my children can read and write in English but not in Italian," he says, any adopted Boro burr lost beneath his thick Cagliari twang. As a rugged member of Boro's rearguard, he has worn his heart on his sleeve on 156 occasions for the Teessiders. Now, the 31-year-old former Roma and Internazionale centre-half betrays the nerves of a prolonged relegation scrap, worries heightened by that home defeat by Southampton. Charlton, in lofty eighth place and without a care in the world, visit the Riverside today. Festa, who experienced relegation in 1997, five months after arriving from the San Siro, will not tolerate a second failure.

"We simply must stay in the Premier League," he says. "To play in the First Division is a nightmare. I have done that once and I don't know whether I could do it again. We must be positive and fight hard to stay up, although the threat is there if we don't pick up results, starting against Charlton."

Next week's trip to Newcastle hardly promises rich pickings before Boro travel to Chelsea at the end of the month, briefly reuniting Festa with his mentor Claudio Ranieri. That union could have been permanently renewed. Having seen his form coincide with Boro's nose-dive to the foot of the table late last year, the Italian was dropped by Bryan Robson in favour of his £8m recruit Ugo Ehiogu. Festa promptly handed in a transfer request.

"I said to the club if Robson did not pick me for the first team I would go away," he says. "I have been very honest while I've been here, saying what I think, and that was a bad time."

Ranieri, who worked with Festa during a three-year spell at Cagliari, was keen to recruit him as a replacement for Frank Leboeuf, but when the Frenchman's transfer to Monaco failed to materialise, so did the Italian's passage down to the King's Road.

"I was very close to signing for Chelsea," admits Festa. "But Terry Venables wanted me to stay until the end of the season. It would have been difficult for him to find a replacement. The door is still open to go to Chelsea, but I really need to speak with Boro. Maybe I can stay here for two or three more years. I will decide what is to be done in the summer."

His decision to come off the list last week came as something of a godsend to El Tel. Gary Pallister is recovering slowly from a back injury but is unlikely to feature until the Fat Lady is practising her arpeggios; Ehiogu may have scored his first England goal in midweek but he will spend the next seven weeks kicking his heals on the sidelines serving a four-match suspension after punching Wimbledon's Jason Euell.

"I felt I was important to the team even before Pallister was injured and Ehiogu suspended," he says, "but that wasn't getting me in the side. But we have experienced players here. People like Alen Boksic and Christian Karembeu really care and want to play well for Middlesbrough. All our foreigners are all very good professionals. Nobody could doubt that.

"While I respect Robson - even if we disagreed on some things - and he is a very good man, things got a lot better for me when Terry Venables came here. He is very professional. I am nearly 32 years old but I still want to learn about football. Under him, I can. We have started from scratch and worked hard at every aspect of the game. He is like an Italian coach but you would expect that with his European experience."

Robson spent this week on the continent himself attempting to prise the Spanish striker Dani away from Barcelona. Instead, the Teessiders are lining up Dean Windass who they hope to sign from Bradford for £;750,000 next week. The striker will have to wait to make his debut as he is suspensed for one game.

"I think it will be very difficult given we have so many players injured or suspended for the next few games," adds Festa. "If we all stay together we can do well. We must show our strength and fight on the pitch if we really want to stay in the Premiership."

webTitle: Stan and Sven would have shared common ground

fields.headline: Stan and Sven would have shared common ground
fields.trailText: Cullis' golden vision from the black and white age lives on in technicolour.
fields.body:
How sadly ironic that Stan Cullis, whose Wolves teams once epitomised the strengths, and delusions, of the English game, should die in a week when England played their first international under a foreign coach.

In the 50s, Wolverhampton Wanderers kept the home fires of English pride and ambition burning during a period when the country's football began, for the first time, to experience serious doubts about its status in the world at large.

In 1950, England - Stanley Matthews, Tom Finney and all - came home early from the World Cup in Brazil chastened by losing 1-0 to the gauche part-timers of the United States of America in Belo Horizonte. In 1953 and 1954, England lost 6-3 and 7-1 to Hungary and suddenly the masters of the world, the game's inventors, were looking like playground patsies.

Wolves came to represent a beacon of hope in an age of disillusionment. Towards the end of 1954 their 3-2 victory over Honved, the Hungarian army team led by Ferenc Puskas and including several of those who had again outplayed England in the Nep stadium that summer, convinced many that the English way could at least be the equal of fancy continental methods.

All that Cullis's team really did was to preserve an illusion for a few years more. The reality was that had England participated in the World Cup before 1950 and competed with the outstanding Italy and Austria teams of the 30s on neutral territory the truth would have dawned some 20 years earlier, give or take the odd world war.

This, however, was the broader picture. As a team to watch, the Wolves of Cullis gloriously embodied J B Priestley's description of professional football as conflict and art rolled into one. Their style was breathtaking in its simplicity but was made not so much by the system as the quality of the players.

Peter Broadbent was the playmaker, directing assured passes through opposing defences which opened up the wings for Johnny Hancocks and Jimmy Mullen to find the head of Roy Swinbourne or laid on chances for Dennis Wilshaw. It was exciting, innocent football and between 1949 and 1959 it brought to Molineux three league titles and two FA Cups.

To the fan of today the idea of Wolverhampton Wanderers as the country's leading club might appear not so much old gold as an iron-age concept. Yet to some extent the elements which made Cullis's Wolves such a dominant force are surely not that much different to those that today continue to keep Manchester United ahead of the Premiership pack. As a manager Cullis, like Sir Alex Ferguson, was a disciplinarian who would brook no nonsense from any player, no matter how famous he might be. It was said that the cooking of Cullis's goose at Molineux, and the end of his 14-year reign in 1964, began when, after an away game, he ordered the team coach to leave without the new chairman, John Ireland, who was still in the boardroom.

Manchester United are a thoroughly modern football side but Ferguson's regard for the importance of fast and effective wing play, the value of David Beckham's long passes, the box-to-box strength of Roy Keane and the dependibility of Jaap Stam at centre-back carries echoes of Mullen, Hancocks, Broadbent, Billy Wright and Bill Slater, even at a distance of half a century.

Where Cullis's Wolves side became outdated was in what happened when they lost possession. The conception of denying opponents space and making runs off the ball was slow to catch on in England until Hungary's historic win at Wembley. Positional play was still dictated by numbers - No9 at centre-forward, No6 at left-half, No10 inside-left, and so on.

Nevertheless Cullis's style became the model for the theories of one Wing Commander Charles Reep, who evolved a statistical shorthand through which to demonstrate that the quicker the ball was moved from one end of the pitch to the other the more likely were goals to be scored.

So impressed was the Football Association by this study that Reep's ideas bore remarkable similarity to the philosophy of the FA's director of coaching, Charles Hughes, among whose disciples was Graham Taylor, manager of Watford, Aston Villa and England, and Egil Olsen, one-time coach of Norway and Wimbledon.

In part, this was a reaction to the some of the coaching theories which followed the Hungarian experience and placed so much emphasis on possession that after two dozen passes movements would have advanced five yards while the opposition blocked off all available channels. But, too often, the direct approach was imposed on players who would have been better suited to something more profound.

England's new coach has stated from the outset that he intends adapting systems to players and not the other way round. Eriksson also believes that in style the better English footballers have become indistinguishable from their counterparts in mainstream Europe.

The Swede exudes common sense and had they been contemporaries he and Stan Cullis might have shared much common ground. Yet the old golden age of Wolves effectively ended with a 9-2 aggregate defeat by Barcelona in the 1960 European Cup quarter- finals. And even now some parts of English football are still trying to catch up.

fields.headline: The curse of Romford just goes on and on
fields.trailText: The curse of Romford just goes on and on
fields.body:
It has been a stop-start kind of season for Romford of the Ryman League First Division. A fire in the summer caused their Sungate ground to be closed and its reopening was delayed by boardroom shenanigans, which led to their temporary suspension from the league in December. No fewer than 21 players came and went in two months, including the have-boots-will-travel Barrie Fox, who signed from Braintree Town in November, moved on to Aveley in December, then returned to Romford in January. Then came the bad weather, which meant Tuesday's 3-1 win over Northwood was their first home league game since mid-November. All of which leaves them in relegation strife, though with no fewer than 10 games in hand on some of their rivals - possibly a record but don't write in. With a bit of luck a traumatic season will be over by June, if they can steer clear of the foot and mouth exclusion zone down the road in Brentwood.

According to one agency report this week, Bobby Robson has "thrown down the gauntlet to teenage star Shola Ameobi and told him: 'You can be the new Duncan Ferguson'." Let's hope Shola didn't pick it up, otherwise he'd probably have pulled something.

Alarming news for Spain's Alfonso, who appeared on the cover of the programme for Wednesday's game against England resplendent in his white boots - even though he hasn't appeared for his country since Euro 2000. Inside, the striker would have learnt that he "has kept his place in Camacho's pool of possibles despite playing Second Division football". Alfonso's side, Barcelona, aren't quite in the Second Division yet.

The movie Hannibal sells itself with the subtitle, "The Silence Will Be Broken". In one scene from the film, a TV can be seen showing Premiership football - Aston Villa, to be exact. Some kind of ironic comment on the atmosphere at Villa Park, perhaps?

Without wishing to cast aspersions on my Diary colleague's gambling nous, I returned from two weeks away to find our betting account reduced from £112 to a paltry £37. As a result, to put us all out of our misery, we have splashed the lot on an improbable, six-team, damn-the-torpedoes, multi-league parlay involving clubs as diverse as Bristol City and Celta Vigo, who take on away defeat specialists Real Oviedo this weekend. If Stan Collymore decides it's time to start scoring, we're done for.

A sign has gone up outside the Shoreditch Baptist Church in east London proclaiming "Glory, Glory Man United". Presumably that's God's idea of a joke.

Burnley will be without Ian Cox for today's game at Portsmouth after he returned late from international duty with Trinidad, a state of affairs which infuriated the Clarets' manager Stan Ternent. "We have to pay his wages and insurance to play for some tin-pot outfit," he said. "It's a joke." Cox was playing in a Concacaf World Cup qualifier against Jamaica, with three places in the finals up for grabs between the six remaining teams. Meanwhile, Burnley were training in the gym because their training ground was off limits due to the foot and mouth crisis. Maybe not the ideal time to lecture the world about who is or is not a tin-pot outfit.

Stadium naming rights have reached a new low in the Unibond League, where Witton Albion's Wincham Park is now known officially as the Bargain Booze stadium. A heady example for any youngsters who might go along.

All of which leaves them in relegation strife, though with no fewer than 10 games in hand on some of their rivals - possibly a record but don't write in. With a bit of luck a traumatic season will be over by June, if they can steer clear of the foot and mouth exclusion zone down the road in Brentwood. According to one agency report this week, Bobby Robson has "thrown down the gauntlet to teenage star Shola Ameobi and told him: 'You can be the new Duncan Ferguson'." Let's hope Shola didn't pick it up, otherwise he'd probably have pulled something. Alarming news for Spain's Alfonso, who appeared on the cover of the programme for Wednesday's game against England resplendent in his white boots - even though he hasn't appeared for his country since Euro 2000. Inside, the striker would have learnt that he "has kept his place in Camacho's pool of possibles despite playing Second Division football". Alfonso's side, Barcelona, aren't quite in the Second Division yet. The movie Hannibal sells itself with the subtitle, "The Silence Will Be Broken". In one scene from the film, a TV can be seen showing Premiership football - Aston Villa, to be exact. Some kind of ironic comment on the atmosphere at Villa Park, perhaps? Without wishing to cast aspersions on my Diary colleague's gambling nous, I returned from two weeks away to find our betting account reduced from £112 to a paltry £37. As a result, to put us all out of our misery, we have splashed the lot on an improbable, six-team, damn-the-torpedoes, multi-league parlay involving clubs as diverse as Bristol City and Celta Vigo, who take on away defeat specialists Real Oviedo this weekend. If Stan Collymore decides it's time to start scoring, we're done for. A sign has gone up outside the Shoreditch Baptist Church in east London proclaiming "Glory, Glory Man United". Presumably that's God's idea of a joke. Burnley will be without Ian Cox for today's game at Portsmouth after he returned late from international duty with Trinidad, a state of affairs which infuriated the Clarets' manager Stan Ternent. "We have to pay his wages and insurance to play for some tin-pot outfit," he said. "It's a joke." Cox was playing in a Concacaf World Cup qualifier against Jamaica, with three places in the finals up for grabs between the six remaining teams. Meanwhile, Burnley were training in the gym because their training ground was off limits due to the foot and mouth crisis. Maybe not the ideal time to lecture the world about who is or is not a tin-pot outfit. Stadium naming rights have reached a new low in the Unibond League, where Witton Albion's Wincham Park is now known officially as the Bargain Booze stadium. A heady example for any youngsters who might go along. mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Lennon told to take his time

fields.headline: Lennon told to take his time
fields.trailText: Celtic manager Martin O'Neill has urged Neil Lennon not to make any hasty decision over the future of his international career.
fields.body:
Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill has urged Neil Lennon not to make any hasty decision over his international career.

The Northern Ireland midfielder was booed by a group of supporters during the international against Norway in Belfast on Wednesday before being substituted by Sammy McIlroy at half-time.

But O'Neill, a former Northern Irish international himself, admits that Lennon is in a no-win situation. "I don't want him to rush into a decision. I think deep down he doesn't want to do that himself but he is going to be asked on a daily basis what he is going to do.

"I don't think he wants all those things hanging over him. He just wants to play football. Considering it is not over football, that would be more disappointing."

O'Neill, who collected his third manager-of-the-month prize yesterday, went on: "I hope that it won't affect his club form because he has been absolutely fantastic since he arrived here. But I know that it is a cloud hanging over him at the moment," said O'Neill.

The midfielder Alan Thompson has expressed his surprise at the extent of the feeling towards Lennon since his move to Parkhead. But the former Aston Villa man insists that the Irishman is buoyant again after returning to Glasgow.

"I do feel for Neil because he has got a difficult decision to make and only he can do that with the help of his family and possibly the manager," said Thompson.

"He has got a decision to make and I think he wants to make it soon," he added.

Meanwhile, the Dunfermline manager Jimmy Calderwood insists that if Sunday's game against the Hoops had been scheduled for today it would have been postponed. Temperatures plummeted to -9C last night and a mist rolled into the town making visibility poor.

This week's snow has been cleared - but the East End Park club are keeping their fingers crossed that the weather will improve.

"It's poor at the minute," admitted Calderwood. "It's very misty and very cold as well which is making things difficult.The snow has all cleared and the balloon's up on the pitch so I think it should be okay.

"We've got to hope that things improve and if it snows then that will flatten the balloon and then we're going to see a few problems.

"The danger is it's going to be very cold and it's very, very misty and if it was going ahead today it would have been hard to play."

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Ian Bond wants advice about driving over the Tiz'n'Test pass in the Atlas Mountains. Although the maps describe it as a passable road, the guide books say it is extremely narrow and dangerous.
fields.body:
Ian Bond wants advice about driving over the Tiz'n'Test pass in the Atlas Mountains. Although the maps describe it as a passable road, the guide books say it is extremely narrow and dangerous.

It probably depends on whether you are a passenger or a driver. As a driver, you have to maintain more than your usual share of concentration, and while negotiating hairpin bends, you won't get much of an opportunity to enjoy the spectacular views. Apart from crumbling edges - especially dodgy when squeezing past oncoming vehicles - there's the odd goat or camel to pass, so great care must be taken, with very low speeds at all times. Do it if you are experienced at driving along narrow mountain roads. If not, leave it. Accidents there can be horrendous, and the hospitals are not too great; no view on earth is worth the risk.

Ann Eastman

We drove over in January this year. Although perfectly okay in terms of Tarmac, the road is rather narrow with a lot of gravel on the edge and a pretty dramatic drop on one side. The biggest problem is the continual hairpin bends around the mountains so, whoever is driving, unless a very experienced driver in this sort of terrain, will not be able to appreciate the scenery as they will need to concentrate continually. I would, however, recommend the Berber omelette at the café just before the pass coming up from Taroudannt.

Karen Wilkin

I drove over the pass last month, and it's nowhere near as hairy as the Rough Guide would have you believe. As long as you're a reasonably competent and confident driver, you should have no problem. The worst part was driving into the evening sun on the way down to Taroudannt. Do stop at the Tin Mal mosque and at the small café at the pass. There's even a couple of rooms there, though you'd need warm sleeping gear.

Mike Venis

We were driven over in a Mercedes taxi on February 7 from Taroudannt. It was exhilarating but not dangerous - room for cars to pass at most places. It's worth having a driver who knows the route - the only hazardous moments were when we met hire-cars driven by Europeans. It also means you can enjoy the stunning scenery. Good value, too - the whole day out cost 1,600 dirhams (about £107) for four people.

Bob Rhodes

This week's question

Where can a fairly weak swimmer go snorkelling over coral direct from the beach rather than from a boat?

Elizabeth Hopkins

fields.headline: Powder and the glory
fields.standfirst: Britain's best-ever skier Martin Bell explains the basic techniques for handling off-piste virgin snow
fields.trailText: Britain's best-ever skier Martin Bell explains the basic techniques for handling off-piste virgin snow.
fields.body:
Powder skiing is magnificent once you've learned the technique, but it is not easy. The feeling of having your skis in the snow, rather than on the snow, takes some getting used to. Before you ever try to make turns in powder, you should find a powder slope that is flat enough to allow you simply to go straight down.

As you do so, practise bouncing up and down in a straight line, using mainly your ankles and knees (not the upper body). You'll get accustomed to how your skis rise to the surface and sink to the bottom of the soft snow as you bounce. It will become apparent that the timing of these movements has to be fairly slow - you can't rush your up and down movements in powder. In fact, this "slow motion" feeling is one of its attractions.

You should also experiment with leaning from side to side, putting most of your weight first on one ski and then on the other - you'll probably fall over when you try this. You'll therefore very quickly understand that it's vital in deep snow to keep your weight evenly spread between both feet, and this applies whether turning or going straight. If one ski is too heavily weighted, it'll sink in deeply. The other, unweighted ski, will float upwards, snag on the surface, and flip you over. This is the most common mistake made by novice powder skiers.

A common misconception is that "you have to sit back in powder, to keep the tips at the surface". But this will limit your range of knee and ankle movement, and will tire out your thigh muscles. Expert skiers just look like they're sitting back in powder, because of a phenomenon called tail sink. This simply means that the tails of the skis sink deeper into the snow than the tips. It's because the tails are thinner, and the bindings are always mounted behind the middle of the ski. So, even though skiers are standing perpendicular to their skis, it appears that they're "sitting back" in relation to the slope. When powder skiing, you should just try to stand normally over the middle of your foot, sometimes pushing down slightly with your heels to ensure enough "tail sink".

To start turning, you need to time your bounces so that your skis are rising to the surface at the beginning of each turn, making it easier to pivot your feet to start the turn. And you should be sinking in to your deepest point as you finish each turn.

Of course, all the other elements of short turns need to be in place, just as for on-piste short turns: solid pole-plants to set your rhythm, and you should be turning just your legs beneath you, while your upper body remains facing down the slope at all times. Many powder experts like to use a narrow stance - keeping your feet together can reduce the chances of your inside foot snagging in the snow.

The modern trend towards wider skis has made powder skiing much easier. These new fat skis have allowed off-piste skiers to use a technique similar to on-piste skiing, keeping the feet wider apart, using less up-and-down motion, and carving big wide arcs. Like snowboards, fat skis have opened up remote areas of the mountain to those previously not skilled enough to venture there, and so avalanche safety education is now more important than ever.

Before heading off-piste, check the current risk level of the snowpack (whether it is stable or unstable). Always take a local guide; he can at least avoid areas that have slid frequently in the past. Make sure everyone in the group has a shovel, probe, and radio beacon. Always descend or traverse steep slopes one at a time, so that only one of you will be buried if the worst occurs.

But don't be deterred by these dire warnings - powder skiing is one of the most intense pleasures you will ever have.

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.trailText: Milly is getting used - sort of - to her hotel job in Australia, Sam has been having a go at being an Aussie surfer and Sue has been trying to avoid touts in Bali
fields.body:
Milly is getting used - sort of - to her hotel job in Australia, Sam has been having a go at being an Aussie surfer and Sue has been trying to avoid touts in Bali. Our trio, an 18-year-old gap student, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant and a 51-year-old divorced mother of three, are now well into their six-month trips around the world on Bridge the World tickets.

Milly in Sydney: "That evening, I was serving at a wine-tasting conference, and the phrase thrown in at the deep end seems entirely appropriate here. Besides dropping a tray of wine down myself and some of the hotel furniture, nothing went too badly wrong, and I even got to finish early. At midnight.

"Another traveller, Amanda and I went across the road again for a drink. It was here that I met another of my occasional freaks. He had just arrived from LA, alone, and was keen to sit and buy us a drink, so we let him. Shortly after that Amanda looked down to see his hand in her bag, to which he commented: 'I hope you don't think I'm trying to steal anything!' We both did. We made excuses to go - he'd also said some other odd things, too, and people like that are best when you're a long way away from them."

Sam in Byron Bay: "The breakers were huge and it was a real struggle to fight my way beyond them to the calmer sea. I bobbed up and down on the swell for a while before having a go at bodysurfing. I saw a biggish wave coming up behind me, swam hard and managed to catch it. I had a brief glorious sensation of being swept along. Then everything turned upside down as the wave broke and I was pulled under. I could only have been down for a short while but by the time I escaped, I was left flapping about in the shallows gasping for breath.

"Not one to give up that easily, I went out for another go. This time the force of the wave almost ripped my shorts off."

Sue in Bali: "We found a deserted road that skirted the lake through a layer of solidified lava. Feeling free of sellers, we got out of the car to enjoy the views at leisure. Out of nowhere came a motorbike, complete with driver and collection of paintings. How do they do it? Radar, short-wave radios, acute sense of the smell of tourists?"

fields.headline: Dark secrets
fields.standfirst: What do a remote slate quarry and the National Gallery's collection of masterpieces have in common? Gareth Parry unravels a remarkable tale while walking the Quarrymen's Paths
fields.trailText: What do a remote slate quarry and the National Gallery's collection of masterpieces have in common? Gareth Parry unravels a remarkable tale while walking the Quarrymen's Paths
fields.body:
Driving down into Blaenau Ffestiniog in Snowdonia to walk the recently-opened Quarrymen's Paths is, for a flash in the mind, like seeing island Greece for the first time. Old women in headscarves and aprons sit on sunlit doorsteps gossiping as dark-eyed little girls skip to a Welsh rhyming song and a long line of cars stops as a couple of old sheep amble across the road in pursuit of a tourist dishing out crisps.

Paradoxically, life for those old ladies' ancestors was harder when Blaenau was busier. In the early 19th century it was The Slate Capital. The beautiful, fine-grained, blue-grey slates, called Empresses, Small Duchesses, Broad Countesses and Wide Ladies, roofed much of the world.

In the 1800s, more than 4,000 quarrymen blasted and then wrestled the slate out of the earth, where it had hidden for 400 million years since the Ordovician age. But since the 1960s, when it was cheaper to buy German, Spanish or even Chinese slates and mass-produced tiles, the number of working quarrymen has fallen to a few hundred.

Unemployment is one of the highest in Britain, particularly since the ageing Magnox nuclear power station at Trawsfynydd went off line in 1991 to remain a blot on the landscape for 100 years. It is all very quiet in an area once deafened by dynamite blasting. There is an atmosphere of that heavy pathos felt in any place that has seen great energy enjoyed or squandered.

Before I began the walk up to the Manod quarry, I stood in the town centre. Only a tiny red-and-green quarry locomotive, No 2207, and two wagons mounted on a slate plinth, hint at the history of a place where men worked for three shillings a day for the quarry owners - Lords and MPs who built mansions and even castles, on the fortunes.

Blaenau Ffestiniog crouches below galleries, canyons and mountains of slate waste which drop down to the cottages' back yards. Blaenau is an oddity: an exclusion zone in the heart of the 840 square miles of Snowdonia National Park. It is so because it was classed an "industrial development area" when the park was created in 1952 to protect natural and wild places. Including it would have inhibited new industry, they said then. In the event, few came to stay.

Ironically, it is this exclusivity that today makes it a unique place. It is not, by any measure, a bespoke "tourist experience", but to walk for a day on carpets of sphagnum moss, through lichen-spotted granite and in between slate blocks the size of a small house is sensational. On sunny days, the heat-waves bounce and shimmer over the slate mountains. Rainy days (and there are many of them) are probably even better. Then the photograph is a glistening monochrome, relieved by the liturgical purple of Rhododendron ponticum, the shallow-rooted weed that kills all competition and thrives in the grey slate waste.

Gwynedd Council has established walking routes within the five valleys of the so-called Slate Valleys Initiative. I took one of the paths that were once used by the quarrymen going to and from work. It was not uncommon for men to walk 10, even 20 miles to start work at 6am, and the same distance home that evening.

I went to the Manod Quarry with Steffan ab Owain, one of several erudite local historians and an authority on the quarries where he once worked. In 1968, when Steffan left to study and eventually take a degree in archaeology, he was a fitter's mate earning £9 and 15 shillings a week for three weeks and £11 and 10 shillings on the fourth "big money" week.

The Manod is a cold and lonely place, 1,750ft above sea level. Its isolation caused it to be one of the most secret places in the second world war. The entire National Gallery Collection was hidden in its underground labyrinth in case Trafalgar Square was bombed, which, of course, it was in 1940. Londoners feared for their lives each night, and sheltered from the bombs wherever they could. But the Ministry of Works gave top priority to a nine-month building programme at Manod to ensure the paint ings would be safe beneath a 300ft thick slate ceiling in the highly unlikely event of Hitler deciding to bomb a lonely mountain in north Wales.

Six vast underground chambers were installed for the treasures. Each had its own air-conditioning system, which ensured four changes of air an hour, and a constant atmosphere of 65F and 42% humidity. Five thousand tons of slate were removed from the moutain entrance increasing it from a 6ft square hole through which generations of miners had passed, to one 13ft by 10ft. This allowed masterpieces by Gainsborough, Hogarth, Constable, Turner, Monet, Degas and Rembrandt, as well as the remainder of the British, French and Dutch Schools, to be unloaded unobtrusively from lorries driven inside the mountain. The road surface under the railway bridge at Ffestiniog, was lowered two and a half feet so that the lorry carrying the vast Van Dyck canvas Charles I on Horseback and Piombo's Raising of Lazarus could edge underneath with inches to spare.

The lowered bridge footings are still visible, but a locked barred gate closes the entrance to the Manod quarry. I peered through the bars into the darkness and was hit by an icy blast of air coming from inside the mountain where the six secret storage chambers remain. The paintings were kept under armed guard at Manod for more than six years. The air-conditioned facilities at the quarry were retained by the Government for much longer because of the possibility of another war, particularly during the Cuban missile crisis.

The remoteness of the quarries meant that many of the men would have to leave their homes just after midnight on Sunday in order to start work at 6am on Monday. Some walked to work over trackless mountains, guided in the winter blackness only by markers of white stones. They stayed in the Barracks in the quarries for the rest of the week, only returning home at the weekend for clean clothes, food, warmth and Sunday chapel. The paths they took are all now recorded.

The tumbling, dry-stone walls of the Barracks can be seen on most of the paths today. The lintels and window sills are marked with graffiti recording the "Big Money" pay days by sum, date and the day's weather. The Barracks were infamous in the industry: draughty, flea-ridden and damp. Men ate, cooked, and slept in double beds for warmth, each in as little as 200 cu ft - the equivalent of 30 people in a modern semi. For this they paid one shilling (5p) a month to the quarry owners. They were overcharged. At close to 2,000ft, the winters were cruel, but the men had to buy their own coal and water from enterprising peddlers.

The average age expectancy among the quarrymen was 47 years, the slate makers 34, many dying from the lung disease silicosis. The rockmen who climbed down the sheer faces of cliffs attached to ropes and chains in order to place dynamite charges would have arms and legs torn away by a sudden fall of slate. The remains of the quarry hospital still exist today.

But if the working conditions were horrific, the winter weather in the area I walked was worse. Winter lasted four months. Easterly winds blew so constantly on to one quarry, men called it the North Pole. When the snot froze in their noses the quarrymen would retreat to dress and cut slates in underground shelters called Caban Crwn. One of these circular dugouts with corbelled roofs of heavy slate slabs can still be seen on the Manod.

At the top of the Manod Path an explosives magazine remains. It is an unremarkable, square structure except that it is built of brick and isolated from all other structures because new safety rules were enforced in the 1870s after a series of explosions caused by quarrymen living - and smoking their pipes - close to huge amounts of dynamite.

The magazine is also the site of the Murder on Manod. Before dawn on a Monday morning in March 1898, quarrymen walking to work found the body of Mary Bruton, aged 33, lying in the snow next to the magazine. Police quickly arrested her lover, a hawker called Thomas Jones. He confessed to murdering Mary during a drink-inflamed quarrel. He said Mary had insisted on taking the wrong path over the mountains and they had lost their way. Jones was hanged at Caernarfon gaol that August.

Other attractions

There are two local steam railways. The Ffestiniog Railway travels from Porthmadog to Blaenau Ffestiniog. The Welsh Highland Railway (01766 512340) has two separate services covering a couple of miles at either end of the track from Caernarfon to Porthmadog.

Llechwedd Slate Caverns (01766 830306, www.llechwedd.co.uk has deep mine tours and underground son et lumière.

Way to go

The Quarrymen's Paths booklet detailing 14 circular walks in the Ffestiniog area is available for £1.76 incl p+p from Tourist Information, Gwynedd Council, Dolgellau, Gwynedd LL40 2YB (tel: 01341 422888). The Slate quarries are on the margins of OS 1:25 Outdoor Leisure maps 17, 18 and 23.

Accommodation: The Queen's Hotel, Blaenau Ffestiniog (01766 830055). B&Bs: Cae'r Blaidd Country House, Llan Ffestiniog, Gwynedd LL41 4PH (01766 762765). Tyddyn Du Farm, Gellilydan, Maentwrog, Blaenau Ffestiniog. LL41 4RB (01766 590281). Details of guesthouses and B&Bs can be obtained from the local tourist information centre (open April-September only, 01766 830360).

Reading: The Slate Regions of North and Mid Wales and their Railways. AJ Richards (Carreg Gwalch) £7.50.

General enquiries e-mail: tourism@gwynedd.gov.uk

fields.headline: A splash of Grenadines
fields.standfirst: Hank Wangford  gets a taste for winter heat on the volcanic island of St Vincent
fields.trailText: Hank Wangford gets a taste for winter heat on the volcanic island of St Vincent.
fields.body:
I am a Caribbean tenderfoot. I've been there a thousand times with Caribbean aristocracy like King Tubby, Prince Buster and Lord Short Shirt, but I've never dipped my toe in the perfect waters or been caressed by the constant breezes. Now I've tasted nature Caribbean style at her five-star best, all I can tell you is GO. Now. Jump on the next flight to Barbados and take it from there.

I found St Vincent, off the track in the Windward Islands, with no major tourist resorts. Why? Black Sand. But the Caribbean means perfect white sand beaches, and the necklace of small islands, the Grenadines, that run down from St Vincent are bedecked with them. St Vincent's beaches themselves are black or grey or coffee-coloured. It's the volcano, La Soufrière, Old Souffry, that's to blame, still ruling the island from 4,000ft with a sulphurous and cindery fist. She last blew in 1979.

St Vincent looks like a children's fairytale island from the sea, hundreds of pointy, conical hills covered in green; a battalion of little volcanoes from a time when the earth was bubbling all over with them. For US$100-$120 any taxi in Kingstown will drive you up to the trailhead for Old Souffry, with refreshments and a trail guide to take you up to the crater.

It was a wet day. Souffry was inside her mantle of cloud. The drive along the dramatic Windward coast was raw and wild, with the Atlantic surf lashing at apocalyptic black sand beaches. They'd call it a lovely day in Galway. Riverbeds, normally dry, were now full of people with their arms up to their elbows in the torrents.

We stopped. People ran at us holding plastic bags. One pushed her gap-toothed smile and a polythene bag of black stuff through the taxi window. "Nice. Chree chree." Close up, it was full of little wriggling things, like embryonic newts, some kind of Hell spawn. I backed off. Our taxi driver bought a $20 bag.

Chree chree are tiny baby fish that appear after the rains. They are a delicacy and are cooked whole in chree-chree cake, favoured round Christmas. Delicate, sweet, savoury fishcakes, we had some later.

Meantime, we drove up through banana plantations, dripping with sweaty rain and dangling thick with fruit, to the rainforest trailhead. It was a wonderful monochromatic walk up through the steamy tropical forest. The path is easy and well kept. Cracks like pistol shots ring out through the rain forest as huge bamboo canebrakes sway in the wind and bamboo bark splits explosively from the stem. Our guide was Erd, a local boy with a hip hop haircut.

We crossed the first wide lava run halfway up where mists and rainforest open, a big party spot. Then, before leaving the treeline behind, comes The Garden, where the forest canopy opens out with bright volcanic flowers and butterflies. Out on the cindery top, Erd showed us Souffry grass that grows nowhere but here, is a surreal bright green and looks like a furry volcanic bonsai Christmas tree. Erd stuck a piece in his locks.

Whether from the forbid den picking of the Souffry grass or out of sheer bloody mindedness, we were greeted with stinging horizontal rain, a deluge so violent I had two inches of water in my boots.

We whisked up the sunnier leeward side to the Baleine Falls in the north in a motorboat. The whole island, every volcanic cone, is covered with a dense green blanket. Deep valleys and steep gullies packed with banana plantations and coconut groves slip down to the water's edge. Small fishing villages with no road access lie in bays along magical black and coffee-coloured shores. Dark beaches lined with coconut palms sparkle mysteriousl like black diamonds in the sunlight. By one of these obsidian strands Mrs Wangford learned how to snorkel. Watching underwater, I will take with me forever the image of her streaking down at 45 degrees through turquoise water to the coral stands with the princess parrot fish, dusky damsels, electric Blue Tangs and watchful moray eels.

Baleine Falls are stunning. A short walk into a cut in the basalt cliffs take us into a moss- and fern-lined bowl with 60ft waterfalls cascading into a sapphire plunge pool of cool, sweet water.

Inland, just north of Kingstown, is a valley of surreal beauty. With its rich volcanic soil, the whole island is green and fertile, but in the Mesopotamia Valley nature is exuberant, bursting out everywhere, valley floor to vertiginous walls. Over the glistening banana trees and rustling coconut groves tower abrupt green velvet cliff faces. A volcano falling into itself created the sudden and surprising depth of this valley. Looks like a tropical version of the cauldron subsidence in Glencoe. Even in the mist and rain, its magic isn't dampened.

Toyota vans loaded down to their back axles with bananas creak into Kingstown. On Mondays the banana boat is in port. Suddenly the whole of the Banana Boat Song made sense and in a flash changed from pure cheese to a top work song. "Day-oh, is a day-ay-ay-oh, daylight come and I wanna go home." See, they're packing the banana boat through the night. Look, there's the tallyman. "Tally me banana, daylight come and..." I was off. And Harry Belafonte, acceptable face of black culture to 1957 British suburbia, was vindicated at last.

On a rock jutting out of the sea near Villa Beach is a large white cross. Below it a local landowner who owned much of this developed shoreline, is buried standing up, they say, to better see the sunset. His other eye, however, is still unblinkingly fixed on his old shoreline property. Two hundred yards offshore is Young Island, an exclusive and expensive resort that has uniquely white sand beaches unlike the rest of St Vincent. They put us in one of their beach huts with its back-to-nature no-telephone-radio-TV philosophy and its own outdoor shower, Jacuzzi and gazebo. Suited me, at night time watching the fireflies and listening to the astonishing tree frogs. These little critters, barely one-inch across, can belt out a good tune all night long.

Over dinner on Young Island, the air was thick with phrases like "offshore banking". Wealthy people seemed to enjoy staying offshore. One night Sir James "Son" Mitchell came over and introduced himself. The only prime minister of St Vincent for 16 years, he had just stepped down to give way to a younger man of his choice. When I enquired after his recent resignation, he leaned forward and said reassuringly "It's all right. I'm still first minister." Hearing we were going to Bequia, he brought me some brochures for his own hotel there, the Frangipani. A hands-on politician in a family-run country. Recently, the nice lady who runs Young Island married the master brewer who makes the ultra-strong Guinness in St Vincent. The brewer's name is, of course, Mr Porter.

I heard it first stepping into the Paradise Inn. Instead of reggae, it was Patsy Cline wanting me to Pick Her Up on My Way Down. Turns out this is Cross Country Radio, the local St Vincent Country station. Thick West Indian accents introduce George Jones and Merle (H)'aggard. Like in Africa and all the Caribbean, Country is popular in the Grenadines.

I shook out my breadfruit print Hawaiian shirt for a pilgrimage to Kingstown's Botanic Gardens, the oldest in the Caribbean. A photo-opportunity awaited by the first breadfruit tree, grown from the original brought by Captain Bligh from Tahiti in 1793. The gardens were beautiful but the breadfruit tree unremarkable. I still posed. The Cannonball Tree, however, had a forest of woody tendrils, like Medusa's serpentine locks, growing horizontally out of the trunk. Inside, cannonballs burst into the unlikeliest waxy pink flowers, explosions of colour burning out of the knotted mass of tendrils. Some wonderful trees scrape the sky here.

Bequia

The sailing in the Grenadines is the best in the world bar none, say the yachties. Reliable north-easterly winds and beautiful islands with great anchorages all help. We sailed gloriously over to the next island Bequia (Beck-way) with Johnny Olivierre. His is from a big Bequia family of seafarers and whalers. Bequia's whaling tradition goes way back and they still take one whale a year. Johnny's uncle was Athneal Olivierre, the last harpoonist to kill a whale singlehandedly with a handheld harpoon. A small whaling museum is run by cousin Harold.

Bequia is a delight, rustic, hilly and green, laid-back, with colourful houses and Rasta shacks on the golden beaches. A dream island,

Port Elizabeth has all you can need. I like Lower Bay, a friendly, down-home neighbourhood with beautiful beaches. Rastas do nice juice, Theresa's is jumping and you get a good fish dinner at Keegan's. A place to Lively Up Yourself.

This island has wonderful beaches, dramatic surf on the Atlantic side, calm lagoons on the Caribbean, with fine snorkelling and diving. Harold Macmillan once rented a house on Bequia. He first thought "You've never had it so good" living there. He was right. I haven't.

Way to go

Hank Wangford flew with Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747) to Barbados and with Mustique Airways (001 784 458 4380, www.mustique.com) to St Vincent for £697 plus tax.

Young Island (+784 458 4826, www.youngisland.com) beach hut with Jacuzzi costs US$530 per night. Paradise Inn (+784 457 4795) costs US$60 - $90 for a double room. Frangipani Hotel: (+784 458 3255) costs US$ 40 - $150. Keegan's (+784 458 3530) Double Dive St Vincent: (+784 457 4714, www.divestvincent.com).

Trip to Baleine Falls costs US$120 for two. Further information from St Vincent Tourist Office, 10 Kensington Court, London W8 5DL (020-7937 6570). Bequia Tourist Office: (+784 458 3286).
