One pushed her gap-toothed smile and a polythene bag of black stuff through the taxi window. "Nice. Chree chree." Close up, it was full of little wriggling things, like embryonic newts, some kind of Hell spawn. I backed off. Our taxi driver bought a $20 bag. Chree chree are tiny baby fish that appear after the rains. They are a delicacy and are cooked whole in chree-chree cake, favoured round Christmas. Delicate, sweet, savoury fishcakes, we had some later. Meantime, we drove up through banana plantations, dripping with sweaty rain and dangling thick with fruit, to the rainforest trailhead. It was a wonderful monochromatic walk up through the steamy tropical forest. The path is easy and well kept. Cracks like pistol shots ring out through the rain forest as huge bamboo canebrakes sway in the wind and bamboo bark splits explosively from the stem. Our guide was Erd, a local boy with a hip hop haircut. We crossed the first wide lava run halfway up where mists and rainforest open, a big party spot. Then, before leaving the treeline behind, comes The Garden, where the forest canopy opens out with bright volcanic flowers and butterflies. Out on the cindery top, Erd showed us Souffry grass that grows nowhere but here, is a surreal bright green and looks like a furry volcanic bonsai Christmas tree. Erd stuck a piece in his locks. Whether from the forbid den picking of the Souffry grass or out of sheer bloody mindedness, we were greeted with stinging horizontal rain, a deluge so violent I had two inches of water in my boots. We whisked up the sunnier leeward side to the Baleine Falls in the north in a motorboat. The whole island, every volcanic cone, is covered with a dense green blanket. Deep valleys and steep gullies packed with banana plantations and coconut groves slip down to the water's edge. Small fishing villages with no road access lie in bays along magical black and coffee-coloured shores. Dark beaches lined with coconut palms sparkle mysteriousl like black diamonds in the sunlight. By one of these obsidian strands Mrs Wangford learned how to snorkel. Watching underwater, I will take with me forever the image of her streaking down at 45 degrees through turquoise water to the coral stands with the princess parrot fish, dusky damsels, electric Blue Tangs and watchful moray eels. Baleine Falls are stunning. A short walk into a cut in the basalt cliffs take us into a moss- and fern-lined bowl with 60ft waterfalls cascading into a sapphire plunge pool of cool, sweet water. Inland, just north of Kingstown, is a valley of surreal beauty. With its rich volcanic soil, the whole island is green and fertile, but in the Mesopotamia Valley nature is exuberant, bursting out everywhere, valley floor to vertiginous walls. Over the glistening banana trees and rustling coconut groves tower abrupt green velvet cliff faces. A volcano falling into itself created the sudden and surprising depth of this valley. Looks like a tropical version of the cauldron subsidence in Glencoe. Even in the mist and rain, its magic isn't dampened. Toyota vans loaded down to their back axles with bananas creak into Kingstown. On Mondays the banana boat is in port. Suddenly the whole of the Banana Boat Song made sense and in a flash changed from pure cheese to a top work song. "Day-oh, is a day-ay-ay-oh, daylight come and I wanna go home." See, they're packing the banana boat through the night. Look, there's the tallyman. "Tally me banana, daylight come and..." I was off. And Harry Belafonte, acceptable face of black culture to 1957 British suburbia, was vindicated at last. On a rock jutting out of the sea near Villa Beach is a large white cross. Below it a local landowner who owned much of this developed shoreline, is buried standing up, they say, to better see the sunset. His other eye, however, is still unblinkingly fixed on his old shoreline property. Two hundred yards offshore is Young Island, an exclusive and expensive resort that has uniquely white sand beaches unlike the rest of St Vincent. They put us in one of their beach huts with its back-to-nature no-telephone-radio-TV philosophy and its own outdoor shower, Jacuzzi and gazebo. Suited me, at night time watching the fireflies and listening to the astonishing tree frogs. These little critters, barely one-inch across, can belt out a good tune all night long. Over dinner on Young Island, the air was thick with phrases like "offshore banking". Wealthy people seemed to enjoy staying offshore. One night Sir James "Son" Mitchell came over and introduced himself. The only prime minister of St Vincent for 16 years, he had just stepped down to give way to a younger man of his choice. When I enquired after his recent resignation, he leaned forward and said reassuringly "It's all right. I'm still first minister." Hearing we were going to Bequia, he brought me some brochures for his own hotel there, the Frangipani. A hands-on politician in a family-run country. Recently, the nice lady who runs Young Island married the master brewer who makes the ultra-strong Guinness in St Vincent. The brewer's name is, of course, Mr Porter. I heard it first stepping into the Paradise Inn. Instead of reggae, it was Patsy Cline wanting me to Pick Her Up on My Way Down. Turns out this is Cross Country Radio, the local St Vincent Country station. Thick West Indian accents introduce George Jones and Merle (H)'aggard. Like in Africa and all the Caribbean, Country is popular in the Grenadines. I shook out my breadfruit print Hawaiian shirt for a pilgrimage to Kingstown's Botanic Gardens, the oldest in the Caribbean. A photo-opportunity awaited by the first breadfruit tree, grown from the original brought by Captain Bligh from Tahiti in 1793. The gardens were beautiful but the breadfruit tree unremarkable. I still posed. The Cannonball Tree, however, had a forest of woody tendrils, like Medusa's serpentine locks, growing horizontally out of the trunk. Inside, cannonballs burst into the unlikeliest waxy pink flowers, explosions of colour burning out of the knotted mass of tendrils. Some wonderful trees scrape the sky here. Bequia The sailing in the Grenadines is the best in the world bar none, say the yachties. Reliable north-easterly winds and beautiful islands with great anchorages all help. We sailed gloriously over to the next island Bequia (Beck-way) with Johnny Olivierre. His is from a big Bequia family of seafarers and whalers. Bequia's whaling tradition goes way back and they still take one whale a year. Johnny's uncle was Athneal Olivierre, the last harpoonist to kill a whale singlehandedly with a handheld harpoon. A small whaling museum is run by cousin Harold. Bequia is a delight, rustic, hilly and green, laid-back, with colourful houses and Rasta shacks on the golden beaches. A dream island, Port Elizabeth has all you can need. I like Lower Bay, a friendly, down-home neighbourhood with beautiful beaches. Rastas do nice juice, Theresa's is jumping and you get a good fish dinner at Keegan's. A place to Lively Up Yourself. This island has wonderful beaches, dramatic surf on the Atlantic side, calm lagoons on the Caribbean, with fine snorkelling and diving. Harold Macmillan once rented a house on Bequia. He first thought "You've never had it so good" living there. He was right. I haven't. Way to go Hank Wangford flew with Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747) to Barbados and with Mustique Airways (001 784 458 4380, www.mustique.com) to St Vincent for £697 plus tax. Young Island (+784 458 4826, www.youngisland.com) beach hut with Jacuzzi costs US$530 per night. Paradise Inn (+784 457 4795) costs US$60 - $90 for a double room. Frangipani Hotel: (+784 458 3255) costs US$ 40 - $150. Keegan's (+784 458 3530) Double Dive St Vincent: (+784 457 4714, www.divestvincent.com). Trip to Baleine Falls costs US$120 for two. Further information from St Vincent Tourist Office, 10 Kensington Court, London W8 5DL (020-7937 6570). Bequia Tourist Office: (+784 458 3286).

webTitle: Work Your Way Around The World, by Susan Griffith, Vacation Work Publications, £12.95

fields.headline: Work Your Way Around The World, by Susan Griffith, Vacation Work Publications, £12.95
fields.trailText: The book aims to enable those with little money but plenty of motivation to have a great time abroad while earning their keep. It blends anecdotes with information to build up a picture of the possibilities for the working traveller across the globe
fields.body:
Want to travel but unable to finance a long trip? For almost 20 years Work Your Way Around The World has been helping travellers to overcome this problem.

The 10th edition was published this week and aims to enable those with little money but plenty of motivation to have a great time abroad while earning their keep. It blends anecdotes with information to build up a picture of the possibilities for the working traveller across the globe.

The first two parts contain advice on preparation and outline the main sources of employment for travellers. Travel sections examine the chances of a working passage as well as more conventional forms of transport. The red tape governing EU members working within the EU has a dedicated section.

Parts three and four comprise a country by country guide to job opportunities and the rest of the red tape. Part three is dedicated to Europe and comprises half the book. Many entries are supported by maps showing the location of work opportunities identified in the text. But the volume of information provided for countries varies - Finland, for example, merits two pages while France nets 30.

The disparity of coverage between countries is most striking in the world beyond Europe. Australia, New Zealand, Israel, Canada and the US all boast good-sized entries, but Latin America merits just 14 pages, Africa 19 and Asia 27. Worst off is the Middle East, whose entry is restricted to two pages supplemented by a six-page entry on Turkey.

Travellers sticking to established destinations will find all the information they need in the volume. If you want to leave the beaten track, however, more research is required but the book will help you do it.

Despite the bias toward mainstream destinations, this volume still represents a good investment for hard-up travellers.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Rheged Discovery Centre | Secret Hills Discovery Centre | The British Museum | David Bailey | Treasures of the Pharaohs | Bradford Film Festival | National Football Museum
fields.body:
Fell swoop

Visitors to the new Food from the Fells shop at the Rheged Discovery Centre near Penrith can buy a range of local goodies including sticky toffee pudding from Mallerstang and Herdwick lamb from the Cumberland upland fells.

 Rheged Discovery Centre. 10am-5.30pm Mon-Sun. Redhills, Penrith, Cumbria (01768 895598).

Shropshire ladder

Discover the secrets of the Shropshire hills at this new centre. A trail leading visitors back through time to find out how the hills were created, who used to live on them and what forces helped shape the area.

 Secret Hills Discovery Centre. £4.25/ £3.75/£2.75/£12.20. 10am-3.30pm Mon-Sun. School Road, Craven Arms, Shropshire (01588 676000).

My old Dutch

Rembrandt the Printmaker includes a large selection of self-portraits, scenes from the Bible and character studies as well as insights into his working practices.

 Until April 8. £6/ £3. 10am-5.30pm Mon-Wed, Sat, Sun; 10am-8.30pm Thurs, Fri. The British Museum, Great Russell Street, London, (020-7636 1555).

Star snapper

A retrospective of the work of David Bailey, with portraits of icons such as Mick Jagger, Andy Warhol, Paul McCartney and John Lennon, as well as more recent subjects including the Gallagher brothers, Jarvis Cocker and Damien Hirst.

 David Bailey - Birth of Cool. 10am-5pm Mon-Sat; noon-5pm Sun. £3/£2. The Dean Gallery, Belford Road, Edinburgh (0131-624 6200).

Ancient highlights

Ancient Egypt is coming to Doncaster this month with the Tutankhamun and the Treasures of the Pharaohs exhibition featuring more than 300 exact replicas of ancient artefacts.

 March 6 - April 1. £6/£4/£18. 10am-10pm Mon-Fri; 10am-8pm Sat, Sun. The Dome, Bawtry Road, Doncaster (01302 370 999).

Wide and handsome

The seventh Bradford Film Festival includes the UK premiere of Jude Law's Enemy of the State and the Shine Awards for first- or second-time directors. The Wide Screen Weekend features 70mm films, and Cirque du Soleil's Journey of Man at the IMAX cinema.

 March 1-17. The National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, Bradford, West Yorkshire (01274 202030).

A game of two halves

The new £12 million National Football Museum takes visitors on a journey through the beautiful game; the First Half deals with the history of footie, while the Second Half is a themed interactive exhibition with the FIFA collection of football memorabilia.

 Open 10am-5pm Tues- Sat, 11am-5pm Sun. £6.95/£4.95. Deepdale Stadium, Sir Tom Finney Way, Deepdale, Preston, Lancashire (01772 908 442).

fields.headline: Keeping up with the Joneses
fields.standfirst: From small spa towns hosting mind-boggling events to hiring a Norman castle for the weekend,  Joanna Israelsohn uncovers a fantastic range of holidays available in the principality
fields.trailText: From small spa towns hosting mind-boggling events to hiring a Norman castle for the weekend, Joanna Israelsohn uncovers a fantastic range of holidays available in the principality
fields.body:
From beautiful coastal walks, crumbling castles and two of Britain's 18 World Heritage sites to some of the best surfing, a wealth of outdoor activities and one or two slightly more unusual pursuits like bog snorkelling, Wales packs a lot in for such a small country. Here are some holiday suggestions.

Walks

As well as Offa's Dyke Path, there are nine more long-distance walks and by the time the weather picks up hopefully the foot and mouth restrictions will be over. The newly-established Taff Trai links Cardiff with Brecon, while the Pembrokeshire Coast Path takes the walker 186 miles along some of the most beautiful and varied coastline in Britain. Glyndwr's Way retraces the 128-mile route taken by Owain Glyndwr through the heart of Wales to gather his army against the English in the first years of the 15th century; and the Wye Valley Walk takes ramblers along 144 miles of water meadow and wooded scarp, which provided inspiration to Wordsworth and Turner. The Dyfi Valley Way is a fairly recent creation that marks 108 miles of rugged countryside between Bala Lake and Borth on the coast of Cardigan Bay.

The other walks are the North Wales Path, the Cambrian Way, the Usk Valley Way and finally the 210-mile Severn Valley Way, one of the longest way-marked trails in the UK. There are plenty of youth hostels along these routes; call The Ramblers' Association on 01978 855148, or visit www.ramblers.org.uk, or www.totalwales.com for more information.

Nature

Nature lovers can get away from it all on Skokholm Island, 30 minutes by boat off the Pembrokeshire coast. The first bird observatory in the British Isles, Skokholm is a National Nature Reserve with no electricity or running water and accommodation for only 15 people. Birds on the island include Razorbill, Guillemot, Puffin and many more, and the surrounding seas are home to porpoise, dolphins and grey seal. Three-night or seven-night full-board breaks with the Wildlife Trust (01239 621212) cost £159 or £269.

The brand new National Botanic Garden of Wales is a £43.4 million garden dedicated to science, education and leisure, with a strong emphasis on the study and sustaining of endangered plants. The gardens centre on a vast Norman Foster-designed glasshouse with a Mediterranean climate; plantings inside reflect the bio-diversity in regions around the world that have the same weather conditions. Outside, in the Temperate Woods of the World section, a series of one-acre plots are dedicated to regions that share the Towy Valley's wet but mild climate, as well as an area dedicated to organic farming. Open 10am-4.30pm, Mon-Sun, £6.50 adults/£3 children/£16 families. Middleton Hall, Llanarthne, Carmarthenshire (01558 667148).

Action

The small spa town of Llanwrtyd Wells plays host to all manner of quirky events, including the Man versus Horse marathon on June 2, a 23-mile race in which runners, horses and three-man relay teams compete against each other. Sponsored by William Hill, if a single runner beats a horse this year he/she will pocket £22,000. The World Bog Snorkelling Championships is on August 22, when competitors have to swim two lengths across a 50m bog with flippers and a snorkle. Otherwise, try your hand at the less strenuous Real Ale Wobble in conjunction with Mid-Wales Beer Festival in November - contestants cycle a 15-, 25- or 40-mile off-road course, with free beer at all the checkpoints. For more information, call 01591 610236. The tourist information centre, on 01591 610666, has details of accommodation.

Llangennith, on the Gower Peninsula, is one of Britain's mellowest surfing beaches with relatively consistent Atlantic rollers year round; no competition, no flashy labels, just a huge expanse of sand attracting everyone from beginners to experts. The Welsh Surfing Federation Surf School (01792 386426) operates from Llangennith and the local surf shop is run by Welsh surf legend Pete Jones.

Adventure

Step back in time on a week-long break travelling 50 miles through the Brecon Beacons in an authentic four-berth Gypsy caravan. A quick lesson on harnessing and driving the horse in the small hamlet of Llangorse, and you're on your way, through Talgarth then on to Hay-on-Wye, where you follow the river upstream to Llanstephan with overnight stops in fields along the way. The caravan comes with basic cooking facilities, a two-man tent, folding chairs and table and a portaloo. Acorn Activities (08707 405055 www.acornactivities.co.uk) offers one-week breaks between May and October for £495. Mid-week and weekend breaks are also available.

Take to the water on a barge holiday sailing through the Monmouth and Brecon Canal, built in 1812 to transport iron ore from Blaenavon to Newport through the Brecon Beacons National Park. The canal is ideal for beginners: its six locks and 375-yard tunnel are easily navigable and the purpose-built narrowboats are handled by two people. Each boat is equipped with a library of books on the history of the canal, the park and places of interest in South Wales. Three-night breaks with Beacon Park Boats (01873 858 277) cost from £300.

Relaxation

Snuggle down for the weekend, choosing from Manorbier Castle, a Norman castle complete with drawbridge and private gardens; St Anne's Head lighthouse near the village of Dale; The Cabin on Tenby harbour, featured in the Jude Law film Basil; a cottage with gas lamps on the cliffs at Strumble Head or a converted 18th-century chapel in Lower Town in Fishguard, where Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton filmed Under Milk Wood. Coastal Cottages of Pembrokeshire (01437 765765, www.coastalcottages.co.uk) features more than 500 properties, with prices starting from £130 for a four-night break.

Re-enact The Prisoner at Portmeirion , set on a rocky peninsula in Tremadog Bay. Best known as The Village in the 1960s cult television series, Portmeirion was the brainchild of eccentric architect Clough Williams-Ellis, whose idea was to build a perfect village that enhanced rather than blended in with its surroundings. Endangered buildings from all over Britain and abroad were pulled down, transported and rebuilt in every conceivable style - the village houses a Jacobean town hall, Siamese figures on Ionic columns, Neoclassical collonades from Bristol and a Pantheon, all set around a Mediterranean piazza. In the summer, more than 3,000 visitors a day come to ogle - so, go early spring and see the village at its surreal best.

Accommodation is in the Victorian Hotel Portmeirion, or the self-catering cottages in the village, which sleep between two and eight. Prices for these start from £106pp half- board. The most atmospheric of the cottages get booked up well in advance, especially during The Prisoner weekend convention in September. Call 01766 770000, visit /www.portmeirion-village.com.

Culture

The Centre for Alternative Technology, founded during the oil crisis of 1974, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Wales. A once derelict slate quarry has become home to an almost entirely self-sufficient community generating 80% of its own power from the wind, sun and water. From the start, the idea was to showcase sustainable technology; houses were to demonstrate energy-saving ideas and to show how homes can be built with local materials and minimal skills. The centre offers a wide range of residential courses including Eco Renovation, Family Birdwatching, Yurt Structures and Feltmaking, Introduction to Renewable Energy Technologies, Working with Willow and The Art of Composting. Centre for Alternative Technology, Machynlleth, Powys (01654 702400, www.cat.org.uk). Courses start from £120. Accommodation is either on the main site or in eco cabins, meals are served in the centre's award-winning vegetarian restaurant.

Visit Castell Henllys, a partially-reconstructed Iron Age hill fort in the Pembrokeshire National Park near Newport, soon to be featured on BBC1's living history series Surviving the Iron Age. Seventeen people lived on the site in as authentic a manner as possible, carrying out daily tasks such as grinding corn for flour, carrying water and working iron. Open April 1- November, 10am-5pm, £2.80/£1.90/ £7.50. Castell Henllys, near Newport, Pembrokeshire (01239 891319).

The south-east Wales iron and coal town of Blaenavon, with its remains of early ironworks, railways, waterways, mines, quarries and workers houses, was awarded World Heritage status by Unesco this year for the crucial role it played in the Industrial Revolution. During the 19th century, the Blaenavon works grew to be one of the largest in Britain; the ironworks are now open to the public and visitors to the Big Pit get a fascinating insight into the experience of a miner's work and life as they are taken 300ft down into the dark pit where child workers were once paid two pence for a six-day week, with one penny taken from their wages to pay for the cost of candles. Blaenavon tourist office on 01495 792615.

March 3: Wales special

Dark secrets What do a remote slate quarry and the National Gallery's collection of masterpieces have in common? Gareth Parry unravels a remarkable tale while walking the Quarrymen's Paths.

The small city with the big kicks Alf Alderson finds plenty of outdoor adventure in Britain's smallest city - with only one pub.

Cool Cymru The Welsh capital now brims with self-confidence and style. Peter Morgan enjoys the new-found freedom of the city.

Special Offa This week Wales celebrated St David's Day. Bill Bryson celebrates the day with a ramble along the Offa's Dyke Path.

Each boat is equipped with a library of books on the history of the canal, the park and places of interest in South Wales. Three-night breaks with Beacon Park Boats (01873 858 277) cost from £300. Relaxation Snuggle down for the weekend, choosing from Manorbier Castle, a Norman castle complete with drawbridge and private gardens; St Anne's Head lighthouse near the village of Dale; The Cabin on Tenby harbour, featured in the Jude Law film Basil; a cottage with gas lamps on the cliffs at Strumble Head or a converted 18th-century chapel in Lower Town in Fishguard, where Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton filmed Under Milk Wood. Coastal Cottages of Pembrokeshire (01437 765765, www.coastalcottages.co.uk) features more than 500 properties, with prices starting from £130 for a four-night break. Re-enact The Prisoner at Portmeirion , set on a rocky peninsula in Tremadog Bay. Best known as The Village in the 1960s cult television series, Portmeirion was the brainchild of eccentric architect Clough Williams-Ellis, whose idea was to build a perfect village that enhanced rather than blended in with its surroundings. Endangered buildings from all over Britain and abroad were pulled down, transported and rebuilt in every conceivable style - the village houses a Jacobean town hall, Siamese figures on Ionic columns, Neoclassical collonades from Bristol and a Pantheon, all set around a Mediterranean piazza. In the summer, more than 3,000 visitors a day come to ogle - so, go early spring and see the village at its surreal best. Accommodation is in the Victorian Hotel Portmeirion, or the self-catering cottages in the village, which sleep between two and eight. Prices for these start from £106pp half- board. The most atmospheric of the cottages get booked up well in advance, especially during The Prisoner weekend convention in September. Call 01766 770000, visit /www.portmeirion-village.com. Culture The Centre for Alternative Technology, founded during the oil crisis of 1974, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Wales. A once derelict slate quarry has become home to an almost entirely self-sufficient community generating 80% of its own power from the wind, sun and water. From the start, the idea was to showcase sustainable technology; houses were to demonstrate energy-saving ideas and to show how homes can be built with local materials and minimal skills. The centre offers a wide range of residential courses including Eco Renovation, Family Birdwatching, Yurt Structures and Feltmaking, Introduction to Renewable Energy Technologies, Working with Willow and The Art of Composting. Centre for Alternative Technology, Machynlleth, Powys (01654 702400, www.cat.org.uk). Courses start from £120. Accommodation is either on the main site or in eco cabins, meals are served in the centre's award-winning vegetarian restaurant. Visit Castell Henllys, a partially-reconstructed Iron Age hill fort in the Pembrokeshire National Park near Newport, soon to be featured on BBC1's living history series Surviving the Iron Age. Seventeen people lived on the site in as authentic a manner as possible, carrying out daily tasks such as grinding corn for flour, carrying water and working iron. Open April 1- November, 10am-5pm, £2.80/£1.90/ £7.50. Castell Henllys, near Newport, Pembrokeshire (01239 891319). The south-east Wales iron and coal town of Blaenavon, with its remains of early ironworks, railways, waterways, mines, quarries and workers houses, was awarded World Heritage status by Unesco this year for the crucial role it played in the Industrial Revolution. During the 19th century, the Blaenavon works grew to be one of the largest in Britain; the ironworks are now open to the public and visitors to the Big Pit get a fascinating insight into the experience of a miner's work and life as they are taken 300ft down into the dark pit where child workers were once paid two pence for a six-day week, with one penny taken from their wages to pay for the cost of candles. Blaenavon tourist office on 01495 792615. March 3: Wales special Dark secrets What do a remote slate quarry and the National Gallery's collection of masterpieces have in common? Gareth Parry unravels a remarkable tale while walking the Quarrymen's Paths. The small city with the big kicks Alf Alderson finds plenty of outdoor adventure in Britain's smallest city - with only one pub. Cool Cymru The Welsh capital now brims with self-confidence and style. Peter Morgan enjoys the new-found freedom of the city. Special Offa This week Wales celebrated St David's Day. Bill Bryson celebrates the day with a ramble along the Offa's Dyke Path.

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Studland Bay?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Studland Bay
fields.standfirst: Claire Rayner
fields.trailText: Claire Rayner
fields.body:
Why? I used to take my kids to stay in an amazing hotel called Knoll House, in Studland Bay in Dorset, which was purely aimed at children - if you didn't have children of school age, you couldn't go there. It had everything - a swimming pool, nature reserve, horse-riding, and, of course, the beach at Swanage. It's a wonderful beach with acre after acre of gorgeous yellow sand and nearby caves you can visit on a gloomy day. You wouldn't see the kids from dawn till dusk - there was so much for them to do. I'd just read and sleep and read. One of my sons learnt to fish there - he caught his first sea bass there. The hotel cooked it up for us and we sat and ate like royalty. The area is dripping with history and if your kid is interested in geology, you can find all sorts of things along the beach. We went for a number of years and the kids still have friends that they made in those years.

My perfect day: A beautiful sunny day with breakfast noisy and early before spending most of the day on the beach. We'd walk back to the hotel through the reserve for lunch, where we'd have masses of food, served on a buffet.

The best thing: The fact that they liked children. There are many places that tolerate children and think that if they put a few high chairs in the dining room, that's all they need to do. But this was quite different, they just loved having children around.

My advice: Don't expect glamour and bright lights because this is the English seaside at its best.

How do I get there: By road (A31), or train - the nearest station is Wareham. Or you can go across the water by chain ferry from Poole Harbour. Knoll House is open from April 2 to October 28. Visit www.knollhouse.co.uk, or call 01929 450450/fax: 01929 450423. A basic twin room in low season with full board costs from £88.

 Claire Rayner will be joining a host of celebrities at the NOJOs (Not Old, Just Older awards) at the Savoy London on March 22. Please call the events hotline number for ticket information on 020-7239 1922.

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: A weather front is moving across the Alps bringing heavy snow, desperately needed in some resorts. Regular light snowfalls across most US states mean that conditions remain excellent.
fields.body:
A weather front is moving across the Alps bringing heavy snow, desperately needed in some resorts. Regular light snowfalls across most US states mean that conditions remain excellent.

Austria

Soll (****) has great conditions and perfect weather. Obergurgl (***) and Hochgurgl (***) are also recommended. In Mayrhofen (***) on piste is good although off piste is windswept at altitude.

France

Snow showers have greatly improved Les Deux Alpes (***) and Alpe d'Huez (***). More snow is needed for Méribel (***) and La Clusaz (***) where the lower slopes are becoming icy and bare.

Switzerland

New snow has softened the pistes in Grindelwald (***) and Wengen (***) and refreshed Verbier (****) and St Moritz (****) .

Italy

Sestrière (****) and Sauze d'Oulx (****) have soft snow on the slopes and powder off piste. Cervinia (****) has had a light dusting, more forecast.

Andorra

New snow has rejuvenated the pistes, but Pas de la Casa (***) is windy with poor visibility.

US

The hard work of the piste groomers in Killington (****) has paid off and conditions are excellent. With more snow forecast, Aspen (*****) and Breckenridge (****) have topped up the snow depths.

Canada

Pistes in the Banff Ski Area are soft packed although groomed to perfection. In Whistler (****) on-piste is better than off.

Liz Russell, The Ski Club of Great Britain

 No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. ** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition.*** = plenty of good skiing. **** = good conditions. ***** = fantastic on and off piste.

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Late deals and other news
fields.body:
As fears persist about the long-term impact of global warming on skiing, American resorts are taking a fresh look at cloud seeding as a way of increasing the amount of snow they get. Telluride and Durango Mountain have just started doing so, following in the footsteps of Vail and Beaver Creek. Aspen is expected to decide soon on whether to join them. Cloud seeding involves firing silver iodide crystals into clouds from generators on high ground. The particles act as ice magnets and can increase precipitation.

Easter update

Neilson (08705 141414) has space left at some US and French resorts. Holidays still available include a week's B&B at California's Lake Tahoe, with the option of skiing at a range of resorts including Heavenly and Squaw Valley, for £650. Departure is from Gatwick on April 7. Among the high-altitude French options are chalet packages in the Trois Vallées starting a week later, with flights from the same airport and prices from £494. And family holiday specialist Ski Esprit (01252 618300) still has one-week packages available, with April 15 departures from Stansted or Manchester, in Chamonix, Courchevel, La Plagne, La Rosière and Verbier. Prices start at £490 per adult to cover flights, seven nights' chalet accommodation, six evening meals with wine and one night's babysitting. There is a 50% discount for under 18s and a £30 supplement for flights from Manchester.

A new luxury hotel is to be built in the Wyoming resort of Jackson Hole, significantly increasing the options for skiers who prefer to stay at the foot of the mountain rather than a short drive away in town. The 125-room, "ski in, ski out" property is due to open in 2003. It will be operated by the Toronto-based Four Seasons group, which plans to open another hotel in the Canadian resort of Whistler in the same year.

webTitle: St David's Hotel and Spa, Cardiff Bay

fields.headline: St David's Hotel and Spa, Cardiff Bay
fields.trailText: Address: Havannah Street, Cardiff Bay, South Wales CF10 5SD.
fields.body:
Address: Havannah Street, Cardiff Bay, South Wales CF10 5SD.

Reservations: 029-2045 4045.

Web address: www.rfhotels.com

E-mail: enquiries@rfhotels.com

First Impressions: A miniature Canary Wharf Tower with the Sydney Opera House stuck on top. Smart, modern and fashionable, Wales's first five-star hotel is saved from being sniffy by the staff - nothing is too much bother. Pool, massage fountains and whirlpools are free to hotel residents. E'Spa beauty treatments are extra but heavenly.

What are the rooms like? Conran feel decked out in two-tone cherry and beech wood. All overlook Cardiff Bay with private decked balconies. The view may be more cranes and docks than hills and dales, but it's not uninteresting.

The bed test: Muted green and beige linen hides a fluffy, cotton-coated white cloud of a duvet and bouncy mattress.

The bathroom test: Functional with huge, well-lit mirrors, healthy selection of Molton Brown products and a hairdrier that works.

The restaurant: The Tides - well cooked and presented local produce for hearty appetites. Going à la carte isn't cheap - £16.50 for grilled Dover sole - so take advantage of the set menu (£20 for two courses, £25 for three). Afternoon tea at £10.75 is for one but there's plenty for two.

The lounge: Reminiscent of a New York whiskey bar - willow branches peppered with tiny fairy lights and comfortable twin sofas. Stereophonics frontman Kelly Jones is a regular.

What is there to see within walking distance? On the spa break, there's so much to do, you've no need to leave.

How much a night? Weekend prices start from £110 per night B&B based on two sharing. A two-night stress buster spa package includes breakfast, lunch and dinner and several spa treatments for £265 based on two sharing.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth
fields.body:
Foot and mouth

In the wake of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease in farms across England, Wales and Northern Ireland, many tourist attractions around the country have chosen to close their doors in order to reduce the risk of any further spread of the infection. They say it is best to phone for latest information before attempting a visit. Some country hotels report a drop in bookings and some cancellations.

Zen wings

A new travel company is selling luxury paragliding holidays in the French Alps. ZenFly (020-7586 4103, www.zenfly.com) aims to provide high levels of comfort while teaching you to fly paragliders in as little as three days. Alternative options are available for partners or other family members. The holidays will run from April to September.

Pets abroad

The Passport for Pets scheme, which has now been in operation for one year, has seen Eurotunnel carry more than 11,000 animals under the Channel.

High diver

Regal Diving Holidays (www.regal-diving.co.uk) has been voted Travel Operator of the Year for the fourth consecutive year by readers of Diver magazine. The company will be one of the exhibitors at the Dive Show at the Excel exhibition centre in London's Docklands today and tomorrow.

Irish crossing

Stena Line (reservations 08705 421166) is to resume its fast ferry service between Fishguard and Rosslare from April 1.

Open rail

Rail Europe has launched a France Railpass, offering options of travel on any three to nine days within a one-month period. You may stop where you like and the pass is valid on all trains on the national rail network, including TGVs. The basic version costs £112.

An Inter-Rail ticket covering the whole of Europe for one month costs £229 if you are under 26 and £319 for those over 26. A ScanRail pass, with unlimited travel on the national railways of Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden starts at £129 for adults. Full details are in the brochure Freedom to Explore Europe, available from Rail Europe on 08705 024000 www.raileurope.co.uk

£50 flights

Go (www.go-fly.com) has return tickets to Bilbao, Bologna and Munich from £50 including tax if you book before 5pm on Monday for travel between March 6 and April 11.

webTitle: The small city with the big kicks

fields.headline: The small city with the big kicks
fields.standfirst: Alf Alderson finds plenty of outdoor adventure in Britain's smallest city - with only one pub
fields.trailText: Alf Alderson finds plenty of outdoor adventure in Britain's smallest city - with only one pub
fields.body:
In 1995, the Queen conferred upon St David's a status it had long considered itself to have anyway - that of being a city. In return for this, she was given her own seat in the cathedral and this community of little more than 2,000 people, perched atop one of the wildest peninsulas in Wales, could now justify its claim to be the smallest city in Britain.

St David's is also the only city in Britain's only coastal National Park, as well as being the only city in Britain to have just one "real" pub, the Farmer's Arms. For visitors this is no bad thing, as it guarantees that you'll always be at the centre of the city's low-key scene, at least until the summer beach parties start after chucking out time - and St David's is a place for outdoor action rather than nightlife anyway.

It's probably an inheritance of the community's deeply religious past that it has so few places to knock back a pint (the nearby village of Solva, for instance, has four pubs despite being half the size), for in terms of religion St David's has always fought well above its weight. St David, the patron saint of Wales, was born at nearby St Non's Bay in the 6th century.

The beautiful 12th-century cathedral that bears his name, made of warm purple and gold-flecked stone, is tucked in a hollow beside the sparkling River Alun, almost out of sight. On the other bank is the Bishop's Palace, built around the turn of the 14th century and now a classic old ruin in which Shakespeare's plays are performed on summer evenings.

But it's more often the impressive coastline of the windswept St David's Peninsula that attracts visitors - surfers, climbers, kayakers and hikers who come in ever-increasing numbers to get their kicks in one of Britain's finest outdoor playgrounds.

The focal point for all the action is Whitesands Bay. The beach regularly receives rave reviews in travel guides, as does the surf. In summer, the waves can also get crowded.

There's a reasonable selection of accommodation available in the city, best booked in advance in summer. The Old Cross, Cross Square (01437 720387), is in the centre of the city and has en-suite rooms for £35 per person. Y Gorlan, Nun St (01437 720837) is located on the road out to Whitesands, with ensuite rooms for £22pp. Pen Albro B&B (01437 721865) is a popular and friendly spot next to the Farmer Arms on Goat Street, with rooms from £14.50pp.

One of the best campsites is Caerfai Farm (01437 720548) above Caerfai Bay, a 15-minute walk from town, and there's also a campsite near Whitesands Bay (01437 720245).

Where to eat

There's not a great deal to choose from, the city being so small. Morgan's Brasserie, 20 Nun St (01437 720508) is good for locally-caught fish, while The Cartref, Cross Square (01437 720422), has reasonably-priced local dishes. The Farmers Arms, Goat St (01437 720328), does decent pub grub but until 8.30pm.

One of the best restaurants in the area is The Old Pharmacy (01437 720005), in Solva, three miles east of St David's.

Things to do

Climb to the top of Carn Llidi, the 181m high crag above Whitesands, for great views. For other walks in the area, contact the National Park Visitor Centre and St David's Tourist Office, The Grove, St David's (01437 720392).

Surf the waves at Whitesands. Hire equipment from Ma Simes Surf Hut, High Street, St David's (01437 720433 www.masimesurfhut.co.uk). Board hire costs £7.50 a day, wetsuits £5.50 a day.

Coasteer. This involves traversing the sea cliffs at sea level - a mix of climbing, scrambling and swimming, which is becoming one of the most popular new adrenalin sports in Pembrokeshire. Guided trips, including hire of wetsuits, helmets and buoyancy aids, are organised by TYF Adventure, 1 High St, St David's (01437 721611, www.tyf.com). Adults £60 full day, £35 half day; children under 16 £40 full day, £25 half day.

Kayak the coastline of the peninsula, where you may see seals, dolphins and porpoises. TYF Adventure (see above) organises guided trips with all equipment for the same rates as coasteering.

Jetboat the Bitches rapids and around Ramsey Island with Thousand Islands Expeditions, Cross Square, St David's (01437 721686, www.tiex.co.uk). Two-hour trips around Ramsey cost £22.50 adults, £10 children; Bitches trips are £25, adults only (early booking essential as these only operate on spring tides).

St David's is also the only city in Britain's only coastal National Park, as well as being the only city in Britain to have just one "real" pub, the Farmer's Arms. fields.headline: 6th Baron Byron, George Gordon (1835)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Thomas Phillips (1770 - 1845), a Royal Academician who specialised in portraits of the eminent of the day, including Michael Faraday and William Blake (whose intense expression Phillips is said to have elicited by asking him to recount his meetings with the Archangel Gabriel). Phillips painted Byron from life in March 1813, in the first flush of the poet's celebrity. The original is in the British Embassy in Athens; this version is the painter's own 1835 copy.

Subject: George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron (1788-1824), who in 1812 published the first two cantos of Childe Harold's Pilgrimage, a poetic account of the travels around the Mediterranean shores by a jaded, over-sexed adventurer - it was considered a self-portrait. Byron instantly "woke to find himself famous". His life, including his incestuous relationship with his half-sister, his denunciation by Lady Caroline Lamb as "mad, bad and dangerous to know", and the heroism of his fighting alongside the Greeks in their war of independence, transfixed contemporaries. He cultivated his heroic (or anti-heroic) image in his writing: "Seek out - less often sought than found -/A soldier's grave, for thee the best;/Then look around, and choose thy ground/ And take thy rest" he counselled himself, in lines written at Missolonghi three months before his death from fever.

Distinguishing features: This is the poet as man of action, far from the wilting melancholy of the other Romantics in the same room at the National Portrait Gallery. Byron's eyes are bright, fixed on the distance; his thin moustache is dashing; his is dress flamboyantly foreign - his hair wrapped in a silk head-dress, a jewel at his neck, his poets' shirt just showing beneath his gold and red velvet coat. The absence of background places him in a world of dreams and stories. This image conjures up everything later imitators would flaunt: danger, the exotic, masquerade. Byron asserts his right not to be British, not to be a member of the House of Lords, but to become other; to become, in this painting, an Albanian. Byron wears a costume he purchased on his travels to Ioannina and the Epirus region, which was then in Albania (today it is part of Greece). Albania is the subject of several verses of Childe Harold. The author himself met Ali Pasha - the fearsome chieftain - and lived among the Albanians, a ferocious yet generous people who, he said, lived outside all conventions; because they were a mixture of Muslims and Christians they were hated by both Greeks and Turks. Childe Harold describes the costumes of Ali Pasha's followers thus: The wild Albanian kirtled to his knee/With shawl-girt head and ornamented gun/ And gold-embroidered garments, fair to see." Byron poses here in that outfit.

Inspirations and influences: Byron's portrait is an archetypal Romantic image of the artist as outsider; the first was by the 17th-century Italian painter Salvator Rosa, who was said to have not only painted bandits but consorted with them, and whose self-portrait is in the National Gallery.

Byron's image pervades modern culture, from Benjamin Disraeli's self-presentation as Britain's only Byronic prime minister, to Dracula - strongly influenced by The Vampyre (1819), a story first composed by Byron's doctor, John Polidori, based on Polidori's notorious patient, and written after both men participated in the same story-telling session that spawned Frankenstein.

Where is it? National Portrait Gallery, London WC2 (020-7306 0055).

France: From April 17 to June 30, two nights' B&B at the two-star Belgrand Hotel, Paris, costs from £129pp with British Airways Holidays (0870 2412412) including return flights from Heathrow.

Jordan and Israel: :An 11-day Easter trip departs April 8 for Amman, Jerash, Medaba, Mt Nebo, Kerak, Petra, Wadi Rum, Jericho, Beth-Shean, Tiberias, Galilee, Capernaum, Nazareth, Jerusalem, Massada and the Dead Sea. The price of £1,595p, includes international flights, transfers, four-star half-board accommodation, sightseeing in air-conditioned transport with an English-speaking guide. Steppes East (01285 651010, www.steppeseast.co.uk).

Australia: If you book before 7pm on Tuesday March 6, you can spend 10 days in May exploring Australia in a Maui motorhome plus four nights at the Grand Chancellor Hotel in Melbourne for the special price of £865pp (based on two sharing) including return flights. Austravel (0870 055 0206, www.austravel.com).

Asia

Hong Kong: Departing May 1 to June 30, Tradewinds (0870 7510004) is offering a three-night break for £549pp. The price, based on two sharing, includes return flights from Heathrow or Manchester with Cathay Pacific, room-only accommodation at the three-diamond Stanford Hillview Hotel and a free city tour.

Barbados: Book before March 31 for travel between April 20 and June 29 and one child goes for free when staying with two adults at the Coral Reef Club. A week costs £1,295 per adult including return flights with Virgin, airport transfers and room-only accommodation. Scott Dunn Oceans and Islands 020-8672 1234.

webTitle: Taliban blow apart 2,000 years of Buddhist history

fields.headline: Taliban blow apart 2,000 years of Buddhist history
fields.standfirst: Fighters begin job of demolishing Afghanistan's statues
fields.trailText: Fighters begin job of demolishing Afghanistan's statues.
fields.body:
Deep in the heart of Afghanistan's once serene Bamiyan valley, the sound of gunfire and mortar explosions could be heard yesterday.

Bearded men dressed in baggy salwar kameezes loaded and reloaded their rocket launchers under a clear azure sky. The Taliban fighters were busy - busy destroying two giant Buddhas carved into the hillside nearly 2,000 years ago, busy erasing all traces of a rich pre-Islamic past.

Though no one knows for certain, it seems likely that the massive Buddhas, previously Afghanistan's most famous tourist attraction, have been pulverised. Taliban and opposition sources yesterday confirmed that troops spent all day demolishing them.

"They have started attacking the Buddhas with guns and tank shells, with whatever arms they are carrying," a militia source said last night. "People are firing at them out of their own sentiments."

Western diplomats had hoped that Mullah Mohammed Omar, the Taliban's spiritual leader, might reconsider the edict he issued on Monday ordering the destruction of all of Afghanistan's statues, which he considers idolatrous.

A tidal wave of international condemnation from the US, Germany, Russia, India, the European Union and even Pakistan, the Taliban's closest ally, made no difference. It appears that local commanders have already launched a ferocious attack, before the statues could be formally blown up.

"We have also heard reports that they are attacking them with rockets and tank shells," opposition spokesman Mohammad Bahram said last night, speaking from the western mountains of Bamiyan, which are controlled by anti-Taliban groups.

The isolated valley, deep in the Hindu Kush mountains, was the scene of heavy fighting last month, when it fell briefly to opposition forces. The Taliban retook it in massive numbers. Much of the hardware they used in that offensive litters the mountainside and is now being deployed against a sandstone enemy unable to fight back.

The valley, visited by Buddhist pilgrims for hundreds of years, was closed to foreigners last month and local Afghans have also been kept out.

In all of Afghanistan's cities, Mullah Omar's edict was being implemented yesterday, some sources suggested. Two days ago the information minister, Qudratullah Jamal, confirmed that the historic statues in Kabul's bombed out museum and in the provinces of Ghazni, Herat, Jalalabad and Kandahar were also being destroyed.

Western cultural experts fear that as many as 6,000 Buddhist antiquities - some lying in the basement of the Taliban's information ministry - may already have been destroyed.

Unesco's director-general, Koichiro Matsuura, said: "Words fail me to describe adequately my feelings of consternation and powerlessness as I see the reports of the irreversible damage that is being done to Afghanistan's exceptional cultural heritage."

The destruction, which has only added to the war-shattered pariah state's misery, is being seen by most observers as a defiant response to the fresh wave of UN sanctions imposed on Afghanistan last month.

The country is already in the grip of the worst drought in 30 years, with 12m people affected, 3m of whom are on the brink of starvation. Some half a million Afghans have fled their homes this year, many in a massive exodus to neighbouring Pakistan.

In the capital, Kabul, yesterday, a woman, two-month old baby and four-year-old boy were trampled in a stampede for charity food coupons.

In the capital, Kabul, yesterday, a woman, two-month old baby and four-year-old boy were trampled in a stampede for charity food coupons.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on Blair's election chances

fields.headline: Tony and the feel-bad factor
fields.standfirst:
Leaders who lose control of election dates lose elections

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Leaders who lose control of election dates lose elections.
fields.body:
It's a rule of politics that a prime minister edging towards an election is seeking to create a feel-good factor. Ronald Reagan built an eight-year presidency on producing the illusion of a warm glow across America. With Gordon Brown's mammoth piggy-bank ready for Budget tax-cuts (or tax "refunds" in the clever new Americanism), Tony Blair was planning to have the electorate feeling about as good as is possible without the door-to-door distribution of illegal substances.

And yet suddenly Blair faces a feel-bad Britain. A disrupted railway service intended to be restored to normality by Easter, nicely timed for the assumed election date of May 3, has now returned to uncertain timetables after this week's latest tragedy. John Major's credibility suffered from the BSE crisis but the terrors for the public in that case were largely theoretical and reflective (did I once eat a fatal burger?) while Blair's foot and mouth epidemic tangibly affects movement, shopping and entertainment.

Now with less racing and rugby to distract from it, the toughest and most disruptive winter in recent memory shows no sign of giving way to spring. Tourists getting off the plane face a Britain which most resembles Soviet Europe: erratic transport, empty supermarket shelves, restrictions on travel, depressed and tired faces on the streets.

It's true that, barring the discovery of smoking government memos in either rail or agriculture inquiries, none of these catastrophes is demonstrably Blair's fault. On any prime ministerial insurance policy, they would be excluded as acts of God. Yet a side-effect of being PM is a general connection with the occurrences in your country. This can be beneficial - a sporting triumph raises your ratings - or detrimental: you get blamed for the storms and snowdrifts on your watch. Blair's advisers must have begun to tremble that voters will identify him as the Jonah, or wonder if there's a shot albatross somewhere on his deck.

Blair is particularly at risk in this area because, more than any other modern politician since Reagan, his main pitch to the electorate was that he would change the national mood music. Too cautious economically to attempt major social change, he won power on a pledge to make the electorate feel better about themselves than had been possible under the divisions of Thatcherism and the vacillations of Majorism. Now that the mood music is funereal, it may be hard for Blair to claim that he doesn't run the orchestra.

It's revealing that the two most frequently quoted modern political sayings, both spoken by PMs called Harold, counsel against long-term planning: Wilson's "a week is a long time in politics", and Macmillan's famous reply, when asked what he most feared in politics: "Events, dear boy, events."

Although all serving politicians carry these sentences around on actual or metaphorical scraps of paper, British democracy in the past few months has proceeded on two largely unchallenged assumptions: that the next general election would be on May 3 and that Tony Blair would inevitably win it. Who would give a bookie money now on both?

As he contemplates the black-edged headlines, there's even worse news for Blair on the bookshelf. Political history holds grim warnings for prime ministers who lose control over the election date. Non-choosers end up begging for another term, and usually don't get it.

Edward Heath was required by the miners' strike to consult the country earlier than he planned. Jim Callaghan - who suffered such speculation about the timing of the poll that he was required to make a conference speech about it - nursed a failing administration for as long as possible in the hope of improvement. Also waiting for the last possible date, as he gambled that New Labour might accidentally announce a massacre of the first-born, John Major became vulnerable to the foot in mouth disease of himself and his colleagues on Europe.

While the current mess in Britain does not yet approach either Heath's state of emergency or Callaghan's winter of discontent, the combination of flooded or frozen fields, snail-trains, food shortages, rural curfews and transport fatalities, with an investigation of ministerial sleaze taking place in the background, is very far from what the spin doctor would order for the approach to an election. If still reality on polling day, they would surely nudge some fingers in the booth. Even as recent memory, they might have an effect. And, on top of all that, Blair still has to worry that there is more to come: Macmillan's events.

Certainly, conventional wisdom about the next election does not now apply. The so-called "safe date" of May 3 is now highly dangerous and remains plausible only if the nation's cloven-footed animals obey the neatest epidemiological estimates. And, whenever the election is, the size of Blair's majority, if nothing more, must be vulnerable to the sudden public judgment that he is the country's bad luck. His one remaining piece of good fortune is William Hague as opposition leader.

At least the prime minister doesn't have to catch a train to Chequers to reflect on these dilemmas but, as it's in the country, they'd better disinfect the wheels of the government limo, the keys to which no longer seem as firmly in his grasp as two weeks ago, when trains were beginning to speed up again past contented sheep and cows in English fields.

fields.headline: Tories prepare for EU showdown
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: William Hague will reignite the Tory civil war over Europe this weekend by pledging to stage Britain's most serious confrontation with its European partners weeks after a Conservative election victory.
fields.body:
William Hague will reignite the Tory civil war over Europe this weekend by pledging to stage Britain's most serious confrontation with its European partners weeks after a Conservative election victory.

In a significant hardening of his Euroscepticism, the Tory leader has thrown his weight behind a plan to renegotiate Britain's entire relationship with Brussels at the first European summit after the election. The move will bring an end to an uneasy truce between the Tory leadership and the party's pro-European "big beasts", such as the former chancellor Kenneth Clarke, who had agreed to keep their heads down during the election campaign.

Francis Maude, the fiercely Eurosceptic shadow foreign secretary, will set out the new hardline approach when he tells the Conservative spring conference tomorrow that a Tory government would close off the "one-way street towards a European superstate".

In his keynote speech to the conference in Harrogate, Mr Maude will declare that a Tory government would use the EU summit in Gothenburg in June to call for the renegotiation of the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy and last December's Nice treaty. He will also pledge to introduce legislation soon after the election to ensure that the European court of justice cannot override the will of parliament.

Mr Maude will tell the conference: "Lots of people think it is inevitable that Britain will lose more and more of its sovereign powers. It is only inevitable if Britain lets it happen. It is absolutely clear that Labour would let this happen. A Conservative government will stop the slide to a European superstate."

The shadow foreign secretary, who will claim that he is speaking for Britain's mainstream majority, will declare that it is absurd for agricultural and fisheries policies to be decided at an EU level. "Why should the North sea fisheries management be decided by Greece and Italy?"

Mr Maude will also tear apart last December's Nice treaty, which reformed the way the EU is run to allow for up to 15 new members to join. He will say the Tories are in favour of EU enlargement, but oppose the areas of the treaty that limited Britain's veto.

"We will renegotiate the Nice treaty. No further loss of Britain's veto," Mr Maude will declare. "We will bring an end to the continental intrusion of the EU into areas that parliament agreed."

Were the Tories to win the election, Mr Maude's pledge would lead to the UK's most serious confrontation with Brussels since Britain joined the EEC in 1973. Such fundamental changes could only be introduced with the agreement of all EU member states, which they would never give.

The Tories gathered in Harrogate last night amid gloomy hopes for their election prospects, but Mr Hague told them they could still win.

webTitle: Open advocate of withdrawal who puts pressure on Hague

fields.headline: Open advocate of withdrawal who puts pressure on Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, is one of a number of Tory figures who operate within the maze of Eurosceptic organisations slowly pushing William Hague toward outright opposition to the single currency.
fields.body:
Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, is one of a number of Tory figures who operate within the maze of Eurosceptic organisations slowly pushing William Hague toward outright opposition to the single currency.

Lord Pearson, however, is a rare figure inside the Tory party in that he is an open advocate of withdrawal. He has tabled bills to this effect in the Lords, but won no overt support from his front bench colleagues. His dabbling with the UKIP has alienated him from the Conservative leadership in the Lords.

Nevertheless, he is not as isolated a figure as one might expect. He was an influential figure in the fight to retain the hereditary peerage and more importantly he is president of the influential anti-European group Cafe. Cafe has flirted with withdrawal, but currently declares on its web site "We must not agree to economic and monetary union", as well as urging renegotiation of the CAP and the common fisheries policy.

Four shadow cabinet ministers are vice-presidents of Cafe - Angela Browning, David Heathcoat-Amory, Oliver Letwin and Iain Duncan Smith. A total of 40 Conservative MPs support Cafe, including John Redwood, who yesterday spoke at a conference organised by IG, the spread betting firm run by Stuart Wheeler who is providing £5m to the Tory election campaign.

Lord Pearson made his money from insurance, but has a number of wealthy friends eager to ensure the Conservatives remain Eurosceptic after the election. Many spend their time in plotting over what will happen to the Tory leadership in the event of a big election defeat.

Much time is spent poring over the Tory leadership rules, and speculating on the shape of the party in the event of an election defeat and then a defeat on the referendum on the single currency.

One shadow cabinet member said this week: "The single most interesting issue in the Tory party is whether we come to accept a defeat in a referendum and go along with the single curency, or whether we go on fighting".

Senior Tories believe a yes vote in a referendum held more than two years after the election could yet be reversed in another general election.

Tory rightwingers are convinced that Michael Portillo, rapidly becoming the candidate for the left, will abandon the battle over the single currency if the election and then the referendum is lost.

Lord Pearson's office insisted yesterday he was travelling abroad and would be unable to comment until next week, if he does so at all.

webTitle: Labour fails to pick more women

fields.headline: Labour fails to pick more women
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour has admitted that it has selected only 142 women candidates for the coming general election and 17 from the ethnic minorities.
fields.body:
Labour has admitted that it has selected only 142 women candidates for the coming general election and 17 from the ethnic minorities.

The party has only 27 more candidates to select out of a planned total of 643 covering England, Scotland and Wales. The figures sent out by its women's officer mean Labour has selected women in 23% of seats, far better than the 14% figure for the Conservatives.

It nevertheless represents a disappointment for a party that has espoused equality of race and gender. The Fawcett Society said at the last election Labour selected 158 women, the Liberal Democrats 122 and the Conservatives 67.

The remaining endorsements are expected to be completed at a meeting of Labour's national executive next month. The party asserts it already has 10 ethnic minority MPs and now seven prospective candidates.

Calculations suggest that Labour could lose up to 80 of its most marginal seats and still have the same proportion of women MPs as at present. The party claims 23% of the parliamentary party are women.

The calculations suggest that in the Tories' top 100 target seats only 13 candidates are women. Labour has 31 women contesting the same 100 seats.

The Fawcett Society complains that the overall number of selections of women disguises the extent to which women have lost ground in Labour safe seats. Only three women have been selected in the 30 constituencies where Labour MPs are retiring. Fawcett calculates that a 5% swing away from Labour would see 12 women lose their seats.

The Conservatives have no women standing in seats where the sitting Conservative is standing down. One Conservative woman is standing down - Teresa Gorman.

The figures underline the extent to which women still suffer at Labour selections without women only shortlists. The party was forced to drop such lists before the last election after an industrial tribunal ruled them unlawful.

In this parliament's round of selections, the party has encouraged constituencies to try to ensure there are at least two men and two women on every shortlist.

The party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, told the Labour women's conference in Glasgow a fortnight ago that she would be pressing for a change to the law after the election to allow parties to reinstate women-only shortlists, or other forms of positive discrimination.

The party's women fared much better in the Welsh and Scottish assemblies where they got 50% representation largely by twinning seats.

The Fawcett Society said experience in Europe showed that only positive discrimination ensured women got a fair share of seats. France has just passed a law making state support dependent on political parties running positive discrimination for selection.

Whatever its own difficulties, Labour has also calculated that it will take the Conservatives at their current rate of progress selecting women candidates 100 years to reach the number that Labour has.

Candidates selected by Labour include Matthew Syed, an Olympic competitor at table tennis.

The youngest prospective candidate is a 23-year-old Oxford educated barrister, James Norman. He is standing in the solid Tory seat of Surrey Heath, represented by Nick Hawkins.

John O'Farrell, the Guardian columnist and author of Things Can Only Get Better, is representing Labour in Maidenhead against the shadow education secretary, Theresa May. The shadow environment minister, Damien Green, is facing a challenge from a one-time City banker and Financial Times journalist, John Adams.

fields.headline: '£2m deal' to shield Tory marginals
fields.standfirst:
UK Independence party had talks with intermediary over strategy to boost influence of Eurosceptic wing

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A secret £2m plan to protect key Tory MPs from election challenges by the UK Independence Party is alleged to be part of a wider plot to strengthen the Eurosceptic wing of the Tory party in the event of William Hague standing down after the election.
fields.body:
A secret £2m plan to protect key Tory MPs from election challenges by the UK Independence Party is alleged to be part of a wider plot to strengthen the Eurosceptic wing of the Tory party in the event of William Hague standing down after the election.

The claim was made yesterday by Nigel Farage, the UKIP MEP who confirmed talks with Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, that would see UKIP candidates withdraw from up to 30 Tory seats.

The conduit for the talks between Mr Farage and Lord Pearson was Lord Neidpath, a friend of Lord Pearson, a member of the UKIP and heir to the Earl of Wemyss and March.

Lord Neidpath, a former page of honour to the Queen Mother, told the Guardian: "The worry is that if all the potential get-out-of-Europe Tory MPs lose their seats because UKIP stands, then that will be a huge set back for Euroscepticism.

"The leadership might then go to Kenneth Clarke, or even Michael Portillo."

He insisted that Lord Pearson never made a direct offer of cash. "It was not a formal bargain. Would it not be nice to have £1m to £2m if UKIP candidates stood down where Eurosceptic MPs were standing? UKIP is a loose-limbed uncentralised organisation, but we thought we could pull it off".

Mr Farage had to pull out of the talks after news of them leaked. Lord Neidpath claimed the Tory Eurosceptic MP Patrick Nicholls had told fellow Tory Nicholas Soames, who became indignant at any possibility of a deal.

"It was very unfortunate. The whole thing started to be portrayed as if we were blackmailing the Conservative party. That was not the case."

Mr Farage said Lord Pearson was anxious to protect the rightwing of the Tory party grouped around John Redwood and Iain Duncan Smith. Mr Farage claimed Mr Hague's party remains "paranoid" about the threat that 400 UKIP candidates would pose to the Tories at the polls.

But Mr Farage, an MEP since 1999, told the Guardian: "They know they have lost the general election. The battle is now about who takes over from Hague and who takes control of the party. It is the Redwood camp as opposed to the Portillo camp.

"The kind of people they want us to stand down against are people who would vote for Redwood rather than Portillo," he claimed, pointing to figures such as David Heathcoat-Amory, Oliver Letwin and even Mr Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, whom many MPs regard as a leadership hopeful if Mr Hague achieves a fatally poor result against Tony Blair.

Some of Mr Farage's analysis will strike many Tory MPs as unlikely, given the weakness of Mr Redwood's current political base.

Lord Neidpath added that Michael Spicer, the leading Eurosceptic MP and possible candidate for the leadership of the 1922 committee after the election was also anxious to see the UKIP stand down in his constituency.

Mr Spicer is seen as a key player in the fight for the leadership succession if there is a heavy election defeat.

Mr Spicer, MP for Worcestershire West, has a majority of 3,846 and is number 17 on the Liberal Democrats' hit list. Neither the UKIP nor the Referendum Party stood in Mr Spicer's seat in 1997.

Lord Pearson also wanted to protect other sceptic allies from UKIP candidates, such as Mr Letwin. He has a wafer-thin majority of 1,840 votes in Dorset West. Overall, the Tories currently hold 12 seats with a majority of less than 1,000.

Mr Farage, who was authorised to discuss a cash deal with wealthy, unidentified Tories by his party leader, Jeffrey Titford MEP, described Lord Pearson - an insurance tycoon ennobled by Lady Thatcher in 1990 - as "a fervent Euro-sceptic deeply sympathetic to UKIP's aims and goals".

fields.headline: '£2m deal' to shield Tory marginals
fields.standfirst: UK Independence party had talks with intermediary over strategy to boost influence of Eurosceptic wing
fields.trailText: UK Independence party had talks with intermediary over strategy to boost influence of Eurosceptic wing.
fields.body:
A secret £2m plan to protect key Tory MPs from election challenges by the UK Independence Party is alleged to be part of a wider plot to strengthen the Eurosceptic wing of the Tory party in the event of William Hague standing down after the election.

The claim was made yesterday Nigel Farage, the UKIP MEP who confirmed talks with Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, that would see UKIP candidates withdraw from up to 30 Tory seats.

The conduit for the talks between Mr Farage and Lord Pearson was Lord Neidpath, a friend of Lord Pearson, a member of the UKIP and heir to the Earl of Wemyss and March.

Lord Neidpath, a former page of honour to the Queen Mother, told the Guardian: "The worry is that if all the potential get-out-of-Europe Tory MPs lose their seats because UKIP stands, then that will be a huge set back for Euroscepticism.

"The leadership might then go to Kenneth Clarke, or even Michael Portillo."

He insisted that Lord Pearson never made a direct offer of cash. "It was not a formal bargain. Would it not be nice to have £1m to £2m if UKIP candidates stood down where Eurosceptic MPs were standing? UKIP is a loose-limbed uncentralised organisation, but we thought we could pull it off".

Mr Farage had to pull out of the talks after news of them leaked. Lord Neidpath claimed the Tory Eurosceptic MP Patrick Nicholls had told fellow Tory Nicholas Soames, who became indignant at any possibility of a deal.

"It was very unfortunate. The whole thing started to be portrayed as if we were blackmailing the Conservative party. That was not the case."

Mr Farage said Lord Pearson was anxious to protect the rightwing of the Tory party grouped around John Redwood and Iain Duncan Smith. Mr Farage claimed Mr Hague's party remains "paranoid" about the threat that 400 UKIP candidates would pose to the Tories at the polls.

But Mr Farage, an MEP since 1999, told the Guardian: "They know they have lost the general election. The battle is now about who takes over from Hague and who takes control of the party. It is the Redwood camp as opposed to the Portillo camp.

"The kind of people they want us to stand down against are people who would vote for Redwood rather than Portillo," he claimed, pointing to figures such as David Heathcoat-Amory, Oliver Letwin and even Mr Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, whom many MPs regard as a leadership hopeful if Mr Hague achieves a fatally poor result against Tony Blair.

Some of Mr Farage's analysis will strike many Tory MPs as unlikely, given the weakness of Mr Redwood's current political base.

Lord Neidpath added that Michael Spicer, the leading Eurosceptic MP and possible candidate for the leadership of the 1922 committee after the election was also anxious to see the UKIP stand down in his constituency.

Mr Spicer is seen as a key player in the fight for the leadership succession if there is a heavy election defeat

Mr Spicer, MP for Worcestershire West, has a majority of 3,846 and is number 17 on the Liberal Democrats' hit list. Neither the UKIP nor the Referendum Party stood in Mr Spicer's seat in 1997.

Lord Pearson also wanted to protect other sceptic allies from UKIP candidates, such as Mr Letwin. He has a wafer-thin majority of 1,840 votes in Dorset West. Overall, the Tories currently hold 12 seats with a majority of less than 1,000.

Mr Farage, who was authorised to discuss a cash deal with wealthy, unidentified Tories by his party leader, Jeffrey Titford MEP, described Lord Pearson - an insurance tycoon ennobled by Lady Thatcher in 1990 - as "a fervent Euro-sceptic deeply sympathetic to UKIP 's aims and goals".

webTitle: Open advocate of withdrawal who puts pressure on Hague

fields.headline: Open advocate of withdrawal who puts pressure on Hague
fields.trailText:
Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, is one of a number of Tory figures
         who operate within the maze of Eurosceptic organisations slowly pushing William Hague
         toward outright opposition to the single currency.
fields.body:
Lord Pearson of Rannoch, the Thatcherite Tory peer, is one of a number of Tory figures who operate within the maze of Eurosceptic organisations slowly pushing William Hague toward outright opposition to the single currency.

Lord Pearson, however, is a rare figure inside the Tory party in that he is an open advocate of withdrawal. He has tabled bills to this effect in the Lords, but won no overt support from his front bench colleagues. His dabbling with the UKIP has alienated him from the Conservative leadership in the Lords.

Nevertheless, he is not as isolated a figure as one might expect. He was an influential figure in the fight to retain the hereditary peerage and more importantly he is president of the influential anti-European group Cafe. Cafe has flirted with withdrawal, but currently declares on its web site "We must not agree to economic and monetary union", as well as urging renegotiation of the CAP and the common fisheries policy.

Four shadow cabinet ministers are vice-presidents of Cafe - Angela Browning, David Heathcoat-Amory, Oliver Letwin and Iain Duncan Smith. A total of 40 Conservative MPs support Cafe, including John Redwood, who yesterday spoke at a conference organised by IG, the spread betting firm run by Stuart Wheeler who is providing pounds 5m to the Tory election campaign.

Lord Pearson made his money from insurance, but has a number of wealthy friends eager to ensure the Conservatives remain Eurosceptic after the election. Many spend their time in plotting over what will happen to the Tory leadership in the event of a big election defeat.

Much time is spent poring over the Tory leadership rules, and speculating on the shape of the party in the event of an election defeat and then a defeat on the referendum on the single currency.

One shadow cabinet member said this week: "The single most interesting issue in the Tory party is whether we come to accept a defeat in a referendum and go along with the single curency, or whether we go on fighting".

Senior Tories believe a yes vote in a referendum held more than two years after the election could yet be reversed in another general election.

Tory rightwingers are convinced that Michael Portillo, rapidly becoming the candidate for the left, will abandon the battle over the single currency if the election and then the referendum is lost.

Lord Pearson's office insisted yesterday he was travelling abroad and would be unable to comment until next week, if he does so at all.

They last for ages, no sickness, no litter, and no haggling over the price of water each time you are thirsty.

fields.trailText: Muscle- and skin-care products that come in plastic, leakproof bottles and cost £7-£8 each. The pre-sport muscle balm warm-up reduces risk of injury. The British Alpine team swears by it.
fields.body:
My New Year's fitness campaign is taking its toll. What's the answer to blisters, backache and aching muscles I never knew existed? Try a selection of Biobas Active muscle- and skin-care products. They come in plastic, leakproof bottles and cost £7-£8 each. The pre-sport muscle balm warm-up reduces risk of injury. The British Alpine team swears by it.

How can a cream warm up muscles? It's made from natural ingredients, such as pepper, thyme and rosemary essential oils, which increase circulation and stimulate muscle tissue.

Is there a magic potion for hand blisters? Try Hand:Grip. It contains silica, which absorbs perspiration and keeps your hands dry so they don't slip.

Anything for aching feet? Try Foot:Balm. The peppermint oil soothes the feet, sea salt reduces sweat and bacteria, and shea butter forms a protective film.

Doesn't it make your socks all oily? No, you just apply it over your entire foot before exercising, then leave it to dry for 30-40 seconds. It almost feels like wearing silk socks.

 For stockists, call 020-7702 3239 or visit www.biobas.com
