webTitle: Shanghai on cutting edge of China's hi-tech drive

fields.headline: The city at the dragon's head roars into the future
fields.standfirst:
Shanghai is on the cutting edge as China enters hi-tech new millennium

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Shanghai is on the cutting edge as China enters hi-tech new millennium.
fields.body:
It was the Paris of the East, the commercial hub of the Orient and the place where Mao Zedong and comrades founded the Communist party. Margot Fonteyn learned to dance here, Auden and Isherwood inspected the nightlife and the Japanese forced the city to join the Empire of the Sun. Ultra-red Maoists declared a people's commune here and the Gang of Four made it their base.

Shanghai has always been in the vanguard of change and since the death of Mao it has changed radically again. In Beijing next week, the National People's Congress will gather to discuss China's future: Shanghai already knows where it is going.

Last week, in a room with dazzling lights hung in dense crystal, the mayor, Xu Kuangdi, flashed his own dazzling smile and announced the latest plan. Shanghai is to become "East Asia's biggest semi-conductor production base" within five years. But how did the city make this remarkable transition from semi-colonialism to semi-conductors, and can its momentum be maintained?

Shanghai's main feature is the ability to do everything at the same time: new and old industry, commerce and services surge ahead at 2% above the national growth rate. Shanghai has more coffee bars than any other city in China, more high-rise buildings (more than 1,800), more supermarkets and department stores.

"This is the place to come back to," says one of the hundreds of young Chinese who have collected their Masters in Business Administration (MBAs) from the US or Britain, "but I cannot recognise it."

For the Guardian and for myself, it is also a place to come back to. Last month The Guardian set up its China office in Shanghai rather than Beijing, calculating that the country can best be watched from the "dragon's head" of the Yangtze. Shanghai may be among the most advanced, but just a few hours away by bus are the "backward" provinces of Jiangxi and Anhui, upstream along the dragon's body.

The last resident Guardian correspondent filed from Shanghai in the late 1930s. H J Timperley was an Australian journalist and friend of Edgar Snow, author of the classic Red Star Over China. "Tim" wrote an equally powerful but less remembered book, What War Means, documenting the Nanjing massacre by the Japanese army in December 1937.

My own experience of Shanghai began 30 years ago in April 1971, on a tour organised by the Society for Anglo-Chinese Understanding. It was the midpoint of the cultural revolution and we were only the second group from Britain to visit.

Even though the Red Guard struggles were over, Shanghai was still a tense place. Slogans hung up over shopfronts denounced "the evil wind of capitalism."

A mass shelter-building campaign was under way, in deference to Mao Zedong's instructions to "prepare against war".

At a machine tool factory, the "revolutionary" atmosphere was intense. "The workers don't smile," I noted at the time. "[The managers] say nervously that they are asking the 'broad masses' to criticise them."

Thirty years on, I ask a European diplomat where Shanghai is heading now. He gives Mr Xu a warm testimonial: "You get a clear sense of a strong united leadership in Shanghai with a common sense of purpose." Shanghai, he adds, has the 38th most powerful computer in the world.

Then, as so often with questions about Shanghai, caution sets in. "The authorities are on a learning curve with entry to the World Trade Organisation (WTO). We have to dampen expectations; this is not the place for the first time exporter."

The Guardian's new office is in a small estate of 1930s houses which would not be out of place in Weybridge, save for the fact that they are overlooked by high-rise blocks. The community that lived there was destroyed in the cultural revolution, when the capitalists and cadres (government officials) were exiled to the countryside and the houses were partitioned.

There are still traces of room partitions and of cooking stoves on the verandah. Pedicarts collecting scrap ring their bells for custom. But more houses are being renovated as the property market picks up and there is talk of widening Huashan Road nearby - formerly Avenue Haig on the edge of the British Settlement.

Today the Peace Hotel - formerly the famous Cathay hotel - is about to sell off a substantial share to the Mandarin hotel chain owned by the Jardine Group. That is Jardines of opium-trading fame, one of the biggest British companies in pre-communist Shanghai.

The old ferry to Pudong, then a marshy waste but now the pride of Shanghai's future, is still running. Passengers pay 50 cents (4p) to board the rusty deck along with pedicarts carrying huge loads and migrant workers but the journey back may now be made by the sensational Bund Tourist Tunnel - tickets 20 yuan (£1.70) - starting at the foot of the Oriental Pearl TV Tower. Glass-enclosed cable cars carry sightseers under the river, entertained by pulses of coloured lights that flash psychedelically along its length.

In 1971, at a workers' housing estate, we heard about the policy of late marriage - 26 years old for men and 28 for women. Marriage then was a simple declaration before a Communist party official.

Marriage business

Today, says Faye Shen - one of the returned MBAs - a wedding in Shanghai can cost as much as 160,000 yuan (£13,000). Ms Shen runs a marriage website and offers wedding loans up to 100,000 yuan. "I try to tell people that marriage is a commitment not a format. But I have to sell weddings too because it is my business," explains Ms Shen. "We plan to offer them in three different styles, Chinese, Japanese or American."

On an orning walk from in 1971, along the grimy Suzhou Creek which links the Huangpu River with inland waterways, we came across a group of men playing cards - defiantly bourgeois behaviour.

Now half of Shanghai is playing the stock exchange and there are more share shops than Internet cafes. The Suzhou creek is no longer grimy and some old warehouses have been converted into artists' studios. There are still barges on the Huangpu, but no junks.

Shanghai is also fighting - not very hard - a battle against cars and fumes. The overhead motorway which has cut a swath into the city centre is uncritically admired: the Bund is a four-lane highway.

Mayor Xu is bemused by a question about the dangers of uncontrolled vehicle growth. "In fact we want more cars and fewer bicycles," he insists cheerfully. "Did you know that two bicycles take up the same road space as one car?"

For now, old and new Shanghai coexist, though perhaps not for much longer. Mayor Xu and most other Shanghainese want to keep on the move.

fields.headline: Trendy vision without shock tactics
fields.trailText: A MaxMara show is always that strange thing in fashion - a collection in which every outfit is made to end up on the shop floor.
fields.body:
A MaxMara show is always that strange thing in fashion - a collection in which every outfit is made to end up on the shop floor. The Italian label, which yesterday in Milan presented its look for Autumn/Winter 2001, is a quiet powerhouse, creating looks, and a vast income, without needing to resort to shock tactics.

At the same time, the brand's design team still has the vision to feature some of the key trends that have come through these past few weeks. Every show seems to have them - polo necks, chunky knits, one-sleeved sweaters and double-breasted jackets and coats.

But instead of being pushed to the extremes of wearability, at MaxMara they came in their most approachable, neutral-coloured form - like the beautifully made high-neck sweaters matched with boot-cut cigarette pants, or the long double-breasted coats with large, stand-out buttons, which were repeated on the pleat at the back. Skirt lengths too were on-message, rarely going above the knee, mostly sitting on the calf and usually with some form of drape or kick.

There were some great worn denim pieces, such as the tailored frock coats similar to the ones at the hit Marc by Marc Jacobs show in New York. The jackets also came cropped, double-breasted, fur-lined and buttoned to the side - obviously, once they get on a trend, the Italians know how to ride it till it's broken.

As the show continued, the influence of two of London's great talents became apparent. The silhouette of the jackets - strong shouldered, structured waist - echoed the masculine line that is Alexander McQueen's trademark. And, when the collection moved into evening wear and the territory of the Grecian goddess, the clothing seemed inspired by Sophia Kokosalaki, with jersey draped around the body, brought together with a strong, wide belt, often embellished with flowers.

No one expects anything more of MaxMara, just this efficient distillation of all that is happening on the catwalks around them. But when the clothes are this wearable, no one is going to complain.

But instead of being pushed to the extremes of wearability, at MaxMara they came in their most approachable, neutral-coloured form - like the beautifully made high-neck sweaters matched with boot-cut cigarette pants, or the long double-breasted coats with large, stand-out buttons, which were repeated on the pleat at the back. Skirt lengths too were on-message, rarely going above the knee, mostly sitting on the calf and usually with some form of drape or kick. There were some great worn denim pieces, such as the tailored frock coats similar to the ones at the hit Marc by Marc Jacobs show in New York. The jackets also came cropped, double-breasted, fur-lined and buttoned to the side - obviously, once they get on a trend, the Italians know how to ride it till it's broken. As the show continued, the influence of two of London's great talents became apparent. The silhouette of the jackets - strong shouldered, structured waist - echoed the masculine line that is Alexander McQueen's trademark. And, when the collection moved into evening wear and the territory of the Grecian goddess, the clothing seemed inspired by Sophia Kokosalaki, with jersey draped around the body, brought together with a strong, wide belt, often embellished with flowers. No one expects anything more of MaxMara, just this efficient distillation of all that is happening on the catwalks around them. But when the clothes are this wearable, no one is going to complain.

webTitle: Press coverage of Europe and the euro

fields.headline: Laying it online, as dully as possible
fields.standfirst:
Europe and the media

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Over the weeks we have been looking at press coverage of Europe and the euro, and how it contributes to the debate. We have noted the government's reluctance to engage in the issue. Is it less reticent on its websites.
fields.body:
What about the web? Over the weeks we have been looking at press coverage of Europe and the euro, and how it contributes to the debate. We have noted the government's reluctance to engage in the issue. Is it less reticent on its websites, to which it is so committed? Does the government argue the case for the euro more enthusiastically, or simply more, than it does in ministerial speeches, debates and briefings? Where better to start than at No 10?

We are welcomed to the home page with these headlines: Free basic education for all; £60m investment to expand and improve NHS heart surgery; Selby rail crash; Foot and mouth disease; Modernising the criminal justice system. No mention of Europe here.

So we try the button marked Facts. "The factfiles section gives you background on policies," we are told. There are Brief Fact Files. These include files on beacon schools, cutting car crime, rough sleeping, transport 2010, and winter fuel payments. At first glance, nothing on Europe. Then you notice the word Nice in the menu. Presumably a reference to the Nice summit, with its crucial discussions on the development of the EU. Click. "What does the National Institute of Clinical Excellence do?" we are asked.

And there are In Depth Fact Files, files on rural Britain, crime reduction strategy, and sharing prosperity. No mention of Europe. We are digging deep when we visit Manifesto Commitments, the 177 items the government laid out back in 1997. The "leadership abroad" section starts at commitment 155, and finally, at 162, there it is: single currency. But that is simply the state of play four years ago.

And that is the way the government wants to keep it. Lobby briefings, or a version of them, are given on the No 10 website. I looked for one where the euro was mentioned, and found February 19 2001. Quote: "Asked if the prime minister agreed with Stephen Byers on the outlook for business investment in the UK relating particularly to the fact that Britain was outside the euro, the prime minister's spokesman noted that this was one of those stories where if we said anything we were accused of either warming up or cooling down on the euro. The government's position on the single currency was entirely as was set out and well known.."

Hardly a ringing government endorsement of the euro. How very different when we visit the online Conservatives. The "keep the pound" logo is on the home page. One click and we are in the "keep the pound" section of the site. There is the running total of the percentage of the electorate which wants to keep the pound. There is the mission statement: "We believe that Britain should be in Europe, but keep the pound." It is a busy, active page, packed with anti-euro passion.

No 10 may not seem to care, but what about the Foreign Office? Its site is as fond of "facts" as No 10's. "Facts, not myths," proclaims one of the "key foreign policy themes" pages. Yes, Europe, a key foreign policy theme. The Foreign Office minister Keith Vaz welcomes us with his photograph. But the words hardly have the passion or the propagandist tone of the Eurosceptics.

And on the EU myths pages we find "common misconceptions", "rebuttals" and "frequently asked questions". Vaz deals with all these points himself, which suggests some interest in the subject. But it is all very downbeat.

So yes, we can get official information on Europe and the euro online, but it suffers many of the same faults as much of the newspaper coverage. Passion from the antis. Solid, unexciting data from the pros.

The European commission's site is ponderously detailed. There is a series of statements such as "Emu means a superstate through the back door" followed by screens of rebuttal text. Slow, unappealing.

How much better are the media sites, for example the BBC News website, full of good, accessible information about the issues.

The website devoted one of its regular talking point features to The euro: what do you think? And that gave the lie to the idea that the public is simply not interested. Just the selection of views BBC Online put on the site ran to 24 pages when printed out. There is an appetite for debate, clearly.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

fields.headline: Escaped prisoners win payout
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Two former high-security prisoners, including one wrongly convicted of IRA offences, were yesterday awarded damages for injuries they received from prison officers during one of the most audacious and carefully planned escape attempts of the past 10 years.
fields.body:
Two former high-security prisoners, including one wrongly convicted of IRA offences, were yesterday awarded damages for injuries they received from prison officers during one of the most audacious and carefully planned escape attempts of the past 10 years. A third man who was also jailed for IRA terrorist offences had his claim dismissed.

The men were in a party of six prisoners who briefly escaped from the special secure unit of the new £58m Whitemoor prison in Cambridgeshire in 1994, wounding one prison officer with a gun.

It was considered to be one of the most serious lapses of security since the spy George Blake escaped from Wormwood Scrubs in 1966.

The men were all arrested within minutes and the three said they had been punched, kicked or beaten with batons by the prison officers as they were taken back to the segregation unit. The Home Office argued that all the injuries were escape-related.

A report by Sir John Woodcock, the chief inspector of constabulary, concluded at the time that the breakout was "a disaster waiting to happen" and criticised poor management at every level of the prison service, including that of Home Office ministers. As well as the two guns used in the escape a kilogram of Semtex was found in the grounds.

The incident led to a huge public row between the then home secretary, Michael Howard, and the then head of the prison service, Derek Lewis, about where responsibility lay.

In a three-hour judgment in the high court yesterday Mr Justice Crane accepted the claims of Danny McNamee, 40, and Andrew Russell, 38, an armed robber, for assault and battery or misfeasance of public office. But he rejected the claim of Liam McCotter, 37, who has completed a 15-year sentence imposed in 1988 for conspiracy to cause explosions.

Mr McNamee, whose conviction for playing a part in the 1982 Hyde Park bombing was quashed in December 1998 on new evidence, was awarded £5,000. He had protested his innocence for 12 years and was released under the Good Friday agreement. Russell, who is still serving a 20-year sentence for robbery and hijacking a helicopter for a jailbreak at Gartree prison, was awarded £2,500. The judge found that the use of handcuffs on McCotter was reasonable force.

The awards included aggravated damages but the judge declined to award exemplary damages against the Home Office because, he said, the prisoners had exposed themselves to the risk of injury. He praised the "outstanding courage" of the prison officers who gave chase. But he went on: "Their courage does not, of course, justify any unlawful use of force. The officers had been frightened by the actions of the escapers in carrying and using firearms. It was conceded on behalf of the claimants that by involving themselves in an escape they voluntarily exposed themselves to the risk of injury.

"I go further. The actions of the claimants had undoubtedly contributed to the heated atmosphere in which they were recaptured and in that sense to their injuries."

Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, said: "We will consider the judgment very carefully. Staff involved in the recapture of the prisoners put their own lives at risk in ensuring the protection of the public."

A police inquiry into the complaints did not lead to any prosecutions and the men's own trials were abandoned after media coverage revealed the alleged IRA connections.

Mr Justice Crane addressed public criticism of the men's civil action, which was legally aided and is likely to cost the taxpayer more than £500,000.

"Some people may take the view that if a group of armed prisoners escape from a prison, they should not be entitled to complain about any violence to them in the course of their recapture. However, the duty of the court is clear: to ascertain the facts and to judge the issues that arise. Those who break the law do not forfeit its protection."

fields.headline: Standard bearer for the flat tax society
fields.standfirst:
Interview Steve Forbes, president and chief executive, Forbes Inc

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Interview Steve Forbes, president and chief executive, Forbes Inc.
fields.body:
When Steve Forbes, two-time presidential candidate and multibillionaire publisher of the eponymous magazine, arrived at the cosy Greenwich village restaurant, nobody gave him a second glance.

Few people in the United States, where Forbes magazine is a business bible, would be able to pick out its tall, greying owner in an identity parade. Yet, in spite of spending at least $60m (£40m) on his attempt to lead the free world, Forbes doesn't seem to mind. When asked what he likes best about his post-campaign lifestyle, he says: "Being able to eat at little Italian restaurants like this one."

A year after giving up his battle for the Republican presidential nomination, Malcolm Stevenson Forbes Jr appears happy to be running his magazine and agitating for his pet political causes.

His stiff face, with eyes that rarely blink, breaks into a smile when we talk about the impact this week's cover story on Tony Blair has had. Forbes Global ran an article on "Red Tape Tony", which personified the prime minister as the biggest threat facing Britain's entrepreneurs and infuriated Downing Street. A huge fan of Margaret Thatcher, or Lady T as he calls her, Forbes believes that the Blair government is undoing some of her good work. "The UK is sitting on its laurels and the world is moving on," he says.

Once he starts talking about the burdens of bureaucracy or the need to encourage business, Forbes becomes voluble. Otherwise, he appears almost shy and speaks with a staccato voice.

None of these attributes are common in the average politician - especially one who aspires to the top job in the US. Forbes's personal behaviour appeared odd on the campaign trail, where he needed to be encouraged to press some flesh before giving speeches. Reports suggest he was happier going straight to the podium to talk about a few of his favourite things, such as a flat tax rate. A Forbes staffer was once asked on live television: "Is your candidate an alien?"

Six years after Forbes ran in his first presidential race and a year after he stepped down from the last one, people still wonder why he did it. Marshall Whitman, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, says: "It was always a mystery why Steve Forbes didn't run for a lower office before president. The whole notion is that you at least run for dogcatcher before you run for the most powerful position in the world. Probably he thought those other offices were below him."

Filling a void

Forbes himself blames "happenstance" for his decision to run for president. In 1995, Jack Kemp decided to drop out of the race for the Republican nomination, leaving those on the economic right wing of the party without a standard bearer. "I never intended to go into politics," says Forbes. "But I saw a vacuum and decided that, instead of complaining about it, I should fill it."

His first candidacy caused quite a stir as his low taxation, pro-business message struck a chord with Republican voters. Last year, he dropped out in early February after coming third to both George Bush and senator John McCain.

Not that Forbes sees the campaign as a defeat. In fact, he takes credit for the president's plan to cut $1.3 trillion from the tax bill. "They would not have had it if I hadn't been running," he says. Bush annoyed the right wing of his party early on in the campaign by using "Democratic language" such as: "We cannot balance the budget on the backs of the poor." This changed once Forbes decided to run, he says: "When they realised they had a contest, they showed up their party face."

He also takes credit for the administration's more vigorously anti-abortion stance and its more conservative approach to social security. "The message did better than the messenger," he says.

During lunch, it is easy to see where his true passion lies. Whenever there is a slight lull in the conversation, he returns to the economy and the issue of taxation.

When asked what the focus of his work is now, he says: "I'll be trying to get the Bush tax cut - a good one - through .. We have a job of agitation and education."

Critics say self-interest played a part in his support for a flat tax of 17%. The Centre for Public Integrity, a non-profit research group, has estimated that the Forbes family itself would save "millions" from such a rate. The figures are less than precise partly because Forbes has refused to make his tax returns public, which he has the right to do as a private citizen rather than a politician.

What the Forbes and Bush tax plans share, according to the centre, is that both benefit the top 1% of American earners. According to the centre's research, president Bush's own annual tax bill would have been cut from $3.8m to just over $10,000 as a result of the flat tax plan.

Supporters of Forbes reject any suggestion of self-interest. They point out that the amount he has spent on the campaign more than outweighs any tax dodge on his estimated $450m wealth.

Some more psychologically inclined pundits believe that Forbes's decision to run represents a sort of one-upmanship against his father. Malcolm Forbes Sr, the son of the magazine's Scottish immigrant founder and father of Steve, did run for office - he tried and failed twice to become governor of his home state of New Jersey.

Undeterred, Forbes Sr - the Richard Branson of his age - embarked on a round the world trip via bike and hot air balloon. He escorted Elizabeth Taylor and had a renowned collection of Fabergé eggs, among other trinkets. For his 70th birthday, he flew hundreds of guests to Tangiers, where he entertained them with 600 belly dancers and Berber horsemen.

His eldest son has said: "My father once spent $5m on a birthday party for himself. Why can't I spend a few more running for president?"

Steve Forbes still holds well-attended parties on the family's yacht and in its desirable Fifth Avenue townhouse, but flamboyant he is not. His entrance into the restaurant for lunch is typical of his entrances everywhere.

Yet friends such as Lawrence Kudlow, the supply-side economist at ING Barings, vouch for a wry sense of humour and a fine line in self-deprecation. After the Guardian first tracked him down in a Starbucks coffee shop, Forbes sent something to make the office "chuckle" - a scarf printed with "Capitalist Tool", the company motto.

Contrary to some newspaper reports, he also speaks warmly of his family. He has five daughters aged between 13 and 27 and has been married to the same women for 31 years. He says he likes working with his four brothers in the family business as they "can learn things through osmosis".

He denies that his campaign suffered from an emphasis on politics rather than personality. "What people want to see is whether you have what it takes to do the job. Nixon would never win a personality contest and he won."

He cites the Watergate president a few times during lunch. "In the information age, as Nixon demonstrated over 30 years ago, you don't necessarily need to either hold an office to .. impact an issue."

There has been some speculation that he might run for governor or even senator of New Jersey. Forbes, however, says he is unlikely to run for any other political office any time soon. "You never say never but certainly for the foreseeable future there are no plans to run," he says.

Political analysts who believe that Forbes simply wanted a national stage for his right-wing agenda also doubt he would run for another political office.

Peter Eisner, managing director of the Centre for Public Integrity, says: "Forbes belongs to a group of right-wing ideological zealots. He knew that he could never win [the presidency] but he was able to use the platform to advance his causes."

One thing Forbes is clear about is his continuing involvement in the family firm. Asked what he will be doing in 10 years' time, he says: "That's a scary thought. It goes so bloody quick. I'm sure I'll still be involved in the magazine." As an afterthought, he adds: "I never would have predicted the past 10 years."

He joined the magazine company at 22, after graduating from Princeton. His credits as a journalist included co-founding a business magazine at university and writing a report which graded his teachers while in the fifth grade.

He took over the magazine empire in 1990. Yet he genuinely appears to enjoy the life of a publisher. "When an issue comes out it feels like a new child - you get that rush," he says.

Staff believe he maintains firm editorial control over the magazine, which is renowned for its heavy editing. Forbes denies any undue influence.

Forbes appreciates the platform the magazine gives him, with its estimated readership of 900,000. He continued to write his fortnightly column on the campaign trial, where he trained his sights on everything from Alan Greenspan and the European Union (both bad) to company matters and the latest New York restaurant. "I have a curiosity to poke into everything and anything," he says.

He has poked into UK politics several times, last time when he criticised Michael Portillo's tax-cutting plans as too lily-livered. He still gets worked up about the issue now. He calls the Tory plan a "measly, skimpy skinny tax cut phased in over 500 years. If you're going to do it, make it real, make it something people can get excited about."

His enthusiasm for Lady T seems to know no bounds. He saw her before Christmas and said: "She's in fine form, she'd be ready to take over tomorrow." He is less warm about William Hague, but calls him extremely bright. The Tory leader did himself no favours when he met Forbes two years ago. "The only thing he wanted to talk about was the Bushes, which obviously didn't please me very much."

Although Forbes was invited to the president's first economic forum in January, few analysts were surprised that he was passed over for a post in the administration. He is sanguine about the fact. "He has so many people he has to take care of," he says. "I don't think anything will pop up for at least two or three years anyway." He does not intend to "lobby for anything" in the interim.

He spends a lot of time travelling to speak at conservative-minded conferences and attending Republican bashes. Tomorrow he will be in Norfolk, Virginia, attending the inauguration of an aircraft carrier devoted to Ronald Reagan.

He insists on paying for lunch and seems perfectly happy as he leaves the restaurant. "I shall be agitating from the outside," he says with a smile.

Contrary to some newspaper reports, he also speaks warmly of his family. He has five daughters aged between 13 and 27 and has been married to the same women for 31 years. He says he likes working with his four brothers in the family business as they "can learn things through osmosis". He denies that his campaign suffered from an emphasis on politics rather than personality. "What people want to see is whether you have what it takes to do the job. Nixon would never win a personality contest and he won." He cites the Watergate president a few times during lunch. "In the information age, as Nixon demonstrated over 30 years ago, you don't necessarily need to either hold an office to .. impact an issue." There has been some speculation that he might run for governor or even senator of New Jersey. Forbes, however, says he is unlikely to run for any other political office any time soon. "You never say never but certainly for the foreseeable future there are no plans to run," he says. Political analysts who believe that Forbes simply wanted a national stage for his right-wing agenda also doubt he would run for another political office. Peter Eisner, managing director of the Centre for Public Integrity, says: "Forbes belongs to a group of right-wing ideological zealots. He knew that he could never win [the presidency] but he was able to use the platform to advance his causes." One thing Forbes is clear about is his continuing involvement in the family firm. Asked what he will be doing in 10 years' time, he says: "That's a scary thought. It goes so bloody quick. I'm sure I'll still be involved in the magazine." As an afterthought, he adds: "I never would have predicted the past 10 years." He joined the magazine company at 22, after graduating from Princeton. His credits as a journalist included co-founding a business magazine at university and writing a report which graded his teachers while in the fifth grade. He took over the magazine empire in 1990. Yet he genuinely appears to enjoy the life of a publisher. "When an issue comes out it feels like a new child - you get that rush," he says. Staff believe he maintains firm editorial control over the magazine, which is renowned for its heavy editing. Forbes denies any undue influence. Forbes appreciates the platform the magazine gives him, with its estimated readership of 900,000. He continued to write his fortnightly column on the campaign trial, where he trained his sights on everything from Alan Greenspan and the European Union (both bad) to company matters and the latest New York restaurant. "I have a curiosity to poke into everything and anything," he says. He has poked into UK politics several times, last time when he criticised Michael Portillo's tax-cutting plans as too lily-livered. He still gets worked up about the issue now. He calls the Tory plan a "measly, skimpy skinny tax cut phased in over 500 years. If you're going to do it, make it real, make it something people can get excited about." His enthusiasm for Lady T seems to know no bounds. He saw her before Christmas and said: "She's in fine form, she'd be ready to take over tomorrow." He is less warm about William Hague, but calls him extremely bright. The Tory leader did himself no favours when he met Forbes two years ago. "The only thing he wanted to talk about was the Bushes, which obviously didn't please me very much." Although Forbes was invited to the president's first economic forum in January, few analysts were surprised that he was passed over for a post in the administration. He is sanguine about the fact. "He has so many people he has to take care of," he says. "I don't think anything will pop up for at least two or three years anyway." He does not intend to "lobby for anything" in the interim. He spends a lot of time travelling to speak at conservative-minded conferences and attending Republican bashes. Tomorrow he will be in Norfolk, Virginia, attending the inauguration of an aircraft carrier devoted to Ronald Reagan. He insists on paying for lunch and seems perfectly happy as he leaves the restaurant. "I shall be agitating from the outside," he says with a smile.

webTitle: Mr Smith sticks to the business he knows

fields.headline: Mr Smith sticks to the business he knows
fields.standfirst:
Leisure group's cyber-bet

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Rank ragbag of leisure businesses has now been streamlined. Under chief executive Mike Smith out have gone almost all the businesses associated with the group's movie heritage - Odeon cinemas, Pinewood Studios, the half-share of Florida's Universal Studios - along with the Tom Cobleigh pub chain and Butlins.
fields.body:
The Rank ragbag of leisure businesses has now been streamlined. Under chief executive Mike Smith out have gone almost all the businesses associated with the group's movie heritage - Odeon cinemas, Pinewood Studios, the half-share of Florida's Universal Studios - along with the Tom Cobleigh pub chain and Butlins. There are just three strands left - gaming, the Hard Rock cafe chain and film and video unit Deluxe, which given its recent performance would be more aptly named Dismal.

The rot set in at Deluxe a couple of years ago, when the company hit an iceberg with Titanic. It could not cope with demand for 50m copies of the blockbuster double video, had to subcontract the business and ended up all but losing money on a contract which should have been the video business's biggest money-spinner to date.

Last year Rank lost the contract to produce Fox Home Entertainment Videos in the United States and profits from the offshoot dived by 36% to £24.7m last year.

The arrival of DVDs, which Mr Smith thought might provide a boost, has instead caused more problems. Deluxe replicated 3.3m of them last year, but start-up costs and lower than expected volumes conspired to produce a loss of £4.7m.

Deluxe has been up for sale for three years, and still no one wants it.

Hard Rock, meanwhile, rolls on. A Hard Rock hotel has just opened in the US and a new cafe - to have its own Hard Rock casino alongside - is open in Manchester, away from the usual touristy locations. Mr Smith reckons new outlets could work in Leeds and Glasgow too but should beware of devaluing his prize brand.

With debt now down to £320m, Mr Smith is in a position to consider an acquisition and, unlike his predecessor, intends to stick to businesses he knows.

That means gaming, where profits grew 19% last year. Having come from Ladbrokes this is a business that Mr Smith knows a thing or two about. He is planning a chain of cyber-casinos and although he was tight-lipped yesterday, there is growing speculation he will turn Rank into a bookie. Ladbroke, William Hill or Coral are all in play.

There is other speculation that Mr Smith might try to engineer a buy-out.

Watch this space. With a business that spans burgers, bingo, the Claremont Club and videos, Rank is still an unfocused mess and Mr Smith must make a big and bold move soon.

Profits gap

If two profits warnings could be considered carelessness, then what should we make of six?

The Gap, the US fashion retailer that dressed the world in grey sweat tops and combat pants, yesterday reached the half-dozen warnings in as many months. The company admitted it had lost its fashion edge.

Fourth quarter profits fell 34% to $272m (£185m), despite an increase in sales to $4.6bn. At the same time, it told investors that the company would be unlikely to meet forecasts for the first quarter of its new financial year. In the past 12 months the share price has halved.

The Gap is often named as being one of the retailers that ate away at the market previously occupied by Marks & Spencer. It was among the smarter, more fashionable chains which stole share from big, bland behemoths like M&S.

But The Gap's rapid expansion - it now has 2,000 stores - has left it in the same position, a lumbering retailer which is losing business to smaller, sharper competitors. In the US particularly, The Gap faces a far tougher market against rivals like J Crew, which are putting out similar mainstream lines but are doing a far better job of it.

The company at least has acknowledged where things are going wrong. "We slowed down this past year on fashion and newness, and clearly there will be change in the future," Millard Drexler, The Gap's chief executive said. "We've got to get back to the creative strength that we've had and we've just got to be faster doing it."

A laudable sentiment, indeed, but as M&S has demonstrated, not an easy one to execute once a fashionwear group has lost its way.

Masterstroke

Barclays spent much of last year with an apparent public relations death wish. There was the potentially mega-pay packet put on the table for chief executive Matt Barrett which came at the same time as the closure of 172 branches, causing uproar in the countryside. Then there were charges for non-customers who had the cheek to use its cash machines. There was a hugely expensive television advertising campaign extolling its virtues - just as rural customers were being turned away.

Its decision to delay loan repayments for farmers hit by foot and mouth is, by comparison, a PR masterstroke.

fields.headline: The Guardian's success continues...
fields.trailText: Awards
fields.body:
Awards

The Guardian has picked up four more nominations for this year's British Press Awards :

 Newspaper of the Year

 Steve Bell, cartoonist

 Guardian Unlimited, Website of the Year

 Tom Jenkins, sports photographer

This brings our total of nominations to 11.

The Observer has been nominated for seven awards.

Brand strength

The Guardian was voted strongest quality newspaper brand in the Media Brands 2001 survey by Ocean Consulting. The survey of 39 senior directors from the top media agencies in the UK - half at CEO/MD level - found the Guardian had a consumer brand more than three times as strong as its nearest rival, the Sunday Times. Media Week praised our "clear positioning, communication and execution... A clear identity and reader loyalty are the key offerings for advertisers".

Sales

The Guardian's sales for January rose to 410,152. The 2.13%rise year-on-year was the highest of any mainstream national daily. The Guardian's success continues to be overwhelmingly built on full price sales.

In January our full price sales represented 87%of the overall ABC - against 74% for the Independent, 66% for the Times and 57% for the Telegraph. The Observer's ABC figure for January was 440,090 - up 5.67% year on year and the largest leap in sales of any quality Sunday paper.

fields.headline: The last word on   Conflict
fields.standfirst: Wars of opinion, as they have been the most destructive, are the most disgraceful of conflicts, being appeals from right to might and from argument to artillery -  Charles Caleb Colton
fields.trailText: Wars of opinion, as they have been the most destructive, are the most disgraceful of conflicts, being appeals from right to might and from argument to artillery - Charles Caleb Colton
fields.body:
It would be encouraging to think that when conflicts cannot end in outright victory for one side, they tend to end in weariness and a growing sickness at the waste they cause. If this were so, conflict would be self-limiting, dying down as a fire does when it has consumed its fuel. But human conflicts seem to defy this hope. They pause, and for a time there is a simulacrum of peace; but grudges are passed like heritable diseases from one generation to the next, and there is always dry tinder in the human stock ready to catch alight when friction is renewed.

History is rich in examples of this dismal lesson. The Balkans, the Middle East, Indonesia, Kashmir and central Africa provide current instances, but it would be a mistake to think conflict naturally belongs to dispensations outside the charmed circle of western democracies. Ireland, two world wars and Vietnam prove otherwise; the selfsame infection took hold in these cases, involving what some of the participants liked to think were the richest, most developed and civilised polities in the world.

What are the sources of these conflicts? It is natural to think they share deep common roots in the fact that resources are few, people many. Competition over resources can easily turn into conflict. Societies evolve means for adjudicating disputes among the individuals and interest groups constituting them, chiefly by institutional means such as government and law; but sometimes the conflict is too great even for that safeguard. The same applies in the international sphere, where on a larger scale the same cost is exacted by failure - bloodshed and destruction.

There is one thing wrong with this picture. It mislocates the roots of conflict in competition over resources, the model being imagined tribes of early man quarrelling over access to water-holes or pastures. No doubt such things happened. But the real reason for the bitterness and persistence of human conflicts has little to do with resources and everything to do with ideology, opinions, beliefs and traditions.

The news this week from Afghanistan is that the supreme Taliban leader, Mohammed Omar, has ordered his men to destroy Buddhist statues in the region he controls. These include the tallest standing Buddha in the world, erected in the fifth century AD. "Because God is one God and these statues are there to be worshipped, they must be destroyed," said Mr Omar. He thus reprises the impeccable logic of his namesake, the Caliph, responsible (so legend has it) for burning the great library of Alexandria, saying: "If these books agree with the Koran they are unnecessary, if they disagree with it they are false, so either way they must perish."

Meanwhile, the Christian Dayaks of Indonesia are butchering their Muslim Madurese neighbours. Because the Dayaks were head-hunters before Christian missionaries arrived, and because superstitions never displace each other but only accrete, the Dayaks have been mounting their victims' heads on poles in the traditional way. One can tell Christian from Muslim in Indonesia's conflicts by the colour of the respective headbands they wear: red for one, white for the other, as if murderous zealotry were a football match.

The recent discovery that humans have only twice as many genes as fruit flies has tipped the balance in the nature-nurture debate back to nurture. On this evidence it is our culture, history and belief systems that make us what we are. We look at the rest of nature and see carnivores killing to eat, but we do not see zebras forming armies to wage war on gnus. It is only humans, with their congenital vice of inventing differences of politics and faith, who murder one another because they disagree. What makes the tragedy more poignant is that the less secure their grounds for belief, the more anxious and violent their adherence to it - and the greater their readiness to kill and die in its defence.

webTitle: Delicacy without the tyranny of design

fields.headline: Delicacy without the tyranny of design
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
Herbs and Aromatics

This series began with the proposition that it might be a good idea to look at the kind of garden that could be made, on any site from a balcony upwards, using only 100 packets of seed. I have so far avoided flowers which, although they could well be raised from seed, are much better acquired as plants.

The point is not to make things harder. The point, to recap, is to look at the flower garden at the beginning of the season as if it were a vegetable garden and ask simply: what do I want to grow this year? Forget design for a moment. Design has become a terrible, stupid and expensive tyrant. The emphasis here is all on content. Such a flower garden should have the same beauty as an allotment. It says: this is what I felt like having this year.

If I feel like making myself an omelette fines herbes , I need equal quantities of finely chopped parsley, tarragon, chives and chervil. But where do I get the chervil? It is the slenderest, most delicate and wilting of herbs and I really must grow it if I am to have it. So, for this reason alone, Chervil takes its place as no 51, Anthriscus cerefolium . Cow parsley's kid brother, it will make no great impact on the garden, but the garden is where you need to have it.

Chives (no 28) have already appeared as on this list, as has Dill (no 44). For Tarragon I would purchase a plant. Parsley (no 52) Petroselinum crispum , is of great interest in the flower garden. By parsley, I mean the curly-leaved traditional variety. On the allotment, when it runs to seed, it may seem a nuisance, but when it seeds itself near the kitchen door it is both handy and handsome. That green is beautiful. That leaf is beautiful too.

Another herb you have to grow from seed if you are to have it is Summer Savory (no 53) Satureja hortensis . There is one thing to do with it (apart from various supposed medicinal uses with which I have no patience), but that one thing is excellent: it is served chopped with young broad beans, dressed with olive oil or butter. It is an annual like chervil. Winter Savory, Satureja montana , its perennial cousin, is a nice thing, but not really a substitute.

Sorrel (no 54), Rumex acetosa , you will sometimes see in the shops, but packaged in such mean quantities one wonders what the vendors can possibly have in mind. This is a leaf that, on the slightest contact with heat, dissolves into gunge. A handful, stewed in butter, reduces almost to nothing. This "nothing" fills an omelette, or gets added to a chicken stock for a sorrel soup. For those Jane Grigsonish moments of summer, this is what you need. Again, the only practical way is from seed.

Lovage, Levisticum officinale , comes in at no 55 although you may prefer to buy a small plant. It will stay with you, putting on a good six feet of growth in a year, before dying back. Like many of my favourite garden plants, it is an umbellifer, and it stands happily at the back of the flower border. The leaves are chopped into a salad when young - later in the season they become too tough and strong-tasting. The flavour is like celery. The books say it goes in casseroles or stocks. Take my advice: it will easily overwhelm a stock. Used in a salad, it stands up very well to a strong dressing of anchovy, garlic, lemon and olive oil. One is told to cut the stems back to provide a fresh supply of young leaves. But I like to have one or two salads in early summer, and then enjoy the plant for its gigantism.

What is Borage for? Borago officinalis (no 56) is for distributing small flowers of pure sky blue around the garden. Admittedly, these blue flowers can look pretty in a salad, and there is the whole business of Pimms. But does anybody really grow Borage in order to add a cucumber taste to Pimms, when a slice of cucumber would do the trick just as well? Borage is a really useful and friendly self-seeder, an incomparable addition to the garden's informal look. The white version may be thought to miss the point somewhat, but it too is welcome with us.

The various forms of culinary Sage are normally grown from cuttings, as is Rosemary, although the latter has seeded itself in my paving, and grown well there along with different thymes. This reminds one that a plant such as common Lavender, although easily bought, can be raised in quantity from seed, and that if you wanted a hedge of, for instance, no 57, Lavandula spica (or angustifolia ), "Hidcote Blue", this would be one way of acquiring it.

I take it that Basil is more of a plant for the house, the windowsill, than for a garden in Britain. Even there, one is lucky to achieve anything approaching the herb as it grows in a hot climate. When I bought a bunch of basil from a farmer's market in New York, I was stopped in the street, it was so spectacular: woody at the base, and pungent enough to leave its smell on your hands and clothes. Ocimum basilicum (no 58) is the name: one can but try and try again. Chiltern Seeds list almost 20 varieties.

Two final umbellifers for their garden beauty: Sweet Fennel, Foeniculum vulgare , in its bronze form, is no 59, a plant to smell in the heat of a Mediterranean day. At no 60 is Sweet Cicely, Myrrhis odorata , known once as Cow Chervil, Sweet-Humlock, Sweets or British Myrrh - "very good for old people that are dull and without courage; it rejoiceth and comforteth the heart and increaseth their lust and strength".

 All seeds mentioned may be obtained from Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverstone, Cumbria LA12 7PB. Website: www.chilternseeds.co.uk

Borage is a really useful and friendly self-seeder, an incomparable addition to the garden's informal look. The white version may be thought to miss the point somewhat, but it too is welcome with us. The various forms of culinary Sage are normally grown from cuttings, as is Rosemary, although the latter has seeded itself in my paving, and grown well there along with different thymes. This reminds one that a plant such as common Lavender, although easily bought, can be raised in quantity from seed, and that if you wanted a hedge of, for instance, no 57, Lavandula spica (or angustifolia ), "Hidcote Blue", this would be one way of acquiring it. I take it that Basil is more of a plant for the house, the windowsill, than for a garden in Britain. Even there, one is lucky to achieve anything approaching the herb as it grows in a hot climate. When I bought a bunch of basil from a farmer's market in New York, I was stopped in the street, it was so spectacular: woody at the base, and pungent enough to leave its smell on your hands and clothes. Ocimum basilicum (no 58) is the name: one can but try and try again. Chiltern Seeds list almost 20 varieties. Two final umbellifers for their garden beauty: Sweet Fennel, Foeniculum vulgare , in its bronze form, is no 59, a plant to smell in the heat of a Mediterranean day. At no 60 is Sweet Cicely, Myrrhis odorata , known once as Cow Chervil, Sweet-Humlock, Sweets or British Myrrh - "very good for old people that are dull and without courage; it rejoiceth and comforteth the heart and increaseth their lust and strength".  All seeds mentioned may be obtained from Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverstone, Cumbria LA12 7PB. fields.headline: Bergman? Dodgy bowels, you know
fields.standfirst: Kenneth Rive, the man who taught Britain to love European cinema, tells Steve Rose about his brushes with the great directors
fields.trailText: Kenneth Rive, the man who taught Britain to love European cinema, tells Steve Rose about his brushes with the great directors
fields.body:
For British followers of European cinema, Kenneth Rive is a name etched on the subconscious. Though few would be able to put a face to it, they have probably seen it, followed by the word "presents", in front of innumerable foreign films since the late 1950s - predominantly French movies but also those of Ingmar Bergman, Luis Bunuel, Federico Fellini and Akira Kurosawa. As founder of Gala Film Distributors, Rive is one of the most influential figures in British cinema. Now in his 80s, Rive introduced many of these directors to British audiences and counted many of them as friends. Closest to Rive was François Truffaut, four of whose films he is re-issuing this week.

A signed photo of a smiling Truffaut has pride of place amid the tarnished Baftas, framed awards and elegant stationery in Rive's decidedly low-tech office in Islington, and Rive speaks of the man and his films with a mixture of adoration and pride. "Oh, he was a very dear friend," says Rive. "My beginnings as a distributor were really picking up him and the rest of the nouvelle vague. I handled all his films except two. Even the ones I didn't like."

Rive met Truffaut just after the shooting of his feature debut, The 400 Blows. "I saw a rough cut and it made a deep impression on me. It was the sort of film you don't walk out on. At the end you waited for the credits and you sat there for another 10 minutes, and then you got up." Rive snapped up distribution rights to the film, which went on to win Truffaut the best director award at Cannes in 1959 and became a landmark film of its era.

Truffaut was renowned for his contempt for "impecunious middlemen", but Rive was obviously spared this. He witnessed the director's more controversial activities, such as Truffaut's closing down of the Cannes film festival in 1968 (he was part of the protest that led to the setting up of directors fortnight at Cannes). But whatever confrontations they may have had are long forgotten. "People tend to think he was dark in his personality but... how can I describe him? He always looked to me as if he was enjoying life. When I first met him, he was really struggling, he was always short of money. He invited me up to his apartment round the corner from the Champs Elysées for a snack. It was a tiny little place, didn't even have a bathroom. But it had a terrace on top where he used to sit. You could look across and see the Eiffel Tower. I think it used to inspire him."

Their friendship blossomed with their careers. Truffaut's next film, Shoot the Pianist, performed only moderately; but 1961's Jules et Jim was a great success, playing in London for more than a year. At the same time, an unprecedented number of European film-makers were coming on to the scene, and Gala took on most of them: Alain Resnais, Claude Lelouch, Claude Chabrol, Eric Rohmer and Marcel Pagnol. And, beyond France, Fellini's La Dolce Vita and 8 1/2, Vittorio De Sica's Two Women - which introduced Sophia Loren to this country - and the entire catalogue of Ingmar Bergman.

Since many of these directors' films ran into trouble with British censors, Rive met a lot of them. "I was very proud to have met Jean Cocteau when we were having trouble with a release of Les Enfants Terribles. I went to see him in Paris and when I got there I thought I had the wrong address. It was a dirty old staircase, there was a pram in the hall, and the smell of cats was overpowering. When I got to the top, there he was with Jean Marais, both of them with cats on their shoulders and cats running around everywhere. He had some skin infection he'd picked up from them. He was very persuasive but wildly eccentric.

"Bergman was always difficult too. He refused to make any cuts to his films. Tremendously talented guy, but always peculiar. He always said he'd come to the premiere of his films but he never did. At the last minute he'd always disappear. He had terrible trouble with his bowels, though - perhaps that's why. He was always being taken short somewhere."

Rive's purchases seem prescient in hindsight, but, he confesses, it was less a matter of strategy than a combination of good timing and lack of choice. The son of a cameraman, he had grown up with cinema. As a child star in the 1920s, he appeared in high-profile German films such as William Dieterle's Behind the Altar, and Rasputin, starring Conrad Veidt. After the war, he became a projectionist at a "fleapit" in Tottenham Court Road, which he later bought. As an aspiring film exhibitor in the 1950s, there were few alternatives to such a move, he says, since the circuit for British and American films was a virtual duopoly between ABC and Rank Corporation. The only other option was the foreign market, which was also dominated by other distributors. "So where could I start? I thought: 'Nobody's showing any Soviet films, and they must have a market somewhere.' So I popped along to their embassy and I spoke to an attaché and he asked if I wanted to go to Russia. So off I went." Rive came back from Moscow with three films (including a Russian ballet film called Gala Festival, from which the company took its name), plus a five-year contract for the exclusive distribution of Russian films.

This success enabled Rive to expand his cinema chain along with the distribution side, giving Gala the clout to bid for those other European classics. "British cinema? It didn't exist. They made crap movies really. So did the Americans, apart from the big blockbusters, and that's why we survived so well in those days. People wanted to see something a bit more intelligent. There was some cachet to subtitled films. If you hadn't seen the last Truffaut, you hadn't lived. But America and Britain started to make some very good movies again, more art films, and that was it. People got fed up with subtitles."

Gala has still had successes since the 1960s, such as Claude Berri's Jean de Florette and Manon des Sources, Truffaut's The Last Metro, Kieslowski's Short Films About Killing and Love, and Erick Zonca's The Dream Life of Angels. But the golden age is over. Today, multiplexes, a dwindling art-house circuit, higher overheads and shorter cinema runs have made life hard for distributors of foreign films. And when a popular foreign film does come along, the independents are often outgunned by American companies. "If I'd had the money, I'd have snapped up Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," Rive says. "But we're just not big enough. We were in negotiations, but in the end it was too expensive. Columbia was big enough to take it on, and voila! - today's top foreign film in the UK."

Of course, with so many classics in Gala's back catalogue, Rive's future is by no means bleak. "I'm a great believer in DVD," he says. "There'll always be the first run in the big cities, but for the wider audience DVD and video are the only way they're going to get to see these films. But one way or another, people will always want to see them."

 The Truffaut tribute is at the Curzon Soho, London W1 (020-7734 2255), today and tomorrow.

webTitle: If you want to get ahead, get a herbaceous border

fields.headline: If you want to get ahead, get a herbaceous border
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Virginia Woolf, we can assume, wasn't much of a housewife. What with writing about lighthouses, trips to South America and transgender aristocrats named after bits of Florida, she can't have had much time to zip round the house with a Dustbuster, or the Edwardian equivalent thereof. And that's not even counting all her time- consuming moping around after Vita Sackville-West. I bet you could have written your name - or a novel about identity, language and phalluses - in the dust on her mantelpiece. One suspects she even got a woman in to sweep that room of her own.

A stranger to Vim, Virginia lamented the rise of the housewife managing tolerably in suburbia. As The Middle Classes: Their Rise and Sprawl (BBC2) showed, she was just one of those upper-class folks who fretted over the growth of the middle class between the wars. The middle class, ensconced in the newly created suburbs and entrenched in domesticity, were to be scorned for their lack of adventure, romance and possibility. This from a woman who threw herself into a river with stones in her cardigan pockets.

As this charming, if not compelling, documentary explained, the new middle class were meanwhile distancing themselves from their roots, some building walls to separate their nice streets from those lined with council houses. With their herbaceous borders and bay windows, they clearly wanted to forget that they were working class people made good.

It's hard to tell which skirmishes in the class war were worse - upper versus middle or middle versus working. Everyone asserted their identity with negatives: "I am what I am not" and all that. The Middle Classes thoroughly explored the evolution and the anatomy of its subject. It charted prime minister Stanley Baldwin's attempts to give people enough that they would support the status quo, a trick copied by Tory governments ever since. It eloquently told the stories of those on all sides of the class divides and even suggested, albeit half-heartedly, that the suburbs weren't wholly conservative places.

For all that, The Middle Classes couldn't quite overcome its dry subject matter. Maybe Virginia was right after all - about the middle class's lack of adventure, not the stones in the pockets while swimming. That's just suicidal.

Exposing the nastiness in suburbia in an altogether more mythic way, Buffy the Vampire Slayer (Sky One) had to deal with a slithering alien demon that attacked mentally ill people. No, not Ann Widdecombe (she just does asylum seekers) but a Quellor, so called because it quells things. In a week when The X-Files told what could have been a Buffy story - individuals stalked by incarnations of their own worst fears - so Buffy told what could have been an X-File. Interesting crossover or derivative sci-fi shows running out of ideas? I have no idea. Whatever, I like it.

Adrian Mole - The Cappuccino Years (BBC1) continues interminably. The only surprise is that the writing becomes even more cliched with every passing week. Pray to God there isn't another instalment in the offing. Adrian Mole - The Steradent Years would be enough to drive anyone to voluntary euthanasia. On themselves.

fields.headline: Busted in New York
fields.standfirst: A night-time walk and an illicit smoke on the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave Darryl Pinckney a bitter taste of Mayor Giuliani's zero tolerance
fields.trailText: A night-time walk and an illicit smoke on the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave Darryl Pinckney a bitter taste of Mayor Giuliani's zero tolerance
fields.body:
How long had it been since I'd been out late on the Lower East Side? Back in the New Wave Bohemian days of the late 1970s and early 80s, the Lower East Side was the capital of mischief. The low life was still literary. I could be persuaded to go anywhere in search of an authentic urban experience. But then my friends grew up, and I moved far away, as Europe seemed to me at the time. Because I don' t drink and run wild any more, because I now live down a dirt track in the English countryside, a Manhattan roomful of the young and the smooth can be intimidating.

But the reggae club the summer before last was known as a chill lounge. Rona let her hair hang over the beat. We were waiting for Billie. I was telling myself not to have a hard time waiting. I was looking forward to my session with that inner-child finder, marijuana. The reggae swelled around me. My head bobbed like a duck's when there's bread on the water. I saw what looked like a ballet dancer's leg. Billie, and a Billie who knew the score. Her opening drink would not take long. We were going to step outside. We couldn't smoke pot in this reggae club. Not even in a reggae club? That's how long it had been since I'd been out late on the Lower East Side.

Street lamps threw a spotlight over pedestrians crossing Second Avenue. Killer taxis left unpleasant gusts. I leaned into the summer heat. Soon we three were alone in the dark of Sixth Street. Rona checked behind her. Then, like backup singers on the downbeat, Billie and I snapped glances over our right shoulders. Maybe some people wouldn't have bothered, but we were pros. We were veterans of the streets. Rona fired one up, and we passed it. We were chatting. I hogged it. We were drifting towards midnight. Billie handed it back to Rona. Three shapes in front of a doorway decided to heckle us: "You're having a good time." They sounded like unappetising old kids. We moved to the curb. "We know what you're doing."

Rona pushed her hand against the air to let them know that the joke, whatever it was, had to stop. "Smoke it." We shook our heads at their being so boisterous when they were maybe getting high themselves, and in a doorway, of all places. We should have looked ahead instead of behind.

We saw the corner and we saw the big man in the white-guy plaid shorts cutting a pigeon-toed diagonal from across the street. Everything about him was aimed towards us. His bright white sneakers continued to rise and fall in our direction. A huge meat-packing arm was held out to us, and a big voice was coming at us, too. His other arm came out of his undershirt with a square of ID. We had to keep moving toward him, like something swirling down a drain. There now seemed to be enough light for a film crew's night shoot. How could we have missed the blue unmarked van parked on the other side of Sixth Street?

"Been smoking something?" No answer. "Put your hands flat on the trunk of this car." The women, my friends, were side by side at the back of the car. I was on the sidewalk and had to bend over. Other undercovers quickly appeared. "We're going to empty your pockets." A woman had taken up position behind Rona and Billie. I felt a hand go into my pocket. My total financial assets held by a faded money clip hit the trunk of the car. "Did you all just meet tonight?" a new voice demanded. "No." My own voice was thin and completely lacking in the authority of outrage. The money clip was followed by a pack of menthol cigarettes, a disposable lighter, a case containing reading glasses, a John Coltrane/Johnny Hartman CD - "You listen to some good music," a head of hair said - and a mobile phone. "Where's your beeper?" He patted me down. "You got a beeper?" "No," came the thin reply.

The detectives murmured. They'd found the smallest stub of weed in a matchbox in Rona's pocket. The woman detective left. The detective with the hair asked the ladies to step over to the sidewalk. Where Plaid Shorts had, like me, the beginnings of his father's stomach, this one had pecs and biceps rolling out of a magenta tank top. He looked like a television actor in the role of maverick cop. The rest of him was in the suburban version of casual: crisp bluejeans and clean sneakers.

"So you guys just met tonight?" Tank Top asked. It was my turn. He was going to compare answers. Plaid Shorts said he was going over to the van to check something. "How do you know each other?" Tank Top demanded. "School." If he identified us as middle class, wouldn't he have to watch himself? Maybe I was trying to prick some white blue-collar resentment, anything to turn the tables a little.

When he asked about my bleeper, I thought maybe he hoped he'd interrupted something good, criminally speaking, such as a black dude giving two white chicks a taste of the street herb they were about to buy or get ripped off for. But if he saw that we were OK, then the paperwork on the citation that they give out in these cases would speed up. One black guy with gray in his beard and one and a half white girls, not two, because by that time they must have figured out that Billie's honey skin and the Asian cast to her eyes and her Church of England accent were some weird Caribbean story. Yes, officer, I wanted to explain, the one with the henna highlights is a famous Jewish scientist, the daughter of the British Commonwealth is a banker, and I'm a black guy who needs two pairs of glasses and won't be on your computer lists, not even a credit rating.

Billie and Rona had shown no emotion until Plaid Shorts brought the handcuffs. Then they gave out soft, pastel exclamations. Plaid Shorts led them, affronted and vulnerable, across the street to the side door of the van. I thought, Rona's daughter walks just like her. I felt my watch being removed. Tank Top put my arms behind me and pushed my hands high up my back. I felt the metal around my wrists. I thought of my parents and how they would hurl themselves into this if they found out. I felt and heard the handcuffs lock.

I thought of my parents and their lawsuits. Back in the good old days, they'd sued our hometown police department to force it to desegregate, and when that worked they sued the fire department - things they did in their spare time, as good citizens, as blacks of their generation, members of the NAACP rank and file. Injustice had only to ring their doorbell and they were off to the poorhouse. And there was frivolous me, letting a white man put me in handcuffs for something other than protest. I remembered what my father had said to my tears at my sister's memorial, the year before: "Keep it together."

But I was in shock. "I'm going to be sick." I was starting to list from side to side. "Have you been drinking?" "No." I was going deaf. "I'm going to pass out." Tank Top gripped me just below the right armpit and we started off. But my feet waited before they followed my legs. The world broke into silent, colourful particles. I got to the door and fell flat into the van. Rona's face floated. I began to hear her. I concentrated on finding her face in one place, something I could get up for and move toward, even if only on my knees. "Don't hurt him," Rona and Billie called. "I'm trying to help him," Tank Top countered.

Keep it together, I chanted to myself. Not because I was a black man in handcuffs in front of two white guys; not because I was powerless, which made it all the more necessary at least to imitate the examples of dignity in confrontations with the police which I'd witnessed; and not because I was a grown man losing it in front of two women who, though in handcuffs, were trying to defend me. But because they were my friends. They were the ones with children at home. I crawled over to my friends in the seatless, windowless rear of the van, dripping sweat on them.

Plaid Shorts yanked the van into the street. Because we couldn't grab, and there was nothing to grab on to, we rolled into Alice-down-the-rabbit-hole positions and rolled again when Plaid Shorts hit the gas. "This is such bullshit," Billie said to the ceiling. "This sucks," Plaid Shorts said, but he wasn't talking to us. He looked across at Tank Top. "You got that right." "A big one," Plaid Shorts added. "Hate it," Tank Top said to his window. "Total bullshit." Rona had dusted off her repertoire of apt facial expressions. This one said, "Are these guys for real?" "Five years, man and I'm out," Plaid Shorts said. "I just can't wait to do my band." He did a near wheelie around a corner. We shouldered back up into sitting positions pretty expertly after two corners. Tank Top took some gum from the dashboard and said he had to keep at this bullshit until he could pay off his wife. He told Plaid Shorts that instead of alimony he was offering his wife a once-in-a-lifetime, can't-refuse lump sum. "It's like a buyout."

The acid-driven power chords of Pink Floyd took over the van. Rona's expression said, "These guys are too much." "They're wild," Billie's eyes said back as she looked for the place behind her where the music was blaring from. Maybe the detectives were trying to tell us something. Not that they were nice guys who regrettably had to do their job but that they were better than the job they'd been reduced to doing, and that they too had aspirations. The Rolling Stones came on next, and Plaid Shorts sang along. The music was perhaps meant to say that they weren't uncool, redneck cops having a blast at the expense of the liberal, the black, and the in-between.

The van door slid open, and in the shaft of light Tank Top was helping a Hispanic woman, maybe in her 50s, climb aboard the bummer bus. "Hey, officer," she said when we were under way. Then he turned off the lights, slammed the door, and left me with this woman who made unsavoury sounds in the dark. I thought she was trying to ditch her vials of crack and the detectives would then claim they were mine. I went over on my side, practising the I-was-asleep defence. They put Rona and Billie back in the van, turned on the lights, drove off, stopped again, and got out by themselves.
