"Dalgliesh is probably the most intelligent officer in modern detective fiction," says Ruth Rendell, author of the Inspector Wexford novels and James's closest rival. "He is the sort of person readers like to think the police might be like - sensitive and elegant, not elitist like Dorothy L Sayers's Peter Wimsey. He is the sort of person you wouldn't mind being interviewed by." None the less, accusations of elitism have occasionally arisen. During a radio interview five years ago, James attempted to explain how contrast is at the root of good crime writing by arguing that middle-class murderers make better characters, because the contrast between their ugly deeds and their urbane environment has a more dramatic effect. This was seized on, in some quarters of the crime-writing world, as covert advancement of the theory that the middle classes are more capable of making moral choices than the lower. One of the critical voices was Mark Timlin, creator of the fictional detective Nick Sharman, who, as a drug using, university drop out, is as far from Dalgliesh as the dimensions of the genre will allow. "Phyllis is talking a lot of nonsense," he said in an interview at the time. He said that James's criminals were far removed from "the reality on the streets of south London" and rounded on the Crime Writers Association as "snobbish and stuffy" thanks largely to her and those like her. Rendell leaps immediately to James's defence. "She writes about all sections of the community - you don't have to be upper class to feature in her books." And this is true, although James's original premise ensures that her novels tend to be set in colleges and hospitals - environments in which most of the characters are highly educated. "But she writes intelligently about crime," says Fyfield. "She was one of the first detective writers to put pain into crime fiction - compassion, real suffering." There is no emotional squeamishness in James's fiction. Death In Holy Orders is set in a theological college, and James doesn't flinch from dumping a body in the church or tackling, alongside the momentous occasion of Dalgliesh's first flirtation, mental illness, suicide and a gambit of ugly human emotions. Neither is she a prude. The novel includes sympathetic portrayals of an incestuous couple and, more controversially, a priest with a conviction for child abuse. "For a detective story," she insists, "the contrast between respectability and planned brutality is of the essence. I think contrast does intensify horror. If you have appalling and violent events happening in a civilised place, it's a great deal more horrific. I think it was WH Auden who said: 'The single body on the drawing-room floor is more horrific than the bullet-riddled body on Raymond Chandler's mean streets'. And Auden felt that very strongly - that you want a contrast between order and hierarchy and apparent goodness and the horror of the deed." There is a difference, says James, between the public's interest in real-life crimes and the popularity of the detective fiction genre. "With the detective story there is horror - I think one needs to make the murder realistic. But I think the main attraction isn't the horror, it's the puzzle, the bringing of order out of disorder." She is intensely interested in and repelled by violence, and has confessed to a disproportionate fear of intruders. "I don't agree with Ruth Rendell that motivation is more interesting than the act of murder. The physical act of killing a human being has an awesome and horrible fascination. All that flesh to dispose of, all that blood to be washed away, so many lies to be told." Which, for PD James, is where the story begins. Phyllis James encountered no physical violence during her childhood, but there was enough emotional disturbance to leave her with the impression that the world was an unreliable place. She was born in Oxford in 1920, the eldest of three children each born 18 months apart. Her father Sidney was an Inland Revenue official and remote from his children. Her mother Dorothy suffered from a mental illness that might be treatable at home today, but in the 30s confined her to hospital. James says: "In one sense, I was very lucky - I've always felt at home in the world. But yes, I did feel that in some ways it was a frightening place and those two things don't seem very easy to reconcile. I was a child of a not very happy marriage and therefore I think it was a childhood of some apprehension, living in a sense with fear, that things might erupt, that things might go wrong." Her mother's illness, she says quietly, ensured that she grew up prematurely. The insecurity is apparent still in James's lingering fear of violence, and more obscurely in her dislike of the distorting effects of great pressure. She will not accept money in advance of writing, since the burden of having to earn it back - even at this advanced stage in her reputation - will, she says, interfere with getting the job done. "Suppose I took a huge advance for the next two books?" she has said. "Will they be any good? Will the publishers like them? Will they wish they hadn't given me that huge amount?" For years after becoming a published author she continued to work full-time for the Home Office and to insist that she was not a "professional" writer. Writing was never something she did under duress, but because she chose to. It was clear from the beginning, however, that writing was one of the few constants in her choppy existence. Her happiest childhood memories are of books. "I read from a very early age. My mother used to buy us comics every week: the Rainbow and one called Tiger Tim. She read them to us when we were three or four. And then, one day, I suddenly discovered I could read it. I was probably helped by the pictures. But I remember that moment of thinking, I don't have to wait for her! I can read it myself!" It was a moment paralleled 40 years later when she heard that her first novel had been accepted by Faber. "It was certainly one of the great moments of my life," she says. "I remember dancing for joy." Her education was short: she left school at 16, armed with a thorough knowledge of Shakespeare and the Bible, which for the purposes of becoming a writer she found quite adequate. She is scandalised that today's school curriculum pays such scant attention to the Bible. "This is so much part of our history and our literature that one would suppose that the King James Bible would be a set book. One was brought up listening to some of the most wonderful English prose. The cadences stayed with me. It's amazing that we can so neglect it." In retrospect, James thinks that had the money had been available, she would have liked to go to university and become a barrister. As for the police force, she would have found the administration irksome, but reckons she has a talent for sniffing out the truth. "I imagine, without being conceited, that I would have been a good detective for two reasons: people do tend to tell me things, quite astonishing things sometimes, often on quite short acquaintance. And I do seem to have an idea when people are lying." In the end, however, the career she took up fed as much into her writing as she would have got from anywhere (the nursing demonstration with the tube was used to dispatch a character in her fourth book, Shroud For A Nightingale). In 1949, James moved to London and joined the NHS, where she was responsible for the administration of psychiatric outpatients (details were used in a Mind To Murder, 1963). She stayed in the civil service for 30 years, accruing enough qualifications to enter the Home Office in 1968 and work first as an administrator for the forensic science service (Death Of An Expert Witness, 1977), and then in the criminal law department. "I couldn't bear not to be a success at the job. I am ambitious. Inevitably, I qualified myself for promotion. Whether it's a matter of personal pride, if I'm doing it, I want to succeed at it." Knowing of her desire to write, her mother suggested she turn the experiences of her first job into "a cheerful book about all these lovely people in hospital, where a nice nurse falls in love with a lovely doctor". James suspects that her mother always knew that "within the first chapter there'd be a dead body in the sluice room and the nice nurse would probably have done it". Through her 20s and early 30s, James waited for a convenient moment to begin her writing career, but none came. Her life at home in London was not easy. Connor Bantry White was an Anglo-Irish doctor whom she had married at 21, after meeting him at the Festival Theatre in Cambridge. They had three happy years together before he went off to war with the Royal Army Medical Corps and returned with his mental health broken. Their two daughters, Clare and Jane, who went on to become a midwife and a teacher, were largely cared for by James's parents-in-law at their home in Ilford, Essex. Connor White was admitted to hospital for psychiatric treatment, where he adopted the name Ted and played eccentric games of football with the other patients. It was not unknown for the goalkeeper, distracted by voices in his head, to stand immobile while the ball shot past into the net. "One suffers with the patient and for oneself," writes James of her husband's illness, in her autobiography. "Another human being who was once a beloved companion can become not only a stranger, but occasionally a malevolent stranger." After years in and out of psychiatric hospitals, Connor died at home in 1964, aged 44. During this time, it occurred to James that a convenient moment to start her writing career would never present itself and that if she didn't hurry, she would wind up "unfulfilled as a human being". At 35, she began her early morning regime. Detective fiction was an obvious choice, since it reflected her own interests and, she thought, had a good chance of being published. "It's a kind of instinct, really," she says. "I read a lot of classical detective stories when I was a girl, it was my light reading. So to an extent it seemed to come about naturally. The novel is a way in which the writer's own enthusiasms, interests, compulsions, maybe even neuroses, are rearranged in a form that he or she hopes will be compelling and attractive to the reader." There were two principles on which James was immoveable: that the intricacy of a plot could never make up for poor writing ("I find with my own reading, that it doesn't matter how exciting a book is: if it's badly written one just can't be bothered with it."); and that an author must always write with the reader in mind, and not the publisher or the book market. James talks about this with a sort of belligerent modesty. "At the end of a book, I want to feel, well that's as good as I can do - not as good, perhaps, as other people can do - but it's as good as I can do. There are thousands of people who do like, for their recreational reading, a classical detective story, and I think they are entitled to have one which is also a good novel and well written. Those are the people I write for.. They don't want me to adapt to what I think is the popular market. They want a good novel, honestly written and I think they are jolly well entitled to it." "Some modern detective fiction can be very didactic, used as a vehicle for a lecture," says Joan Smith. "But James never does that to her readers. The story comes first." After experimenting with Phyllis James and Phyllis D James, PD James was chosen because she thought it would look enigmatic on a book spine. It didn't occur to her that she would be mistaken for a male author, and when someone pointed it out, she did not see it as a particular advantage. It is rare, she believes, for readers to reject a book because they dislike the sex of the author, especially in crime fiction. Before writing, she constructed a chart to keep track of who was doing what, where and with whom, planning and structure which took a whole year. After five years of early mornings, she sent an agent Cover Her Face, a detective story in which Adam Dalgliesh investigates the murder of Sally Jupp, a parlourmaid found dead in mysterious circumstances on the day after the church fete. James finds the book dated now, confined to the cosy, domestic setting of an English village in the shadow of its Elizabethan manor, that puts it very much in the Agatha Christie mould. In the 40 years since, her novels have had to keep pace with great advancements in modern policing. DNA testing has caused her some trouble, since it leaves no room for doubt and could solve a crime in the first chapter. In Death In Holy Orders it is introduced to the storyline only at the last minute, after more traditional policing has been exhausted. The book also contains references to the Macpherson report into racism and the latest policing methods. It is important to her to remain contemporary. Cover her Face was a critical success, but it was the Black Tower (1975), in which Adam Dalgliesh, grown disillusioned with the force, investigates the death of a friend at a care home in Dorset, which Kingsley Amis called "almost Iris Murdoch with murder in it". Financially, the breakthrough was Innocent Blood (1980), one of the few novels not to feature Dalgliesh, in which an adopted 18-year-old girl discovers the identity of her murderous true parents. The paperback rights went for £380,000, the film rights for £145,000, which was more than she had earned in 10 years at the Home Office. She retired happily. "I started out as more of a cult writer. The one that broke through here was Shroud For A Nightingale. Then the huge international bestseller was Innocent Blood. At the beginning of the week I was relatively poor and at the end of the week I wasn't." Did they make an enormous fuss of her at the Home Office? James laughs. "No dear, the Home Office doesn't make a fuss. Just occasionally people would come up at Christmas and say 'We want to give the Home Secretary one of your books, would you mind signing it?' Otherwise, no. I was Mrs White there, you see. They knew I was a writer, but there was a general feeling that you don't encourage people in hubris. It was very funny really." It was while writing the opening scenes of Devices And Desires, her 12th book, that James had the most powerful sense of her own duality, of being someone who both experienced things and stood aside and watched them, a self-consciousness that she believes might only be lost during extreme agony or the death of a loved one. It is the closest she comes to delineating the process of her writing: "A girl is on a lonely road and begins to remember that there's a psychopathic serial murderer loose. And we know she's going to be killed, because the book opens with a reference to her as the fifth victim. It's a terrifying opening. Now when I was writing it, I was, of course, that girl. But with another part of my mind I was thinking, well, I wonder if I ought to have a moon, or whether that's going a bit far? What have we got on each side of the road? We must have lots of bushes so you can feel that people might be lurking. And I think I'll have a car coming past, because that will seem reassuring, but obviously it goes past at speed and there's no help there. "You think, how do I increase the menace? You feel the emotion of the girl and at the same time wonder how best it can be conveyed." James does not know if there is another book in her. She always waits for an idea to possess her, usually inspired by a particular location. Her great regret is that she didn't start writing sooner, although if Death In Holy Orders turns out to be her last book, she won't complain. With the promise of a relationship between Dalgliesh and Emma Lavenham, a Cambridge academic, hanging in the air, however, she is pretty sure there is another one coming. "I want it to be quite subtle; I don't want to have buttocks heaving everywhere. They are both private people." If another book doesn't arrive, she has plenty to occupy her. Afternoon indolence not withstanding, there is a briskness to PD James that shows itself in her enthusiasm for public duty: she has served as a governor of the BBC, a board member of the British Council and is president of the Society of Authors. In 1991 she was created a Tory life peer, Baroness James of Holland Park. The pick-your-ideas up, anti-dogma of old-style Conservatism has always appealed and she is a regular guest speaker at local party level. She has told her daughters that in the event of a debilitating illness, she doesn't want to linger but would prefer to be "put out of my misery". In April, she flies to Texas for a book tour. "It has been a very busy life," she says, with a touch of defiance. "But a busy life by compulsion." Life at a glance Phyllis Dorothy White, Baroness James of Holland Park Born: August 3 1920, Oxford. Education: Cambridge Girls High School. Married: 1941 Connor Bantry White, died 1964 (two daughters Jane, Clare). Career: Administrator, NHS 1949- 68; Principal, Home Office police dept 68-72; criminal policy dept 72-79. Publications: Cover Her Face 62; A Mind To Murder 63; Unnatural Causes 67; Shroud For A Nightingale 71; The Maul And The Pear Tree (with TA Critchley) 71; An Unsuitable Job For A Woman 72; The Black Tower 75; Death Of An Expert Witness 77; Innocent Blood 80; The Skull Beneath The Skin 82; A Taste For Death 86; Devices And Desires 89; The Children Of Men 92; Original Sin 94; A Certain Justice 97; Time To Be In Earnest (autobiography) 99. Honours: Life peer 1991.  Death In Holy Orders is published by Faber and Faber (£17.99) on Monday March

fields.headline: Beavering about
fields.standfirst: There are plans to reintroduce the European beaver to Scotland, which looks very like its Canadian cousin but has a nicer character
fields.trailText: There are plans to reintroduce the European beaver to Scotland, which looks very like its Canadian cousin but has a nicer character
fields.body:
I would like to start by apologising to Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH) for saying last week that it is planning to introduce the Canadian beaver into Scotland. It is not.

It is hoping instead, by the end of the year, to reintroduce the European beaver, which looks very like its Canadian cousin but has a nicer character. The European beaver was wiped out in Britain more than 400 years ago, but survives in other parts of Europe. It is important to SNH that we understand that it is not proposing to bring in Canadian beavers, which are familiar to viewers of wildlife programmes as destructive animals that kill large trees and mess up rivers with their dams. European beavers prefer the bark of small trees, and don't much like building dams. SNH would have us regard them as useful foresters and "river engineers" that create wet woodland habitats where insects thrive and provide food for birds and fish.

All its efforts to promote the reputation of these proposed immigrants as well-meaning, useful and fundamentally British animals will have been in vain if it gets around, falsely, that they are actually not European but uncivilised brutes from Canada. And in that circumstance, SNH would suffer damage to its own reputation as a caring, responsible organisation. It assures me that it has no intention of reintroducing other more alarming species of animal that were once indigenous to Scotland, such as wolves or wild boar.

Just such a kindly, philanthropic image is now sought by virtually every organisation in the world, especially by companies whose only real purpose is the pursuit of profit. Take the recent announcement that Coca-Cola is paying £95m to become "the sole global marketing partner" with Warner Bros of the forthcoming film, Harry Potter And The Sorcerer's Stone. There will be joint promotions of Harry Potter and Coca-Cola in supermarkets, and specially decorated Coca-Cola cans to emphasise the connection.

The great Atlanta corporation clearly hopes to reap financial benefits from Harry Potter's worldwide popularity. But its press release didn't mention this aspect of the deal. Coca-Cola was joining forces with Warner Bros, it said, "to celebrate and promote the magic power of reading". Its efforts would "centre on helping people discover the magical world of their imaginations through reading, while reinforcing the core values and attributes shared by Harry Potter and Coca-Cola". It didn't say how Coca-Cola intended to promote reading, but it will doubtless do it somehow. I wouldn't be surprised if this is at JK Rowling's insistence, for she was directly involved in the negotiations.

There followed in the press release an uplifting quotation from Jan Hall, described as senior vice- president consumer marketing, Coca-Cola North America. "Coca-Cola celebrates and embraces the ideals promoted through the stories of Harry Potter - friendship, love, self-reliance, the importance of the family, the magic of shared experiences, and the value of diversity," she said, sounding like a New Labour manifesto. I can see that Coca-Cola, engaged as it is in ferocious competition with Pepsi and other soft drinks manufacturers, might find difficulty in claiming those ideals without a bit of help from the young wizard.

Hall is clearly a wonderful, high-minded woman, but hardly more wonderful than the people who work for IBM. "IBM and its employees around the world find the atrocities committed by the Nazi regime abhorrent and categorically condemn any actions which aided their unspeakable acts," it said in a press release last month. This is an astonishing statement since, as the journalist Michael Kinsley points out in the Washington Post, nobody ever suggested that IBM was in favour of the Holocaust even at the time, let alone now. Kinsley also doubts that the corporation consulted all 307,400 of its employees on the matter: "Did it interview each one of them? Not one closet Nazi-phile in the bunch? None even who find Nazis 'disgusting' but not quite 'abhorrent'?"

The press release was issued in response to a current lawsuit asking IBM to pay profits, plus interest, made from its dealings with Nazi Germany in the 30s. This lawsuit results from a new book about the Nazis'uses of Hollerith tabulating machines - named after Herman Hollerith, the American statistician who invented punch cards - which were then available in Germany through an IBM subsidiary company. Even the book doesn't suggest that IBM loved the Nazis.

So why this overblown insistence that IBM and all its workers "abhor" Nazis? Kinsley's explanation for this kind of thing is: "It's good for business for a company to look like it cares about more than just what's good for business. The puzzle is that if people came to believe this, it would no longer be true. The business justification for corporate high-mindedness depends on the perception that there is no business justification." They tried to persuade us during the Thatcher era that greed was good, but they clearly failed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ransom paid | Kohl deal agreed | Estrada loses | Dietrich sale
fields.body:
Ransom paid

Seven abducted oil workers were released after their employers reportedly threw a £9m ransom to their captors from a helicopter in a remote region between Ecuador and Colombia. The four Americans, New Zealander, Chilean and Argentine were snatched last October.
Alex Bellos

Kohl deal agreed

A German court yesterday approved a deal allowing the former chancellor Helmut Kohl to pay a fine and avoid criminal charges in the Christian Democrat party's financing scandal. Mr Kohl must pay 300,000 marks (£94,000).
AP, Berlin

Estrada loses

The Philippine supreme court affirmed the legitimacy of the rule of Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo yesterday, clearing the way for the prosecution of the former leader, Joseph Estrada, on charges of bribery, corruption and economic plunder.
Reuters, Manila

Dietrich sale

Love letters written by Hollywood star Marlene Dietrich to a baker in the 1920s have been found in an attic in Hanover, western Germany, and are to be auctioned later this month, a spokesman at a Hanover auction house said yesterday.
AFP, Hanover

webTitle: French court strikes blow against fugitive Nazi

fields.headline: French court strikes blow against fugitive Nazi
fields.standfirst:
Brunner convicted in absentia for deporting children to death camps

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: A Paris court yesterday sentenced in absentia Alois Brunner - Adolf Eichmann's right-hand man and the world's highest-ranking Nazi fugitive believed still alive - to life imprisonment for sending hundreds of Jewish children to their deaths at Auschwitz.
fields.body:
A Paris court yesterday sentenced in absentia Alois Brunner - Adolf Eichmann's right-hand man and the world's highest-ranking Nazi fugitive believed still alive - to life imprisonment for sending hundreds of Jewish children to their deaths at Auschwitz.

"Life imprisonment is too good for him," said Henri Zajdenwerger, 73, who lost 14 members of his family to Brunner's SS henchmen during the war and was among dozens of protesters outside the courthouse yesterday. "But in reality he has never paid for his crimes, and he never will."

In all, Brunner, who fled to Syria after the war and is now 88 if he is still alive, is held responsible for sending some 140,000 European Jews to the gas chambers. Nearly 24,000 of them were deported from the notorious Drancy transit camp outside Paris, where Brunner was commandant from June 1943 to August 1944.

The former Gestapo officer was sentenced to death twice in his absence in the 1950s, but had never been charged with the specific crime addressed in yesterday's hearing - the arrest and deportation of 345 orphans from the Paris region.

Aged between 15 days and 18 years old, the children were packed into cattle trains and shipped off to Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen death camps in August 1944, just weeks before the Allies liberated Paris. Only 61 survived.

"Alois Brunner must be considered the true organiser of the deportation of Jews from France between June 1943 and August 1944," said the investigating magistrate Hervé Stephan, who presented the case to the court. "These final arrests sprang from a desire to deport and to exterminate the very last Jewish children it was still possible to find on French soil."

The French Nazi-hunter Serge Klarsfeld, who spent nearly 15 years bringing the case to court, admitted that without a defendant the trial was largely symbolic - an effort to honour the names and the memories of victims like Celestine Ajzykowicz, 11, Jean Bender, four, and Alain Blumberg, a two-week-old baby kicked to death by an SS guard.

"This was a case where the culpability of the defendant did not have to be proven," said Mr Klarsfeld, whose own father, arrested in in Nice in 1943, was among Brunner's early victims. "But what counts here is the victims. It was important to me to have the names of these children pronounced solemnly in a French courtroom."

Syria has always denied harbouring the Austrian-born Brunner, who, before arriving in France in 1943, emptied Vienna of 43,000 Jews and Salonika of 46,000; in the last days of the Reich he managed to deport another 13,500 from Slovakia.

"We don't know anything about Brunner," a Syrian official said this week. But despite denying knowledge of his whereabouts, Damascus has consistently barred French investigators from entering the country and has several times refused entry to Mr Klarsfeld.

Brunner fled Germany only in 1954, on a fake Red Cross passport, moving first to Egypt and then to Syria where he assumed the name Georg Fischer.

In 1961 he lost an eye to a letter bomb sent to his Damascus address in the rue Georges Haddad, by the French secret service, allegedly because he was selling arms to the Algerian liberation movement.

Another letter bomb, sent this time by the Israeli secret service, blew off four fingers of his right hand in 1980. In 1985 he gave an interview, illustrated with photographs taken in the Syrian port of Lattaquie, to the German magazine Bunte, saying he had "no regrets whatsoever". He was last seen alive by reliable witnesses in 1992.

The Jewish rights organisation the Simon Wiesenthal Centre accused Syria of hiding the truth. "Until Damascus produces either the man or evidence of his demise, the trauma of his victims' families will not be concluded," its director for international liaison, Shimon Samuels, said.

"Brunner is anti-semitism at its most extreme," said Mr Klarsfeld, responsible for tracking down Klaus Barbie, the Lyon Gestapo chief. "What business did he have rounding up these little children? I know them in a way, I feel affection for them; I fought to get hold of their photographs. What can we give to the dead if not our loyalty?"

 Additional reporting by Celine Bruneau
fields.bodyText: A Paris court yesterday sentenced in absentia Alois Brunner - Adolf Eichmann's right-hand man and the world's highest-ranking Nazi fugitive believed still alive - to life imprisonment for sending hundreds of Jewish children to their deaths at Auschwitz. "Life imprisonment is too good for him," said Henri Zajdenwerger, 73, who lost 14 members of his family to Brunner's SS henchmen during the war and was among dozens of protesters outside the courthouse yesterday. "But in reality he has never paid for his crimes, and he never will." In all, Brunner, who fled to Syria after the war and is now 88 if he is still alive, is held responsible for sending some 140,000 European Jews to the gas chambers. Nearly 24,000 of them were deported from the notorious Drancy transit camp outside Paris, where Brunner was commandant from June 1943 to August 1944. The former Gestapo officer was sentenced to death twice in his absence in the 1950s, but had never been charged with the specific crime addressed in yesterday's hearing - the arrest and deportation of 345 orphans from the Paris region. Aged between 15 days and 18 years old, the children were packed into cattle trains and shipped off to Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen death camps in August 1944, just weeks before the Allies liberated Paris. Only 61 survived. "Alois Brunner must be considered the true organiser of the deportation of Jews from France between June 1943 and August 1944," said the investigating magistrate Hervé Stephan, who presented the case to the court. "These final arrests sprang from a desire to deport and to exterminate the very last Jewish children it was still possible to find on French soil." The French Nazi-hunter Serge Klarsfeld, who spent nearly 15 years bringing the case to court, admitted that without a defendant the trial was largely symbolic - an effort to honour the names and the memories of victims like Celestine Ajzykowicz, 11, Jean Bender, four, and Alain Blumberg, a two-week-old baby kicked to death by an SS guard. "This was a case where the culpability of the defendant did not have to be proven," said Mr Klarsfeld, whose own father, arrested in in Nice in 1943, was among Brunner's early victims. "But what counts here is the victims. It was important to me to have the names of these children pronounced solemnly in a French courtroom." Syria has always denied harbouring the Austrian-born Brunner, who, before arriving in France in 1943, emptied Vienna of 43,000 Jews and Salonika of 46,000; in the last days of the Reich he managed to deport another 13,500 from Slovakia. "We don't know anything about Brunner," a Syrian official said this week. But despite denying knowledge of his whereabouts, Damascus has consistently barred French investigators from entering the country and has several times refused entry to Mr Klarsfeld. Brunner fled Germany only in 1954, on a fake Red Cross passport, moving first to Egypt and then to Syria where he assumed the name Georg Fischer. In 1961 he lost an eye to a letter bomb sent to his Damascus address in the rue Georges Haddad, by the French secret service, allegedly because he was selling arms to the Algerian liberation movement. Another letter bomb, sent this time by the Israeli secret service, blew off four fingers of his right hand in 1980. webTitle: How the Buddha got his wounds

fields.headline: How the Buddha got his wounds
fields.standfirst: On Monday Afghanistan's Taliban rulers were promising to safeguard the country's historic treasures. On Thursday they started shelling them.  Luke Harding  explains what changed their minds
fields.trailText: On Monday Afghanistan's Taliban rulers were promising to safeguard the country's historic treasures. On Thursday they started shelling them. Luke Harding explains what changed their minds
fields.body:
It had seemed like a good meeting. Sitting in one corner was Afghanistan's bearded foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Mutawakel. On the sofa opposite, a delegation of western cultural experts who had flown to Kabul to discuss the preservation of Afghanistan's few remaining antiquities.

Over cups of green tea, Mutawakel smilingly assured the delegation that all was well. The Taliban, Afghanistan's fundamentalist rulers, had no intention of destroying what was left of the country's heritage, he said. This was at 5.30pm on Monday. Two hours later, however, Radio Sharia - the Taliban's official station - broadcast an announcement that would plunge Afghanistan into further isolation and provoke a major international outcry. Mullah Mohammed Omar, the Taliban's reclusive, one-eyed spiritual leader, had issued a new decree: that all Afghanistan's ancient statues should be destroyed.

The decision was in line with Islamic law and had been taken following a gathering of the country's most senior religious leaders, he explained. "We were just blown away," said Brigitte Neubacher of the Society for the Preservation of Afghanistan's Cultural Heritage (SPACH). "This came immediately after our one-and-a-half hour meeting. Whether the timing was deliberate or not we don't know. I am totally horrified."

By Thursday, Taliban fighters deep in the Hindu Kush mountains started putting Mullah Omar's edict into effect. They set about what was once Afghanistan's most famous tourist attraction - two enormous statues of Buddha, 38 and 55 metres high, carved into a cliff-face. Using tanks and rocket launchers they began to destroy the two works, which had survived since the second century AD.

The magnificent colossi were built in the remote and beautiful Bamiyan Valley - seven hours' drive from Kabul - 1,000 years before the arrival of Islam in Afghanistan. They were built by the flourishing Buddhist Kushan dynasty, which had grown rich from its strategic position on the Silk Road between China and Rome.

The statues were unique. They were visited by pilgrims from across Central Asia; tended by yellow-robed priests who lived in caves carved into the sandstone hillside; and decorated with exquisite frescoes. "The buddhas are absolutely spectacular. I have never seen anything like them in my life," one awed visitor to Bamiyan told me. The statues even outlasted an attack by Genghis Khan in the 13th century. But they have finally met their match in the Taliban.

In retrospect, the international community could have spotted the danger signals. Three weeks ago, Taliban officials allegedly broke into Kabul's bombed-out museum and destroyed around 50 objects of cultural significance, according to reports.

There was not, it has to be said, much left to destroy. Rival Afghan mujaheddin factions looted most of the museum's best pieces when they fought for control of the city in 1992. But a few things were still on display when I visited last October: a couple of friezes, a limestone Islamic bowl and a rather fetching statue of King Kanishka, who ruled Afghanistan 1,800 years ago.

One observer who recently managed to peer through the locked museum's windows spotted some white marks on King Kanishka's enormous royal feet, suggesting the already headless statue had been hit by a hammer. "We don't know how great the damage is. We weren't allowed into the museum to verify the reports," one member of the SPACH delegation said.

The Taliban's decision to destroy the few relics that managed to survive 20 years of war and Soviet occupation can only be explained by recent political events. In February, the UN imposed fresh sanctions on Afghanistan. The Taliban's office in New York was closed down by the United States, a country obsessed with capturing the Afghanistan-based Saudi dissident Osama bin Laden. Within the Taliban, a dialogue of sorts had been going on. Moderates, such as the Taliban's culture minister Abdul Rahman Hotaki, advocated a degree of co-operation with the west. But after the most recent wave of sanctions Mullah Omar appears to have concluded that a policy of engagement was entirely pointless. Instead, he has thumbed his nose at the international community. "All we are breaking are stones," he shrugged. "I don't care about anything but Islam."

Since the Taliban swept into Kabul four years ago, imposing the world's most extreme brand of Islam, portrayal of the human image has been forbidden. Painters, for example, are now confined to depicting landscapes; Kabul's art gallery is hung with innocuous Victorian pastorals. In September 1998, a renegade Taliban commander blew off the head of the smaller Bamiyan buddha using dynamite. He also fired rockets at the large buddha's groin, damaging the luxurious folds of the statue's dress.

But the Taliban then decided to take a more pragmatic view of Afghanistan's pre-Islamic past. In July 1999 Mullah Omar issued a decree that said the Bamiyan buddhas should be preserved. There were, he pointed out, no Buddhists left in Afghanistan to worship them. But he added: "The government considers the Bamiyan statues as an example of a potential major source of income for Afghanistan from international visitors. The Taliban states that Bamiyan shall not be destroyed but protected."

Then, over another cup of green tea four months ago, Hotaki assured me that the Taliban had no intention of damaging the statues. To suggest as much was "foreign propaganda", he said. Sadly, though, the rumours have proved all too true.

The Bamiyan valley, with its serene mountain views and pastel colours, is also an unwelcome reminder to the Taliban of their own vulnerability. Opposition fighters from Afghanistan's Northern Alliance seized the valley last month and were dislodged only after a massive battle. The Taliban have now sealed the valley and have rejected all requests by foreign observers to visit.

It is not just the buddhas that face annihilation: 20 tin trunks that may contain the Kabul museum's celebrated Bactrian treasures are currently stored in the vaults of the presidential palace and the Taliban's culture ministry. They have not been opened, so no one is sure what they contain. The only certainty is that after Monday's edict, they are likely to be lost to the world for ever.

"I consider myself a friend of Afghanistan. I have spent 15 years trying to help the country," one western cultural expert said this week. "But it is becoming an island of madness."

fields.headline: I kid you not
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the left-handed gunman who wasn't
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the left-handed gunman who wasn't
fields.body:
Not long ago, when our Washington correspondent filed a report of moves in the United States to secure a posthumous pardon for Billy the Kid, we illustrated the story with a photograph of the famous outlaw. This is a ferrotype, or tintype, probably taken in 1880, the year he was captured by Sheriff Pat Garrett.

The photograph, familiar to all students of the West, but less so to the rest of us, shows Billy the Kid, full-length, the butt of his Winchester resting on the ground and the tip of the barrel gripped lightly in his right hand. More to the point, he carries his single-action Colt on his left hip, the handle pointing backwards.

To everyone involved in editing the page on which it appeared, everything seemed as it should be. Wasn't Billy, after all, a notorious left-hander - played as such by Paul Newman in Arthur Penn's 1958 film The Left-Handed Gun?

Almost immediately after the Guardian report appeared, I received an email from a reader: "Your reproduction of the famous photograph of Billy the Kid is reversed. You can see by the waistcoat buttons and the belt buckle. This is a common error which has continued to reinforce the myth that Billy the Kid was left-handed. He was not. He was right-handed and carried his gun on his right hip." The writer of the email was, it transpired, a former curator of the National Film and Television Archive of the British Film Institute, Clyde Jeavons.

His points about the buckle and buttons were indeed borne out on closer examination. The prong on the belt buckle is pointing the wrong way, and the buttons run down the wrong side of his waistcoat. There is no doubt that what we are looking at is a reverse image.

Was it simply another case of "flipping the picture"? After all, we have in the past presented readers of the Guardian with a photograph of an entirely left-handed orchestra and a flipped image of the Horsehead nebula. This case, however, did not prove so simple.

My correspondent produced further argument. "This particular reproduction error has occurred so often in books and other publications over the years that it has led to the myth that Billy the Kid was left-handed, for which there is no evidence. On the contrary, the evidence (from viewing his photo correctly) is that he was right-handed: he wears his pistol on his right hip with the butt pointing backwards in a conventional right-handed draw position."

He cites the Pictorial History of the Wild West by James D Horan and Paul Sann, 1954, in which the authors caption the "correctly printed" picture: "Billy the Kid. He was right-handed and carried his pistol on his right hip."

Edward Buscombe, in The BFI Companion to the Western, 1988, now sadly out of print, while not commenting directly on the left hand/right hand issue, says this: "There has probably been more tedious argument about the facts of Billy the Kid's life than about anything else in the West." Alongside he prints the photograph to show the gun on Billy's right hip (buttons and buckle all in order) - the reverse of the Guardian's presentation.

A quick internet search produces vast quantities of information, including sites devoted to Billy the Kid which reproduce the image in question, usually showing it, as it appeared in the Guardian, with the pistol on the right of the picture - that is, on his left hip, if you regard it as you would a modern photograph.

The answer, in fact, is in the technique used to obtain the image in the first place. The tintype or ferrotype, to quote Britannica.com, was "a positive photograph produced by means of a nitrocellulose (collodion) solution applied to a thin enamelled black iron plate immediately prior to exposure". It says they remained a kind of folk art for the rest of the 19th century.

The best description I have found is in the online work, A History of Photography, compiled by Robert Leggat (www.rleggat.com/photohistory. He makes the following essential point: "The print would come out laterally reversed (as one sees oneself in a mirror); either people did not worry about this, or just possibly they did not discover it until after the photographer had disappeared!"

So the "authentic" tintype of Billy the Kid, if one is to be purist about this, should be shown as it appeared in the Guardian, but pointing out that the image is reversed. If we want to see Billy the Kid the right way round, we have to grit our teeth, break our own rule forbidding the flipping of pictures, and reverse it again.

If you are still with me, the essential point in all this is that Billy the Kid was not, on the evidence of this image, left-handed. I find myself on the side of the right.

 The Guardian carried the picture of Billy the Kid on February 3. Special thanks to Clyde Jeavons, who provided me with a good deal of the material for this column; and to Edward Buscombe. A key book is Billy the Kid: A Short and Violent Life by Robert M Utley, University of Nebraska Press, 1989. Fax 020-7239 9897.

fields.headline: How to... find things
fields.trailText: Things don't really get lost, they're just in the last place you left them. The reason you can't find them is because you've put them somewhere you don't usually leave them. For example, nobody in their right mind leaves the remote control on the fridge.
fields.body:
Things don't really get lost, they're just in the last place you left them. The reason you can't find them is because you've put them somewhere you don't usually leave them. For example, nobody in their right mind leaves the remote control on the fridge.

The good news is that once you start looking for it you'll spot it immediately, because things that aren't where they're supposed to be stick out like a sore thumb. But that's only if you've left it out on a surface. If it's got inside something, like the bread bin, you won't be watching television until just after your next sandwich.

One of the most trying aspects of losing things is the advice you get from other people - for example, 'Where did you last have it?' If you knew where you last had it, you'd go and get it and it wouldn't be lost. Or people try to get all rigorous and say things such as, 'Go through your last movements.' If you've gone back more than a year and you still haven't found anything, stop.

Normally, the place you look in first is where the things is. But the difference is that, instead of being in that place, it is now under that place. If you've lost something in the bedroom it will be under the bed. Don't argue, just go and look.

When things get lost, people start looking in extraordinarily unlikely places. One moment you can't put your hands on the photo you had seconds ago, the next you're ripping out plasterwork, carpets and load-bearing walls. The reason for this is that the only thing you've really lost is your mind.

In fact, lost things are always in exactly the same place: mobile phones are under the passenger seat of the car; your keys are in the pocket of your other jacket; your glasses are on the small table on top of that pile of books; your remote control is down the side of the sofa; and your illegitimate love-child is in Canada.

There is another category of things you often have to look for, and that is very small items that you drop accidentally. For women, this is the fiddly bit at the back of the earring. For men, it is the grub screw that goes in the back of the doofer. The instinct is to freeze exactly where you are and to look at the carpet directly beneath you. Don't bother. Between falling from your fingers, the clasp or screw or contact lens can actually move 15 ft horizontally in any direction. That, or it's nestling in a fold of your trousers.

fields.headline: Obsessions
fields.standfirst: David Newnham wants to get fit, he really does. But is it an exercise in futility?
fields.trailText: David Newnham wants to get fit, he really does. But is it an exercise in futility?
fields.body:
Isn't it typical? For years, they have been on at me to take some regular exercise. And what happens when I finally relent? They double-cross me. A word of thanks would have been nice - maybe a certificate, or a congratulatory email. Okay, so I didn't expect them to organise street parties. But nor did I expect them to renege on the deal. Because a deal there most certainly was. Would I have spent 200 quid on an exercise bike otherwise?

A little but often, that's what I signed up to. No running up mountains or playing squash at lunchtime. Just 20 minutes of moderate exertion, three times a week. Enough to puff the wrinkles out of the lungs. Enough to jolt the heart into second gear. Enough to begin sluicing away the coagulated evidence of 10,000 full English breakfasts. In return, I would be spared pain, suffering and premature death. I would lose unsightly fat, become irresistible to women, regain my short-term memory and command the respect of my GP. That was the deal. But no sooner had I submitted to the new regime than I became aware that something was amiss. "Twenty minutes?" said a friend when I announced that I had taken ownership of my body.

That's right, I told him, mistaking his disdain for approval. Not bad, eh?

"Well, it's a start," he said. "But I think you'll find that the recommended time per session is now 30 minutes minimum."

Thirty minutes? But that's half an hour, for heaven's sake. It's an increase of 50%. Who says? And since when? "It's the recommended minimum," said my friend, unhelpfully. "What does it matter since when? They're not insisting you backdate it. And what's 10 minutes anyway?"

What's 10 minutes? I began bellowing that 10 times three equalled 30, and that, by the time I was 80, I'd have been tricked into doing an entire month of extra exercise. He said that if I continued limiting myself to one hour a week, I wasn't going to make 60, let alone 80. Then he said that if I didn't calm down a bit, I'd be lucky to see 50. He had a point. What with all the shouting, not to mention the mental arithmetic, I was beginning to feel giddy. So we agreed that he would go away and get me chapter and verse on this 30 minutes business. But what's the point? I know he'll be proved right. Of course they'll have increased the minimum. It will be fruit and veg all over again.

Remember that one? First we had to eat so many portions of fresh produce a day. Oh, and so many slices of wholemeal bread, too. Then, one Friday afternoon when nobody was looking, they sneaked in an extra banana and another handful of aduki beans. Did they think we wouldn't notice? It's as if the people who issue these guidelines don't care about public opinion. Well, I've got news for them. There's a general election coming up, and I for one am saying: enough is enough.

Yes, I thought that would ring a bell or two. So come on you spin doctors. Stop worrying about public sector borrowing requirements and start looking at recommended daily amounts instead. That way, you can give the voters what they crave and it won't cost you a penny. What would the treasury care if you slashed wholemeal bread, or halved the number of oily fish we're expected to eat in a week? Never mind tinkering with pensions and tax. Go for the full-fat factor.

"If we win the election, we will raise the recommended maximum weekly intake of alcohol by three units for men and two units for women [applause from the public gallery]. That's an extra five units for a married couple!" Opponents might raise them two units, or trump them by allowing us a couple of fried eggs apiece. Worried about the Labour heartlands? Chuck in a couple of sausages. Desperate for the women's vote? Grant them equal measures.

And if you want my vote, I'll settle for a return to those 20-minute exercise sessions. Although, if anyone's prepared to drop it to 15...

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText: Celia Woolfrey
fields.body:
Time to

Prune roses - in their first year, roses benefit from being pruned to about 15cm from the ground after planting, to stop them becoming leggy. After that, go easy with the secateurs, removing dead, diseased or spindly wood and cutting on a slant just above an outward-facing bud, depending on the shape you want the plant to develop. It's worth noting, however, that certain varieties won't flower if pruned hard.

Seeds of recovery

Donate £1 for a pack of 'Tranquillity' sunflower seeds in the Greenfingers charity appeal, and you could win a French villa holiday (each pack has details of how to enter). The money will go towards creating gardens at children's hospices, where 20,000 children receive support each year. The appeal target is £50,000; for your nearest participating centre, visit www.greenfingersappeal.co.uk or call 01473 688821. Seeds are also available from all Wyevale Garden Centres.

Plant of the week

The seashore perennial sea kale, Crambe maritima (above), is edible and loosely related to the cabbage. It has waxy, blue-grey leaves and large clusters of white-scented flowers that make a bold statement in any border. Sea kale still grows wild on shingle beaches near the high-tide line - as you'd expect, it is hardy, and demands sandy soil and free drainage. Readers can order a C. maritima for £9.99 (inc UK p&p), by calling 0870 4421940. Allow 28 days for delivery.

Earth works

Compost, Pests, Soil and Weeds, the first four titles by Charlie Ryrie in the Gaia Organic Basics series, are jargon-free and cut to the chase. They are ideal for novice gardeners, but there's enough expert advice to enlighten experienced gardeners, too. Available from bookshops and garden centres from March 30, they cost £5.99 each, and are endorsed by the Soil Association and the organic association HDRA.

fields.headline: Good housekeeping
fields.standfirst: 'Fred goes pale with rage. The steward delightedly dabs his lap with tissues'
fields.trailText: 'Fred goes pale with rage. The steward delightedly dabs his lap with tissues'
fields.body:
Leaving Tobago was never going to be easy. The plane is full, and we have one of those horrid delays on the Tarmac just before takeoff - perhaps there's a tiny glitch somewhere in the system that's going to turn into a full-blown, wings-falling-off crisis above the lonely Atlantic. The BA pilot reassures us, however. British pilots still sound like Battle of Britain heroes with crinkly hair.

When the massive thing finally begins to thunder down the runway, like the Wigmore Hall on wheels, I'm convinced I'm about to be punished for my hedonistic hol, and foresee my whole memorial service, during which Great Aunt Elspeth announces loudly that she can't remember who I was.

Soon after takeoff, a steward minces up and says to Fred, "You've just leaned on my button, dear - or was it an accident?" A gay flirtation springs up. I let them get on with it. Holidaying with a bisexual is a piece of cake. Sandwich cake, naturally. I begin to reflect on the extended family waiting for me at home, and the black looks I shall get. A Battle of Britain of my own.

The steward brings drinks and pretzels. Fred asks for a glass of wine, but I stick to water, and three different homeopathic remedies to ward off jet lag.

"I've never known anyone take so many pills," comments Fred, looking at me in a manner more anthropological than admiring.

"Crunch my pretzels!" I cry and, with a mistimed attempt to offer him nibbles, knock his wine all over his lap. Fred goes pale with rage, though the steward hovers about delightedly dabbing at his lap with a handful of tissues. At least I've made somebody happy.

Thank God Fred has a change of trousers: his winter corduroys are in the overhead locker. I decide the tactful thing to do is to go to sleep. Dream that Harriet has had a party in my absence, and Great Aunt Elspeth has been accidentally dismembered.

Awake with a lurch as the plane starts to bump and judder. Fred gives me an icy look. Still furious. It seems we have encountered the first cloud - literally as well as metaphorically. Slip back into dream, where in another room I discover that Elaine has decapitated Gordon but that we still have to feed his disembodied head, which cries like a baby. Wake to find we are above Gatwick, circling in featureless greyness. Try to shake off the anxiety about my dysfunctional family, so clearly revealed by my unconscious mind. Whenever the plane tilts, my brain threatens to balloon out of my right ear and float off towards Club Class.

Fred still looks grim. "There's no need for you to take me back home, Fred," I suggest, anxious to escape. "It's totally out of your way. I can get a train from Gatwick that goes cross-country to Reading."

"Oh no, I'll take you - no trouble at all." Cold politeness. The M25 in Fred's sports car was the bit of the journey I was dreading most of all. Now that he suddenly and inexplicably hates me, it will be even worse. Wonder what on earth I am doing with him, anyway, as I've never understood what he saw in me. For the first time on the holiday, wish I was alone.

Once things have gone wrong, they usually get worse. Fred waits by the carousel with increasing rage for his most important case to appear - the one with the sketches for his next exhibition. When everybody else has gone, we turn in despair to look for someone to complain to, and see the missing case neatly stacked on a trolley in a corner. It was just behind us all the time. By now, Fred has turned to stone, and not a nice, soft, yielding limestone, either.

But the last twist of the knife is provided by his car. It won't start. The battery's flat. Fred rings the RAC. Offer to wait with him and see the whole thing through, but he admits it would make more sense for me to go home by train after all. The briefest of token kisses on the cheek, and I make my escape.

Doubt if I will ever see him again, somehow. After love gone sour, black looks and jet lag will be a piece of cake. Rock cake, I suppose.

fields.headline: The questionnaire:   Trevor Nelson
fields.standfirst: Trevor Nelson was born in Hackney, London, in 1964. His father was a financial adviser, his mother a nursery teacher. After school, he worked in a shoe shop until, in the 80s, he made a name for himself as a DJ and warehouse party organiser. In 1986, he began broadcasting for Kiss FM, then a pirate station. Ten years later, he left to join Radio 1, where he now has a twice-weekly show, The Lick.
fields.trailText: Can you guess his idea of perfect happiness?
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
The feeling of being in love.

What is your greatest fear?
Dying without achieving.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I'm too easy-going.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Turning up late for breakfast at Downing Street.

Where would you like to live?
Anywhere closer to the coast.

What is your favourite building?
Tate Modern.

What is your favourite journey?
Tower Bridge to Stamford Bridge, via the Embankment, for a Chelsea evening match.

How did you vote in the last election?
Sorry to say, I didn't - that's why I never complain about politics.

How will you vote in the next election?
My beliefs veer towards socialism.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
No - they bring too much money into the country through tourism.

For what cause would you die?
Honestly, a decade ago, it would have been apartheid.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes, that's why I got married.

Which living person do you most despise and why?
Any dictator.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes, a couple of times when I was younger. I still hate myself for it.

What is your greatest regret?
Not travelling when I had a chance.

When and where were you happiest?
A year after leaving home, renting a council flat and loving the independence.

How do you relax?
A movie usually does the trick.

How often do you have sex?
Not often enough, due to my schedule.

What would your motto be?
Be patient. Fate can be a good four-letter world.

How would you like to die?
With a smile on my face.

How would you like to be remembered?
As an all-right bloke who loved life.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Treat people like you would like to be treated. There is always shit waiting around the corner.

fields.headline: Opposites attract
fields.standfirst: It's a common complaint that can end in disaster, says Bob Granleese - two people meet, fall in love, move in together, only to find that they don't eat the same things. Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, devises a solution for one such divided couple.
fields.trailText: in love, move in together, only to find that they don't eat the same things. Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, devises a solution for one such divided couple.
fields.body:
Agi and Edward Hurst have a serious problem. It's an affliction that blights thousands of couples year in, year out, bringing with it discord and resentment where there should be sweetness and light. And, no, before you ask, it has nothing to do with sex.

Agi explains all in a letter to the Kitchen Doctor: "My husband and I would like to cook and eat together, but I don't eat meat. I do eat fish, seafood and all manner of vegetables." Not too much of a quandary there, you might think, but read on: "My husband is very much a meat-eater, does not like fish, and will not touch seafood. Vegetarian dishes are usually met with a, 'Mmmm, the only thing missing is a steak'."

See what I mean? That's not so much a job for the Kitchen Doctor, and more one for a miracle worker. And though both Hursts are management consultants, even their problem-solving expertise hasn't helped them find a solution.

Rosie Sykes, however, loves a challenge, even one as seemingly insurmountable as this, which is how the KD crew find themselves one wet Thursday lunchtime unpacking the tools of their trade at Agi and Edward's flat in Surbiton, Surrey. Agi has to speak for both of them, as Ed is snowed under at work. "We live completely independent lives as far as food is concerned," she says. "I heat up ready meals, he makes pasta with tomato and meat sauce."

Agi adds that her aversion to meat is not an ethical matter, or even one of flavour - she just can't stand the texture - so meat stocks and the like are not the complete no-nos Rosie had feared. Which is just as well, considering that her first act is to plonk a hunk of gammon in a pot, cover it with water, add herbs and veg, and bring it up to a boil.

The ham will form the basis of the first dish on her latest mercy mission, a bean stew that, Rosie explains, "is a bit like a baked bean thing - only they're not actually baked". Before anyone can query her logic, she adds quickly that Ed can eat the beans with a slice or two of the ham, while Agi has them with a sort of Italian stir-fry of broccoli, anchovy and chilli. Agi, who, if truth be told, is not overly confident that Rosie can pull this one off, perks up no end.

Her spirits rise even further when Rosie tells her, "It's time to get your hands dirty and make a spinach and cheese tart - and, yes, I know there's no meat in it, but surely even Ed can do without once in a while."

Agi concurs, and makes short work of converting a benchtop full of spinach, eggs and cheese into a gloriously golden gloop for the tart filling. "Add some nutmeg," says Rosie after dipping her finger into the mix for a taste. "It's always a good plan with the old spinach."

The KD has brought ready-made pastry (Agi and Ed's other requirement was that they wanted food that didn't take an age to prepare), so the final stages are easy as, well, pie. "Fine old job you did there," Rosie tells Agi, before turning her thoughts to an Asian-inspired soup.

Agi is soon hard at work chopping and slicing, while Rosie makes the broth. Half an hour later, the soup is poured into a bowl, which is placed on a plate and surrounded with sliced chicken, tiger prawns and two dipping sauces. "The idea is to share the old broth, and Ed eats his with chicken and you have tiger prawns."

Agi, looking more impressed by the minute, nods happily and licks her lips, but before she can try it, Rosie comes over all concerned: "I seem to be saying 'old' a lot, in a Jamie Oliver kind of way. I hope I'm not possessed." Agi suddenly seems unsure quite what she has let herself in for, as if Rosie is about to unleash a blizzard of "pukka"s and "blinding"s. Instead, an embarrassed KD buttons her lip while she prepares her rather grand take on mushrooms on toast, cheering up no end as a garlicky, buttery scent fills the kitchen. "Pile it up," she exhorts Agi.

"As Jamie might say," quips Agi.

"Tssst," says Rosie, caught out again. "Anyway, he'd say, 'Whack it on.' And enough of that cheek - you need to cook the tuna now."

"Ed's main problem with fish is the bones," explains Agi, suitably chastened. "And he detests shellfish: if it's got tentacles or a shell, it's out."

The tuna should not be a problem, then, says Rosie: "The steaks are boneless, it's a really meaty fish and, to make it even more appealing to Ed, we're going to do them in a classic beef steak-style: au poivre." Agi, who by now is a slaveringconvert to the KD approach, fries the fish and makes the sauce as per Rosie's tuition and is soon tasting the fruits of her labours: "That is delicious," she declares. "It's definitely my favourite."

Rosie's creations have hit the mark every time... but Agi is only one half of the problem: what of the absent Ed, who will be tasting the dishes after work? The answer came a day or so later. "We were really sceptical," said Ed. "We just couldn't see any common ground for you to work with. But I very much liked everything. I don't know how you did it."

Perhaps he shouldn't have been so surprised - that's what a Kitchen Doctor is for, after all.

Tuna steak au poivre

A good compromise for Agi and Ed: a meaty, boneless piece of fish cooked in a classic steak way. Serves two.

2 decent-sized tuna steaks
2 tbsp peppercorns (black or mixed)
30g butter
1 tbsp olive oil
Salt
1 shallot, finely chopped
2 tbsp brandy
60ml red wine
150ml stock (chicken or beef)
2 tbsp double cream (or crème frache)

Crush the peppercorns. Sprinkle over the fish, press into the flesh and drizzle with half the olive oil. Cover and refrigerate for at least half an hour. Heat the rest of the oil and the butter in a pan, season the fish with a little salt and, when the butter starts foaming, cook the tuna until it turns opaque on the pan side - a couple of minutes, say - then turn over, add the shallot, and cook for two minutes more. Transfer the fish to a warm place, and make the sauce.

Turn the heat to high, add the brandy, which should evaporate pretty instantly,then add the wine and reduce by two thirds. Add the stock, reduce by half, taste, season, add the cream and cook until the sauce is slightly thicker than milk. Pour over the tuna, and serve with the following potato dish.

Crisp potatoes, olives and rocket

1 large waxy potato
2 tbsp olive oil
30g pitted black olives
50-75g rocket
4 basil leaves
Salt and pepper

Cook the potato whole in salted water, drain, peel and cut into cubes. Just before you cook the fish, heat the oil in a pan, add the potato, cover, and leave to crisp up. Turn, and crisp up the other side. When you add the stock to the tuna's sauce, add the olives and rocket to the potatoes, stir until the leaves wilt, add the basil, season to taste and serve.

Ham and beans

A good, robust stew. I used tinned beans for speed, but for the best flavour use dried beans, soaked for eight hours. Ed gets his meat fix, and Agi has the full flavoured pulses with a dish of broccoli, anchovy, garlic and chilli. Serves four.

750g gammon
1 carrot
1 small onion
Parsley stalks, or any other useful stock trimmings
1 sprig fresh thyme
1 bayleaf
A few peppercorns
400g tin kidney beans
400g tin canellinni beans
400g tinned tomatoes
1 small green pepper, finely sliced
2 shallots, finely sliced
2 large cloves garlic, crushed
1 tbsp molasses sugar
2 tbsp olive oil
10g parsley, roughly chopped

First, cook the gammon - allow 55 minutes/kg, so you're looking at around 40 minutes here. In a big pan, cover the meat with water, add the carrot, onion, herbs and peppercorns, and bring to a boil. Skim to remove any foamy impurities, then simmer until done. Lift out the meat, pass the liquor through a sieve into a pot, measure out 150ml into another pot, and keep the rest for something else (the soup below, say).

To the 150ml liquor, add the beans, tomatoes, pepper, shallots, garlic, sugar and oil, bring to the boil and simmer for half an hour. When it's time to eat, slice off a few pieces of ham per person, reheat this on top of the beans, keeping the pot covered. Lift out the meat, stir in the parsley and serve.

Broccoli, anchovy, garlic and chilli

Agi's alternative accompaniment to the beans: a classic combination that's quick, easy and very tasty. Serves four.

1 tbsp olive oil
450g broccoli or romanesco, broken into very small florets
small red chilli
30g anchovy fillets, roughly chopped lemon

Heat the oil in a pan, add the chilli and broccoli, toss them around, add a dash of water and cover for a couple of minutes, so the steam cooks the broccoli. Remove the lid, add the anchovies and stir. Add a squeeze of lemon, taste for seasoning and serve.

The soup

This Asian-style soup is based on a dish made by my best friend's mum. I love its simplicity, and that you can choose what bits you want to eat. Serves four.

2 chicken breasts (part-boned, skin-on organic, if you can afford them)
250ml chicken stock (or the ham stock from the previous recipe)
2 tbsp sherry (fino or amontillado)
4 spring onions, finely sliced
20g ginger, peeled and finely sliced
100g beansprouts
80g pak choi (or baby spinach)
225g fat rice noodles
100g baby corn
100g tofu, cubed (I like smoked)
16 tiger prawns, cooked and peeled

For the dipping sauces

3 cloves garlic, very finely sliced
4 shallots, finely sliced
100ml sunflower oil
tsp sesame oil
Soy sauce
1 small chilli, very finely chopped

Place the chicken in a pan with the stock, sherry and 250ml water, bring to the boil, skim and simmer until the chicken is just cooked. Lift out the chicken, peel off the skin and cut the meat on a slight diagonal into thick slices. Cook the noodles as per the instructions on the packet, drain and refresh under cold water.

Now make the dipping sauces. Heat the oils in a small pan, add the garlic and shallot, and fry until golden-brown. Tip into a little dish (a ramekin, say). Make the other dip by putting the chopped chilli and a pinch of the ginger sliced for the soup in another small dish, and cover with soy.

Reheat the broth, throw in the remaining ginger, beansprouts, corn and tofu, and simmer until the corn is just cooked. Add the pak choi, spring onions and noodles, and heat through. Pour into a tureen or suitable bowl, place on a big plate, and surround with prawns, the chicken slices and some thinly sliced spring onions, each of which you dip into whichever sauce takes your fancy before eating with a mouthful of broth.

Mushrooms on toast

A great dish that works both as a side dish for a fillet steak, say, for the carnivores or, bulked out with leeks, cavolo nero and pinenuts, as a main for those who don't want meat. Serves four.

30g dried ceps, soaked in hot water for 30-45 minutes
600g mixed mushrooms (such as oyster, shiitake, chestnut)
1 loaf rustic white bread
2 tbsp olive oil
4 large cloves garlic, 3 crushed, the last reserved whole
15g flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
80g butter, softened
10g chives, snipped fine
30g fresh Parmesan
Salt and pepper

Carefully wipe any dirt off the mushrooms; do not wash them. Slice the shiitakes and chestnuts, and shred the oysters into thick pieces. Mix the butter, crushed garlic, parsley and a dash of olive oil to a smooth paste, and season.

Heat a tablespoon of oil in a pan, add the fungi and cook down over a lowish heat. They will let out a lot of liquid. Add a generous tablespoon of the garlic butter mix (keep the rest in the fridge: it's a really handy thing to have about, as it gives a lift to all manner of dishes, from steamed fish and veg to grilled meat), turn up the heat a little, and cook until the mushrooms have reabsorbed all liquid in the pan. Meanwhile, toast one slice of bread per person, rub each with the reserved garlic, and keep warm until the mushrooms are ready.

To serve, top the toasts with the mushrooms, and sprinkle with chives and roughly grated Parmesan.

Spinach, courgette and cheese pie

Strong-flavoured enough to make even Ed forget meat for a night. Serves four.

1 packet ready-rolled puff pastry
500g frozen spinach, defrosted
2 courgettes, sliced thinly
100g cheddar, roughly grated
100g soft goats' cheese, mashed
100g ricotta
80g Parmesan, roughly grated
Nutmeg
6 eggs, beaten
55g fresh breadcrumbs
lemon, zested
10g flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
15g cold butter, grated

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Beat all the cheese, bar a tablespoon of Parmesan, with the eggs, a little grated nutmeg and spinach until smooth. Line a 30x10cm baking tin with the pastry, and roll down the edges. Fill with the cheese mix and lay the courgettes on top. Sprinkle with the butter, then the breadcrumbs, parsley, lemon zest and the reserved Parmesan. Cook on the top shelf until the pastry is golden and the filling set, about 35 minutes.

Peas, potatoes and fennel

A versatile dish to which you can add other seasonal treats such as broad beans, asparagus or artichoke hearts. Good with sausages, lamb chops or a nice piece of white fish. Serves four.

350g new potatoes, scrubbed
150g peas, fresh or frozen
1 head fennel, thinly sliced
1 lemon, juiced
60ml double cream
15g mint, leaves picked and chopped, stalks reserved
Sea salt and black pepper

Put the spuds and mint stalks in a pan of salted water, bring to the boil, then simmer until almost cooked. Add the peas and cook until tender. Drain off the water leaving 1cm in the pan, add the fennel and lemon juice, season, and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring often. Add the cream, cook down until reduced by a third, stir in the mint and serve

fields.bodyText: Agi and Edward Hurst have a serious problem. It's an affliction that blights thousands of couples year in, year out, bringing with it discord and resentment where there should be sweetness and light. And, no, before you ask, it has nothing to do with sex. Agi explains all in a letter to the Kitchen Doctor: "My husband and I would like to cook and eat together, but I don't eat meat. I do eat fish, seafood and all manner of vegetables." Not too much of a quandary there, you might think, but read on: "My husband is very much a meat-eater, does not like fish, and will not touch seafood. Vegetarian dishes are usually met with a, 'Mmmm, the only thing missing is a steak'." See what I mean? That's not so much a job for the Kitchen Doctor, and more one for a miracle worker. And though both Hursts are management consultants, even their problem-solving expertise hasn't helped them find a solution. Rosie Sykes, however, loves a challenge, even one as seemingly insurmountable as this, which is how the KD crew find themselves one wet Thursday lunchtime unpacking the tools of their trade at Agi and Edward's flat in Surbiton, Surrey. Agi has to speak for both of them, as Ed is snowed under at work. "We live completely independent lives as far as food is concerned," she says. "I heat up ready meals, he makes pasta with tomato and meat sauce." Agi adds that her aversion to meat is not an ethical matter, or even one of flavour - she just can't stand the texture - so meat stocks and the like are not the complete no-nos Rosie had feared. Which is just as well, considering that her first act is to plonk a hunk of gammon in a pot, cover it with water, add herbs and veg, and bring it up to a boil. The ham will form the basis of the first dish on her latest mercy mission, a bean stew that, Rosie explains, "is a bit like a baked bean thing - only they're not actually baked". Before anyone can query her logic, she adds quickly that Ed can eat the beans with a slice or two of the ham, while Agi has them with a sort of Italian stir-fry of broccoli, anchovy and chilli. Agi, who, if truth be told, is not overly confident that Rosie can pull this one off, perks up no end. Her spirits rise even further when Rosie tells her, "It's time to get your hands dirty and make a spinach and cheese tart - and, yes, I know there's no meat in it, but surely even Ed can do without once in a while." Agi concurs, and makes short work of converting a benchtop full of spinach, eggs and cheese into a gloriously golden gloop for the tart filling. "Add some nutmeg," says Rosie after dipping her finger into the mix for a taste. "It's always a good plan with the old spinach." The KD has brought ready-made pastry (Agi and Ed's other requirement was that they wanted food that didn't take an age to prepare), so the final stages are easy as, well, pie. Half an hour later, the soup is poured into a bowl, which is placed on a plate and surrounded with sliced chicken, tiger prawns and two dipping sauces. "The idea is to share the old broth, and Ed eats his with chicken and you have tiger prawns." Agi, looking more impressed by the minute, nods happily and licks her lips, but before she can try it, Rosie comes over all concerned: "I seem to be saying 'old' a lot, in a Jamie Oliver kind of way. Instead, an embarrassed KD buttons her lip while she prepares her rather grand take on mushrooms on toast, cheering up no end as a garlicky, buttery scent fills the kitchen. "Ed's main problem with fish is the bones," explains Agi, suitably chastened. "And he detests shellfish: if it's got tentacles or a shell, it's out." The tuna should not be a problem, then, says Rosie: "The steaks are boneless, it's a really meaty fish and, to make it even more appealing to Ed, we're going to do them in a classic beef steak-style: au poivre." Agi, who by now is a slaveringconvert to the KD approach, fries the fish and makes the sauce as per Rosie's tuition and is soon tasting the fruits of her labours: "That is delicious," she declares. "It's definitely my favourite." Rosie's creations have hit the mark every time... but Agi is only one half of the problem: what of the absent Ed, who will be tasting the dishes after work? The answer came a day or so later. "We were really sceptical," said Ed. "We just couldn't see any common ground for you to work with. But I very much liked everything. I don't know how you did it." Perhaps he shouldn't have been so surprised - that's what a Kitchen Doctor is for, after all.
