"I don't think it can," says Leckridge, "but it changes the way she copes with the world, her strategies for survival. Why does a child behave aggressively, or in an attention-seeking manner? I saw a boy of 14 with attention deficit disorder, and he had been born six weeks prematurely and kept on a ventilator for weeks. If that's the way you enter life, you live with a deep unconscious knowledge that you could die at any moment. You can respond to that in two ways. You can be scared and frightened of many things, or you can react with aggression and impulsiveness, things that cause chaos around you - because those behaviours say, 'I exist, I matter, I make things happen', which is the opposite of your initial experience of life. If a remedy can deal with that primary experience, the child doesn't have to use those behaviour patterns any more."

Aggression, arson, truancy, aggressive attention deficit disorder... Unlike its Scottish counterpart, it has been here for 150 years, recalling an era when homeopathy wasn't just the preserve of new age hippies, but a second string to the allopathic bow. Here, I am shown an operating theatre where post-operative patients were healed homeopathically up until the 60s. Its wards were once full, but all it offers now is an outpatients' clinic, a homeopathic pharmacy and a handful of treatment rooms. All kinds of complementary therapies are available here, and itsenzyme potentiated desensitisation clinic - the homeopathic equivalent of immunisation - has had marked success in treating asthma, food allergies, allergic rhinitis, irritable bowel syndrome, migraine and inflammatory arthritis.

Around 25% of GPs in Scotland have had a year's postgraduate training in homeopathy. It's just a personal interest, but it's also a cultural thing. The Scots are practitioners, the Scots are pragmatic, the Scots give value for money to all - and we don't really care what other people think."

Spring is on the way, but those cold and flu viruses are still out there. And there is now a whole host of homeopathic alternatives to traditional bug-battling remedies:

Aconite From the toxic flower wolfsbane - best prescribed early on, especially when a cold starts suddenly. Take four remedies of 6C strength, one hour apart.

Allium cepa Onion - suitable for colds where the eyes and nose are streaming, especially if the nose is sensitive or itchy. Take one dose of 6C strength every four hours. Continue for 24-48 hours.

Belladonna The deadly nightshade plant - often prescribed for children with flu, especially if they have a sore throat and fever. Take a single dose of 6C strength.

Bryonia Wild hops - for dry, irritating coughs, especially in children - ideally taken in linctus form (rather than pills). Take one spoonful every four hours.

Gelsemium Yellow jasmine - for shivery, heavy sensations of the body, combined with fatigue and headache. Doses as for Allium cepa.

Ipecacuanha The root of the South American shrub ipecac - suitable for fits and spasms of coughing. Take one dose every four hours until symptoms subside.

Pulsatilla From the wind flower, a type of wood anemone - best for catarrhal colds, where the nose is blocked at night and flowing in the morning, with thick green or yellow mucus. Take one remedy of 6C strength every four hours.

Stannum metallicum Tin - for loose, rattly coughs. Doses as for pulsatilla.

Remedies used to treat psychiatric and emotional disorders:

Agaricus The bug agaric remedy used by Dr Robert Jamieson, a Glasgow GP, to treat a woman with a terror of breast cancer.

Anacardium From an oriental nut - used by Dr Anne Pettigrew, a Greenock GP, to treat a down-and-out with depression, paranoid delusions and alcohol addiction.

Arnica The mountain flower, leopard's-bane, is usually prescribed for bumps and bruises - but paediatrician Dr Bob Leckridge used it to treat a 10-year-old girl with a severe depressive disorder, who refused to walk, eat or drink. 'It's specifically for people who don't like to admit they're sick,' says Leckridge. The girl recovered.

Chamomilla The camomile flower is usually given to infants with teething pain and colic. Leckridge used it to treat a five-year-old girl with severe brain damage caused by meningitis, whose bowels wouldn't function. He also prescribed it to a girl with Williams Syndrome who had an acute sensitivity to noise. In the 19th century work Materia Medica, it is recommended for people with a 'fear of the wind'.

Stramonium Thorn apple - used by Dr Pettigrew to treat a man with insomnia, violent mood swings, anxiety attacks and paranoia.

 Homeopathic remedies, like most conventional medication, should be taken only after consultation with a qualified practitioner. If symptoms persist, consult your GP or homeopath.

Even if we ignore the slightly troubling fact that there is no chamomilla in the chamomilla, how can an essence of a plant reverse the real, concrete effects of brain damage? Leckridge would be the first to admit that there has been no physical change in his patient's brain, yet her bowel function has returned to normal as if the damaged neural network has somehow been repaired. Then again, maybe the little girl's bowel problem was the result of her irritability and low spirits, rather than the other way around - that is, what Leckridge was treating was an emotional disturbance rather than an organic one. "To me," he says, "whether a disease is organic, or functional, or psychiatric, or physical doesn't matter. Chamomilla is used to treat infant colic, so it is associated with bowel disease - but that's not the point." What he was doing at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, he says, was treating "the inner wound, the inner lesion, the inner heart" - in other words, whatever trauma makes a child behave in a certain way. One girl with microcephaly - a brain disorder - constantly bit herself until treated homeopathically. She became calmer and stopped her aggressive, animal-like gnawing. Another child, with a chromosomal abnormality called Williams Syndrome, was acutely sensitive to noise. She couldn't bear the sound of a vacuum cleaner, which made her run around the house screaming with her hands covering her ears. After taking chamomilla (suggested in the Materia Medica as a treatment for "fear of the wind"), she is unfazed by Hoovers and even by thunderstorms. Perhaps the most remarkable of Leckridge's cases is a 10-year-old girl diagnosed with a "depressive disorder" because she refused to walk, eat or drink. Over a nine-month period, she had developed what seemed like a chronic fatigue syndrome, with debilitating tiredness and pains in her stomach and legs. Repeated investigation found nothing wrong with her, so she was admitted to a psychiatric unit. "When she came to see me," says Leckridge, "she was in a wheelchair and had a tube up her nose to give her sustenance, but she hadn't drunk a drop of water in four months. She wasn't going to live very long." Listening to the girl's mother, Leckridge learned that three things had happened around Easter of the previous year. First, the girl had fallen from a tree and been concussed. Second, her grandmother had suffered a stroke in her presence and she'd phoned for an ambulance because there was no one else at home. (She was nine at the time.) Finally, her cat had died. "All three could have been traumatic," says Leckridge, "but there was something about the way the girl behaved in the room, and in how the story was told, that suggested to me the remedy arnica. It's for people who don't like to admit they're sick. They don't want to reveal that, because the real horror for them is not being healthy." A day or two after taking the remedy, the girl ripped the tube from her nose and drank a litre of fluid. After a month of taking soft food and soup and drinking normally, she walked into the children's clinic - out of her wheelchair - and was discharged from the psychiatric unit. All this sets me thinking about the potential of homeopathy as a psychiatric tool. If a single dose of arnica can stabilise a 10-year-old traumatised by her cat dying (or even, if we see it that way, a child with a stubborn temperament), why not a teenager damaged by divorce, or a truant, or an arsonist, or a delinquent who disagrees with everything his parents say? Instead of the Short Sharp Shock, what about the Long Blunt Shock? If homeopathy can calm a girl with brain damage, can it be used to change her personality? "I don't think it can," says Leckridge, "but it changes the way she copes with the world, her strategies for survival. Why does a child behave aggressively, or in an attention-seeking manner? I saw a boy of 14 with attention deficit disorder, and he had been born six weeks prematurely and kept on a ventilator for weeks. If that's the way you enter life, you live with a deep unconscious knowledge that you could die at any moment. You can respond to that in two ways. You can be scared and frightened of many things, or you can react with aggression and impulsiveness, things that cause chaos around you - because those behaviours say, 'I exist, I matter, I make things happen', which is the opposite of your initial experience of life. If a remedy can deal with that primary experience, the child doesn't have to use those behaviour patterns any more." Aggression, arson, truancy, aggressive attention deficit disorder... We have come a long way from Glasgow Homeopathic Hospital with its feng-shui gardens, aromatherapy candles and blond wood furniture - and even further from the Royal London Homeopathic Hospital, a stately Victorian building on Great Ormond Street, overlooking the leafy haven of Queen Square. Unlike its Scottish counterpart, it has been here for 150 years, recalling an era when homeopathy wasn't just the preserve of new age hippies, but a second string to the allopathic bow. Here, I am shown an operating theatre where post-operative patients were healed homeopathically up until the 60s. Its wards were once full, but all it offers now is an outpatients' clinic, a homeopathic pharmacy and a handful of treatment rooms. All kinds of complementary therapies are available here, and itsenzyme potentiated desensitisation clinic - the homeopathic equivalent of immunisation - has had marked success in treating asthma, food allergies, allergic rhinitis, irritable bowel syndrome, migraine and inflammatory arthritis. Compared with Glasgow, though, it is a poky, underfunded backwater. Why does homeopathy seem so much more dynamic north of the border? "There is a kind of axis with the academic and research work being done in the south and the hands-on, practical stuff in Scotland," says Dr Kim Jobst, a former NHS homeopath at the Glasgow hospital who now treats patients privately. Bridgeton Health Centre's Dr Jamieson disagrees: "The first bit isn't true," he says, "because there's plenty of good research being done in Scotland, too. I agree with the second part, though. Around 25% of GPs in Scotland have had a year's postgraduate training in homeopathy. It's just a personal interest, but it's also a cultural thing. The Scots are practitioners, the Scots are pragmatic, the Scots give value for money to all - and we don't really care what other people think." Spring is on the way, but those cold and flu viruses are still out there. And there is now a whole host of homeopathic alternatives to traditional bug-battling remedies: Aconite From the toxic flower wolfsbane - best prescribed early on, especially when a cold starts suddenly. Take four remedies of 6C strength, one hour apart. Allium cepa Onion - suitable for colds where the eyes and nose are streaming, especially if the nose is sensitive or itchy. Take one dose of 6C strength every four hours. Continue for 24-48 hours. Belladonna The deadly nightshade plant - often prescribed for children with flu, especially if they have a sore throat and fever. Take a single dose of 6C strength. Bryonia Wild hops - for dry, irritating coughs, especially in children - ideally taken in linctus form (rather than pills). Take one spoonful every four hours. Gelsemium Yellow jasmine - for shivery, heavy sensations of the body, combined with fatigue and headache. Doses as for Allium cepa. Ipecacuanha The root of the South American shrub ipecac - suitable for fits and spasms of coughing. Take one dose every four hours until symptoms subside. Pulsatilla From the wind flower, a type of wood anemone - best for catarrhal colds, where the nose is blocked at night and flowing in the morning, with thick green or yellow mucus. Take one remedy of 6C strength every four hours. Stannum metallicum Tin - for loose, rattly coughs. Doses as for pulsatilla. Remedies used to treat psychiatric and emotional disorders: Agaricus The bug agaric remedy used by Dr Robert Jamieson, a Glasgow GP, to treat a woman with a terror of breast cancer. Anacardium From an oriental nut - used by Dr Anne Pettigrew, a Greenock GP, to treat a down-and-out with depression, paranoid delusions and alcohol addiction. Arnica The mountain flower, leopard's-bane, is usually prescribed for bumps and bruises - but paediatrician Dr Bob Leckridge used it to treat a 10-year-old girl with a severe depressive disorder, who refused to walk, eat or drink. 'It's specifically for people who don't like to admit they're sick,' says Leckridge. The girl recovered. Chamomilla The camomile flower is usually given to infants with teething pain and colic. Leckridge used it to treat a five-year-old girl with severe brain damage caused by meningitis, whose bowels wouldn't function. He also prescribed it to a girl with Williams Syndrome who had an acute sensitivity to noise. In the 19th century work Materia Medica, it is recommended for people with a 'fear of the wind'. Stramonium Thorn apple - used by Dr Pettigrew to treat a man with insomnia, violent mood swings, anxiety attacks and paranoia.  Homeopathic remedies, like most conventional medication, should be taken only after consultation with a qualified practitioner. If symptoms persist, consult your GP or homeopath.

fields.headline: Death threat fan goes free
fields.standfirst: Singer Billie Piper still terrified by hate campaign
fields.trailText: A music fan who left chart-topper Billie Piper terrified with a barrage of "evil and savage" death threats was yesterday allowed to walk free from court.
fields.body:
A music fan who left chart-topper Billie Piper terrified with a barrage of "evil and savage" death threats was yesterday allowed to walk free from court.

Juliet Peters, 32, of Canning Town, east London, was given an 18-month prison sentenced suspended for two years, combined with a 24-month supervision order.

She had spent night after night writing abusive messages before reading them down the phone to the singer's record company. Branding her a "whore" and a "cow", Peters warned of decapitation, dismemberment, burning, flogging and shooting.

The singer's parents were also threatened with a grisly end, while her 10-year-old brother, Charlie, appeared to receive a chilling mention after an outburst of maniacal laughter.

Peters, who is unemployed, was convicted three weeks ago of five sample charges of threatening to kill the singer between 14 and 25 August last year. She was also found guilty of four similar offences aimed at the singer's father, Paul Piper, and mother, Mandy Kent.

Passing sentence Judge Brian Pryor QC said there was no doubt her behaviour had left people in fear of their lives.

Miss Piper had told the court that the messages were "scary" and the "worst thing" she had ever had to listen to. Her parents had spoken of being "totally shocked and horrified" by what they heard.

The judge said of the messages: "The obscenity and the savagery of the language used by you give a picture of intense hatred."

The judge said he had no doubt Peters knew what she was doing and that it was wrong. Doctors who examined her concluded that she suffered from neither psychiatric illness nor a treatable personality disorder.

However, the judge said that, without exception, doctors had spoken of her "social isolation .. detachment and chronic low self-esteem".

He also had to bear in mind that this was the first time she had been before a court.

In normal circumstances he would have imposed an immediate jail sentence of 18 months, but because she had already served the equivalent of a year on remand awaiting trial and because of the "exceptional circumstances" of her case nothing would be gained from her returning to a cell.

The four-day trial heard that Peters's campaign of hate began last May when she was part of a studio audience at a recording of Channel Five's weekly Pepsi Chart Show, jointly presented by Billie and the DJ Neil Fox. A few days later when Peters sat down to watch a video of the event some friends remarked that the pop star, who had been standing next to her, gave her a "sly, dirty look". Her guests treated it as a joke but for Peters it was not so easily forgotten.

She brooded over the slight for more than a week before writing a furious letter to the entertainer's fan club, heralding the vitriol that was to follow.

As the weeks passed with no sign of a reply, her anger and resentment "slowly festered", Mark Aldred, prosecuting, told the jury. Finally, in the early hours of August 14, she "boiled over".

Over the next 40 minutes she left five expletive-ridden death threats of "calculated viciousness" on an answering machine at Billie's record company, Innocent.

"She needs to be cut into little pieces," Peters said in one. "She is going to be dead."

Another warned: "I am going to kill her parents. They are going to get their heads cut off very soon."

By August 25 there had been eight more and there was also talk of shooting Billie on stage and letter-bombing her fan club and record company.

Peters admitted sending the messages but maintained that it had been a prank carried out against a background of boredom, depression and loneliness.

She told the court: "I was only joking."

Press Association

webTitle: Guide to fraud on the net alarms banks and police

fields.headline: Guide to fraud on the net alarms banks and police
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The world's first online fraud museum, offering the latest artefacts of hi-tech criminal culture, has been launched by a group of US internet security experts, to the alarm of police and banking organisations.
fields.body:
The world's first online fraud museum, offering the latest artefacts of hi-tech criminal culture, has been launched by a group of US internet security experts, to the alarm of police and banking organisations.

For a signing-on fee of $99 (£69), the guide, described by one visitor as eye-popping, explains in painstaking detail how credit card numbers can be stolen over the internet or by telephone and then used to order products online.

Alongside examples of real e-mail scams used to fool trusting web users into parting with their gold card numbers, bank account details and internet passwords, the Ad Cops exhibit includes an insider's explanation of what the combinations on different card types mean, and how to establish the credit limits and validity of the cards once the numbers have been obtained.

The information is detailed, right down to the ideal modem speed for masquerading as a trader to pilfer credit information.

Daniel Clements, president of Ad Cops, insisted that the museum was a legitimate resource, which was designed to keep online retailers and banks up to speed on the latest scams.

"Adcops' primary focus is to restore, regain, or establish profitability for the merchant. He is the one paying the bill for all net fraud."

The registration fee would act as sufficient deterrent against the would-be fraudster looking for a few lessons, he added. But British police and internet security experts yesterday criticised the site as irresponsible.

A spokeswoman for the national criminal intelligence service said: "More and more criminals are moving into counterfeit credit cards because they believe it is easy to make large amounts of money. Any information which highlights the ease of this crime could encourage people to get involved."

Matthew Whitaker, of the Credit Card Research Group, which is funded by the major UK card issuers, said: "This information certainly seems dangerous.

"Consumers are protected from fraud but this is still thieving and people have to pay for it further down the line in the form of higher card rates or charges."

Internet card fraud remains less of a problem in Britain than in the US, where the boom in online shopping has provided a fertile ground for criminals.

But even in this country, electronic fraud is on the rise; as a proportion of online retail transactions, it is more prevalent than conventional fraud is on the high street, according to industry figures.

Visa, for example, says that 47% of all complaints and disputes it receives over payment across the EU are internet-related - a statistic made more startling by the fact that only 1% of its European transactions are online.

webTitle: Boys find dissected body floating in canal

fields.headline: Boys find dissected body floating in canal
fields.trailText: Detectives are hunting a murderer who dissected the body of the victim, a woman, put the pieces in bags weighed down with bricks and tiles, and threw them in a canal.
fields.body:
Detectives are hunting a murderer who dissected the body of the victim, a woman, put the pieces in bags weighed down with bricks and tiles, and threw them in a canal.

However, not all the bags sank. A boy out fishing found some floating in the Regent's canal at Camden, north London. The 10-year-old and his two companions spotted the bags on February 19. After dragging one bag out of the canal and opening it, they were horrified to discover its contents; they are receiving counselling.

Police recovered other bags and identified the victim, whom they said had been neatly dissected by the killer. But not all the body has been found, and they fear the killer could be keeping the remaining parts as "trophies".

DNA tests identified Paula Fields, 31, a mother of two. Having moved from Liverpool three years ago, she was working as a prostitute in Stoke Newington in north London. Police believe she had a £150-a-day crack habit.

The discovery comes two months after the severed upper torso of Zoe Parker, also a prostitute, was found in the Thames at Battersea. Her lower body has not been recovered.

Miss Fields's sister, Irene, said yesterday: "Paula was the youngest sister and the baby of our family. She was young and should have had a lot of life in front of her. If anyone knows of Paula's last whereabouts or any details, no matter how small or unimportant they may think they are, I would plead with them to come forward and help us catch the killer."

Detective Chief Inspector Norman McKinlay, heading the investigation, said: "This is a truly horrific murder and we urgently need public assistance."

webTitle: Leader: Budget priority must be public services

fields.headline: A Budget for the future
fields.standfirst:
Gordon's priority must be public services

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: As Gordon Brown puts the finishing touches to his fifth budget, he can take satisfaction that he has so far proved to be - on most counts - a spectacularly successful chancellor.
fields.body:
As Gordon Brown puts the finishing touches to his fifth budget, he can take satisfaction that he has so far proved to be - on most counts - a spectacularly successful chancellor. He has managed as no other chancellor, Labour or Conservative, before him to combine fiscal prudence - reflected in a huge budget surplus - with a forensic approach to social policy that is helping the deserving poor and encouraging the non-working poor back into employment. The big idea that binds his grip on so many areas of the microeconomy is not new, but it is deadly serious. It is to increase opportunity for all: for entrepreneurs to start businesses; for people to educate and re-educate themselves; for the unemployed, including forgotten groups like single mothers, to find work; and, above all, the opportunity for the economy to expand in a sustainable way to create the wealth and tax revenues to underpin the future. It is true the chancellor inherited a benign environment of low inflation and strong public finances - including £9bn of tax increases bequeathed by the outgoing Conservatives. But things can go wrong even within a favourable climate.

There are two serious criticisms. First, he may have avoided stop-go policies for the economy as a whole, but public spending - desperately needed to improve Britain's crumbling infrastructure - actually fell in real terms during his first two years, in fulfilment of a pre-election pledge to match Tory restraint. The Conservatives admit they would never have kept to their own plans. Those two years of inactivity proved beyond doubt to the City that this iron chancellor was not made of cheap alloy. But they also delayed vital investment in education, health and transport.

Mr Brown's most important job on Wednesday is to convert the stop-go of public spending into a sustainable long-term plan that will rid this country of its rotting infrastructure. The chancellor is generally reckoned to have £3-4bn he can prudently "give away" in the budget, of which £1.7bn has already been committed in his pre-budget statement (mainly to placate the road lobby). He should not waste this on tax cuts, however much he might be tempted to throw in a pre-electoral stimulant. Consumers have already spent their way to a record trade deficit, even though - wrongly - few people seem to worry about it any more. The overwhelming priority is to provide 21st-century Britain with railways, hospitals, schools and roads. Mr Brown should pay no attention to the bleatings of the IMF that public investment should be financed entirely by tax revenues and not borrowing - a recipe which, if applied to industry, would bring expansion to a halt.

The chancellor is right to stick to his "golden rule" that spending on non-capital items should paid for out of tax revenues, but that investment, as long as it is cost effective, can be financed by borrowing. And few things are as cost-effective as education, the single factor that most determines long-term economic growth. The government has made a good start, but its aims cannot be secured without more teachers and better qualified ones, particularly in science and information technology. As part of a long-term strategy for public spending, Mr Brown should provide for regular above-norm increases for the teaching profession to restore it to the status of a quarter of a century ago. That ought to count as capital investment, because it will yield a return to the nation in future years.

The second important thing that Mr Brown should do is to address the pound. Sterling has been "strong" for so long now that people and politicians think it does not matter. Yet the years of Labour government have seen an erosion of the manufacturing base on a scale that Mr Brown and others railed against when Mrs Thatcher was in power. Company after company, from BMW to Corus, have been unable to compete because they have been handicapped by a 15 -20% price disadvantage in international markets.

What can be done? The Budget will help, if Mr Brown's plans are deemed prudent enough by the Bank of England to warrant another cut in interest rates. The government could intervene on the foreign exchanges with others. Arguably, the cheapest thing the government could do would be to declare that if it did decide to campaign to join the euro, then it would only go in if the pound was in a much lower target range. Such a move would at least tell the markets that the government has a (lower) target level in mind against which they must make their decisions.

Wednesday's budget is the first pre-electoral one taking place with an independent Bank of England setting interest rates. Mr Brown wrought this change precisely in order to prevent politicians indulging in pre-electoral bribery. The IMF's warning against more public spending, whether the chancellor likes it or not, will be one of the factors the Bank will have to consider before deciding whether the budget is prudent enough to reduce interest rates or whether it will have to raise them. At this pace of change, budgets may soon become a serious spectator sport.

The Budget will help, if Mr Brown's plans are deemed prudent enough by the Bank of England to warrant another cut in interest rates. The government could intervene on the foreign exchanges with others. Arguably, the cheapest thing the government could do would be to declare that if it did decide to campaign to join the euro, then it would only go in if the pound was in a much lower target range. Such a move would at least tell the markets that the government has a (lower) target level in mind against which they must make their decisions. Wednesday's budget is the first pre-electoral one taking place with an independent Bank of England setting interest rates. Mr Brown wrought this change precisely in order to prevent politicians indulging in pre-electoral bribery. The IMF's warning against more public spending, whether the chancellor likes it or not, will be one of the factors the Bank will have to consider before deciding whether the budget is prudent enough to reduce interest rates or whether it will have to raise them. At this pace of change, budgets may soon become a serious spectator sport.

webTitle: Scottish homes without power for fourth day

fields.headline: Snow misery
fields.standfirst:
Homes without power for fourth day

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Thousands of homes in Scotland were without electricity for a fourth day yesterday as engineers battled to restore power supplies cut off by the bad weather.
fields.body:
Thousands of homes in Scotland were without electricity for a fourth day yesterday as engineers battled to restore power supplies cut off by the bad weather.

Heavy snow and strong winds brought down power cables on Monday, leaving many communities in the Scottish Borders and the east of Scotland without heat or light.

Although engineers have been flown to remote areas by helicopter, around 10,000 homes were still without electricity yesterday and ScottishPower said it was finding it difficult to reach more remote areas.

The drifting snow has left some regions of the Borders entirely cut off and helicopters have been dropping in supplies of fuel, bread and milk to the worst affected areas.

Territorial army soldiers have also been placed on standby to help police rescue stricken motorists and residents.

A spokeswoman for ScottishPower said the company hoped to restore electricity supplies to most homes by last night.

fields.headline: £150m boost for science in north
fields.standfirst:
Daresbury projects meant to stave off technological divide

Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: The government has unveiled plans to pump millions of pounds into scientific research in the north-west of England yesterday in an attempt to stave off criticism that it was contributing to a north-south technological divide.
fields.body:
The government has unveiled plans to pump millions of pounds into scientific research in the north-west of England yesterday in an attempt to stave off criticism that it was contributing to a north-south technological divide.

Less than 12 months after the government caused fury among heartland backbench Labour MPs when it announced it would move a synchrotron science project to Oxfordshire rather than the north-west, there was finally some good news for Daresbury laboratory when the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, announced £150m of funding for the creation of a north-west science council and two new projects at Daresbury in Cheshire.

The announcement may go some way to mollifying Labour backbenchers who were furious over the government's lack of attention to a northern scientific base demanding investment.

Two projects will be set up including a fourth generation light source for accelerator physics and a proton cyclotron, which has potential medical, scientific and industrial benefits.

A £24m biopharmaceutical manufacturing facility will also be set up with £3m from the government and funding from Europe and the regional development agency.

A public/private partnership was also established to act as a bridge between Daresbury and industry to exploit its scientific expertise for the benefit of the region.

Announcing the funding, Mr Byers said: 'The north west science and Daresbury development group are to be congratulated in bringing together all the key players in the north-west and for their report which clearly demonstrates the importance of integrating science with the region's economy in the long term."

The headline figure of £150m for a lavish new science facility at Daresbury should be music to the ears of the centre's 500 staff, who faced being scattered to the winds last year after hearing that the government and the Wellcome Trust were shifting investment in their field to the south of England.

The decision to replace Daresbury's centrepiece, a massive doughnut-shaped physics instrument called a synchrotron, with a more modern version in Oxfordshire dented the credibility of Mr Byers in the north-west.

He had earlier given local unions the impression that the new synchrotron would go to Daresbury.

Daresbury management is convinced that Mr Byers genuinely wants to preserve the Cheshire site as a world-class centre of excellence in physics.

However, there is no guarantee that the minister will be able to find the £150m to build the new Centre for Accelerator Science and Imaging and Medicine (Casim), even if a review body of scientists decides later this month that the project is scientifically worthwhile.

Mr Byers is believed to have given Daresbury private assurance that they will get Casim.

"I don't know the ins and outs of where the money is going to come from," said one source at Daresbury yesterday. "That's something that, for now, I am happy to take at face value."

Mr Byers' statement yesterday only committed the government to feasibility studies into the two components of Casim, an advanced laser and another physics device called a proton cyclotron.

Tony Buckley, the chief spokesman for Daresbury, said: "Having had the minister here, we are more confident.

"I think there is a difference between what was said by the minister on his visit and what was in his press statement. The words we heard from Stephen Byers leave us feeling very confident for the future of the Daresbury laboratory.

Derek Twigg, the Labour MP for Halton, who was chairman of the consortium of north-west MPs who lobbied for the synchrotron to be moved to Daresbury, said he was delighted by the news.

"We had told the prime minister that we did not agree with the decision and we were not prepared to walk away from it," he said. "I think this shows that the north-west, by pulling together, is able to deliver."

webTitle: The inside view: Labour and the economy

fields.headline: You can bank on this government
fields.standfirst:
Labour's determination to be City friendly means its first term will warrant just a paragraph in the economic history books

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Labour's determination to be City friendly means its first term will warrant just a paragraph in the economic history books.
fields.body:
It was such a relief. New Labour was going to be all right for the London financial community. Why? Well, Clare Short didn't eat peas off her knife, that's why. At least, I think that's what was going through my colleagues' minds at the time.

The scene? The 20th floor dining rooms in Kleinwort Benson's offices at 20 Fenchurch Street. The date? Some time in late 1995, early 1996. Around the table was a cross-section of KB's bankers and brokers, plus Ms Short as representative of the expected incoming Labour administration. The subjects? Transport policy and the public finance initiative.

The lunch was one of many hosted by Kleinwort as it sought to change horses mid-gallop. Little that was said by Ms Short was controversial. However much she might have itched to do otherwise, she was scrupulously "on message" throughout. It was all that was required by the hosts. First and foremost we were looking for reassurance.

In true City style, KB had tied itself assiduously to successive Conservative governments. It usually had a Tory backbencher on the consultancy roster - and a rising star at that. Michael Portillo, in the early days of his political career, was one. In my day, David Willetts wrote an insightful weekly piece on politics that was distributed around the bank. His name was not attached but his authorship was an open secret.

As the seams of the Major government gave way, so the Kleinwort board turned its thoughts to the incoming regime. For months it harboured hopes that a "tame" New Labourite could be found to take the place of the outgoing Tory. David Willetts had been promoted to junior ministerial rank and thus, conveniently, a vacancy existed.

In retrospect, this hope was laughable. Nevertheless, I lunched Andrew Smith and then Geoff Hoon. Others no doubt fulfilled their roles in the search process.

For my part, the lunches were like soufflés - momentarily pleasant but essentially insubstantial. I have no doubt, however, that taken together, they built the foundation of a relationship between the bank and Labour that has since proved useful.

Four years into Labour governance and, with its renewal impending, I am still amazed at just how little Tony Blair's administration has ruffled City feathers. In part this must be a result of the mutual schmoozing both "sides" invested in ahead of the last election. However, it is also a consequence of Labour's conservative approach.

When economic historians write their analyses of Britain in the late second and early third millenniums they will devote one long chapter and one very short paragraph to the first Blair government.

The long chapter will tell the tale of the monetary policy committee, the introduction of which was - for Britain - truly radical. The short paragraph will read something like this:

"The UK economy continued its steady recovery from the early 1990s traumas of recession and sterling's exit from the ERM. Economic growth allowed the Treasury to run a budget surplus. The basic structures of the micro-economy, substantially reworked under Thatcher, remained unchanged."

There can be little doubt that the introduction of the MPC was bold. Some have argued the opposite - that the chancellor was abrogating responsibility for interest rates, thereby ensuring he would never be blamed for monetary policy mistakes. However, politicians - and chancellors in particular - are control freaks. Gordon Brown will not have ceded the interest rate weapon lightly.

Emboldened by the success of the MPC, the chancellor has set out his stall as a man of prudence, unwilling to squander the growth dividend that has accrued to the public purse.

However, at the same time he has spurned the opportunity afforded by his government's popular mandate to try anything radical within the workings of the economy.

Keys to Downing Street

The Labour government should collectively stand accused of possessing lily livers. It may be that his colleagues are cowed by Gordon Brown's towering economic intellect and demeanour to match. But while that may be an explanation, it is not an excuse.

Now, four days away from the Budget and maybe five weeks from the announcement of a general election, the time for radicalism is past - or at best postponed. What the chancellor is likely to announce this week is the budget of a man who values his reputation for prudence, but not as much as he values his keys to Downing Street.

This week's spat between the Treasury and the IMF about the leaked conclusions of the latter's analysis of British economic policy has been highly amusing.

The Treasury was mightily irked at the suggestion that imprudent government spending posed a threat to sterling and interest rates.

The timing for the Chancellor could not have been worse, intent as he must be on currying favour with the electorate without damaging his scrupulously nurtured image. But if all Gordon Brown has to worry about this close to an election is the opinion of an organisation with an average forecasting record then he is a very fortunate chancellor indeed.

Perhaps Labour will rediscover its radicalism over the next five years, thereby testing the roots of its relationship with the financial establishment. Somehow I doubt it.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: $43m Cruise has no need of cash control

fields.headline: $43m Cruise has no need of cash control
fields.trailText: His marriage to Nicole Kidman may be over but yesterday it became clear that last year Tom Cruise had something else to keep him warm at night: 43m other things, to be precise.
fields.body:
His marriage to Nicole Kidman may be over but yesterday it became clear that last year Tom Cruise had something else to keep him warm at night: 43m other things, to be precise.

Forbes magazine revealed that in 2000 Cruise took home an estimated $43m. And not content with mere income-generation alone, he also had the greatest increase in media exposure of any star.

In short: he is the richest and most famous person in Tinseltown.

This has prompted Forbes to bestow the diminutive but uncommonly wealthy actor with a catchy title. For 2001 at least, Cruise will be known as "the most powerful celebrity on the planet".

"Not only did Cruise earn much more money in 2000 than in 1999 ($27m), but his media exposure increased dramatically," Forbes said. In 2000 Cruise racked up 11 cover stories and 139,000 web hits, as against one cover story and 27,000 web hits in 1999.

But he should not, according to the magazine, rest on his laurels. In a uniquely Hollywood perversion of the axiom about money not being able to buy you love, the magazine is worried that without love Cruise may lose out on money.

As he prepares to battle with Kidman in the divorce courts, the magazine frets about the effect on his star status and income-generating prowess. "How much of that will he be able to keep after his divorce is finalised?" it worries.

He has stiff competition, too, in the opulence league. The next person after Cruise in the Forbes celebrity power rankings is the man who made golf an acceptable sport for the young: Tiger Woods.

Last year Woods, who won the millennium British Open at St Andrews, took in $9m in prize money. But this was a mere trifle compared to his sponsorship deal. For sporting the Nike swoosh - and doing the odd advert - over the next five years, Woods will be paid $100m.

Surprisingly, considering they disbanded some 31 years ago, the Beatles also made it into the league. With an income of $70m from their back catalogue and the "One" compilation album of their UK number one singles, the Fab Four were the only British entry on the list.

But if the Beatles proved that being no-longer-productive rock stars is no barrier to wealth and power, there was also proof that being a young pop star at the peak of your career can prove bountiful too.

The world's most famous virgin, Britney Spears, was, at 19, the youngest person on the list. She made $38.5m from her singing career last year.

fields.headline: Counted out
fields.trailText:
You state that if this year's census were postponed, it would be the first time in peacetime (Ministers may delay census, March 1). In 1921 the census was postponed from April 24 to June 19 because of industrial unrest. Since schedules had been distributed, an amendment slip was produced showing the revised date. For the first time, advertising was permitted on the back - for the Sunday Illustrated, a venture by Horatio Bottomley MP, soon afterwards exposed as a swindler and a fraud. No advertising on census material has been allowed since.
Audrey Collins
London
Audrey@kenaud.dircon.co.uk

fields.headline: Hip talk
fields.trailText: Dave Hill's article on The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in Black Communities (Straight talking, G2, March 1) reeks of middle-class scorn. Black men don't wear those baggy, draping trousers as a "...throwback to black male prostitutes of the 40s who wore them to assist easy access for their clients". Those pants are worn as a badge of identity: "I'm here and I'm not the Invisible Man." Also hip hop's roots are not gay. Hip hop, like the blues, is music for the working class. It was formed in response to capitalist oppression in the suburbs.
fields.body:
Dave Hill's article on The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in Black Communities (Straight talking, G2, March 1) reeks of middle-class scorn. Black men don't wear those baggy, draping trousers as a "...throwback to black male prostitutes of the 40s who wore them to assist easy access for their clients". Those pants are worn as a badge of identity: "I'm here and I'm not the Invisible Man." Also hip hop's roots are not gay. Hip hop, like the blues, is music for the working class. It was formed in response to capitalist oppression in the suburbs.

Fierce masculinity within black men is a form of celebration. Black families are, on the whole, quite big. His nation is far away and here is something of his own. Anything that may undermine that from the outside, eg homosexuality, should be condemned - because that suggests there are other things outside of the family. This is why the priest and the musician are wary of gays. Not because they are supressing feminine emotions.
Austin Collings
London
austin@hyena.co.uk

 In context, Richard Blackwood's reference to the Queen as a bitch on Have I Got News for You, was amusing (Women, G2, March 1). Less so was the PCC's adjudication that bitch is "acceptable street slang for a woman". I would defend the right of black people to decide on appropriate language to describe their race. Similarly, I would be grateful if the PCC would note that this woman does not regard the expression bitch as an acceptable synonym for woman.
Helen Atkinson
London

fields.headline: LA story
fields.trailText:
Jenny Colgan claims (Look out LA, here I come, G2, February 27) there are no bus stops in Los Angeles. One of the great bus journeys in the world is the ride from Downtown along the Santa Monica Boulevard to Santa Monica, from where you walk north along the beach from the pier, with the Pacific rolling in on your left towards the mountains, to the end of Sunset Boulevard at Malibu, where you can bus the 22 miles back to Downtown. Each journey costs 90c cents, approximately 50p. Driving the freeways isolates you from the reason why there are 11m people there, and why this city was inhabited from the midwest, rather than from the sea.
Sheila Bull
London sbjc@pprd.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Modernism is history
fields.trailText: James Meek (Things fall apart, G2, March 1) seems under the impression that "complexity" is a new phenomenon, inherent only to the "modernist" British society of the year 2001.
fields.body:
James Meek (Things fall apart, G2, March 1) seems under the impression that "complexity" is a new phenomenon, inherent only to the "modernist" British society of the year 2001.

However, if one looked back to our society in the 1800s one would find exactly the same situation, fantastic new technological inventions rapidly appearing, new discoveries in the natural sciences, visionaries such as IK Brunel pioneering spectacular building projects. Even the sewage system is given as an element in today's matrix of complexity, yet a vast majority of that was built over 100 years ago.

Every age is going to think itself the exemplar of modernity and technological innovation, just as surely as it will be displaced by history. The problems affecting "modernist Britain" are less to do with complexity per se than other more pernicious factors which have become deeply ingrained in our society: short-term thinking and planning, profiteering at the expense of all else, lack of regard for our natural resources. Much of the sense of horror at many of the recent catastrophes that have befallen our nation comes from public awareness of having been complicit in their making, from turning a blind eye to horrific practices in agriculture to voting, year in year out, for penny-pinching tax-cutting governments while our transport infrastructure atrophies before our eyes.

Things are indeed complex, but it was ever thus, and with many of these problems we are merely reaping the whirlwind.
Eugene Brazil

webTitle: Letters: Sledging on a sticky wicket

fields.headline: Sledging on a sticky wicket
fields.trailText: Reading Harry Pearson's piece (Curtains out in the matter of sledge with edge, February 27), I suddenly realise how much I am missing out on when watching broadcast Test matches or listening to commentaries. I never hear the sledging! If it is such a vital part of the game, and if we can have "clickometers", cameras in the stumps and rugby referees wired for sound, surely it is time that all the cricketers be similarly miked up so that we can all appreciate the finer points of this art?
fields.body:
Reading Harry Pearson's piece (Curtains out in the matter of sledge with edge, February 27), I suddenly realise how much I am missing out on when watching broadcast Test matches or listening to commentaries. I never hear the sledging! If it is such a vital part of the game, and if we can have "clickometers", cameras in the stumps and rugby referees wired for sound, surely it is time that all the cricketers be similarly miked up so that we can all appreciate the finer points of this art?

We will then be able to introduce awards to be given to the "Sledger of the Match", "Sledger of the Series", Wisden's "Sledger of the Year" etc, which can only add to the interest of this absorbing game.

I look forward to the time when all cricket sides as a matter of routine follow Scotland's example and include a sledging coach alongside the batting and bowling coaches, the physios and the sports psychologists which the modern sport requires. And if the quoted example "you've got more edges than a broken piss-pot" is the best that British sledging can offer, it might not be a bad idea to include the odd script writer too. (Maybe one of the Lord's Taverners might oblige.)

Finally, a question which I would address to your cricket journalists. What is the ideal balance between the number of batsmen, seamers, sledgers and spinners in a side and where should the sledgers be placed in the batting order?
Geoff Pogson
Gillingham, Dorset
geoff.pogson@talk21.com

fields.headline: The bandits bite back
fields.trailText: I take issue with your statement on Financial Services Authority plans to force journalists tipping shares to declare their interest (Notebook, March 2) that "the Treasury and the FSA are not really gunning for the national press. The real problem lies with bandit tip sheets and alleged investment websites which claim journalistic privilege, but which are not tied to the industry code of practice".
fields.body:
I take issue with your statement on Financial Services Authority plans to force journalists tipping shares to declare their interest (Notebook, March 2) that "the Treasury and the FSA are not really gunning for the national press. The real problem lies with bandit tip sheets and alleged investment websites which claim journalistic privilege, but which are not tied to the industry code of practice".

It is newspapers that have the special exemption, not websites and tip sheets. Anybody giving investment advice has to be regulated by the FSA or one of its subsidiary bodies - except newpapers (and one or two other exceptions). Our website is regulated by the Securities and Futures Authority. As the editor, I have had to become a registered person, as have other members of my team. We are thus tasked to a stricter regime than the press. Trust me: the Press Complaints Commission has nothing on the SFA. We already have to disclose any interest. We in fact go further than the SFA demands and a lot further than any newspaper.

The stringency sometimes goes too far: websites have been forced to stop reprinting Sunday newspaper tips (which may well be inherently unreliable - a dartboard-led stock pick is beating four of your colleagues on the weekend press, as detailed in the Editor). Tip sheets, too, are regulated, by the Personal Investment Authority and have to uphold a high standard of disclosure and research.

The impetus behind this move almost certainly came from the City Slickers scandal. If any "alleged investment website" were to do what that national newspaper's tipsters and editor did, we might have incurred financial penalties and could well have been closed down. What, one asks, has happened to the Mirror?
Matt Getz
Editor, UK-iNvest.com
MGetz@glbn.co.uk

fields.headline: Alliance gets my vote
fields.trailText:
It is not the electorate that is suffering a "decline in the willingness ... to participate" (Ballot blues, March 1), more that those in government are unwilling to provide a democratic choice worth participating in. I, as someone of the left who is not at all "apathetic", no longer have a corresponding voice in mainstream politics worth backing.
Tom Greatorex
Derby

fields.headline: Denial follows Borneo massacre wake
fields.standfirst:
Accused Indonesian official says he was hostage of bloodthirsty Dayak mob

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Accused Indonesian official says he was hostage of bloodthirsty Dayak mob
fields.body:
The Indonesian government official accused of coordinating the massacre of 118 refugees trying to flee marauding gangs of indigenous Dayaks in Borneo has vehemently denied the charge, despite claims by witnesses that he appeared to be directing the brutal slaughter.

Muhammed Yasin, the chief of Kuala Kuayan, a village deep in the jungle of Central Kalimantan, admitted to the Guardian that he had travelled with some of the 60-strong gang who killed the migrants from the island of Madura in the town of Parenggean.

Mr Yasin insisted, however, that not only had he nothing to do with the executioners, he was in fact their hostage.

When the gang arrived in Parenggean they hijacked a convoy of trucks that was evacuating about 400 Madurese, chased off its six police officers, and took 118 refugees to a school playing field and butchered them with machetes and spears.

It was the worst incident in a two-week orgy of ethnic violence that has officially left more than 500 people dead, and possibly twice this, all but a handful of whom were descendants of or migrants from the island or Madura.

The tens of thousands of Madurese who survived have fled the province, many with vicious wounds, and with only the clothes that they were wearing.

"It's a complete lie to suggest that I had anything to do with the slaughter in Parenggean," Mr Yasin said. "The people spreading these rumours are provocateurs." He said he left Kuala Kuayan before the gang, but that they overtook him and his wife while on the road.

"They bullied and threatened me to go along with them," he said. "They killed people on the road and I feared they were going to harm us. So when we got to Parenggean I sought protection from the officials there."

His version of events is at odds with the reports of witnesses in both Kuala Kuayan and Parenggean.

A neighbourhood chief in Kuala Kuayan, for instance, believes that Mr Yasin organised it all.

"[Yasin] said he got a phone call from Parenggean [on the Sunday morning] telling him that the Dayaks there needed help to 'sort out' the Madurese," Armili Madras said. "So six vehicles left under the command of Mr Yasin."

The next thing Mr Madras knew was when one of the drivers came back many hours later with three human heads in his car, saying they were from the massacre in Parenggean. That driver has gone into hiding, as have all the other people from Kuala Kuayan allegedly involved in the killing.

Mr Madras said he finds the phone call theory hard to believe, claiming that Mr Yasin does not have a telephone at his home and that the Dayaks in Parenggean had agreed that morning to give the authorities five days to evacuate the Madurese.

"What's more, the village police chief here said his counterpart in Parenggean said no one called Kuala Kuayan for Mr Yasin that morning." He alleged that at the time there was only one working telephone in Parenggean.

Udin, a local government official in Parenggean who witnessed the arrival of the gang and the execution, said he saw Mr Yasin play a prominent role. "I never saw him actually kill anyone but he seemed to be directing events at the start," he said. "He brought the people and he was ordering them around."

Mr Udin's boss, sub-district chief Rukmana Priyatna, said that after Mr Yasin had directed the heavily armed Dayaks as to what to do he went off and prepared their food, as if not wanting to be seen to be playing too prominent a role.

"He never asked me for protection at any time," Mr Priyatna said.

Mr Yasin's friends and neighbours in Kuala Kuayan were eager to rush to his defence, however. "He was here with us in Kuala Kuayan," said one man who asked not to be named.

"He wouldn't have done anything like that," Manarung, one of Mr Yasin's work colleagues, said. "He even helped organise the evacuation of refugees from this sub-district."

In the interview, Mr Yasin appeared to be a man of mixed emotions. With one breath he went out of his way to extol his love of all Indonesia's hundreds of ethnic groups: "We are all one nation in one country under one flag. People should have the right to live anywhere."

Yet his next words claimed the Madurese would never again be welcome in Kuala Kuayan: "We can't have them back," he said. "They just cause too many problems. Over land disputes, by carrying weapons, and [by] never apologising or admitting their mistakes."

Another villager, Armin Effendi, said: "He should at least be investigated."

The Indonesian police, however, have shown no signs of even beginning to investigate or search for the perpetrators of the massacre, let alone the hundreds of other killings.

"We haven't received any orders to do anything," Sergeant Abdul Rahman said in Parenggean. "And, as far as I'm aware, no special team has been set up to probe the massacre."

In Parenggean, meanwhile, the school football pitch remains littered with blood-stained shoes, ripped belts, scrawled verses from the Koran written in a child's exercise book and soiled family photos.

webTitle: Letters: The regions take a lead

fields.headline: The regions take a lead
fields.trailText: Although it was nice to see the old warhorse of city regions being given a fresh airing (Leader, March 1), it was a shame that England's historic regions were given such short shrift. Evidence from continental Europe shows that a strong regional tier of government is necessary for balanced economic development.
fields.body:
Although it was nice to see the old warhorse of city regions being given a fresh airing (Leader, March 1), it was a shame that England's historic regions were given such short shrift. Evidence from continental Europe shows that a strong regional tier of government is necessary for balanced economic development.

We will not close the north-south divide until more power is devolved from London and Whitehall. This isn't just because regional assemblies are able to "bat" strongly on behalf of their cities and regions, but more because a region is able to support clusters of highly qualified manpower, to be an effective presence on the international stage and to raise the level of decision-making within the private sector.

Economic growth is being held back by the chaotic mish-mash of bodies at regional level. Bringing these together and forging an overarching strategy will help create the right conditions for the renewal of regional economies - sensible and streamlined planning guidance, workable transport plans, a highly trained workforce and region-wide policies for the arts, culture, agriculture and tourism.
John Adams
Campaign for the English Regions
london@cfer.org.uk

 Successful provincial cities in France and elsewhere in Europe have had for many years the benefits of decentralised, devolved and democratically accountable regional government, as well as strong city and very local government. Such arrangements exist now, in part, in Scotland, Wales and Ireland, whose cities also seem to have performed much better than those in England.

What we need is not a divisive debate about boundaries, but a real commitment to democratically accountable regional government across the whole of England. This could provide the real political clout, resources and vision that are really needed to address the problems and potential of all parts of England - urban and rural - and which most of continental Europe has had the benefit of for many years.
George Morran
Aston University
gmorran@aol.com

 Though controlled by two different parties, Lib Dem Liverpool and Labour Manchester are developing a new relationship which will enable us to act jointly as the powerhouse for the north-west. There are regular meetings between the two council leaders and increased cooperation through the regional development agency on issues such as housing, transport, employment and education.

Two weeks ago representatives of the five northern core cities and seven northern housing associations met to consider housing problems. We agreed to act as the voice of the north in pressing for an understanding of our problems and for the resources to deal with them.

Liverpool, Manchester, Sheffield, Leeds and Newcastle are major economic entities in their own right, and increasingly we are adopting the city region structure you suggest. This is the new reality of the north. We already accept the challenge of regional leadership, but need increased recognition of what we are doing and the assistance that we require to do it properly.
Cllr Richard Kemp
Liverpool city council

 Three city regions for Tyneside, Wearside and Teeside? But none of these conurbations has the population base to make regional government practical. This solution also leaves out "rural" Northumberland and County Durham, where many towns still face deprivation following the pit and steelworks closures. The real answer for the north-east and the other English regions is dynamic, coherent, directly elected government for the whole region, not a patchwork of half-baked city regions.
Geraldine Ormonde
Newcastle upon Tyne

webTitle: US shifts its focus from Israel to Iraq

fields.headline: US shifts its focus from Israel to Iraq
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Iraq
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Bush administration plans to unveil the outlines of its new US policy towards Iraq within the next two weeks, setting the groundwork for tighter, but more focused, UN-backed "smart" sanctions against Saddam Hussein's regime.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
The Bush administration plans to unveil the outlines of its new US policy towards Iraq within the next two weeks, setting the groundwork for tighter, but more focused, UN-backed "smart" sanctions against Saddam Hussein's regime.

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, will set out the key themes of American policy in a public statement before the Arab summit in Amman at the end of March.

Mr Powell wants to build on a notably conciliatory tour of the region last week by ensuring that the Amman summit focuses on how to contain Iraq and does not become a rallying point against last month's US-British bombing.

The new US administration is signalling that Iraq - not Palestine - is at the centre of its Middle East policy, and that a fresh drive to isolate President Saddam's regime without hurting the Iraqi population is its most immediate goal.

"It's a thing that could go wrong early in the administration, so the Americans want to put it right as soon as possible," a British diplomatic source said yesterday.

It is thought, however, that it will be difficult to persuade Iraq's neighbours to monitor their common borders with the recalcitrant country more closely. Washington's efforts to do so will focus on Jordan, Syria and Turkey, all of which have been used to circumvent international monitoring of Iraqi imports and exports.

"You have to be confident that they are real controls not paper controls, and it is complicated when you are seeking to control a select list of items not everything," a senior official said yesterday.

During Mr Powell's trip to the Middle East he was said to have secured promises from Syria's president, Bashar al-Assad, that the revenue from Iraqi oil exports routed through Syria would now be placed under UN supervision.

Syria, however, is only likely to take such action if Jordan and Turkey can also be persuaded to do so.

The new approach towards sanctions against Iraq unites the Bush administration's hawks and doves. The Pentagon chief, Donald Rumsfeld, and his deputy, Paul Wolfowitz, are longtime supporters of active US efforts to promote the overthrow of President Saddam by military and other aid to the Iraqi opposition.

However, diplomats said Mr Sharon's Likud party would be wrong to assume there will be no pressure on Israel to seek a peaceful end to the Palestinian uprising and to resume negotiations for a final settlement.

fields.trailText: The transport research laboratory, referred to in a report headed Driver denies being asleep at the wheel, page 5, yesterday, is in Crowthorne, Berkshire, not Crawthorne, North Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The transport research laboratory, referred to in a report headed Driver denies being asleep at the wheel, page 5, yesterday, is in Crowthorne, Berkshire, not Crawthorne, North Yorkshire.

In a panel listing events that have been, or could be, postponed because of foot and mouth disease restrictions, we included the following: "Britain's oldest horse race, the Derby, faces cancellation for only the second time in its 480-year history." The Derby is not Britain's oldest horse race. Britannica.com, pointing out that the modern age of racing began with the inauguration of the English classic races, lists them in the following order: the St Leger, 1776; the Oaks, 1779; the Derby, 1780 (all of them falling a long way short of 480 years of age).

fields.headline: Arrest Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Here is a chance to stop him in his tracks

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe is due to visit the European commission in Brussels on Monday before travelling to Paris the following day for a meeting with President Jacques Chirac. This is a good opportunity to arrest him.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe is due to visit the European commission in Brussels on Monday before travelling to Paris the following day for a meeting with President Jacques Chirac. This is a good opportunity to arrest him.

Mr Mugabe has a strong prima facie case to answer; and there is justification for such action in terms of law and current international treaties. When Poul Nielson, the Danish development commissioner, sits down to lunch with his guest, he should ask for starters what Mr Mugabe makes of this week's US state department condemnation of his egregious, systematic abuse of human rights. "Significant intimidation by the ruling party and security forces", "a government-sanctioned campaign of violence", "frequent refusal to abide by court decisions", and "serious human rights abuses" including "killings, torture and beatings" are some of the phrases that jump out. For main course, Mr Nielson should demand to know why Mr Mugabe is still blocking publication of the findings of two commissions of inquiry into the 1982-87 Matabeleland massacres which occurred when he was in charge and in which up to 20,000 people died. A Zimbabwe supreme court ruling last July that Mr Mugabe should come clean has been ignored. For afters, Mr Nielson might ask whether Mr Mugabe would agree that his frequent inflammatory statements, his incitement of racial hatred, and the consequential deaths last year of over 31 people amount to personal criminal culpability on his part.

Although the EU is committed to a "critical dialogue" with the Zanu-PF regime, the commission would have been better advised to deny Mr Mugabe this status-enhancing personal visit. It says that since Zimbabwe is not under UN or EU sanctions, there is nothing abnormal about the get-together. On the contrary, there is nothing normal about this man or his recent and past actions. Rather than being given the red carpet, he should be helping the Belgian police with some of the above inquiries.

Mr Chirac, too, has good reason to be ashamed of himself. This is one smartypants Parisian démarche too far. But if he insists on going ahead with Tuesday's meeting, he should ask how Mr Mugabe squares his repressive policies with key UN covenants on political, civil, social and cultural rights which his regime signed in May, 1991. What about the UN's basic principles protecting judicial independence? What about the UN convention on racial discrimination (which Mr Mugabe also signed)? Since Zimbabwe's own constitution is now as degraded as his reputation, Mr Mugabe should be asked to explain why his flagrant disregard for common standards and binding treaties should not now be the subject of judicial inquiry, perhaps both civil and criminal, here in Europe.

Sadly, neither Mr Chirac nor Mr Nielson are likely to call for the cops. And in response to a civil suit filed by four of his victims in New York, Mr Mugabe applied this week for US immunity. As a serving head of state, he no doubt believes that immunity will apply elsewhere, too, and that he can thus escape Pinochet's fate. But legal experts say that is no bar, for example, to concerned French or Belgian citizens asking an examining magistrate to detain Mr Mugabe when he arrives in their countries pending inquiries into his alleged complicity in crimes against humanity in Matabeleland and the ongoing flouting of international law by the regime he heads. It may not work. But given the stakes, it is surely worth a try.

webTitle: Zimbabwe's chief judge to quit after threats

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's chief judge to quit after threats
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's embattled white chief justice finally agreed to take early retirement yesterday after extracting an assurance from the government that it would not embark on an immediate purge of the judges who have incurred Robert Mugabe's wrath.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Harare and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's embattled white chief justice finally agreed to take early retirement yesterday after extracting an assurance from the government that it would not embark on an immediate purge of the judges who have incurred Robert Mugabe's wrath.

The compromise deal came as a diplomatic row threatened to erupt in Europe over Mr Mugabe's planned meeting with a European Union commissioner in Brussels, with the Belgian prime minister Guy Verhofstadt on Monday and with President Jacques Chirac in Paris on Tuesday.

In Zimbabwe, sceptics question the value of the signed agreement between Anthony Gubbay, the 68-year-old chief justice, and the justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa.

The deal was signed several hours after Mr Gubbay received a visit from one of the most notorious leaders of the "war veterans", Joseph Chinotimba, who openly threatened him with violence.

"I talked to him personally and I told him to vacate the office today. No one is above the law," Mr Chinotimba said afterwards. "We ought to teach him how cases are finalised here. We will declare war."

Earlier this week, Mr Gubbay withdrew an agreement to take early retirement in July after the justice minister announced that he intended to appoint a government supporter as the new chief justice.

Mr Mugabe is keen for Mr Gubbay's chosen successor, Godfrey Chikausikyu, to set up a tribunal to hear accusations of misconduct against judges who ruled that the government's seizures of white-owned farms is illegal.

The first targets are expected to be the other four supreme court judges and several high court judges who are likely to rule against the government if, as expected, it tries to raise legal barriers against the opposition in the looming presidential election.

Under yesterday's agreement, Mr Gubbay will retire in July and go on immediate leave. An interim chief justice - Mr Chikausikyu, it is presumed - will be appointed but Mr Gubbay will be able, technically, to block any purge of other judges until July.

In Brussels yesterday, the European commission was forced to defend a controversial decision taken unilaterally by Poul Nielson, the EU's development and humanitarian aid commissioner, to have lunch with Mr Mugabe on Monday.

The lunch has already been condemned by the Zimbabwean opposition, but Brussels signalled that it would not back down. Gunnar Wiegand, a commission spokesman, said that there were no sanctions in force against Zimbabwe to prevent a meeting.

"We will soon start a critical dialogue with Harare and it is very normal under those circumstances that Nielson [the EU's development and humanitarian aid commissioner] would meet the president."

Bizarrely, the commission's weekly calendar, which always records any meetings with heads of state, omitted to mention the lunch. Mr Wiegand denied that this was deliberate.

A source told the Guardian that Mr Nielson would, nevertheless, express his alarm at the treatment of the media and the judiciary on Monday.

"Mugabe is not a nice guy but there are worse. When UN sanctions were still in place on Libya people were queueing up to meet Gadafy. The fact is that Mugabe is in power and has been elected and the commission has to deal with him.."

There were signs yesterday afternoon, however, that Mr Verhofstadt, might be getting cold feet. A spokeswoman at his private office said that no decision had yet been taken. However, the political counsellor at Zimbabwe's Brussels embassy said the meeting would happen.

webTitle: Italian Bishops reject mobile phone masts on churches

fields.headline: Church bells toll for Italy's mobile phone masts
fields.trailText: Church towers should be reserved for communications between God and the faithful and cannot be used to host mobile telephone masts, the Italian Bishops' Conference announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Church towers should be reserved for communications between God and the faithful and cannot be used to host mobile telephone masts, the Italian Bishops' Conference announced yesterday.

Italy has an estimated 100,000 churches and, with 40m users, more mobile phone owners than any other country in Europe, so church towers seemed a heaven-sent opportunity for the telecommunications industry.

But a circular signed by Monsignor Ennio Antonelli, secretary general of the Italian Bishops' Conference, will restore the cross to uncluttered pre-eminence on religious buildings throughout the country.

Use of church buildings for purposes unconnected with religion would violate church law and could jeopardise the fiscal exemptions and other privileges granted to churches by the Italian state, Mgr Antonelli's directive said.

"Any permanent use, even partial, of a religious building for reasons unrelated to its principal purpose would not only violate canon law but could also jeopardise its special civic status," he warned.

The bishop also pointed out that it would be imprudent to compromise the unique meaning and visibility of Christian symbols in an increasingly multicultural society.

Mobile phone masts are deemed to be "alien to the sanctity" of churches and those that have already been installed must be dismantled, the bishops' circular says.

From now on, the towers will return to their traditional form of acoustic communications: the old-fashioned pealing of bells.

webTitle: Rape case could be Pitcairn's first trial in 200 years

fields.headline: Rape case could be Pitcairn's first trial in 200 years
fields.trailText: A case of alleged rape is poised to tear apart the isolated island of Pitcairn, one of the last remaining outposts of Britain's empire.
fields.body:
A case of alleged rape is poised to tear apart the isolated island of Pitcairn, one of the last remaining outposts of Britain's empire.

The island's 44 inhabitants, most of whom are descended from the mutineers who escaped from the Bounty, will hear within weeks whether Pitcairn's public prosecutor, a New Zealand lawyer, is to press charges.

If the case goes ahead, the island could see the first criminal trial in its 200-year history. Pitcairn has a courthouse but it has never been used and lifejackets are stored in its three jail cells. Lawyers, court officials and officers of the Kent constabulary, who are responsible for policing the island, would have to undertake the hazardous journey to Pitcairn, flying to Fiji and then travelling by ship to the island. Pitcairn has no harbour so the final part of the journey involves climbing down the side of the ship into a long boat for the last mile to the shore. The costs would be met by the British government.

A previous allegation of rape five years ago was dropped after a lengthy investigation by Kent police, led by Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, who is also in charge of this case.

According to reports at the time, the police were disturbed by crime levels on the island, although the Foreign Office has been at pains since then to defend Pitcairn's reputation.

Dea Birkett, the author of Serpent in Paradise, an account of the four months she spent on Pitcairn, said the one and a half mile long island was a strange mixture of conformity and repressed hostility. "There are no locked doors, but there's always the possibility that you could be pushed off the edge of a cliff in some kind of violent feud."

Britain administers the island through its high commission in New Zealand and the trial could be held in Wellington, but there is concern about how islanders would react to being removed from their isolated community and exposed to the glare of media publicity. Pitcairn is 3,000 miles from New Zealand, halfway to Peru, and few of the young people who leave ever return.

The Foreign Office said yesterday it had not yet decided whether any trial would be held in New Zealand or Pitcairn.

The Kent team has been investigating the case for nearly a year, making several trips to the island to interview the inhabitants. The alleged rape took place in December 1999 and was reported to Pitcairn's governor, the British high commissioner in Wellington, by the island's resident policewoman, an officer on secondment from Kent.

Pitcairn's stamps used to be popular with collectors, enabling the island to subsidise its electricity costs, but as collecting has fallen out of fashion, revenues have dropped as well.
