webTitle: 'They say the law can burn in hell...'

fields.headline: 'They say the law can burn in hell...'
fields.standfirst:
Harare seizes control of judicial system as diplomatic storm brews in European Union over meetings with Mugabe

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Harare seizes control of judicial system as diplomatic storm brews in European Union over meetings with Mugabe.
fields.body:
Agrippa Mukando was walking near Robert Mugabe's official residence on Monday when soldiers guarding the grounds leapt on the 63-year-old gardener and accused him of being an opposition supporter. They beat him as they beat several others that day.

In many African countries the all-too-common victims of assaults by soldiers consider themselves lucky to escape with their lives. They would laugh off any suggestion that they go to the police; that would just invite more trouble.

But in a telling act of faith in what remains of the rule of law in Zimbabwe, Mr Mukando headed for Harare central police station and laid charges. Other victims did the same.

The complaints are not likely to come to anything; the police are now too deeply compromised by their failure to stop the violence unleashed by Mr Mugabe's "war veterans" and other thugs.

In much of Africa, the rule of law long ago ceased to be more than a meaningless phrase. Due process was sacrificed to the arbitrary decisions of the powerful. Zimbabwe stands on the edge of that abyss.

As Mr Mukando demonstrated, some Zimbabweans still have faith in the judicial process, although the courts are more trusted than the police, but it is being eroded by the week.

The Harare township of Chitungwiza is living in terror of armed thugs unleashed by the government. Sometimes it is the army on the rampage, sometimes it is men too young to have fought Ian Smith's regime but who still call themselves veterans. Their tactics are not always the same but their intent is.

The gangs burst into bars and night clubs, forcing revellers to lie on the floor. Anyone giving a hint of supporting the opposition is singled out for a severe beating. The rest are forced to sing songs in praise of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF, and the liberation war.

Charity Gwanzura did not even have to leave her home to become a target.

"I was sitting in my house and I looked up and there was a soldier standing there," she said. "I didn't understand at first. I thought maybe he was looking for someone or wanted some water. I was about to speak when he smashed his foot down on my table. I couldn't run because he was between me and the door, and then he started hitting me. He never said a word."

It did not take long for the soldier to get bored with beating Mrs Gwanzura. All along the street, doors were kicked in and furniture smashed. When the sound of breaking wood stopped, the screams began. Men were hauled into the streets and forced to pledge support to Robert Mugabe and to sing songs praising him. Then the army left as fast as it arrived.

The army and war veterans are intent on breaking the opposition's spirit. It is working to some extent. Many are disillusioned at the opposition's apparent powerlessness and inactivity. Its MPs make a lot of noise in parliament, Chitungwiza's residents say, but that does not stop the terror.

Mrs Gwanzura says the attacks are also having another effect. "I'll tell you what has changed. A year ago you could have been a Mugabe supporter living in this street and no one would have touched you. They would have said you are a fool or asked how much Mugabe is paying you, but you would have been safe. That is not true now. People are angry.

"They tried to get the police to protect us but now they say the police won't help. It has been made a crime to read a newspaper.

"They say the law can burn in hell with Mugabe, we are going to look after our own interests. They will make criminals of all of us. They have unleashed something."

The "war veterans" in particular are above the law. One of their more notorious leaders, Joseph Chinotimba, is on bail for the attempted murder of a neighbour he is alleged to have shot because she is an opposition supporter. It is unlikely he will ever be brought to trial, but yesterday he turned up at the supreme court anyway with a handful of thugs to threaten Zimbabwe's white chief justice, Anthony Gubbay.

The trampling of the law by the government has been widespread and systematic. White farmers and black workers are murdered with impunity. The killers identities' are frequently known.

Similarly, the killers of opposition activists are free from the threat of arrest. Reporters have been illegally detained and tortured.

If anyone is in any doubt about the government's view of this they only have to listen to Mr Mugabe's ministers. The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, told new police officers this week that maintaining the "rule of law" does not mean obeying the courts but rather "upholding the gains of the liberation struggle".

Any court judgments which "might result in moving away from Zimbabwe, back to Rhodesia, cannot be considered the rule of law", he said. He means court rulings that have declared the land seizure programme illegal.

Questioned about the use of repressive colonial-era security laws to detain opponents, the defence minister, Moven Mahachi, said that if the internal security act was used to convict innocent blacks under Ian Smith then there was no reason why the present government cannot do the same.

And for all the independence of many judges, the courts are increasingly used not only as political weapons but to settle scores.

Last week a bus driver was jailed for three years after being convicted of attempting to murder Mr Chinotimba. The inappropriately named Luckmore Chakanyuka was set upon by war veterans at a roadblock after an argument about driving standards. In his terror, Mr Chakanyuka jerked his bus forward. He was promptly arrested for trying to "kill" Mr Chinotimba.

The court despatched the bus driver to prison. Mr Chinotimba still walks free.
fields.bodyText: Agrippa Mukando was walking near Robert Mugabe's official residence on Monday when soldiers guarding the grounds leapt on the 63-year-old gardener and accused him of being an opposition supporter. They beat him as they beat several others that day. In many African countries the all-too-common victims of assaults by soldiers consider themselves lucky to escape with their lives. They would laugh off any suggestion that they go to the police; that would just invite more trouble. fields.headline: At this price?  Clipserver.com
fields.trailText: Clipserver.com's results seemed to underwhelm the City yesterday.
fields.body:
Clipserver.com's results seemed to underwhelm the City yesterday.

The AIM-listed online cuttings service for people wanting to know what is being written about them in the press has received little coverage of its own, from the media or the City.

The company announced it is looking to take over competitors or complementary businesses in Britain and the US, and plans to expand into continental Europe in 2002. Its shares dropped 0.5p to 30.5p and analysts found little to get excited about.

Clipserver has struck upon a bright idea, but the company does have a lot to prove.

The group, which last year opened an office in the US, issued a profits warning in December. It expanded into the US with European content for American customers, and paid the price.

"We underestimated how domestically focused the US was," Gary Forrest, chief executive, admitted.

Yesterday the company posted pretax losses of £419,000, compared to losses of £136,000 in 1999, due to one-off costs associated with the US expansion and the loss of some clients when it closed offline delivery.

Revenues increased slightly, up from £3.1m to £3.6m, and Clipserver said the group looked forward to an improved performance in 2001, having put in place foundations for growth.

All reasonable, according to analysts, but do not rush in just yet. It appears the endgame for this business is to be acquired, so the management has to grow the business significantly and increase its valuation, but has not done so yet.

There is a lot of potential growth in this company and its market, the share price is low and, with more than £4m cash in the bank and a hungry appetite for acquisitions, it is one to be watched.

This is a year for controlling costs and building revenues, according to Clipserver, so there could be a lengthy wait. Hold.

fields.headline: Celltech turns heads
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
With the vast majority of stocks on the market heading south yesterday, the steady performance of biotech Celltech outfit caught dealers' attention.

As the FTSE 100 index hit levels last seen two years ago, Celltech remained an oasis of calm, finishing 6p higher at £13.35 in respectable volume thanks to one very specific rumour.

According to market professionals, offshore punters, who are usually well informed, have been buying Celltech shares on the suspicion that drugs company GlaxoSmithKline, is thinking about a hostile takeover bid. Unlike most market tales this one seems to have some credibility.

After a series of setbacks - most notably with Lotronex, a treatment for irritable bowl syndrome - Glaxo's late-stage drug pipeline is looking rather thin and management is under pressure to do something about it.

Recent gossip suggests that Glaxo has been trawling the biotech world in search of promising drug candidates. It is said to have become involved in the bidding war for Celltech's new rheumatoid arthritis drug, the quaintly named CDP 870.

Yesterday's buyers reckon things have moved on and Glaxo is now interested in the whole shooting match, a move likely to be opposed by Celltech chief Peter Fellner.

Elsewhere, things were grim. Although it was not the climactic sell-off dealers had been bracing themselves for it was bad enough.

Unsettled by more woeful earnings news from Wall Street - yesterday's culprits were software company Oracle and telecoms firm SBC - the FTSE 100 fell to its lowest close in two years, off 50 points at 5,858.6.

News that Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has not ruled an early rate cut to stimulate the US economy came too late to save the blue-chip gauge, which over the course of last week fell 229.7 points. The FTSE Techmark slipped 3.99 points to 2,248.43.

With a few notable exceptions yesterday's biggest risers and fallers were much the same as Thursday's.

British Airways dived for a second day as a warning of rising losses from US Airways raised concerns about the profits outlook for the airline. BA ended 23p lower at 351.5p.

Shire Pharmaceuticals was also under pressure, easing 37p to £11.69, as arbitrageurs continued to short the stock in the run-up to the completion of its merger with Canadian firm BioChem Pharma.

BAE Systems, 7.5p better at 317.5p, was again among the top blue-chip performers, as analysts rushed to upgrade their ratings in the wake of the Thursday's pleasing figures.

There were also buyers around for engineering conglomerate GKN, up 29p at 833.5p, after Merrill Lynch said the stock was worth at least 900p. Telecoms testing firm Spirent gained 36p to 417p as hedge funds closed their short positions.

Lower down the market, two of Thursday's worst performers - Psion, the handheld computer maker, and ARC International, the chip designer - made good recoveries.

Psion put on 9.25p to 124.25p after Merrill Lynch analyst Sherief Bakr upgraded the stock to "accumulate" and said the firm's stake in Symbian, the operating system for next generation wireless devices, was worth at least 140p.

Meanwhile, ARC climbed 17p to 145.5p as it denied having any plans for a secondary issue of stock.

But PPL Therapeutics, unchanged at 167.5p, did not have a good day. Not only was Dolly - the sheep it cloned - put in quarantine because of the foot and mouth epidemic, but it emerged that Apax Partners, one of its early backers, had been selling some of its stake.

Statements released yesterday showed that two of Apax's funds had sold 775,000 PPL shares, or about 1.5% of the company, earlier this week. Apax still hold a 11.1% stake in PPL and dealers fear it may be looking to sell more.

webTitle: Son of Amstrad boss sells stake

fields.headline: Sugar spices market
fields.trailText: Dealers were yesterday casting an eye over events at Amstrad following reports that Daniel Sugar, the son of Amstrad boss and former Tottenham Hotspur supremo Alan, has sold his stake in the electronics company.
fields.body:
Dealers were yesterday casting an eye over events at Amstrad following reports that Daniel Sugar, the son of Amstrad boss and former Tottenham Hotspur supremo Alan, has sold his stake in the electronics company.

According to investment website Citywire, Mr Sugar, who works at Tottenham despite his father's departure, has sold all of his 500,000 Amstrad shares since November.

Nick Hewer, a spokesman for Amstrad, could not confirm the sale, but said he did not have a connection with the company. Mr Sugar, who works in the commercial department at Tottenham, was not returning calls yesterday.

Amstrad shares, which have performed poorly ever since problems with its move into mobile phones were revealed in November, closed 5.5p weaker at 90p. At the height of the dot.com boom last March, they were changing hands for 600p.

fields.headline: Troops pull back in Congo
fields.trailText: Two armies withdrew front-line troops and a rebel leader apologised to a looted population in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) yesterday as momentum gathered for an end to Africa's four-year war.
fields.body:
Two armies withdrew front-line troops and a rebel leader apologised to a looted population in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) yesterday as momentum gathered for an end to Africa's four-year war.

Three Rwandan battalions, numbering 3,000 men, have been withdrawing from the southern DRC town of Pweto for the past three days.

Further north Uganda, which was also fighting to topple the Congo's president, Laurent Kabila, until his assassination a month ago, is pulling back 1,500 troops.

Meanwhile, Jean-Pierre Bemba, the only rebel leader with popular support, apologised "for mistakes, atrocities, crimes and pillages committed by our soldiers on territory occupied by our movement".

The six nations at war in the DRC met in Lusaka two weeks ago to revive a two-year-old peace treaty. On March 15, all armies are due to withdraw 10 miles from forward positions, according to a UN security council demand.

However, on the other side of the war, Namibia has promised withdrawals without providing details, while Zimbabwe, Angola and the Kinshasa regime, led by Mr Kabila's son Joseph, have made no promises.

webTitle: Profits halve as Rolls pays for delays

fields.headline: Profits halve as Rolls pays for delays
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce's hopes of cashing in on liberalisation in the global energy market have taken a knock as a result of delays to the development of the industrial version of its Trent 500 engine.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce's hopes of cashing in on liberalisation in the global energy market have taken a knock as a result of delays to the development of the industrial version of its Trent 500 engine.

The group yesterday revealed that its profits nearly halved last year, mainly as a result of a £120m provision for extra work needed to get the engine ready for market.

The industrial Trent is intended to power small generation units which the company believes will be in demand as a result of deregulation and liberalisation of the electricity supply industries.

John Rose, RR's chief executive, said that demand for the engine remained strong, and he expected that once it went into production, sales would reach 30 units a year within five years.

The market for the group's energy products, including the Trent, is estimated to be worth about £115bn over the next 10 years. The group reported that £218m of exceptional items, including the Trent provision and losses on the disposal of its material handling business, had overwhelmed the 18% improvement in underlying profits last year.

It ended last year with a pre-tax profit, after exceptionals, of £166m, compared with £360m in 1999. Sales, however, rose 27% to £5.9bn.

The board expects profits for the present year to be relatively flat, with earnings growth resuming next year as profits from projects such as the EJ200 engine for the Eurofighter start to come in.

Production of the EJ200 is expected to reach about 100 by 2003. RR has a 36% stake in the EJ200 production contract which covers up to 1,500 engines.

Mr Rose said that on the civil aeroengine side, the group's wider installed base would drive up revenue from its service and spare part operations.

The integration of Vickers - taken over in 1999 - had created a strong marine propulsion business supplying both civil and military markets. But Vickers' other defence interests would probably be sold.

He said the marine business is expected to grow substantially over the next five years as a naval re-equipment cycle got under way, with new vessels incorporating new technologies.

The group's decision to concentrate its marine development operations at Bristol has led to industrial action at its Ansty plant in Coventry, where some marine work had been carried out.

Mr Rose said the management was anxious to discuss changes to its original plan with the unions - who are refusing to hold talks until redundancy notices have been withdrawn.

The chief executive took a swipe at City analysts who had given the group a poor rating. "This is a long cycle business and it is difficult to judge in terms of short cycles," he said. "Inevitably the City is interested in short cycles."

RR's chairman, Sir Ralph Robins, said the group had entered 2001 with a record order of more than £13bn. It had reduced its average borrowings last year as forecast and would continue to do so this year. "We continue to strengthen our position in civil aerospace, participate in many of the world's defence aerospace programmes and expect to grow our position in the energy sector as we introduce new products," he said.

fields.headline: FDA clears SkyePharma cancer treatment
fields.trailText: SkyePharma, the British pharmaceutical company, has received clearance from US authorities to resume selling its key cancer drug DepoCyt, 18 months after production problems forced it off the market.
fields.body:
SkyePharma, the British pharmaceutical company, has received clearance from US authorities to resume selling its key cancer drug DepoCyt, 18 months after production problems forced it off the market.

The drug, used to treat a potentially fatal complication of cancer named lymphomatous meningitis, was withdrawn by SkyePharma and marketing partner Chiron six months after its launch when batches were found not to meet all the specifications.

The move, which came in October 1999, hit the share price and has been partly blamed by industry observers for the delay in SkyePharma achieving profit, now expected later this year.

But the reassessment by the US food and drug administration, announced yesterday in New York, is a tremendous boost for the company as the US market for DepoCyt is estimated to be worth $50m a year.

SkyePharma chief executive Michael Ashton said that "manufacturing issues" had been resolved and hopes were high that the drug would be very successful.

Lymphomatous meningitis is estimated to affect over 6,000 people every year and a general consensus is that globally the market for the drug could be up to $130m.

fields.headline: Rank targets e-gamblers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The new-look Rank leisure group is going into the online casino business using its Grosvenor and Hard Rock brands to pull in punters of all ages.
fields.body:
The new-look Rank leisure group is going into the online casino business using its Grosvenor and Hard Rock brands to pull in punters of all ages.

The move was announced yesterday as Rank reported it had gone £341m into the red last year, compared with a profit of £107m in 1999.

The reversal was the result of a one-off £527m loss on the sell-off of a vast array of the underperforming group's businesses.

Chief executive Mike Smith, who was hired from Ladbrokes nearly two years ago to revive the business, has unloaded Pinewood Studios, Odeon cinemas, the Tom Cobleigh pubs chain, a 50% stake in Florida's Universal Studios theme park and the Butlins holiday camp business, which was bought by failed Dome bidder Robert Bourne.

The remaining businesses, the Hard Rock Cafe chain, Mecca bingo, casinos and the Deluxe film processing and video duplication operation, produced a 3.6% improvement in profits from £196m to £203m, mainly from gaming.

The businesses sold raised £1.4bn. Group debt has been reduced by £1bn and £300m has been used to finance share buybacks which have reduced the company's equity by 23.5%.

Mr Smith said Rank now had a "platform to build" but refused to comment on speculation that Rank might bid for the Hilton Group's Ladbroke betting operation, Coral's or William Hill. He did say Rank was not interested in London Clubs, the casino group racked with problems in the wake of an overambitious casino expansion plan in Las Vegas.

Profits at Deluxe, the world's biggest film processor and second-biggest video duplication business, fell 13%. Buoyed by films such as Erin Brockovich and Castaway, the film processing unit held its own. But Deluxe lost the video duplication contract for Fox Home Entertainment in the US, and that unit's profits fell 36%.

Deluxe is not a core business and has also been up for sale, but no acceptable offers have landed on Mr Smith's desk.

The businesses sold raised £1.4bn. Group debt has been reduced by £1bn and £300m has been used to finance share buybacks which have reduced the company's equity by 23.5%. Mr Smith said Rank now had a "platform to build" but refused to comment on speculation that Rank might bid for the Hilton Group's Ladbroke betting operation, Coral's or William Hill. He did say Rank was not interested in London Clubs, the casino group racked with problems in the wake of an overambitious casino expansion plan in Las Vegas. Profits at Deluxe, the world's biggest film processor and second-biggest video duplication business, fell 13%. Buoyed by films such as Erin Brockovich and Castaway, the film processing unit held its own. But Deluxe lost the video duplication contract for Fox Home Entertainment in the US, and that unit's profits fell 36%. Deluxe is not a core business and has also been up for sale, but no acceptable offers have landed on Mr Smith's desk.

fields.headline: Hopes of Napster deal fade
fields.standfirst:
Song swapping website admits its $1bn offer found little support

More net news
fields.trailText: Napster's chief executive officer, Hank Barry, yesterday conceded that the song swapping website's $1bn peace offer to the record industry was heading for the scrapheap.
fields.body:
Napster's chief executive officer, Hank Barry, yesterday conceded that the song swapping website's $1bn peace offer to the record industry was heading for the scrapheap.

"I don't want to totally close the door [on a settlement], but I felt like previously we had some good traction to have an agreement and I don't feel that way any more," Mr Barry said.

Napster's five-year revenue-sharing offer was backed by Bertelsmann but rejected by most other record companies, many of which have plans for their own download sites.

Internet research firm Jupiter MMXI said yesterday that plan to turn Napster into a subscription-based service could generate as much as $300m a month.

Its survey of Napster users found that half of the 60m total have sufficient disposable income to pay between $2.95 and $9.95 a month for the service.

"Napster have got it half right with their planned subscription model, which will appeal to much of their existing audience," said Jupiter MMXI music analyst Mark Mulligan.

He added that a lower quality, free service should be offered alongside paid-for one.

Napster had hoped to use revenue generated by subscriptions to pay a licensing fee to record companies.

The paid-for Napster service was announced last month but will not be available until July while the company resolves security issues and battles against legal action brought by the recording industry.

On February 12, a three-judge panel in the United States ruled that Napster was infringing musical copyrights and should stop its music swapping service. A hearing to determine the precise terms of the injunction opened in San Francisco last night.

Napster and Bertelsmann, which invested $60m in the song swapping service last year, would attempt to delay the closure of the service until July, Mr Mulligan predicted.

"It's in their interests to drag this court ruling on as long as possible. Napster mustn't lose their customers between now and July."

If the free service is shut in the next few weeks, Napster users are likely to turn to alternative illicit services such as Gnutella and Freenet. If the ruling is delayed until the subscription service is ready, Napster is more likely to convert free users into paying ones.

Last week, Vivendi Universal-owned Universal Music and Sony announced a plan to buy up licensing rights to half of the world's copyrighted music and offer it on a shared website.

Universal balked at signing an agreement similar to Bertelsmann's, saying Napster would receive too generous a share of subscription fees.

webTitle: GlaxoSmithKline to work on cheap malaria drug

fields.headline: GlaxoSmithKline to work on cheap malaria drug
fields.trailText: GlaxoSmithKline is linking up with the World Health Organisation to develop a malaria treatment to be sold cheaply to poor countries in Africa.
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline is linking up with the World Health Organisation to develop a malaria treatment to be sold cheaply to poor countries in Africa.

The new treatment, Lapdap, is made from existing anti-malaria drugs and is effective against strains of the mosquito-borne disease resistent to current remedies. It would be offered at a preferential price for public health programmes, the company said.

Malaria is endemic in large parts of sub-Saharan Africa, where 90% of the world's 300m cases occur. About 3,000 people, mostly aged under five, die each day from the disease.

The company said the treatment will be available in some countries next year. Clinical trials have shown its effectiveness in uncomplicated cases of malaria - including some resistant to other drugs.

A joint team from the WHO and Glaxo is overseeing the project which is funded in part by Britain's Department for International Development.

"This agreement shows public-private partnerships can achieve important practical results," said Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, director general of the World Health Organisation.

"It is an important collaboration, not only because it will bring a new drug to the market but also because it includes a price structure that aims at making the drug affordable for those who need it."

Glaxo, the world's biggest drugs firm by sales, has come under fire from development groups for pressuring poor country governments which buy cheap copies of its drugs.

Activists claim it and other large drug companies do little to fight disease in the developing world and block moves by poor countries to import or copy the drugs they need.

Yesterday's announcement came just a day after Glaxo said it would work in developing an anti-malaria vaccine with a charity founded by Bill Gates of Microsoft. The aim is to develop and test a vaccine to protect children from a common strain of the disease.

Lapdap is being made from two existing anti-malaria drugs - chlorproguanil and dapsone - and is entering its final development phase.

 Malaria kills at least 1m people each year, about 3,000 a day

 40% of the world's population live in areas with malaria risk but nine out of 10 cases occur in Africa south of the Sahara

 The cheapest anti-malaria drug - chloroquine - is rapidly losing its effectiveness in almost all endemic countries

 In parts of south-east Asia, strains of malaria have developed resistance to the four leading anti-malarial drugs

Source: WHO

fields.headline: Pistes and queues
fields.trailText: I finally went skiing last week, and managed to stay upright for much of the time, except on the last day when my legs refused to do what I told them.
fields.body:
I finally went skiing last week, and managed to stay upright for much of the time, except on the last day when my legs refused to do what I told them. While everyone else in my beginners' group was turning and gliding imperturbably down the slope, I was gathering speed, hurtling downwards as our instructor yelled: "pressure on the right foot, Simon, right foot, hard!" before sliding nimbly out of the way.

In the end I resembled that grand society dame in the Peter Arno cartoon. She's skating out of control with a mad, horrified look on her face. Two other, less majestic, women are impressed as she charges towards them: "Why, it's Mrs Chesterton Smythe, and she's heading our way!" As I myself headed towards the innocent men women and children gathered at the bottom of the slope, I decided to fall down, purely for the public welfare. I like to think that I made a pleasing pattern of poles, legs and skis, like a game of pick-up-sticks.

Still, I got the rudiments right. It's not so hard. The question you have to ask is whether you want to do it at all. Our children thought it was wonderful. They and their friends were naturals, swooping down confidently and gracefully like seagulls riding thermal currents. I on the other hand would get to the bottom of a slope all in one piece, and then realise gloomily that the only thing to do was get back on the lift and do it all again. Sometimes you could queue for 20 minutes in order to spend 40 seconds going back down.

But then for some people queueing is all part of the fun. No wonder it was the British who did so much to popularise skiing outside Scandinavia. At 4.55am at Gatwick, the queue stretched all round the check-in area. At the other end we queued to put our luggage on the coach, queued at the hotel, queued to be fitted with skis and boots. There were queues at the bottom of every lift, and a very long queue for sandwiches at lunchtime. In the evenings we queued for happy hour at the hotel bar, then for the dinner buffet. Dastardly continentals would try to queue jump. One middle-aged Dutch couple simply skiied past my wife, who objected. "Oh, no" the woman said in faultless English, "you will get there much faster if you go on the outside, like we do!"

 I see Ikea is mounting an aggressive new advertising campaign aimed at the "28% of people who live within an hour's drive of an Ikea store, but who have never been". Only 28% have managed to avoid the place! What a horrifying figure. I still shudder when I see my daughter's Ikea chest of drawers, which keeps collapsing, since she persists in putting clothes in it.

The other day I popped into a new shop in the Charing Cross Road, central London, part of a chain called Harmony. It's basically a dirty book and video shop, but in the wake of recent court rulings, has gone legit. It looks like an Ikea store. It's brightly lit, the decor is trendy and minimalist, and the stock is laid out in attractive displays, so you might be looking at a pyramid of Ferrero Rocher chocolates rather than blow-up nurse dolls with realistic mouth action. I suppose the idea is to get cheery middle-class couples. "Darling, I thought you might like this Super-King vibrator for while I'm on that trip to New York!" "Oh, sweetheart, what a treasure you are. Why don't I buy you this fruit-flavoured willy-rub?" But so far as I could see, the clientele was composed of the same gloomy men who you might have seen pushing past the floppy plastic curtains of your grotty old Soho sex shop.

 True story: when the BBC was making Absolutely Fabulous for the first time, they thought it would be sensible to get agreement from the Bollinger champagne people before using their product in such a louche context. A junior executive from the British end of the operation said a stern no. It was only after, at the very last minute, the managing director overturned this idiotic ruling that the girls were allowed to swig Bolly with, I am told, an unquantifiable but "huge" effect on sales.

 I am a huge admirer of John Reid, the new Ulster secretary. But I fear that like his multitudinous predecessors he has fallen for the old line peddled by the people of the province for the past 30-odd years. This week he said: "Of one thing I am sure, and that is that the overwhelming majority of the people of Northern Ireland want peace and demand that their representatives achieve it."

No they don't. They want victory. Representatives who take realistic steps for peace are voted out. They always have been. The getting of wisdom there is the realisation that peace does appear on their wish list, but quite a long way down.

 One of the problems faced by people who live in the countryside is their lack of any useful spokesperson. We townies tend to see rural dwellers as either arrogant, Barbour-wearing, huntin', an' shootin' landowners, or else as ooh-argh rustics who marry their sisters. Grotesquely unfair of course, but there it is. The countryside needs someone who sounds rational, well-informed and sympathetic. Instead it's got Robin Page, the former One Man And His Dog presenter, who writes endless articles, and who cropped up on the Today programme this week, shouting and yelling at the presenters, revealing a curious paranoia at every stage.

I first noticed Mr Page at the last election, when he spoke at a rally for Sir James Goldsmith's Referendum Party. I wouldn't say he was bonkers, but he was certainly several straws short of a haystack. He has an apparent obsession with the BBC ("the Brussels Broadcasting Corporation" - he is very anti-European) "Tell our snivelling politicians, the BBC, ITV, the know-it-alls, that we will not have it! Slap them straight across the face!"

I suppose Mr Page's spittle-flecked anger is a welcome change from the normal public relations smoothie-chops. But I don't think he is doing his cause an awful lot of good at this difficult time.

fields.headline: College fined £20,000 over HIV risk
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The Imperial College of Science was fined £20,000 yesterday for exposing the public to an "unacceptable risk" from the HIV virus.
fields.body:
The Imperial College of Science was fined £20,000 yesterday for exposing the public to an "unacceptable risk" from the HIV virus.

Despite warnings that it was unsafe to continue the manufacture of the virus for research purposes, work was permitted in an "unsealable" college laboratory situated at Chelsea and Westminster hospital.

In the event of a spillage, the "highly virulent" virus could have escaped and infected someone, Blackfriars crown court in south London was told.

Judge Charles Byers imposed a similar fine on the college's safety advisers. But the judge accepted that the chances of the virus escaping were not high.

"When one hears the words 'HIV virus', a shudder goes down one's spine," he said. "But it is not the same as if Legionnaire's disease had escaped from a laboratory.

"It is not really an airborne virus in that way. You have got to be in contact with it."

The judge said he had had to give careful thought as to how much danger the public had been exposed to as a result of the virus being manufactured by Imperial College in its laboratory at Chelsea and Westminster hospital.

He had then had to weigh that risk "against the public interest" in research being done for the benefit of the public.

"In this case it is plain that although there was an unacceptable risk of the public being affected by escape, it was not a high risk and is placed in a much lower category."

Imperial College admitted breaching hazardous substances regulations from 1998 to 1999; it was also ordered to £11,229 costs.

Its advisers, Universal Safety Consultants Ltd, pleaded guilty to breaking health and safety law, and was also ordered to pay £12,033 costs.

fields.headline: Japanese stocks sink to 15-year low
fields.trailText: Japan's ruling party scrambled to stave off a meltdown of confidence in the world's second-largest economy yesterday as growing signs of recession drove stocks in Tokyo to a 15-year low.
fields.body:
Japan's ruling party scrambled to stave off a meltdown of confidence in the world's second-largest economy yesterday as growing signs of recession drove stocks in Tokyo to a 15-year low.

The Liberal Democratic party said it would draw up a package of emergency measures next week to boost financial markets, lift house prices and help banks reduce the bad loans on their books.

"The situation has become more severe than before," said Taro Aso, state minister for economic and fiscal policy. "The government should implement all possible measures to secure recovery."

Spurring the announcement was a cluster of data indicating that Japan's economy is not just slowing - as the government has been insisting - but grinding into reverse.

Figures released yesterday showed that unemployment in January was at a record low of 4.9%, with 3.17m people out of work. That figure is expected to rise because the ratio of vacancies to job seekers deteriorated for the first time in almost two years.

Further layoffs are likely as companies cut production in reaction to a slowdown in the United States, their main export market. Yesterday, Fujitsu joined NEC and Toshiba as the latest electronics manufacturer to scale back its profit forecasts by double digits.

An increasing number of economists believe Japan has been sucked into a deflationary spiral of falling profits, wages, prices and spending. Adding to the evidence for this theory, government figures yesterday showed that spending by salaried households was flat in January while consumer prices, excluding perishables, fell for the 18th consecutive month. The 1.1% decline was the sharpest fall since records began in 1971.

Investors are fleeing Japanese stocks in droves. The Nikkei index slumped by 3.3% yesterday to 12, 261. During the past week, shares have declined by 7.4%, making Tokyo the worst performing exchange in Asia this year.

"I am extremely worried," prime minister Yoshiro Mori told parliament.

The government is hoping its ¥82.65 trillion (£540bn) budget bill - which passed the lower house yesterday - plus the new package of measures from the LDP will soothe investors' fears.

Economic policymakers have been distracted by political feuds and uncertainty over the future of Mr Mori, who is expected to stand down this month. With the prime minister's approval rating at just 6%, the opposition announced yesterday that it will submit a no-confidence vote against the government on Monday.

The governor of the Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, is also under pressure to resign. The LDP blames the turmoil on his decision to end Japan's zero interest rate policy last August. On Wednesday, the bank effectively acknowledged that this decision had been a mistake by cutting rates by a tenth of a percentage point.

fields.headline: OECD accused of tyranny
fields.standfirst: Caribbean leader alleges double standards at tax havens talks
fields.trailText: Caribbean leader alleges double standards at tax havens talks.
fields.body:
Talks between rich industrialised nations and Caribbean states designed to clean up the offshore financial industry appeared to be heading for deadlock last night after Owen Arthur, prime minister of Barbados, snubbed a dinner held in his honour and accused the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development of "technocratic tyranny".

With little hope of a breakthrough in the increasingly bitter dispute, it now appears likely the OECD will be forced to carry out its threat of economic sanctions against the Caribbean states.

The talks at the OECD's headquarters in Paris, which follow earlier meetings in Barbados and London, were meant to find a mutually acceptable way of ending the climate of secrecy in offshore financial centres so that rich industrialised nations can track down tax dodgers.

The offshore centres agree on the need to overhaul their banking systems but argue that the OECD's threat of sanctions unless they comply with a rigid timetable, beginning with a public commitment by the end of July to reform, is high-handed and undemocratic.

Sources at the meeting said Mr Arthur, who chairs the Caribbean Community, or Caricom, demonstrated his anger by failing to turn up for a dinner held in his honour on the eve of the talks. He then opened his address to the meeting by accusing the OECD of "technocratic tyranny" by "nameless, faceless" people with "no common sense". "It was very, very tense," an insider said.

fields.headline: Murdoch deal near collapse
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's plans to take over Hughes Electronics, owner of DirecTV, the US satellite business, are on the verge of collapse after negotiations with General Motors, the car group that controls Hughes, reached an impasse.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's plans to take over Hughes Electronics, owner of DirecTV, the US satellite business, are on the verge of collapse after negotiations with General Motors, the car group that controls Hughes, reached an impasse.

The board of GM and Hughes management are unhappy about the terms of the proposed merger between the company and Mr Murdoch's satellite business, Sky Global, according to sources. Although a deal with Sky could still be reached, executives at GM have started to rethink a possible spin-off of Hughes in the absence of any rival bidders.

Amid growing frustration at the slow pace of the talks, News Corp is also understood to have initiated preliminary merger discussions with Echostar, Hughes's much smaller US rival, sources said.

Andrew Butcher, a spokesman for News Corp, refused to discuss these talks but said: "We remain in negotiations regarding DirecTV.

"However, we are also looking at all alternatives."

The failure of the Hughes deal would come as a blow to Mr Murdoch, who has made no secret of his desire to take over America's largest satellite broadcasting unit, DirecTV. Without it, Sky Global would have no presence in the United States, the world's largest media market.

News Corp approached Hughes about a possible reverse takeover several months ago. It enlisted the support of John Malone, the media investor, and Microsoft, to propose a transaction under which Hughes shareholders would gain 65 % of the merged entity, with the rest going to News Corp investors.

Although both sides said a deal could still be done, one adviser said yesterday: "Everyone seem to think it's dead. GM are just not happy with this deal."

A spokesman for GM said: "We have said all along that we are talking with multiple parties and we continue to have discussions about this."

Some analysts believe News Corp could save the merger if it improved the terms of it offer for Hughes. Shareholders in Hughes reacted badly when the terms of the deal first leaked earlier this year, and its share price has fallen sharply.

News Corp executives have privately indicated they are unlikely to sweeten the terms of the deal, however.

The options for Hughes would be a full listing on the stock exchange or sale to another partner. Few potential partners have emerged to date. Media companies Viacom and Walt Disney would be large enough but have so far failed to express an interest.

Another bidder could be Comcast, although the cable television company could find the cost too high. Even after losing more than half of its market value since last March, Hughes is still valued at $17bn.

Larry Haverty, media analyst at State Street Research, is one of the few large investors in Hughes in favour of the Sky Global deal. "There is no other buyer. It makes no economic sense for anyone other than Rupert to do this deal. And Sky Global is hardly global without a US presence."

Mr Haverty believes that GM has little option other than to do a deal with News Corp if it wants to increase shareholder value. He believes a deal will still be done at some later date. "This has been a very long romance and sometimes in a long romance the partners are better off with a little hiatus, so that they can figure out how much they miss each other."

Advisers to Hughes believe that a spin-off could prove more lucrative, however. Their argument suggests that, if Hughes is fully listed on the stock exchange, News Corp would be forced to launch a hostile bid at a greater premium to gain control. News Corp has rarely made hostile bids, however.

Both Mr Murdoch and senior executives of Hughes are talking at an industry conference in Boca Raton, Florida, next week.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Wolves sets sale deadline
fields.body:
Wolves sets sale deadline

Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries yesterday issued an April 5 deadline to possible bidders for Britain's largest regional brewer in an effort to expedite a sale process that has dragged on since last August.

Industry sources have said two offers are on the table: one from its management team another from leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare.

Both parties are understood to have tabled offers of around 500p a share, valuing the company at around £472m. The winner will also be taking over debt of more than £500m.

Vosper fires counterblast

Martin Jay, chief executive of shipbuilder Vosper Thornycroft, yesterday accused BAE Systems of seeking a monopoly to build British warships.

He urged ministers to reject BAE's bid to build all 12 of the new Type 45 destroyers "on a non-competitive basis". Vosper, he said, was keen to bid for destroyer contracts.

BAE confirmed on Thursday it is was trying to persuade the government to adopt a naval shipbuilding strategy which would favour its warship yards.

Coke chief wins $90m reward

Coca-Cola paid chairman and chief executive Douglas Daft more than $90m (£62m) last year, much of it in restricted stock linked to company performance, according to regulatory filings in the US.

Mr Daft received $87.3m in restricted shares. Two-thirds of his award is related to company performance over the next five years.

"The award allows Mr. Daft to achieve significant wealth only in the presence of significant performance, and the targets set are very aggressive," the company said.

Lego shuts three plants

Despite its product being named Toy of the Century, Denmark's Lego is to sack 500 workers and close three factories after losing €134m (£85m) over the past year.

One of the factories is in Hungary, the other two in Switzerland.

In addition, it will pull out of the clothing and publishing businesses.

"We know what went wrong and we know what to do with it," said company director Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen. Getting into these businesses was a mistake and contributed to Lego losing its direction, the company said.

Lego will focus more on the electronic toys market in response to a change in children's tastes.

Reuters buys Diagram

News and information company Reuters said yesterday it had bought French financial software firm Diagram for £42.6m to bolster its market technology business.

Reuters, which offers risk management products and trading technologies to financial institutions, said it was paying cash to buy Diagram from unlisted French holding company Caravelle.

Diagram generated revenues of £17.4 m in 2000.

Reuters said it would further integrate Diagram's products with Reuters' trade and risk management solutions.

fields.headline: Greenspan drives market rally
fields.trailText: Wall Street shares staged a comeback yesterday after the chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, reawakened hopes of an early cut in interest rates.
fields.body:
Wall Street shares staged a comeback yesterday after the chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, reawakened hopes of an early cut in interest rates.

But Mr Greenspan's comments came too late to rally sentiment in London, where the FTSE 100 index of leading shares fell 50 points to close at 5,858.6, a two-year low, after string of profit warnings from US companies overnight.

Gloom had gripped traders on both sides of the Atlantic in the wake of Mr Greenspan's appearance before the Senate banking committee earlier this week, when he appeared to rule out the Fed cutting rates ahead of its next meeting, despite a raft of weak economic data.

In early trading, the Dow Jones index of leading shares lost 130 points, more than one percent of its value. A profit warning from software maker Oracle hurt technology stocks, pushing the tech-heavy Nasdaq index down 3%.

The markets cheered up after Mr Greenspan signalled that an inter-meeting rate cut was not off the agenda. By noon, the Dow had pared its losses and was up 80 points.

webTitle: Waterstone quits HMV chair to prepare bid

fields.headline: Waterstone quits HMV chair to prepare bid
fields.trailText: Tim Waterstone yesterday formally stood down as chairman of HMV Media, owner of the bookshops bearing his name.
fields.body:
Tim Waterstone yesterday formally stood down as chairman of HMV Media, owner of the bookshops bearing his name.

The resignation was viewed as clearing the way for Mr Waterstone to make an offer for the chain he founded in 1982. He had effectively removed himself from chairman's duties months ago because of his much publicised desire to buy back the chain.

Eric Nicoli, the chairman of HMV's main shareholder, EMI, will take the job until a permanent replacement is found.

Mr Waterstone, 61, has secured backing in principle from PPM Ventures for a bid but price is understood still to be an issue. There have been discussions for weeks with UBS Warburg, which acts for HMV, based on an offer in the region of £200m.

Mr Waterstone has accused HMV of "dumbing down" his concept by putting an emphasis on bestsellers and discounting. He built a business of around 80 shops before selling to WH Smith in 1989. Waterstone's became part of HMV Media in 1997.

Advisers said HMV would consider "sensible offers" but maintained that Waterstone's was being run with a view to keeping and building the business.

In the run-up to Christmas sales at the bookstores improved by 5.6%. Last year comparable sales fell marginally to £404m while operating profits fell 34% to £26.4m.

webTitle: Inside Foot and Mouth control centre

fields.headline: In the bunker: maps and bemusement
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: It is not exactly Winston Churchill's war room, but at least the disease emergency control centre, co-opted to coordinate the battle against foot and mouth, is in a deep Whitehall bunker with secure phones, huge maps spread out on tables, and ministry men sticking different coloured pins into them.
fields.body:
It is not exactly Winston Churchill's war room, but at least the disease emergency control centre, co-opted to coordinate the battle against foot and mouth, is in a deep Whitehall bunker with secure phones, huge maps spread out on tables, and ministry men sticking different coloured pins into them.

Beyond that, the nerve centre of the foot and mouth crisis could be the hurriedly prepared offices of any dot.com start up company.

By noon yesterday the 50 or more vets, epidemiologists and others drafted in from the Ministry of Agriculture offered the very image of a calm and collected bureaucracy.

The reality, said one vet yesterday, was slightly dif ferent. "There's an awful lot we just do not understand about this virus, and goodness knows what all these people are doing."

The control centre team collates the information gathered in the fields, offers advice, classifies the outbreaks and prepares the legal restrictions.

Some 400 vets are now spreading out across Britain, with up to 40 more arriving over the weekend from Australia, the US, Canada and New Zealand.

The UN food and agriculture organisation is also sending in specialists.

Many thousands of livestock movements must be traced and each day the numbers rise. Yesterday, 67,000 animals were waiting checks.

So far 37,000 sheep, cows and pigs, and just one goat, have been earmarked for slaughter and another 4,600 classed as having been in "dangerous contact".

A digital monitor records that 242 investigations of outbreaks are underway or have been completed.

A further 68 "highly suspicious" cases are waiting for vets to report back."The numbers will increase," says Jim Scudamore, the chief vet.

fields.headline: Chinese immigrants 'tricked' by gang
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A court was told yesterday how a snakehead gang tricked Chinese immigrants by telling them they would make the entire journey to Europe by air.
fields.body:
A court was told yesterday how a snakehead gang tricked Chinese immigrants by telling them they would make the entire journey to Europe by air.

In reality much of the journey was by lorry, and during the final leg, from Rotterdam to Dover on the Zeebrugge ferry, 58 out of the group of 60 died of suffocation.

Speaking at the trial of Perry Wacker, 33, a Dutch lorry driver who denies 58 charges of manslaughter, one of two survivors discovered by customs officers at Dover told how he had been tricked into paying £20,000 to snakeheads in Fujian province to travel to England.

Ke Shi Guang, 22, said he did not think he was going to be travelling illegally, as he thought he was flying to England.

"The snakeheads at home, they cheated us. They said we would be buying tickets and travelling by air," he told the jury at Maidstone crown court in Kent.

Michael Lawson QC, counsel for Mr Wacker, put it to Mr Guang that he knew he was breaking the law. He replied that his only concern was to get to England: "Because I like England, I just wanted to get to England."

Mr Guang's family paid a deposit of £2,000 to what he called "the little snakeheads" in his village in Fujian, with a further payment of £18,000 to be made when he reached England. Those on the lorry had various arrangements with the snakeheads, paying instalments at different stages of the trip.

Mr Guang agreed that the snakeheads were "powerful and brutal", and that if the payments were not made his parents' lives would be in danger.

Elizabeth Marsh QC, for Ying Guo, an interpreter who denies a charge of conspiracy to smuggle immigrants, asked Mr Guang why he did not buy a ticket himself to fly to England. He replied: "First, I felt I did not have enough experience. I also needed to be taken care of, I needed someone to escort me."

Mr Guang agreed that his primary reason for leaving Fujian was economic, and that he sought a better life.

After flying from Beijing to Moscow on June 7 last year and on to Yugoslavia, Mr Guang's group travelled by road and on foot into Hungary. There he was instructed by a snakehead minder to call home, and to tell his parents to prepare the money for the final payment.

He said that he made a similar call from a safe house in Rotterdam before boarding the lorry in which he nearly died.

Mr Guang said he was told to copy a name and phone number on to a piece of paper before leaving the Netherlands, and that he should call this person if he was arrested. The number he was given, the jury heard, was that of a mobile phone owned by Ms Gou.

"A person told us 'if you are arrested, all you have to do is call this person and they will come and bail you out'," he said.

Mr Guang, who was carrying $960 when discovered at Dover, said that on arrival he was due to meet a family member in central London's Chinatown, but that he had not carried his name or phone number with him in order to protect his identity.

He would have had to call his parents back home and be given details.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Dolly the sheep in quarantine
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The spread of the foot and mouth outbreak to Scotland has prompted scientists to place Dolly the sheep, the world's first cloned mammal, into quarantine.
fields.body:
The spread of the foot and mouth outbreak to Scotland has prompted scientists to place Dolly the sheep, the world's first cloned mammal, into quarantine.

The Roslin Institute confirmed yesterday that Dolly had been isolated from all other farm animals and the research centre has been closed to visitors until the disease has been brought under control.

"She is in her own accommodation in special housing," said Harry Griffin, a member of the team which cloned Dolly.

Dolly has been quarantined along with other cloned sheep at the institute, but Dr Griffin warned that this would not be enough to protect the animal if foot and mouth were brought to the institute's farm.

webTitle: Eurosceptics may miss the good earners

fields.headline: Eurosceptics may miss the good earners
fields.standfirst: Sensible investors are being urged to set aside any Euroscepticism and to look at euroland as a golden prospect for this year's Isa allowance.
fields.trailText: Sensible investors are being urged to set aside any Euroscepticism and to look at euroland as a golden prospect for this year's Isa allowance.
fields.body:
Fund managers are predicting strong performances by European funds in 2001. And people seem to be taking notice. Statistics from the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds show that in January funds in the "Europe excluding UK" sector were second most popular with investors - trailing only those in the "UK All Companies" sector.

Isas allow investment anywhere in the world, but it wasn't until last year that investors strayed from the markets of UK and Europe. While 40% of Isa sales stayed in the UK and 23% in Europe, a chunky 37% was invested in North America, global funds and specialist funds - particularly technology.

Fund managers say a number of economic factors make euroland a brighter proposition than the UK and US right now. A common line is that European companies are becoming more profitable because of a rash of mergers and acquisitions and increased exposure to competition as the push towards a single market continues.

Fund managers say this leads to greater efficiency and, in turn, higher returns.

Chris Rice, manager of the HSBC European Growth Fund, says: "There are very low real interest rates, an exchange rate that's very competitive for European manufacturers and most European governments are expanding fiscal policy this year.

"Perhaps most importantly, consumer confidence and consumer spending remain very resilient. These factors should mean Europe grows at over 2.5% this year. That should make European earnings one of the most attractive to investors for 2001."

Schroders is pushing Europe as a "haven" for investors at a time of a clear slow-down in the US economy. Mark Pignatelli, head of European equities, says a combination of continuing growth and loosening monetary conditions as interest rates come down should be good news for European equities.

"Equities in continental Europe are likely to benefit significantly if the European central bank cuts interest rates within the next few months. The rate at which new jobs are being created suggests that the economies of the main countries within euroland are likely to remain relatively strong."

Schroders will also tell you that nine out of 10 independent financial advisers frequently recommend European funds. Jason Hollands, deputy managing director at IFA Bestinvest, says his firm has been successfully pushing investment in Europe for the past three years.

"Importantly, Europe has retained high consumer confidence at a time of big structural changes as it moves towards the eurozone.

"Europe has historically gone to the debt markets or banks for funding, but there is a move towards equities now - the European equity market is growing."

Mr Hollands said investors would do well to favour aggressive stock-picking fund managers, including Albert Morillo, manager of the Investec European Portfolio Trust, and Roger Guy of the Gartmore European Selected Opportunities Fund.

Wolverhampton-based IFA Torquil Clark says: "Europe and UK have both had a shaky 2000 but with the euro finding its feet, confidence in both the currency and continent can only go up.

"There will probably be a clash between 'new' and 'old' economy stocks again with the overall picture being dependent on technology stocks at least holding firm over the year. If they can, and even show some positive moves, then Europe as a whole could fare quite well."

webTitle: Genius under the hammer: Sotheby's sale of actors' estates

fields.headline: Genius under the hammer
fields.trailText: The estates of the late Sir John Gielgud and the late Sir Ralph and Lady Richardson come up for auction in London in April. Sir John's effects are on sale on Thursday April 5 and those of the Richardsons on Friday April 27.
fields.body:
The estates of the late Sir John Gielgud and the late Sir Ralph and Lady Richardson come up for auction in London in April. Sir John's effects are on sale on Thursday April 5 and those of the Richardsons on Friday April 27.

The timing of the sales is purely coincidental according to Harry Dalmeny, who is organising both events for Sotheby's. He says: "Sir Ralph died some time ago (in 1983, aged 80) but Lady Richardson, the actress Muriel Forbes, known affectionately as Mu, lived on to last year, when she died aged 86. Both Sir Ralph and his wife were inveterate collectors, as was Sir John Gielgud.

The auctions can be seen as a unique combination of a celebrity sale and a country house clearance. There is bound to be considerable interest, both from those interested in the two great men and wanting to own something belonging to them and dealers interested in the fine antiques and works of art. Both actors assembled fine collections including silver, porcelain, works of art, carpets, books and of course theatrical memorabilia.

Sir John Gielgud was 17 when he decided to become an actor. He won a scholarship to a dramatic academy run by Lady Benson. After first appearing in the Old Vic in 1921, he became a Shakespearean idol in the 30s and 40s playing roles such as Hamlet, King Lear, Romeo, Macbeth and Cassius. He also had a film career, winning an Oscar for his role as the butler with Dudley Moore in the comedy Arthur.

For the last 30 years of his life he lived in South Pavilion, a Queen Anne house in the village of Wotton Underwood in Buckinghamshire. He filled his home with fine furniture and works of art.

The paintings in Sir John's collection range from Old Masters to Modern British. There is a set of six paintings of three cavaliers attributed to Jacob Frans Van Der Merck (estimated at £10,000 to £15,000). In the modern section there is a still life by Sir Matthew Smith of flowers and fruit on a table (estimate £30,000 to £40,000).

Examples of the furniture in Sir John's collection include a satinwood oblong regency breakfast table circa 1810, estimated at £7,000 to £9,000, and a George II mahogany bureau dating from circa 1755 expected to realise between £8,000 and £12,000. Given the great interest in regency furniture at recent country house sales, these pieces could fetch a lot more than the estimates.

Sir Ralph and his wife also collected fine furniture, paintings and watercolours by British artists and antiquities. The collection is rich in theatrical memorabilia with scripts, posters and gifts from fellow actors on offer from a couple of hundred pounds upwards.

Sir Ralph was born in 1902, the son of an art master in Cheltenham. Initially he planned to follow in his father's footsteps and enrolled in an art course, but changed his allegiance at 18 in 1920 and joined a small group of actors in Brighton. He made his West End debut six years later in a play called Yellow Sands and joined the Old Vic in 1930.

Sir Ralph would often treat himself to an antique or work of art as a memento of one of his many stage performances, usually inscribing the piece with the date of purchase. In the sale is a 1st or 2nd century Roman funerary tablet bearing the inscription in Sir Ralph's hand: "Bought for an interior of Home November 70 Ralph Richardson", a reference to the play Home in which he starred opposite Sir John.

He was also a fan of the painter Sir William Nicholson. Included in the sale is an oil still life by this artist of a goblet and orchid, which has an estimate of £40,000 to £60,000.

Ralph Richardson was a passionate bibliophile. Some of his collection related to the theatre but others were of antiquarian or literary interest. Among the highlights of his library are the Nonesuch Press editions of 23 works of Charles Dickens (published in 1937-38) and expected to fetch in the region of £1,500.

For further information, Sotheby's, tel: 020-7293-5169.

webTitle: All roads lead to Wall Street

fields.headline: All roads lead to Wall Street
fields.standfirst: The US still shows unrivalled economic strength which will maintain it as the world's front runner for the forseeable future, Robin Stoddart predicts
fields.trailText: The US still shows unrivalled economic strength which will maintain it as the world's front runner for the forseeable future, Robin Stoddart predicts
fields.body:
Most City analysts believe that the UK economy will continue to grow strongly even if there is little or no progress in output across the Atlantic this year. Yet the strength of the US is unmatched.

Backed by natural and managerial resources in depth and around the globe, there can be little doubt that its economy will remain the front-runner for as long as anyone can contemplate. In what seems set to be an era of disasters, natural and man-made, size and financial strength will count for most.

London continues to be dominated by Wall Street. The strength of the dollar in the face of soaring trade deficits underlines that position. Expectations that faster growth in the eurozone would help its currency have faded, though the euro did recover some lost ground when the spate of continental takeovers of US companies eased.

Whichever currency becomes the year's strong suit, it is unlikely to be the pound. Foreign investment has been a mainstay of both sterling and the economy, but it is bound to fall back while American profits dive. A significant proportion of the fall is arising in overseas subsidiaries. The hundreds of important UK firms owned by US parents would suffer if concern about the infrastructure continues to mount. After so many setbacks in a densely populated island, an erosion of confidence in the UK is inevitable.

Despite unrivalled prosperity in the US, consumer confidence there is at its weakest for nearly five years. On top of profit warnings from both hi-tech and leading brand providers, this has undermined Wall Street lately. Hopes of further reductions in interest rates brought temporary rebounds, but the Federal Reserve central bank is apparently unwilling to resort to more cuts. Few doubt that interest rates will come down again shortly.

Investment in the US by UK institutions and individuals has been far below that justified by the strength of the economy and currency. The failures in direct investment over there by UK companies may have had something to do with it, although the dominance of US financial institutions in the City of London and arrival of leading fund managers might have been expected to correct the situation.

The best returns for UK private investors on Wall Street have been achieved by Fidelity, the privately owned US fund manager that extended its operations into Europe in the 80s. Its main US unit funds have shown fairly consistent appreciation, though over recent months Fidelity Special Situations, investing in smaller companies than the main Fidelity American retail fund, has fallen back. Both have achieved appreciation of more than 170% over three years. Over 10 years it is far more than 1,000% in Special Situations.

Other fund managers who are now part of the international banking giants Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank have invested quite actively in America and done well. Threadneedle American has been a long-term success and over more recent years Framlington units, too, have performed close to the best. The much smaller Abbey US Emerging has also done well, though not its much bigger stablemate Abbey American, which has grown by much less than half over three years.

UK banks and insurers have also been pedestrian performers as has, surprisingly, Merrill Lynch, the top American broking firm over the years of booming mutual fund investment. In smaller companies it has done very well, along with Schroder. Gartmore performed reasonably with all of its American funds before it became part of Nationwide, the US insurer, but has now slipped way down the lists. Oddly, the benighted Equitable has done the reverse, showing one of the strongest performances, though the north American unit fund is tiny.

Among investment trusts there are no outstanding US performers, in spite of the long experience of Scottish fund managers there. Alliance and Second Alliance are UK and international investors from their Dundee base, but they did not raise US stakes at the right time.

Smaller specialists, led by American Opportunity and North Atlantic Smaller, have revived of late with appreciation of half and a third respectively over a year, but barely average similar progress over three. The big Fleming American trust saw a strong advance of 40% last year and a fair 70% over three years, helped by stakes in Cisco Systems, Citibank and Microsoft. Part of the appreciation came from buying that trimmed its shares' discount on assets, while other trusts are priced around an eighth below the value of their holdings. On that basis they must be good value when Wall Street leads the world on to firmer ground.

fields.headline: A kick in the teeth
fields.standfirst: Dentists dispute Alan Milburn's claims
fields.trailText: If you live in Bath you can't get an appointment to see a National Health Service dentist. To do so you will have to travel to just outside Bristol, where you could be squeezed into one practice's jammed schedule in a month's time.
fields.body:
If you live in Bath you can't get an appointment to see a National Health Service dentist. To do so you will have to travel to just outside Bristol, where you could be squeezed into one practice's jammed schedule in a month's time.

In Aberdeen you can at least be seen in your home town, but will be out of luck if your toothache is chronic; you will have to wait four weeks for an appointment.

Londoners and Liverpudlians, on the other hand, have something to smile about. They can get their ailing mouth examined next week. Networks of smart clinics are opening in cities, notably the Whitecross chain in London, Birmingham, Dudley, Bristol and Bedford, where up to 15 dentists can give NHS appointments, in some instances on the next day.

They even offer a nervous patient programme. Elsewhere, you can be seen, but not on NHS terms: increasing numbers of people are being forced to pay for their dental health care.

In other words, oral health is down to postcode. Research by Jobs & Money clearly shows huge disparities between the availability of free or subsidised dental care and it is not necessarily deprived areas which are hardest hit. What, under the founding principles of the National Health service, is supposed to be a democratic provision of equal care for all has become a lottery.

A statement made to Jobs & Money by the Department of Health clearly does not bear out our experience: "There are more dentists than ever before in the General Dental Service and most still devote most of their time to NHS work. Most people can get NHS dental treatment when they need it," says a spokeswoman. She admits that more people are turning to private care, but adds that more check-ups are being carried out on the NHS now than five years ago: 19.9m last year against 19.2m in 1996. About a quarter of NHS dental work is carried out free or at reduced cost. The maximum charge has not increased in real terms since this government took office, she says.

But where people do have to go private they pay dearly. Costs vary round the country, but even the most basic procedure is vastly more expensive - almost two and a half times - on private terms than on the NHS. In London, the Whitecross centres charge £30 for an initial private consultation, £33 for a scale and polish from a dental hygienist, £55 for a white filling and from £325 for a crown.

The only positive is that often dentists will take benefit claimants on to their books where other NHS clients are refused: if you are on income support or pregnant, dental care is totally free (although treatments costing more than £200 must be pre-approved). However, if you have dentures you may find that no one will take you on as a new patient. But the government has acknowledged the severity of the problem of patchy NHS cover: last year it published a dental strategy which made a commitment to making high-quality dentistry available to everyone regardless of where they live. It said that £100m has been earmarked for the project, which will include the establishment of 40 new NHS dental access centres.

"No one has claimed that they (the access centres) will solve the whole problem, that's why the government's strategy includes a whole range of measures, including £20m a year directly rewarding dentists' commitment to the NHS," says the spokeswoman.

But the British Dental Association says the problem is two-fold: first, dentists are not given sufficient funds by the NHS to carry out the work and second, the number of dental practices is insufficient: some have closed their books to new patients for more than two years because they cannot handle any more patients. The Association has criticised Secretary of State for Health Alan Milburn's plans, saying that much of the money being allocated has been double counted.

According to the Review Body of Doctors' and Dentists' Remuneration, a dentist who does only NHS work earns an average of £60,000 a year. But one dentist in the south-east told Jobs & Money: "This morning I spent three-quarters of an hour making a set of dentures, and my paper profit, that is not even taking my overheads into account, was £14. It's madness and something has got to change." He adds that while private dental plans mean a regular income for the dentist (see opposite), they also mean a commitment to carry out all subsequent treatments for a set fee. "You are taking on whatever problems their previous dentist has left them with and this is often not cost-effective," he says.

The Consumers' Association has already highlighted the shortfalls in the system and is currently researching the whole area of dental care provision.

But there is a separate problem emerging: the private dentists to which increasing numbers of people are having to turn are not regulated. The Care Standards Act, which came in last year, applies to all areas of private health care provision except private dentistry. This means that if you think your dentist, operating under private terms, has failed to explain charging structures clearly, or think that the work carried out is substandard, your only recourse is to sue. "More and more people are using private dental services, and not necessarily by choice. This is one area of private health care that must not be permitted to continue to operate without proper safeguards in place for patients. It's appalling that private work done by dentists is not properly regulated," says Clara Macay, principal policy adviser for the Consumers' Association.

A private members bill which would regulate dentists under the Care Standards Commission, the new private healthcare watchdog agency which is due to be established next year, is currently going through parliament.

Back to the DoH, which says: "The government wants dentistry firmly back within the NHS. That is an ambitious target, but the dental strategy shows how, by working together with the profession and the NHS, we can achieve it." If our difficulties in finding such a dentist from the long list of practices which state quite categorically that they carry out NHS work are typical, then this could take quite some time.
