A statement made to Jobs & Money by the Department of Health clearly does not bear out our experience: "There are more dentists than ever before in the General Dental Service and most still devote most of their time to NHS work. Most people can get NHS dental treatment when they need it," says a spokeswoman. She admits that more people are turning to private care, but adds that more check-ups are being carried out on the NHS now than five years ago: 19.9m last year against 19.2m in 1996. About a quarter of NHS dental work is carried out free or at reduced cost. The maximum charge has not increased in real terms since this government took office, she says. But where people do have to go private they pay dearly. Costs vary round the country, but even the most basic procedure is vastly more expensive - almost two and a half times - on private terms than on the NHS. In London, the Whitecross centres charge £30 for an initial private consultation, £33 for a scale and polish from a dental hygienist, £55 for a white filling and from £325 for a crown. The only positive is that often dentists will take benefit claimants on to their books where other NHS clients are refused: if you are on income support or pregnant, dental care is totally free (although treatments costing more than £200 must be pre-approved). However, if you have dentures you may find that no one will take you on as a new patient. But the government has acknowledged the severity of the problem of patchy NHS cover: last year it published a dental strategy which made a commitment to making high-quality dentistry available to everyone regardless of where they live. It said that £100m has been earmarked for the project, which will include the establishment of 40 new NHS dental access centres. "No one has claimed that they (the access centres) will solve the whole problem, that's why the government's strategy includes a whole range of measures, including £20m a year directly rewarding dentists' commitment to the NHS," says the spokeswoman. But the British Dental Association says the problem is two-fold: first, dentists are not given sufficient funds by the NHS to carry out the work and second, the number of dental practices is insufficient: some have closed their books to new patients for more than two years because they cannot handle any more patients. The Association has criticised Secretary of State for Health Alan Milburn's plans, saying that much of the money being allocated has been double counted. According to the Review Body of Doctors' and Dentists' Remuneration, a dentist who does only NHS work earns an average of £60,000 a year. But one dentist in the south-east told Jobs & Money: "This morning I spent three-quarters of an hour making a set of dentures, and my paper profit, that is not even taking my overheads into account, was £14. It's madness and something has got to change." He adds that while private dental plans mean a regular income for the dentist (see opposite), they also mean a commitment to carry out all subsequent treatments for a set fee. "You are taking on whatever problems their previous dentist has left them with and this is often not cost-effective," he says. The Consumers' Association has already highlighted the shortfalls in the system and is currently researching the whole area of dental care provision. But there is a separate problem emerging: the private dentists to which increasing numbers of people are having to turn are not regulated. The Care Standards Act, which came in last year, applies to all areas of private health care provision except private dentistry. This means that if you think your dentist, operating under private terms, has failed to explain charging structures clearly, or think that the work carried out is substandard, your only recourse is to sue. "More and more people are using private dental services, and not necessarily by choice. This is one area of private health care that must not be permitted to continue to operate without proper safeguards in place for patients. It's appalling that private work done by dentists is not properly regulated," says Clara Macay, principal policy adviser for the Consumers' Association. A private members bill which would regulate dentists under the Care Standards Commission, the new private healthcare watchdog agency which is due to be established next year, is currently going through parliament. Back to the DoH, which says: "The government wants dentistry firmly back within the NHS. That is an ambitious target, but the dental strategy shows how, by working together with the profession and the NHS, we can achieve it." If our difficulties in finding such a dentist from the long list of practices which state quite categorically that they carry out NHS work are typical, then this could take quite some time.

webTitle: British holidaymaker killed in Moroccan bus crash

fields.headline: British holidaymaker killed in Moroccan bus crash
fields.trailText: A British woman has been killed in a minibus accident in Morocco.
fields.body:
A British woman has been killed in a minibus accident in Morocco.

The 41-year-old woman, who comes from York but has not been named, was travelling with a party of 17 people on a rambling holiday in Morocco.

The Moroccan driver of the minibus was stated to be in a coma in hospital and two other passengers suffered broken shoulders. Six other holidaymakers were flying home yesterday and a further four were expected to return home today.

Another six passengers were still in hospital, but the majority were expected to be released over the weekend.

Eight Moroccans were understood to have died in the second vehicle.

The British group, who had organised the trip with Ramblers' Holidays, were on a day trip to the imperial cities of Morocco in two separate minibuses, when the accident happened between Marrakesh and Benimallal on Thursday morning.

Stuart Alderman, a spokesman for Ramblers' Holidays, which is part of the Ramblers' Association, said the two minibuses were travelling within the regulation 80 kilometre per hour speed limit when they collided with a vehicle travelling in the opposite direction.

He said the accident appeared to have happened when a people carrier, transporting prisoners, veered into the path of the minibuses. It appeared that a prisoner in the people carrier had grabbed the steering wheel, causing the vehicle to swerve violently.

"It hit the first minibus, then crashed head on into the second minibus, killing a woman in the front seat," he said. The British holidaymakers were aged between 36 and 69.

The British consulate in Casablanca said that those injured in the crash were taken to Ibn Toufail hospital in Marrakesh.

Moroccan roads are notoriously dangerous and each year 3,200 people die in accidents, most of them bus crashes. The accidents are often blamed on bad roads and vehicles which are in poor condition.

webTitle: The Budget: That box: what's in it for you?

fields.headline: That box: what's in it for you?
fields.standfirst:
The Chancellor has up to £4bn to give away. Liz Stuart and Phillip Inman compile a wishlist

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Chancellor has up to £4bn to give away. Liz Stuart and Phillip Inman compile a wishlist.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown has £3bn to £4bn to give away over the next two years, according to the Institute of Fiscal Studies. He has already splashed out £1.7bn on his package for motorists: the rest could be up for grabs in Wednesday's Budget. We asked a range of bodies representing consumer interests what they would like to see in Mr Brown's red box.

Long-term care

The Chancellor has dodged the issue of who will pay nursing and residential care in old age ever since the last election. Most pensioner groups want an end to all charges - a simple solution that would stop people having to sell their homes to pay for care services. But the cost is believed to be £1.1bn, rising to £2.4bn in 2021.

Retirement

Along with most pensioner groups, the TUC is looking for a restoration of the link between the basic state pension and the earnings or prices index, whichever is higher. It wants to replace the minimum income guarantee, which tops up the state pension with income support payments, with an age-related supplement of £22 a week for a single person and £29 per couple. Age Concern says it wants the Chancellor to use his pot to move the state pension closer to its stated target of £90 a week.

The Chartered Institute of Taxation is taking a slightly different stance: it wants pensions to be given the best tax breaks, making it more attractive for long-term saving than Isas or unit or investment trusts. "Isas are about saving money to spend, whereas pensions are about people not having to rely on the state in their old age," says the institute's deputy president, John Whiting.

The National Association of Pension Funds is calling for greater flexibility over the retirement age: it wants people to be able to draw just one part of their pension, allowing them to downshift to a less stressful job and so continue working beyond 65. The other part of their pension would be taken later on. "There needs to be a rethink on the issue of compulsion. There is a danger that the new stakeholder pensions will not be as attractive without compulsion," he adds.

Childcare

Gingerbread, the organisation supporting lone parents, is pushing for additional paid parental leave which could be taken at any point in the child's life. This would be particularly useful at times of change or during school holidays.

It also says that benefit poverty traps must be tackled. Many people who qualify for the Working Families Tax Credit find they no longer qualify for housing benefit, which makes them no better off, says a spokeswoman.

The TUC, meanwhile, wants the new Children's Tax Credit to increase by £1.50 a week to £10.

Savings and investment

The Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds (Autif) is looking for just one thing on Wednesday: a change in the way stamp duty is charged on the buying of shares within a fund of funds (a fund which, as the name suggests, trades only in other funds rather than in stocks themselves - the ultimate collective, and therefore risk-averse, investment). Currently the duty is effectively charged three times, and Autif would like to see it levied just once.

Tax

"We want the whole taxation regime to be simplified. While it may look like there are only three tax bands, because of the multitude of exceptions and clauses and bits and pieces, it's actually more complicated than that: just look at the number of people who can't fill out their self-assessment forms," says the Chartered Institute of Taxation's Mr Whiting, echoing the call of many groups that despair of Mr Brown's complicated tax reforms.

Age Concern, meanwhile, would like more pensioners to join the non-taxpaying community (two-thirds of retired people pay tax). It says the best way to do this is to increase the levels of age- related personal allowances.

The workplace

The Low Pay Unit is calling for an increase in the minimum wage from £3.70. "Ideally we would like to see it going up to £5," says director Bharti Patel. The unit also wants an enforcement agency covering all employment rights issues, to be set up. "Even if we get an indication that the Chancellor is looking to bring this in, we will be very pleased," she says. And it is calling for a reform of the National Insurance system so that the low-paid become eligible for the full benefits; this could be paid for by abolishing the upper earnings limit to increase contributions from high earners.

The TUC will be keeping its fingers crossed for a new tax credit designed to encourage companies to spend more on research and development and training.

webTitle: Bank offers pause on loan repayments

fields.headline: Bank offers pause on loan repayments
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Thousands of farmers who bank with Barclays are to be offered a three month break from loan repayments as a means of easing the cash flow crisis many are experiencing.
fields.body:
Thousands of farmers who bank with Barclays are to be offered a three month break from loan repayments as a means of easing the cash flow crisis many are experiencing.

The bank, which counts one in three of the UK's farmers among its customers, is offering the repayment delays to all its farming customers, regardless of whether they are livestock farmers.

Other businesses, such as hauliers which specialise in moving livestock around the country, will be considered for the help with repayments on a case-by-case basis.

Farmers and hundreds of associated businesses have seen their income evaporate overnight as a result of the foot and mouth outbreak.

Those forced to incinerate their herds have lost all chance of generating any revenue for months.

The government has promised compensation, but many of those affected fear the time delay until any cash is received could be fatal for their businesses.

Grant Phillips, managing director of Barclays' agricultural banking division, said: "In this fast-changing situation, short-term cash flow is a major issue to our farming customers.

"This three month repayment break will, we hope, ease their immediate financial worries."

Interest will still accrue on the loans during the three month period when no repayments are being made, but customers will be able to extend their current loan by three months to ease future repayments, if necessary.

Barclays suspended all farm visits on February 22, when the national ban on livestock movements was announced. Its managers are now contacting farming customers by phone to identify cash flow and viability issues.

webTitle: Analysis: supermarkets as scapegoats for Foot and Mouth

fields.headline: Using the supermarkets as handy scapegoats
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's attack on supermarkets for "putting an armlock" on British farming fulfilled a need to find a clearly identifiable scapegoat for the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's attack on supermarkets for "putting an armlock" on British farming fulfilled a need to find a clearly identifiable scapegoat for the foot and mouth crisis.

Recent Labour party focus groups have been telling him that voters feel angry at not being in control of their daily lives.

Mr Blair and Gordon Brown were warned recently by Steve Morgan, an adviser to both Labour and the former US vice-president Al Gore, that they would need to watch out for the unpredictable events "that have the potential to explode in their faces".

These are the issues that give ordinary people the impression that we teeter on the verge of chaos - train crashes, floods, fuel crises.

The latest, apparently out of the blue, is foot and mouth. The prime minister's promise at a farmers' meeting in Gloucestershire on Thursday night to find a long-term solution to the problem of low prices paid by the big five supermarkets to farmers struck a chord. With very few exceptions, it now costs farmers more to produce food than they can sell it for.

According to Mike Hart of the small and family farms alliance, 50 years ago 50-60% of every pound spent by the consumer on food was returned to the farmer. Today in much of Europe and North America the figure is down to only 10-20%, while in the UK the share is 9%. Before the outbreak of foot and mouth, the price farmers could get at the abattoir for a kilogram of beef was 81p; in 1989 it was £1.25.

The big five supermarkets, Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda, Safeway and Somerfield, account for roughly 80% of grocery sales. This concentration of retail power is far greater than in the rest of the EU or in the US markets. The profit margins of the big five are correspondingly higher, averaging about 6% in the UK, compared with about 2.5% in Europe and the US.

Supermarkets here also exercise great power over their suppliers because they are so dominant in food sales. Manufacturers and producers cannot afford not to have a presence in their outlets, and supermarkets are able to dictate the terms. Manufacturers typically carry the cost of any promotions.

In saying that he will look at ways to redress the imbalance, Mr Blair, an early champion of the hi-tech, bio-tech approach, is picking up relatively late on the growing sense among consumers that our agricultural system makes no sense.

But he will find it hard to pin it all on the supermarkets. To suggest that they alone are responsible for the current state of affairs is an oversimplified view, as his friends Lord Sainsbury, minister at the Department of Trade and Industry and £2m donor to the Labour party, and Tesco, £12m sponsor of the Millennium Dome, will immediately have told him.

Tesco declared itself surprised at his remarks. A courier was dispatched to Downing Street first thing yesterday with letters "seeking urgent clarification" of what he meant. Asda's quick riposte was that it thought the Ministry of Agriculture was responsible for farming policy.

Mr Blair's accusation is undermined by the findings of the competition commission, which as recently as last October cleared the supermarkets of profiteering.

The inquiry, which began at the height of the government's campaign against "rip-off Britain", was a damp squib.

It took 18 months and spent an estimated £20m to conclude that the supermarket industry was "broadly competitive".

The report did show how the concentration of power could create a "climate of apprehension" among suppliers and give the supermarkets disturbing leverage. The watchdog unearthed 52 ways in which supermarkets were alleged to have used that power, including"requests" for retrospective discounts.

One supplier claimed to have been asked for cash payments from one supermarket chain three times in a few months. "The third was by telephone for £100,000 .. as a contribution towards profits," according to the report.

However, the commission did not impose any dramatic sanctions, recommending only that supermarkets should be made to abide by a legally binding code of practice. It is agreement on this code that Mr Blair is now saying he wants to see hurried up.

Planning laws, which rarely give permission for two out-of-town superstores in the same place, have prevented the sector from being truly competitive.

As supply chains have become longer and more complicated, the cost of the food itself has become a smaller part of the price we pay for groceries. The processors, packagers, marketers, and distributors all want to add their margins along the way.

Cutting out the middle men and encouraging shoppers to deal more directly with the producers sounds attractive. But working patterns have changed.

In the past women spent many hours a day buying food in several different shops. The success of supermarkets has been at least in part a response to the changing needs of working women.

And no review of British farming policy will have any impact without an overhaul of the EU common agriculture policy.

fields.headline: Theatre world backs 'ball-breaker' attack
fields.standfirst: Shows 'too expensive, too exclusive and broader audience is needed'
fields.trailText: Shows 'too expensive, too exclusive and broader audience is needed.'
fields.body:
It sounded like the most controversial of rebukes when Sir Richard Eyre, formerly artistic director of the National Theatre, damned aspects of contemporary drama as "head-burningly, ball-breakingly, bowel-churningly bad".

But yesterday leading figures in the theatre world queued up to endorse much of his speech to an industry conference on Thursday, which attacked the staleness of some companies and urged both his peers and the government to make drama accessible to a wider range of people.

Sir Richard told his audience that subsidies were crucial to ensure that going to the theatre was as cheap as going to the cinema, encouraging the public to try out new plays.

"To be asked to pay £25 or even £35 to see a modestly successful production in the theatre when you can buy a hardback book or CD for half the price or go to the cinema for a third just doesn't wash," he warned.

"On top of that, to be asked to pay £3 to read in a programme that the leading actor started his career in Worthing and loves cats is to invite contempt."

But despite his stinging words, most of those in the theatre world seem to feel he had a point. "He could have gone an awful lot further," said Dominic Dromgoole, artistic director of the Oxford Stage Company. "Theatre's too expensive, too exclusive and we need to concentrate on getting a broader audience in.

"Ticket prices are too expensive and that has to be looked into very hard. The case for more subsidies is unanswerable, but you also have to look at the theatre world and ask where the money is going.

"Quite a few companies are almost ludicrously staff-happy and spend so much on development, marketing, infrastructure and admin, you end up seeing two people on stage with no set and 20p for costumes."

His criticisms of high prices were backed up by Philip Hedley, artistic director at the Theatre Royal in Stratford, east London, who accused his peers of being out of touch.

"People in charge of theatres just don't realise what serious poverty is," he complained. "They often think of good concessions being £5 or £10, but an OAP or student can't afford that. Around 60% of our audience comes in for £2 because we are in the poorest district in the country."

Even leading commercial producers felt Sir Richard had accurately summed up the state of modern theatre, with the impresario Raymond Gubbay welcoming his insistence that subsidised theatre should focus on work that could not be found elsewhere.

"He was hard-hitting and right on target," said Mr Gubbay. "There has been a tendency in some theatres to go for obvious musicals, which are not necessarily what subsidies are for.

"To create My Fair Lady at the National Theatre and then have it immediately move to Drury Lane to me seems to be almost a negation of what the National is about."

Those accusations were echoed by Graham Sheffield, artistic director at the Barbican, central London.

"I think there may be some staleness creeping in," he admitted. "But the financial uncertainties on some companies have led to them feeling unable to take risks.

"Our theatres could be more inclusive and experimental in addressing certain areas of contemporary theatre - which in itself makes theatre more interesting and accessible and encourages young people to come."

Others suggested that insularity was to blame for complacency. Echoing Sir Richard's criticism of theatre companies - which he said had a finite lifespan and rarely "[managed] to sustain artistic ardour beyond seven years," - Ian Albery, chief executive of and producer at Sadler's Wells, said that Britain needed to look to its neighbours.

"Sadler's Wells is a window to the world because we bring in the finest international companies," he said.

"British theatre very often hasn't had the rigour of seeing the best of international work and judging itself against that. It's like developing athletics without the stimulus of the international Olympic Games."

But Sir Richard's peers were keen to point out that he had also enthused at length about much modern theatre and its ability to challenge and elate audiences.

"We cannot afford to be complacent, but theatre is still very challenging and inspiring and addresses issues which exercise us all," said producer Thelma Holt.

"When it does work, it's the most radical and exciting cultural experience we have got," agreed Ian Rickson, artistic director of the Royal Court, which was last year named as the European theatre of the year.

The theatre has packed in young audiences by selling tickets for as little as £5 and standing places for just 10p but Mr Rickson insisted that its commitment to running challenging new plays by young, often little-known authors had been just as crucial in attracting new playgoers.

webTitle: Push to go organic tests farmers

fields.headline: Push to go organic tests farmers
fields.standfirst: Germany sets biggest EU target after food scares
fields.trailText: Germany sets biggest EU target after food scares
fields.byline: John Hooper and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
Hans-Peter Wendt is in his element as he kicks around a football with 20-odd six-week-old piglets on his organic farm at Wallmow, north of Berlin. Their squeals as they toss the ball from snout to snout and pull at his trouser legs are signs of contentment, he says proudly.

Free from antibiotics and other chemicals, and warmed solely by their own body heat, which rises in a three-foot layer of mist above the hay, the animals are more robust than those reared on conventional farms, says Mr Wendt. He lets them feed out of his hand - pellets of pea, wheat, and rye, pressed together with rape seed oil. He pops a few in his own mouth to prove that he only gives his animals what he is prepared to consume himself.

In 1991, following the fall of the iron curtain, Mr Wendt, now aged 49, returned to the stretch of land his ancestors began farming in 1688. Within four years he had transformed an East German state-run intensive collective into a 1,400-hectare (3,500-acre) cooperative. Today it is reunified Germany's largest organic farm.

But if Renate Künast, the new agriculture minister, gets her way, there may soon be organic farms in Germany even bigger than the one at Wallmow.

Ms Künast, a Green, was swept into the cabinet in January on a wave of public disquiet over the government's handling of the BSE crisis and the effects of intensive farming methods. She has said she wants 10% of Germany's agricultural land to be organic in five years and 20% in 10.

It would be by far the biggest and fastest conversion of its kind undertaken in Europe. But can it be achieved ? And, if so, how? The answers to those questions will be of keen interest outside Germany - and nowhere more so than in Britain where Tony Blair yesterday said he wanted talks with supermarket bosses and farmers' leaders to chart a long-term future for the food and agriculture industries.

When Ms Künast announced her 20% target, at an agricultural show in Berlin, there was an audible gasp from her audience, made up mainly of farmers. But Michael Lohse of the Deutsche Bauern Verband (DBV), the German farmers' union, insists his organisation remains agnostic on the issue. "It's no problem. Even 30% would be no problem," he says. "But we know that most of the consumers do not want it. Right now, we have more consumers buying organic. But when normality returns, things will go back to what they were before."

Others, though, believe consumer sentiment has gone beyond a point of no return. New fears this week, over foot and mouth disease, have heightened alarm and strengthened the case of the organic farming lobby whose representatives have argued that the conditions in which intensively reared animals are kept and moved favours the spread of disease.

For Germany's farmers today there are no easy choices. If they go organic, their union says, they risk not having a market for their produce. But if they keep to the established, intensive methods, and the demand for organic produce holds up, there is the danger that others will meet it. Denmark, which is committed to a detailed programme of conversion to organic methods, is right next door.

"Since Ms Künast took office, we have had more than 1,000 calls from farmers seeking information," says Thomas Dosch, the director of Bioland, the largest of six bodies in Germany representing organic producers.

Hans-Peter Wendt, who joined Bioland in 1991, remembers the five-year transition programme as "the hardest years of my life".

"I had been told in advance that initially, without the use of sprays and chemical fertilisers, yields were going to be low, and that weeds had to be allowed to take over. But the reality was shocking and went against everything I'd learned at college."

Slowly, results began to show, helped, he says, by high-quality soil. He and his 18 partners in the cooperative now have 160 dairy cows. They produce 2,500 tonnes of six different types of grain. And they send 1,000 pigs, 1,000 sheep and more than 100 beef cattle to slaughter each year.

But, as Mr Wendt himself acknowledges, it will take a lot for farmers to want to make the leap. Average conversion costs are between 450 and 600 marks per hectare per annum. How much the authorities contribute varies from region to region. But it does not vary according to the type of farm - and conversion is easier for some than for others.

Intensive farmers who rear pigs or produce poultry or veal find it particularly hard, says Thomas Dosch. Another factor is soil quality.

"If you are in an area where you have high yields, the costs are higher," says Hiltrud Nieberg, of the Federal Agricultural Research Centre in Brunswick.

All these problems can no doubt be tackled if there is sufficient political will in Berlin - and at the European commission in Brussels, which sets EU-wide limits to the level of conversion grants.

But there is another hurdle which is specific to Germany: the lack of an effective distribution system for organic produce.

"The price difference between organic and non-organic food is greater in Germany than in Britain," says Ms Nieberg. "And in Britain more organic food is sold through supermarkets; in Germany, most of it is sold in health food shops."

One result is that Hans-Peter Wendt cannot consume his own produce. Once it leaves his farm - for pasteurising or slaughtering - there is no local supplier to make it available to him.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 17m see soap shooting | Family jailed for drug laundering | Woman, 92, raped | Marquis's home to be hotel | Twins 'should go back to US' | Irving given time for appeal | Star's daughter mugged
fields.body:
17m see soap shooting

About 17m viewers tuned in for the last 15 minutes of Thursday's episode of EastEnders to see the shooting of hardman Phil Mitchell, one of the biggest audiences for the soap in over a year. The episode, which also saw club owner Steve Owen marry Queen Vic barmaid Mel Healy, pulled in an average audience of 15.4m, a 58% share of the audience.

Family jailed for drug laundering

A 64-year-old grandmother and her two daughters were jailed yesterday at Leicester crown court for their part in laundering £1.5m of drugs money. Harbhajan Rai was sentenced to nine years and her daughters Davinder, 30, and Parminder, 40, to seven and five years. The business was run by Harbhajan's son Mohinder Singh Rai, who was sentenced to 12 years in jail in 1997.

Woman, 92, raped

A 92-year-old woman was raped on her way home from an Ipswich supermarket by a man who dragged her to a parking area. Police said the woman, who was released from hospital yesterday, was deeply shocked and specialist officers were working with her to find out the full details.

Marquis's home to be hotel

The east wing of Ickworth House, the former ancestral home of the Marquis of Bristol, could open as a luxury hotel by the end of the year after the present owners, the National Trust, reached agreement with the LHM hotel chain.

Twins 'should go back to US'

The internet twins adopted by the British couple Judith and Alan Kilshaw should be returned to the US to decide custody, the St Louis circuit court in Missouri has ruled after an application by their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, and father, Aaron.

Irving given time for appeal

The historian David Irving yesterday had his application for leave to appeal against a libel case ruling which branded him a holocaust denier put back from mid-March until June to allow him to raise funds for a specialist QC. He had argued his own case in the original action against the US academic Deborah Lipstadt and the publisher Penguin over her book Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory.

Star's daughter mugged

Tara Newley, 37, the daughter of the actor Joan Collins, has been mugged for a £7,000 Cartier watch in Notting Hill, west London.

fields.headline: Jericho under siege once more
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 years after Joshua reputedly brought the walls of Jericho tumbling down with a mighty blast of his trumpet, the town is under siege once more.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 years after Joshua reputedly brought the walls of Jericho tumbling down with a mighty blast of his trumpet, the town is under siege once more.

The Israeli army has encircled the town with an 11 mile (18km) trench in the desert sand, turning this sleepy oasis into a virtual prison for its 33,000 inhabitants. Two metres deep and almost as wide, it snakes along route 90, the main artery through the Jordan river valley, before turning west to seal off the town from the south.

There is now only one way out of the ancient town - unless residents resort to hiking through the forbidding mountains that guard the northern and western approaches to Jericho - a single road dominated by an Israeli army checkpoint that opens and closes, Palestinians say, at the whim of Israeli soldiers.

"If they close the checkpoint, not even a fly can enter the town," said Adham Taher, a bulldozer driver.

Israeli diggers began gouging out the trench a month ago, largely to protect Jewish motorists using the strategic route 90, one of only two roads linking central Israel to northern Galilee. Although Jericho has been the quietest town in the West Bank during the five-month uprising, an Israeli army spokesman said yesterday that sporadic shooting at the road by Palestinian gunmen was intolerable. He denied the trench represented a form of collective punishment.

"The extreme situation here is that Palestinian gunmen are preventing Israelis from having a normal life," said Lieutenant Colonel Olivier Rafowicz. "No one in the world can put up with shooting. Even if one bullet is fired during the day, or during the night, and another after one week, or 10 days, it prevents people from having a normal life, and in this specific case, we are talking about a vital road."

The siege has devastated the town's economy, which once relied on punters at the region's only legal casino, and tourists visiting its ancient ruins.

Elsewhere in the West Bank yesterday a Palestinian boy, aged nine, was shot dead by Israeli soldiers outside his home in the Ramallah area.

Another Palestinian was shot dead in the Gaza Strip. Palestinians said the 40-year-old had learning difficulties. The Israeli army said he had been trying to plant a bomb on a main road.

According to the official army magazine, Bamahane, there are plans to dig trenches around other towns in the West Bank, enabling the military to tighten the noose around Palestinian population centres without having to deploy additional soldiers.

fields.headline: Branson threatens to sue Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
More about transport
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail industry was thrown into a fresh crisis last night when Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail group threatened to take Railtrack to court to recoup £100m of lost revenue caused by four months of chaos in the industry after the Hatfield rail crash.
fields.body:
The rail industry was thrown into a fresh crisis last night when Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail group threatened to take Railtrack to court to recoup £100m of lost revenue caused by four months of chaos in the industry after the Hatfield rail crash.

This, the first significant threat by a rail company, highlights the deep losses that have borne by the big train operating companies over the past few months, even with the help of government subsidies.

It was followed later yesterday by a statement from Great North Eastern Railways, which said it was still negotiating with Railtrack for compensation payments. GNER trains were innocently involved at Hatfield and in the Selby rail crash earlier this week.

Sir Richard, who operates the west coast mainline jointly with Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, says Railtrack is neither recognising Virgin's total claim for losses nor making interim compensation payments fast enough.

Both Virgin and Stagecoach, which has a 49% stake in Sir Richard's company, are expected to post joint losses of £50m as a direct result of the Hatfield crash and the near closure of the network.

The news that Stagecoach was forced to issue its second profits warning within 12 months led to a 22% drop in the company's share price.

The news will ring alarm bells with the government. It is a warning that private companies will not invest in the railways unless the network is safe and has been modernised.

Keith Cochrane, Stagecoach's chief executive, said: "Having taken legal advice, Virgin Rail is in an ongoing dialogue with Railtrack about the amount of further compensation payments and has not ruled out any further courses of action."

He said the situation had taken Virgin Rail from profit to loss. Revenues had fallen by 32% from October to February - "and at the end the ultimate option is to go to court".

Stagecoach executives are upset that Railtrack's share price hardly alters, bolstered by the knowledge that the government is always likely to step in with more money to sustain its position.

Railtrack said last night that it had reached an agreement with the train operating companies on compensation and was not prepared to negotiate any more. It has set aside £600m to pay for the aftermath of Hatfield, £400m of which will go directly to the train companies.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, said passengers were beginning to return and numbers were the same as 12 months ago. Virgin has launched a half-fare promotion exercise to win passengers back. It has cost £10m but Mr Green said it was still too early to predict the long-term impact of the disruption. Railtrack has promised to return the network to normal working for Virgin by April 23, but cross-country services will be subject to delay until the summer.

The strategic rail authority last night backed off from a row with Railtrack, saying it had approved the company's estimates for the upgrade of the east coast mainline between London and Edinburgh.

GNER trains were innocently involved at Hatfield and in the Selby rail crash earlier this week. Sir Richard, who operates the west coast mainline jointly with Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, says Railtrack is neither recognising Virgin's total claim for losses nor making interim compensation payments fast enough. Both Virgin and Stagecoach, which has a 49% stake in Sir Richard's company, are expected to post joint losses of £50m as a direct result of the Hatfield crash and the near closure of the network. The news that Stagecoach was forced to issue its second profits warning within 12 months led to a 22% drop in the company's share price. The news will ring alarm bells with the government. It is a warning that private companies will not invest in the railways unless the network is safe and has been modernised. Keith Cochrane, Stagecoach's chief executive, said: "Having taken legal advice, Virgin Rail is in an ongoing dialogue with Railtrack about the amount of further compensation payments and has not ruled out any further courses of action." He said the situation had taken Virgin Rail from profit to loss. Revenues had fallen by 32% from October to February - "and at the end the ultimate option is to go to court". Stagecoach executives are upset that Railtrack's share price hardly alters, bolstered by the knowledge that the government is always likely to step in with more money to sustain its position. Railtrack said last night that it had reached an agreement with the train operating companies on compensation and was not prepared to negotiate any more. It has set aside £600m to pay for the aftermath of Hatfield, £400m of which will go directly to the train companies. Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, said passengers were beginning to return and numbers were the same as 12 months ago. Virgin has launched a half-fare promotion exercise to win passengers back. It has cost £10m but Mr Green said it was still too early to predict the long-term impact of the disruption. Railtrack has promised to return the network to normal working for Virgin by April 23, but cross-country services will be subject to delay until the summer. The strategic rail authority last night backed off from a row with Railtrack, saying it had approved the company's estimates for the upgrade of the east coast mainline between London and Edinburgh.

webTitle: Blair in row with supermarkets over Foot and Mouth

fields.headline: Blair sparks stores row
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Major supermarket chains were at loggerheads with Tony Blair yesterday after he accused them of having farmers in an "armlock" to produce cheap food and appeared to blame them for the current plight of British farming.
fields.byline: Felicity Lawrence  and John Vidal Felicity Lawrence and John Vidal
fields.body:
Major supermarket chains were at loggerheads with Tony Blair yesterday after he accused them of having farmers in an "armlock" to produce cheap food and appeared to blame them for the current plight of British farming.

Most retailers reported signs of panic buying as the public responded to speculation about shortages of meat by stocking up not just on meat and poultry but also on other emergency supplies of food such as milk, dried milk, pasta and frozen meals.

Fears of shortages took a new twist yesterday with eight more cases of foot and mouth disease being confirmed, bringing the total to 40. But farmers were thrown a lifeline with the decision to allow licensed movement of animals in areas not affected.

Demand for meat has surged by between 40% and 50% and supermarkets have struggled to keep their shelves stocked, even though they have adequate supplies at their depots and plans for imports in place should British meat run out.

Asda accused Mr Blair of looking for a scapegoat amid concerns that falling farming standards and the industrialisation of food might have contributed to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

"If Mr Blair wants to play politics that is up to him. We were under the impression that it was the Ministry of Agriculture, and not the supermarkets, which set agri-policy in this country," a spokesperson said.

The prime minister's comments had been made to farmers and Labour party supporters at Hartpury agricultural college in Gloucestershire on Thursday. "We all want cheaper food, but on the other hand the supermarkets have pretty much got an armlock on you people at the moment," he said.

He also suggested that the pressure to close small abattoirs had come from supermarkets, a development which has been blamed for the rapid spread of the disease. Once the crisis was over, he wanted talks to review the future of the food industry, he added.

Tesco said it was surprised at his comments and was seeking urgent clarification, given that a recent competition commission inquiry had found that supermarkets were not guilty of profiteering.

Later, a spokesman for the prime minister insisted Mr Blair was not trying to scapegoat the supermarkets. "It is ludicrous to suggest that the prime minister was in some way blaming the supermarkets for foot and mouth," the spokesman said.

"He believes supermarkets are playing an important role during the current outbreak. As the competition commission report identified last autumn, there is an issue around the relationship between supermarkets and their suppliers, and the office of fair trading is currently consulting on a code of practice in this area."

To add to consumers' growing sense of crisis, the safety of foreign meat was called into question as the independent food standards agency disclosed that consignments of beef from Germany and Holland imported into East Sussex were found to contain remnants of spinal chord, which are banned under BSE regulations.The FSA said local authorities and the meat hygiene service had been told to increase BSE-related checks.

The new cases confirmed yesterday were in Tyne and Wear, Worcestershire, Staffordshire, Wiltshire, Dumfries and Galloway, Essex and Cumbria. One case, at Kirkoswald, Cumbria, is believed to have spread via vehicle tyres. The rest were linked to local markets and abattoirs where outbreaks had already occurred.

Under arrangements authorised yesterday, local authorities will issue licences to farmers and abattoirs to move and receive livestock, and animals will be taken to collection points or direct to slaughterhouses in disinfected trucks.

All animals will have to be killed within 24 hours and be declared free of foot and mouth by the farmer, said Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister, and there will be no mixing of pigs, which are particularly susceptible to the foot and mouth virus, with other animals. The first animals are expected to start moving on Monday or Tuesday.

Further restrictions on countryside access were imposed yesterday. The National Trust for Scotland placed off-limits all its rural and countryside properties. Large parts of the Lake and Peak districts were closed to walkers; and the Reading, Berkshire, half-marathon on March 11 was cancelled.

webTitle: 'Here I am, unable to talk or eat. And still, bizarrely, I am happy'

fields.headline: 'Here I am, unable to talk or eat. And still, bizarrely, I am happy'
fields.standfirst: John Diamond, January 1 2000, The Guardian
fields.trailText: I greet the millennium as one who has discovered himself to be, surprisingly and against all professional and personal instincts, an obsessive counter of blessings, a glass-half-full optimist rather than a half-empty cynic, a cheery spotter of silver linings cladding the greyest of clouds. It is a state which I commend to you, if you are up to it.
fields.body:
I greet the millennium as one who has discovered himself to be, surprisingly and against all professional and personal instincts, an obsessive counter of blessings, a glass-half-full optimist rather than a half-empty cynic, a cheery spotter of silver linings cladding the greyest of clouds. It is a state which I commend to you, if you are up to it.

The smart money says I will not be around to see in another, and more mundane, new year but then, the prognosis for my cancerous decline was such that I was not due to be around to celebrate this one - so what do I know?

But, in counting my blessings, I am rather surprised at how many of them are of my own creation. This is no boast, because I imagine most of yours are too. Or, more accurately, if they are not of my own creation then they are not of anyone else's either. But before you grab your pen and start that "easy for him to say" letter, hear me out.

I am a child of the 1960s, the scion of toilers in most of the political parties of the near and far left, and, until the cancer got me, a Labour party member whose activity varied from teenage zealot to middle-aged and desultory knocker-on-of-doors at election time. I joined at 16 and could never quite bring myself to leave.

Nor can I yet, even though I will never again harangue a local ward meeting about whatever it was that so engaged me in my haranguing days. That is the sort of foolish optimist I am, see? I have spent most of my life believing that, in broad terms at least, political change is all there is. Take a barbarian state, chuck a handful of sound politics at it: bingo, case closed, everybody happy.

In those same broad terms, as the father of children at a state school, as the recipient of any amount of NHS treatment, as a regular driver on municipally maintained roads, and an eager depositor of trash in municipal landfills, I believe it still.

Free education, reasonable transport, and public sanitation are pretty key representatives of the sort of things our antecedents saw as the eventual result of their political fight. But to say that I am happy because the children have an education, the dustbins are emptied once a week, and the local roads are more or less free of potholes is a pretty feeble definition of happiness - even though I know that if the children were not at school and the bins were not emptied, I would be less happy.

But then again, here I am unable to talk or eat in any real sense of the words - aware that, compared with most men of my age, I have breathed a greater proportion of the total breaths I am ever likely to breathe. And still, bizarrely, I am happy.

Sure, I spend some of the time being temporarily terrified of things that prescription drugs cannot address, and there are times when I am uncomfortable to the point of suffering pain. At dinner parties I am the non-eating one trying to get a scribbled word into the gaps and, subsequently, the one sitting in a frustrated sulk because I managed to write the bon mot down only after its moment had passed; and in shops you will find me spoken to as a drooling imbecile by assistants who imagine that anyone unable to speak properly must by that token be unable to hear, think, or work out how many 50p pieces make two quid. But, despite all, here I am: a smug and idiotically grinning Pollyanna in a world too much of which has been rebuilt along the sour lines of a Daily Mail headline writer. And, as I say, political activism did not have a lot to do with it.

The things that make me happy are not particularly special, except inasmuch as they are special to me. A wife I love and who, bizarrely, loves me, children who are bright and happy, friends who do all the things I demand of them, and who make only those requests of me that I can feel good about accepting. There are material things too, of course - the cosy house, the comfortable car that starts in the morning, the good fortune to have fluked one of the few non-menial jobs that I could do in my current state, and which pays better than most. I am lucky and am aware of just how much of my contentment is down to luck.

webTitle: John Diamond, an ordinary coward, dies at 47

fields.headline: John Diamond, an ordinary coward, dies at 47
fields.standfirst: Prime minister leads tributes to journalist who chronicled his terminal cancer with courage, humour and insight
fields.trailText: Prime minister leads tributes to journalist who chronicled his terminal cancer with courage, humour and insight
fields.body:
John Diamond, the columnist and author who chronicled his struggle with cancer with humour and what he always insisted was ordinary cowardice, not courage, died from his illness yesterday. The 47-year-old journalist, whose weekly column in the Times won praise for the directness with which he confronted his illness, was admitted to the Royal Marsden hospital in London on Wednesday. After spending some time with his wife, the food writer Nigella Lawson, he lost consciousness on Thursday. The couple have two children, Cosima, seven and Bruno, four.

Surgery on his tongue had left Diamond unable to speak, but he continued to communicate vigorously in writing until days before his death. In an email circulated among friends two weeks ago, he informed them that he would be returning to hospital for more chemotherapy but joked that he hoped to be in remission "long enough for Glaxo Wellcome or Boots to come up with a cure".

In what proved to be his last column, published a week ago in the Times, Diamond described the course of treatment he was about to start. "Next week I start chemotherapy again. Three lots of it at three-weekly intervals as a puking outpatient," he wrote. "And this time my hair will fall out, just like a real cancer patient's, and I'll have to start wearing one of those jokey baseball caps that child leukaemia patients always wear when they have their pictures taken by the local paper."

Friends and colleagues, led by Tony Blair, paid tribute to a man whose repeated successes in overcoming earlier bouts of throat cancer led many to believe he might survive for several years more.

"The prime minister and Mrs Blair were saddened to hear the news of John's death," Mr Blair's official spokesman said in a statement. "Their thoughts and prayers are with Nigella and the children, who have lost a much-loved husband and father. His many friends will recall not just his humour but the extraordinary courage he showed as he fought his illness."

Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, said: "He always denied being brave, but of course he was immensely brave. He charted his encounter with cancer (he refused to call it a fight) in a remarkable way - painfully honest, painfully funny and sometimes just pain-filled." Last week he had attended a party organised by Tina Brown, editor of Talk magazine, where he was "scribbling one-liners, eyes full of mischief, living the life he had left to the full. It was an extraordinary life."

Peter Stothard, editor of the Times, said in a statement: "John Diamond brought all his skill as a journalist to report for the Times from the frontline of the cancer war. He shed unique light on a dark disease. That light will be John Diamond's lasting legacy."

Alan Yentob, director of drama and entertainment at the BBC and a close friend of Diamond's, said: "He was someone who lost some of the faculties most critical to his life - his voice, when he was a broadcaster who loved talking; Nigella is a brilliant cook but he could never taste any of that - and yet during that period he was more essentially himself than he had been before."

Born in Hackney, east London, to a biochemist father and artist mother, Diamond, trained and worked as an English and drama teacher but entered journalism by talking a post on a property newsletter into a job on the Sunday Times, where he quickly developed a reputation for fearsome productivity.

"John in hospital, having chemotherapy, taking liquids into a stomach tube, could still write a better, funnier, more interesting column than 90% of people on Fleet Street," said Victoria Coren, who adapted the book he wrote about his illness - entitled C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too - into a stage play, A Lump in My Throat. The BBC said last night that a TV adaptation of the play would go ahead, as long as Diamond's family agreed.

Ruth Rogers, co-owner of the River Cafe and godmother to Cosima, recalled a party she and her husband, the architect Lord Rogers, organised in 1999 for the couple's 10th anniversary. "People thought it might be the last time they would ever see him, and were worried it was going to be a wake before the death - but of course John and Nigella walked in and everybody realised it was going to be a fabulously happy occasion."

Roger Alton, editor of the Observer, said: "He was the most lovable man I've ever met. Before and even after he had cancer, and while he was ill, he was easily the chirpiest, funniest, most charming and generous person in any gathering."

Cancer specialists also paid tribute yesterday to Diamond who, together with the columnist Ruth Picardie - who wrote movingly in the Observer of the breast cancer that eventually killed her - broke a journalistic taboo in describing the minutiae of daily life with a terminal illness. Gordon McVie, chief executive of the Cancer Research Campaign, said Diamond had "explained the treatment and diagnosis processes and the whole cancer journey in a way that lifted people's spirits and gave them hope."

Diamond was a vociferous critic of alternative therapies and those who offered what he saw as false hope for cancer sufferers. "The lack of cure is a fact," he wrote in 1999. "Yes, I might go into spontaneous and total remission, and I might also win the national lottery, which has about the same sort of odds. The cancerous cells left in my body couldn't give a damn whether I'm determined to live for ever or not."

webTitle: Revealed: the weapon that doesn't hurt anyone

fields.headline: Revealed: the weapon that doesn't hurt anyone
fields.trailText: The Pentagon has unveiled what is surely the perfect hi-tech weapon for today's PR-conscious US military - one that does not hurt anyone.
fields.body:
The Pentagon has unveiled what is surely the perfect hi-tech weapon for today's PR-conscious US military - one that does not hurt anyone.

Not content with attempting to fight wars in which none of its own soldiers ever gets killed and none of its expensive equipment gets captured, the US defence department has now come up with a weapon which uses electromagnetic waves to attack its opponents without causing injury.

So, out go nasty rubber bullets and teargas, which can actually harm people and create embarrassing television pictures. Please welcome instead the safe and silent modern alternative - the "active denial system".

The new weapon looks suspiciously like a satellite dish mounted on the back of an armoured car. The weapon fires bursts of electromagnetic energy at people up to 650 metres away, causing a burning sensation but without burning them. The aim, in Pentagon-speak, is "to influence motivational behaviour". In other words, to make people run away.

After 10 years of research and $40m, the Pentagon put its new toy on show to journalists this week at its non-lethal weapons centre at Quantico, Virginia, and was immediately confronted by a sceptical press corps which accused the Pentagon of deploying a military version of the microwave oven.

"It's not designed to burn," said Colonel George Fenton at a press conference. "It's a heat-induced sensation."

The weapon fires waves that are shorter and at higher frequencies than those in a microwave, Col Fenton protested. The waves can penetrate clothing but are not powerful enough to go more than 0.4mm into the body, he said.

"It's safe, absolutely safe," Col Fenton said. "You walk out of the beam and the pain goes away. There are no lasting effects."

Not content with attempting to fight wars in which none of its own soldiers ever gets killed and none of its expensive equipment gets captured, the US defence department has now come up with a weapon which uses electromagnetic waves to attack its opponents without causing injury. webTitle: How to ... handle a colleague's surprise promotion

fields.headline: How to ... handle a colleague's surprise promotion
fields.standfirst: Stay cool when being passed over puts your temperature up
fields.trailText: Stay cool when being passed over puts your temperature up
fields.body:
It's a familiar scenario. One day you're working happily together as colleagues, then the next day your peer gets promoted. He or she may not be your new boss, but they're still ahead of you in the pecking order and boy, does it hurt.

Sophie Wallis (not her real name) knows the pain all too well. "I started working as a fashion buyer for a company in London two years ago. Shortly after I started, a girl I vaguely knew from university also joined as a fashion buyer and we built up a friendship," recalls Sophie.

"The chance for promotion came up six months ago and we both went for it. And she got it. Now she's senior to me and I don't mind admitting that it has really disheartened me."

Sophie admits her colleague is very good at her job, but points out that she is not particularly thorough. She also reckons that her colleague got promoted instead of her because she gets on better with the bosses. "It's one of these companies where you get on if you're a favourite," says Sophie.

When Sophie asked her boss why she didn't get the promotion, she was told that her colleague had a better knowledge and understanding of the product area. But Sophie disagrees: "I was passed over for what most people in the company thought was going to be my position.

"I try to be positive and do the best job I can, but I have decided to leave. I'm never going to progress here," she says. "I've had a few interviews already and I'll get a good reference."

Sophie's decision to get on and do the best job she can gets top marks from career experts, but her decision to leave is not regarded as a wise move.

"It smacks of sour grapes," comments Professor Cary Cooper, an occupational psychologist at UMIST. If you stay you might find out things about yourself you may not like to hear, but they will help you improve."

If you've been passed over for promotion, the worst thing you can do is have a seemingly endless pity party. To worry or get angry at your company can be counterproductive, as you'll only end up demotivated and your performance at work will suffer.

Instead, try asking yourself honestly why you didn't get the job. You could begin by drawing up your strengths then looking at your weaknesses. Also consider the strengths of the colleague who was promoted over you. You may well be able to learn something from him or her. And you might consider asking your peers why they think you didn't get the promotion.

Often we miss out on promotion because we are not projecting the right image says Neil Franklin, chief executive of Dataworkforce, a telecoms outsourcing company. He reckons anyone seeking promotion needs to start thinking like a winner and acting like a leader, while maintaining and increasing the value of the company.

"One of the best things an employee can do is promote themselves," he adds. "If you've had some good results let the whole company know. That's how you get noticed. A lot of managers are so busy focusing on the business that you need to go to them and shout about your achievements."

It's worth sparing a thought for the bosses who have to make the tough decision to promote someone ahead of peers of similar ability.

"It is agony and you feel awkward, because you know your decision is going to hurt someone," says Graham Lancaster, chairman of PR company Biss Lancaster.

"But if the person who has missed out is being generous, you will feel better about yourself and think more highly of them. And they will get a promotion themselves that much quicker."

If you don't remember anything else...

Remain well-balanced and congratulate with sincerity the person who got promoted. Don't let setbacks damage your self-confidence and work at making yourself more marketable. And by sticking at what you do best, your talent will be recognised when the next opportunity comes round.

webTitle: What will CVs of the future look like in the drive for jobs?

fields.headline: What will CVs of the future look like in the drive for jobs?
fields.standfirst: They may need to be pretty Flash to get you through the door
fields.trailText: They may need to be pretty Flash to get you through the door
fields.body:
The format of the traditional CV has changed little over the past few decades, but the internet and advances in software are bringing new innovations to this basic currency of job-hunting. Does your CV look a little dated for the 21st century? Give your career hopes a boost by trying one of the following:

The Business Card CV

US magazine Fortune recently suggested that, for movers and shakers who do their career-advancement networking at conferences and parties, a business card CV might be just the ticket. During the self-introduction and handshake, you hand over a normal business card - but the flip side features a brief CV of achievements to date. Follow-up contact can be made later and more details provided via the traditional CV and covering letter.

The Beamable CV

It isn't such a great leap to the next new format for transmitting your qualifications - the "beamable" CV. Beamable CVs would be broadcast via a hand-held device like a Palm or Psion palmtop, with a very brief summary of your contact details, qualifications, and experience.

The Web CV

Web CVs are electronic documents posted on a personal web site. Add the URL (website address) to the bottom of an email and potential employers can view your details with a single click. Quick and easy to update, posting a web CV is particularly useful for job-hunters in creative fields who want to display writing samples, illustrations or screen shots. Your portfolio is just another click away.

With the right meta tags - words picked up by search engines like Google or Yahoo! - your CV will be easily accessible to recruiters. The trick of this approach is to make the entire website as professional looking, easy to find, and readable as possible. Forget the cute but amateurish pictures of your pet hamster or recent holiday. A web CV ought to have its own domain, where you can display credentials and supporting materials in a professional, attractive, and printable format.

Companies involved in e-commerce or the creative industries like advertising and design are likely to be the most appreciative of such an approach.

The Flash CV

Another new trend is the interactive multi-media CV, which uses the latest animation effects of downloadable Flash software to catch the reader's eye. The form might range from a space age motif with supersonic sound effects to a Game Boy mock-up with buttons that deliver information on your education and experience. A growing number of companies offer creative CV design using Flash software with standard theme templates and custom designs aimed at producing a "wow" effect. The CV package often includes elements like a photo and covering letter.

A simple search for "Flash CVs" on any big internet search engine will turn up samples of individuals who have gone the multimedia route and companies that provide the service. Prices are usually reasonable, but you might have to pay extra for updates and hosting.

The Talking CV

Bath-based Talking CV gives employers the chance to see job-hunters in action. You simply book a slot at Talking CV's assessment centre in Bath (other centres are to open soon) where you record a "live" structured interview (though you can re-record your answers at any time). The interview can be pre-set up to be industry or role-specific or more general. You answer questions relating to your career, experience, achievements, working style, aptitudes, and aspirations - as well as your hobbies and interests.

After you have completed the recording, the interview is combined with your CV details to produce a web page and CD-Rom for you to send potential employers. The service costs £49.35 and more details are available at www.talkingcv.com.

While there's no doubting the entertainment factor in these souped-up CVs, bear in mind their primary purpose: to impress an employer and land an interview.

No matter what format you try, certain elements are non-negotiable. Your CV must be well written, using effective short descriptions, phrases, and "action" verbs that emphasise results. The language should be tailored to the industry or profession and convey personal qualities that parallel the culture of the targeted company or organisation.

Whether you embellish presentation with a colourful template or post it on the web, you must still communicate the skills, ability, and attitude to fit the targeted position.

"Your CV is your representative," says Charles Walker of recruitment agency Blue Arrow, "and by taking the time to ensure it is easy to read and professionally presented, you can dramatically increase your chances of getting an interview."

webTitle: Companies that grew from a Master plan

fields.headline: Companies that grew from a Master plan
fields.standfirst: Business courses sow the seeds of success
fields.trailText: Business courses sow the seeds of success
fields.body:
It's a well-known fact in the world of business schools that an MBA can be the launchpad for some stunning new companies. Employers often lose graduates they have backed through their studies, sometimes, says Pater Calladine from the Association of MBAs, because they don't know what to do with their newly qualified business stars.

And quite often a business idea thought up as an exercise during MBA studies suddenly seems like a real-life proposition and takes off like a rocket.

These are some of the latest business ideas which began as a twinkle in an MBA student's eye.

InfoTech
Sandeep Rathi saw a gap in the market while he was doing his MBA at Leeds Business School in 1999 to 2000. His own background was in IT in India and he knew there was a 220,000 shortfall of professionals in Britain's IT industry. And he also knew that India was producing some of the brightest and best IT professionals.

During his course at Leeds, he met fellow student John Spindler who had contacts with IT companies in Britain. "I had the idea and he had the contacts," says Sandeep.

"It was a tremendous business opportunity to fill the shortfall with IT professionals from India. I did my MBA project on it and conducted market research and did the groundwork for Info Tech."

The company already has offices in Bangalore, Hyderabad, Bombay and Indore and a recruit database of 1,200. Info Tech interviews recruits, gives them technical tests and arranges UK work permits.

When recruits arrive, they are made to feel at home through introductions to London's large Indian community. The company is recruiting for small to medium sized companies and signs up people to permanent posts.

Yellowtag.com
The idea for this global lost property retrieval service was rejected for a project at the Bath School of Management, where former surgeon Naresh Sharma was taking his MBA in 1998/99.

"It did not appeal to the team," he says, "and they did something else. But the idea stuck with me and I carried on working on it."

The company tags valuable items with an identity code formatted as an email address. The code is linked on yellowtag.com's server and when lost property is found, the owner gets an email telling them where it is.

Yellowtag also comes as an added value item with Olympus cameras and Atlantic luggage.

The company was launched in July 2000. It has just gained a French partner and will be signing up in a joint venture with an Australian company.

Naresh did his MBA because he wanted to get some management skills. "It gave me a chance to have a break and look at the world outside the NHS," he says. "I had no idea I was going to digress from surgery."

Heidiland
This challenge to the big names in the mineral water industry grew out of MBA studies at Strathclyde's Business School centre in St Gallen.

Lorenz Kohler and Mark-James Rosen realised that there was no Swiss water on sale internationally, even though it is renowned for its purity and healthy qualities.

They launched their Heidiland Water Company one year after graduation and now have a board and management team in place, substantial financial backing, a factory and plans to produce 10m litres of water in their first year.

The water, which comes from higher than 1,500m above sea level and is made fizzy with natural oxygen, will be in production in April this year.

Promanex Group Ltd
While Mark Dixon was studying for his MBA at Newcastle School of Management, his sponsor and employer Rolls-Royce Industrial Power Group started to sell off parts of the business.

"I had three choices; to move to Rolls-Royce Aerospace, find an alternative employer or start my own business," he says. "I used the MBA to research the production of a business plan."

With risk capital from two business angels, he set up Promanex in 1997 to provide industrial support services to the power generation business.

Three years later, the company was restructured and Mark and his directors now hold a 60% shareholding in a company with an £11.5m turnover.

Mark keeps in contact with Newcastle School of Management, gives the occasional lecture and is designing a course module. "I am eternally grateful for what happened. It was a great catalyst," he says.

Squaring the Circle
Chris Moyseus graduated from the City Business School in the summer of 2000 and is already running his own business from a 1,500 square feet office in central London with four newly signed up staff.

Before that, he was an underwriter at Lloyd's and worked in the banking business.

Squaring the Circle offers financial consultancy and Chris says he is using his core competencies plus the knowledge gained from his MBA.

"The MBA taught me about strategic planning, marketing, the structure of organisations and organisational behaviour and it gave me the confidence to start my own business.

"It's also about quality of life. I hope that in three or four years' time it will be running smoothly and I can take a back seat."

Article 13
Jane Fiona Cumming took an MBA in strategic marketing at Hull Business School to improve her understanding of the language that business speaks.

Right at the start, she was surprised by the need for a module on ethics in business and began to think about that and other issues.

She set up Article 13 with her business partner Neela Betteridge, assisting companies to embed ethics and good environmental practices in their businesses.

"We emphasise that being ethical brings benefits to the business as well as the staff," she explains.

webTitle: Help: I want some decent holidays!

fields.headline: Help: I want some decent holidays!
fields.standfirst: I hate the thought of losing long holidays once I leave university, but am not that keen on teaching. What else can I do that would give me more than four weeks off a year?  YG, Manchester.
fields.trailText: I hate the thought of losing long holidays once I leave university, but am not that keen on teaching. What else can I do that would give me more than four weeks off a year? YG, Manchester.
fields.body:
If you've spent your life in education and always had your year neatly punctuated with holidays, the prospect of interminable periods without a break is bleak. Now you have to face the harsh reality of forty-something weeks of work a year - or do you?

Teaching is the best career if longer than average holidays are the most important feature of an occupation. Lots of teachers have learned to live with evening work in exchange for this perk, so you wouldn't be alone in your lack of passion for the post - but it's not the sort of thing to talk about openly.

However, long school holidays may not last; there are plans to extend the school year, so beware.

You should also look at FE colleges and universities. Although some have experienced considerable erosion of leave entitlement, they still offer more than most jobs.

Another option is to find work that feels like being on holiday, such as working for a travel company or teaching English abroad.

If you're special or cheeky enough, it's possible to negotiate extra leave in any job. Employers who are having trouble recruiting may be susceptible to the idea of a lower salary in return for more time off, particularly if your reasons are worthy.

Writing a novel, leading an expedition or learning Icelandic all sound better than just wanting long holidays.

ijk@excite.com
