webTitle: Are the blue chips as black as painted?

fields.headline: Are the blue chips as black as painted?
fields.standfirst: Anti-corporate activists work on your conscience
fields.trailText: Anti-corporate activists work on your conscience
fields.body:
MIT student Jonah Peretti wanted to take advantage of Nike's offer to personalise his shoes for $50 by having the word "sweatshop" sewn on under the "Just Do It" swoosh. Nike refused and Jonah's e-mail exchanges with the corporation are whizzing round the web, making him academia's latest ethical activist.

Corporate social responsibility is a hot topic on campus and companies are filling their recruitment brochures with great statements and green statistics to counter ill feeling. So do you hold out for a paltry salary, vegan canteen and unbleached cotton uniform - or do you "Just do it"?

Cambridge University students voiced national concerns about ethical business when they disrupted a careers fair presentation last summer. Nestlé, long demonised by the NUS, was forced to abandon its information stand after protestors stormed the building. The demonstration, backed by the Cambridge University Student Union, aimed to draw attention to Nestlés business policy.

Last year, the Advertising Standards Authority ruled that Nestlé did not sell its products "ethically and responsibly". The company stands accused of putting profit before babies' lives in the world's poorest countries.

The incident demonstrated the dichotomy that exists in the student population. While many supported the protest, others complained that they had missed out on an opportunity to find out about Nestlé's graduate training scheme, and had wanted to talk to company representatives at the careers fair. "I feel that I should have been allowed to absorb both sides of the debate and make up my own mind," said a student.

Natural sciences undergraduate Emma Chapman, goes further. "I'd work for anyone, providing they paid well," she admits. "When you have a student loan to pay off there's not much point being picky about who pays you."

Your choice seems to be between soul and salary. But are the blue chips that promise the brightest graduates impressive training and salary packages really as crooked as their activist opponents would have you believe? The environmental improvements achieved by BT, for example, include a £1.2bn saved over four years by the use of the company's intranet, £150m miles travel (£20m) saved in 1999 by the use of audio conferencing, and a reduction in CO 2 emissions by 44% since 1991.

Fat cat energy operations such as Shell and BP are meant to be a huge turn-off for today's ethically-minded graduates. Yet Charlie Thomas, now 27, saw no problem in working for an oil company on completing his MSc in environmental technology at Imperial College London. His postgraduate thesis on a way of standardising reporting on emissions led first to a secondment to the United Nations and then a job in the environmental policy unit at BP.

"I was one of 15 people trying to develop its climate change strategy," he recalls. "We had influence. BP was the first company to raise climate change as an issue and being there at that time made me feel as though I was making a huge difference."

Charlie, who now works as an analyst on Jupiter Asset Management's socially responsible investment (SRI) funds, sees firms like BP and Shell as leading the way in terms of environmental and social performance.

"They may still have a long way to go," he concedes, "but they are making a concerted effort in this area. I look back on my time there as an incredibly good opportunity to help change a major corporation. If your job is to improve performance of a company then you shouldn't be prejudiced against that company - any environmental improvement is good."

It was a similar sense of wanting to reform the system and make a difference that attracted Michelle Joyce to Railtrack. After three years working as a secondary school history teacher, she joined the much-maligned company as graduate trainee and now works as an account manager in Birmingham. Michelle considered banking and FMCGs before deciding that she wanted to do something she considered "worthwhile".

"[The railways] make such a massive difference to people in the country and people want [them] to work," she says. "I knew what I was working towards and the benefit it was going to have.

"Of course, I've been aware of the controversy that's surrounded Rail track. My employer is a conversation starter - but I feel I can justify what I'm doing and justify what we're doing. I explain to people that it's more complex than they might hear and let them know that a lot of people are working very hard to make it work. Then I share with them the vision of how it could be."

Some companies attract negative publicity even when they try to give back to the community. When Nottingham University accepted £3.8m from British American Tobacco to finance a school of business ethics, the backlash for both institution and corporation was swift.

The Cancer Research Campaign, which funds research at Nottingham, claimed the university had "sold out", while the anti-smoking group ASH branded the support "blood money". Ronald Ridderbeekx, who works in internal communications for British American Tobacco, feels that the firm was quite prepared for the controversy.

"The reason for us [supporting Nottingham] is because one of our mantras is that we are a responsible company in a controversial industry," he says. "Corporate social responsibility is an up-and-coming area and would be very keen to learn more about it."

Ronald, 29, graduated in business communications from Nijmegen University in the Netherlands in 1996. He spent three years working for Kent County Council in international affairs before joining Rothmans, which merged with British American Tobacco in 1999.

"Smoking isn't a problem for me personally," he says. "The whole smoking debate is much more balanced in Holland and my Dutch friends were a lot less bothered."

When Mark Moody-Stuart, chairman of Shell, received the 1999 Environmental Leadership Award for his "outstanding leadership in corporate environmental and social issues", this was the first time that the award had gone to the head of a major corporation. Shell has a partnership with the homeless charity Centrepoint, and last June announced plans to set up an aid organisation to promote sustainable energy and development projects around the world.

Yet perhaps, as activists argue, these public ventures are nothing more than a smokescreen. Perhaps executives hope that by promoting their more benevolent campaigns, the public will forget that Shell defied US sanctions on Iran last year by signing an oilfield development deal.

And that in 1998 Nigerian protestors criticising Shell's poor environmental and human rights policies seized a Shell oilrig. Remember Erin Brockovich, who discovered that behind the facade of an environmentally conscious business, a whole US town was being slowly poisoned.

Delve into corporate social responsibility and brace yourself for a propaganda war. No company wants to be accused of a cover-up and there's plenty of literature available to help you make an informed choice.

Companies are becoming acutely aware that they need to meet the objectives of the people they're looking to recruit, not only in terms of an attractive financial and development package but also in the belief system they operate. Perhaps the hard part is working out what exactly it is you believe.

fields.headline: He used to be such a nice boy
fields.trailText: Keanu Reeves used to rely on his rock band for primal release, but now he's discovering his inner psycho on screen - what does this mean for the Matrix sequels?
fields.body:
Keanu Reeves is bad, very bad in The Gift. But intentionally, and quite effectively. As a wife-beating redneck who threatens Cate Blanchett's small-town psychic, Reeves revels in a nasty performance that couldn't be further from the sweet-tempered stoners of his Bill & Ted period or the iconic action hero that he's more recently developed into. Now preparing for the massive, 16-month simultaneous shoot of the Wachowski Brothers' two sequels to The Matrix, the 36-year-old Reeves is more anxious than ever to be taken seriously as an actor. A few more performances like the one in The Gift might scare critics into offering the kind of respect that's so far eluded him...

For a Canadian-Hawaiian you make a pretty convincing Southerner.

Thanks. I went to Georgia for three weeks before filming. I found some rednecks and just hung out with them. Just going to bars, talking to people about what it was like to grow up in this locale.

Although he's pretty hateful, you don't play him like a standard, two-dimensional villain.

I wanted to make him human. All of these people are trying to understand something that's happened to them. They've been victimised by circumstance or events in their lives, and they've got to see Cate Blanchett's character to try and understand themselves. And through not understanding, this violence occurs. I wanted to understand what happened to Donnie through that. He's a damaged man... and, hopefully, he's not just a special effect.

But since you usually play sweet or heroic guys, was it cool to just vent on everybody Donnie came in contact with?

Yeah, confronting everyone, in the character, was kind of fun for me. And, in an odd way, liberating, in that this guy knows what he's feeling, knows what he's thinking and he's acting upon it. There's no confusion on his part, though he's ultimately misguided.

So are you looking forward to making the Matrix sequels?

I hope that they make incredible demands of me. I know that, while in the first film, the fights were one-on-one, now they're going to have multi-fights, and there are some cool weapons involved.

Any more you can tell us?

It's the continued unfolding of the story of trying to save Zion and answering the question of what is the Matrix. Lots of surprises, and really just an ambition to continue to reinvent cinema to the potential of what actors and what the camera can do. They've done a lot of, and are continuing to do, research and development with new ways for the camera to capture the action.

What kind of training did you do to prepare?

It was four months, officially from 10 to 4 every day. But I was there until 5:30, lifting weights.

And your band, Dogstar - with all the other work you're involved in, will you still have time to nurture your music?

Hopefully. I'm committed to it as long as we're interested in writing together and playing. For me, it's a great experience when I'm not working, 'cause there's kind of a carefree aspect to it that I cherish. It's a different kind of good time. I hope that my band brothers will keep enjoying it and get along. It's hard to keep a band together, but we're working on it.

webTitle: Our Word Is Our Weapon by Subcomandante Marcos

fields.headline: Our Word Is Our Weapon by Subcomandante Marcos
fields.standfirst: Next week, rebels will march on Mexico City demanding rights for the country's indigenous people. But they will not fire a single shot, for this is a new kind of revolution. The Zapatista revolution of the 21st century has at its core a university-educated poet-warrior-spokesman. These are his writings
fields.trailText: Next week, rebels will march on Mexico City demanding rights for the country's indigenous people. But they will not fire a single shot, for this is a new kind of revolution. The Zapatista revolution of the 21st century has at its core a university-educated poet-warrior-spokesman. These are his writings
fields.body:
These writings by Subcomandante Marcos are extracted from Our Word Is Our Weapon, published by Serpent's Tail, priced £20 hardback.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Fifteen Years Ago

September 1999

Every August, year after year, the mountains of the Mexican southeast give birth to a particularly luminous dawn. I don't know the scientific causes, but during this dawn, this one single dawn in the whole of a disconcerting August, the moon is a hammock of swaying iridescence, the stars marshal themselves to encircle it, and the Milky Way proudly lights up its thousand wounds of clotted light. In this August of the end of the millennium, the calendar pointed to the sixth day when this dawn appeared. And with the swaying moon came back a memory of another August and another sixth, 15 years ago, when I began my entry into these mountains that were and are, like it or not, home, school, road, and door. I began my entry in August, and I didn't complete it until September.

I should confess something to you. When I laboriously climbed the first of the steep hills that abound in these parts, I was sure it would be my last. I wasn't thinking of revolution, of high human ideals or a shining future for the dispossessed and forgotten of always.

No, I was thinking I'd made the worst decision in my life, that the pain that squeezed my chest, more and more, would end up totally closing off my increasingly skimpy airway, that the best thing for me would be to go back and let the revolution manage itself without me. If I didn't go back, it was only because I didn't know the way back. All I knew was that I had to follow the compañero preceding me, who, judging by the cigarette he was smoking while effortlessly negotiating the mud, seemed to be merely out for a stroll. I didn't think that one day I'd be able to climb a hill while smoking and not feel as if I was dying with each step, or that a time would come when I'd be able to manage the mud that was as abundant underfoot as the stars are overhead. No, I wasn't thinking at all then. I was concentrating on every breath I was trying to take.

At some point we reached the highest crest of the hill, and the man in charge of the meagre column (we were three) said we would rest there. I let myself fall in the mud and told myself that perhaps it wouldn't be so hard to find the way back, that all I would have to do would be to walk down for another eternity, and that some day I would have to reach the point where the truck had dropped us off. I was making my calculations, including the excuses I would give them and give myself for abandoning the beginning of my career as a guerrilla, when the compañero approached me and offered me a cigarette. I refused with a shake of my head, not because I didn't want to talk but because I'd tried saying, "No thanks", and only a groan had come out.

After a bit, taking advantage of the fact that the man in charge had gone off some distance to satisfy what is referred to as a basic biological need, I used the .20-calibre rifle that I was carrying more like a walking stick than a combat weapon, and pulled myself up as best I could. That was how I was able to see something from the top of that mountain that had a profound im-pact on me.

No, I didn't look down. I didn't look towards the twisted scribble of the river, nor to the weak lights of the bonfires that dimly illuminated a distant hamlet, nor to the neighbouring mountains that painted the ravine, sprinkled with small villages, fields and pastures.

I looked upward. I saw a sky that was a gift and a relief - no, more like a promise. The moon was like a smiling nocturnal swing, the stars sprinkling blue lights, and the ancient serpent of luminous wounds that you call the Milky Way seemed to be resting its head there, very far away.

I stayed looking for a time, knowing I'd have to climb up that wretched hill to see this dawn, that the mud, the slips, the stones that hurt my flesh inside and out, the tired lungs incapable of pulling in the necessary air, the cramped legs, the anguished clinging to the rifle walking stick to free my boots from the imprisoning mud, the feeling of loneliness and desolation, the weight I was carrying on my back (which, I came to know later, was only a token, since in reality there would always be three times that or more), that all of that - and much more that would come later - is what had made it possible for that moon, those stars, and the Milky Way to be there and no other place.

When I heard, from behind, the orders to renew the march, up in the sky a star, surely fed up by its subjugation to the black roof, managed to break away and, by falling, to leave a brief and fugitive trace on the nocturnal blackboard.

"That's what we are," I said to myself, "fallen stars that barely scratch the sky of history with a scrawl." As far as I knew, I had only thought this, but apparently I had thought it aloud, because the compañero asked, "What did he say?"

"I don't know," replied the man in charge. "Could be he's already got a fever. We have to hurry."

What I'm telling you happened 15 years ago. Thirty years ago, a few people scratched history, and, knowing this, they began calling to many others so that, by dint of scribbling, scratching and scrawling, they would end up rending the veil of history, and so the light would finally be seen. That, and nothing else, is the struggle we are making. And so if you ask us what we want, we will unashamedly answer: "To open a crack in history."

Perhaps you are asking what happened to my intention to turn back and abandon the guerrilla life, and you might suppose that the vision of that first dawn in the mountains made me abandon my idea of fleeing, lifted my morale and firmed my revolutionary conscience. Well, you are wrong. I put my plan into operation and went down the hill. What happened is I mistook which side to go down. Instead of going down the slope that would take me back to the road and from there to "civilisation", I went down the side that took me deeper into the rainforest and that led me to another hill, and another and another . . .

That was 15 years ago. Since then, I have kept climbing hills and I have kept mistaking which side to go down, and every August 6 keeps giving birth to a special dawn, and all of us keep being falling stars barely scratching our history.

Wait. What is that shining so bright in the distance? It looks like a crack . . .

Opening remarks at the First Intercontinental Encuentro For Humanity and Against Neoliberalism, July 27, 1996

Chiapas, Mexico

Brothers and sisters of Asia, Africa,

Oceania, Europe and America,

Welcome to the mountains of the

Mexican Southeast.

Let us introduce ourselves.

We are the Zapatista National Liberation

Army.

For 10 years, we lived in these mountains, preparing to fight a war.

In these mountains, we built an army.

Below, in the cities and plantations, we did not exist.

Our lives were worth less than those of machines or animals.

We were like stones, like weeds in the road.

We were silenced.

We were faceless.

We were nameless

We had no future.

We did not exist.

For the powers that be, known internationally by the term "neoliberalism",

we did not count,

we did not produce,

we did not buy,

we did not sell.

We were a cipher in the accounts of big capital.

Then we went to the mountains to find ourselves and see if we could ease the pain of being forgotten like stones and weeds.

Here, in the mountains of the Mexican Southeast, our dead live on.

Our dead, who live in the mountains, know many things.

They speak to us of their death, and we hear them.

Coffins speak and tell us another story, that comes from yesterday and points to tomorrow.

The mountains spoke to us, the Macehualob, we common and ordinary people.

We are simple people, as Power tells us.

The kaz-dzul , the false man, rules our lands and has giant war machines,

like the boob, half-puma and half-horse,

that spread pain and death among us.

The trickster government sends us the aluxob ,

the liars who fool our people and make them forgetful.

This is why we became soldiers.

This is why we remain soldiers.

Because we want no more death and trickery for our people,

because we want no more forgetting.

The mountain told us to take up arms so we would have a voice.

It told us to cover our faces so we would have a face.

It told us to forget our names so we could be named.

It told us to protect our past so we would have a future.

Brothers and sisters:

We have invited you to this meeting to seek for and find yourselves and us.

You have all touched our hearts, and you can see we are not special.

You can see we are simple and ordinary men and women.

You can see we are the rebellious mirror that wants to be a pane of glass and break.

You can see we are who we are so we can stop being who we are to become the you, who we are.

We are the Zapatistas.

Letter to John Berger, Haute Savoy, France

May 12, 1995

A cold dawn drags itself between the fog and the thatched roofs of the village. It is morning. The dawn leaves, the cold remains. The little streets of mud begin to fill with people and animals. The cold and a small bench accompany me in the reading of Boar Land. Heriberto and Eva (five and six years old, respectively) come and snatch the book. They look at the picture on the front cover (it is a Madrid edition from 1989). It is a copy of a painting by John Constable, an image of an English countryside.

The drawing, Mr Berger, elicits from them a quick connection between image and reality. For Heriberto, for example, there is no doubt that the horse in the painting is La Muñeca [The Doll] - a mare that accompanied us in the long year when the indigenous rebellion governed southeastern Mexico, which no one could mount except Manuel, a playmate who was twice the age, size and weight of Heriberto. And what Constable called "a river" is really a stream that passes through "La Realidad". ("La Realidad" is the name of the reality of the village of La Realidad, which is the outer reaches of Heriberto's horizons.) The most distant place that Heriberto's trips and running around have taken him is "La Realidad".

Constable's painting does not transport Heriberto and Eva to the English countryside. It does not take them outside the Lacandon Jungle. It leaves them here, or it brings them back. It brings them back to their land, their place, to their being children, to their being campesinos, to their being indigenous, to their being Mexicans and rebels. For Heriberto and Eva, Constable's painting is a coloured drawing of La Muñeca, and its title, Scene On A Navigable River, is not a valid argument: the river is the stream in "La Realidad," the horse is the mare La Muñeca, Manuel is riding it, and his hat has fallen off. That's it. On to another book. This time it is Van Gogh's turn, and for Eva and Heriberto, the Dutchman's paintings are scenes from their land, of their being indigenous and campesinos. After this, Heriberto tells his mother that he spent the morning with the Sup. "Reading grown-up books," says Heriberto, and believes that this earned him a free hand with a box of chocolate cookies. Eva is more farsighted, and asks me if I have a book about her doll with the little red bandanna.

It Continues Raining Here

September 8, 1998

I was with Pedrito one afternoon, both of us smoking (he a chocolate cigarette and I a pipe), when I wanted to be like Old Don Antonio, and so I began to lecture Pedrito (a Tojolabal and two years old) about life and other painful treasures. And I began to tell him:

"Look, Pedrito, there are things you need to know about when you grow up. Important things like tying your boots, doing up your shirt without missing any buttons, getting comfortable in the hammock, lighting the pipe with the pot mouth down, and other etceteras that you will be learning about. But now we are going to talk about when a man loves a woman."

Pedrito was looking at me seriously, and he continued sucking on his chocolate cigarette. I suppose that I had then, as they say, "captured" his imagination, and I continued: "Look, Pedrito, when a man loves a woman . . . because it's not the same as when a woman loves a man, or when a man loves another man, or when a woman loves another woman, because there is a bit of everything, and it's necessary to know and to understand it. Well, when a man loves a woman . . . well, it's not as easy to explain as, say, what you need to do so that you have no extra buttons when you've buttoned up your shirt, which can be a complicated thing if you don't pay attention. For example, I use a 'from the bottom up' technique, which, in addition to being a concept of political science, is very good for buttoning up. Look, you put on the shirt and look down to the bottom end of the shirt, seriously and with concentration."

Pedrito frowned and looked at me seriously.

"Like that! Good, then you line up the lower edges of the shirt, the right at the same level as the left, which is not as simple as the 'centrists' in politics make it appear. Here, if you aren't careful, the left side could be higher, which wouldn't be an issue; however, the right side could be higher, in which case it would be very regrettable indeed. The balance is very important; they must be even. Then you have to look for the bottom button on the shirt, but the bottom button isn't always the last one. You should know this, Pedrito, there are some evil shirt manufacturers who put on an extra button (to replace a button if you lose one, they say) for the obvious purpose of making this indispensable garment difficult to button. Good, now that you've found the last button, keep on looking for the corresponding buttonhole (double-entendre fanciers, refrain), something that is more difficult to find than any reference to Chiapas in a Zedillo report. As you will learn later on, you'll never lack a ripped seam for a buttonhole. That could be, but what is certain is that there are more buttons than buttonholes, as you will see when you skip buttons.

"Certainly, there are other techniques for not missing buttons. There is, for example, the Sea's method, who puts on shirts as if they were T-shirts. That is, she does not undo the buttons. Ergo, there are no missing buttons. However, I do not recommend that technique because . . . Well, because the Sea and etceteras, and I was explaining to you that when a man loves a woman . . . So, you see now, Pedrito, that it is very difficult to explain how it is when a man loves a woman, but, nonetheless, it's very important to understand it, because . . ."

While I was explaining, Pedrito ate his cigarette. "Cocate," he said to me, stretching out his hand, asking me in his dialect for more chocolates. "There aren't any," I told him. He turned around and left. It's obvious that today's youth has no interest in important issues (sigh). Where was I? Ah, yes! When a man loves a woman . . .

PS

December 23, 1995

La toñita arrives to show off her new teacup. Without warning, she comes out with -

"Love is like a teacup that every day falls to the ground and breaks to pieces. In the morning the pieces are gathered, and with a little wet and a little warmth, the pieces are glued together, and again there is a little teacup. He who is in love spends life fearing that the terrible day will come when the teacup is so broken that it can no longer be mended."

She leaves just as she arrived, reiterating her refusal to give me a kiss, that now more than ever "really prickles".

The Story Of The Live Person And The Dead Person

October 23, 1996

Once there was a live person and a dead person. And the dead person said to the live person:

"My, I envy your restlessness."

And then the live person said to the dead person:

"My, I envy your tranquillity."

And there they were, envying each other, when, suddenly, a bean-brown horse went by at full gallop.

Tan-tan.

The moral of the story, I repeat, is that all final options are a trap. It's imperative to find the bean-brown horse.

Don Durito of the Lacandon

The Tale Of The Little Seamstress

September 3, 1997

Once upon a time, there was a little seamstress who sewed mightily on his sewing machine. The other machines in his neighbourhood laughed at him, and shouted:

"Fairy! Only old women are seamstresses!"

So the little seamstress sewed shut the mouths of everyone who made fun of him. That's why, to this day, we don't know how the story ended, because no one could tell it.

Tan-tan

The Tale Of The Little Newsboy

Once upon a time, there was a little newsboy who was very, very poor and he only sold old newspapers because he didn't have enough money for new ones. People didn't buy his newspapers because they were all so out of date, and they wanted new newspapers. So the little newsboy never sold any, and every day he accumulated more and more old newspapers. What the little newsboy did was put up a paper recycling plant, and he became a millionaire, bought out all the newspaper businesses and the news agencies, prohibited publishing current news, and thus obliged people to read only news of the past. In the papers on sale today, for example, you'd read that the Zapatistas are about to arrive in Mexico City and that they'll meet with the Villistas there. You can't quite make out the date, but it seems to be either 1914 or 1997.

Tan-tan.
fields.bodyText: These writings by Subcomandante Marcos are extracted from Our Word Is Our Weapon, published by Serpent's Tail, priced £20 hardback. Buy it at a discount at BOL Fifteen Years Ago September 1999 Every August, year after year, the mountains of the Mexican southeast give birth to a particularly luminous dawn. I don't know the scientific causes, but during this dawn, this one single dawn in the whole of a disconcerting August, the moon is a hammock of swaying iridescence, the stars marshal themselves to encircle it, and the Milky Way proudly lights up its thousand wounds of clotted light. In this August of the end of the millennium, the calendar pointed to the sixth day when this dawn appeared. And with the swaying moon came back a memory of another August and another sixth, 15 years ago, when I began my entry into these mountains that were and are, like it or not, home, school, road, and door. I began my entry in August, and I didn't complete it until September. I should confess something to you. When I laboriously climbed the first of the steep hills that abound in these parts, I was sure it would be my last. I wasn't thinking of revolution, of high human ideals or a shining future for the dispossessed and forgotten of always. No, I was thinking I'd made the worst decision in my life, that the pain that squeezed my chest, more and more, would end up totally closing off my increasingly skimpy airway, that the best thing for me would be to go back and let the revolution manage itself without me. If I didn't go back, it was only because I didn't know the way back. All I knew was that I had to follow the compañero preceding me, who, judging by the cigarette he was smoking while effortlessly negotiating the mud, seemed to be merely out for a stroll. I didn't think that one day I'd be able to climb a hill while smoking and not feel as if I was dying with each step, or that a time would come when I'd be able to manage the mud that was as abundant underfoot as the stars are overhead. No, I wasn't thinking at all then. I was concentrating on every breath I was trying to take. At some point we reached the highest crest of the hill, and the man in charge of the meagre column (we were three) said we would rest there. I let myself fall in the mud and told myself that perhaps it wouldn't be so hard to find the way back, that all I would have to do would be to walk down for another eternity, and that some day I would have to reach the point where the truck had dropped us off. I was making my calculations, including the excuses I would give them and give myself for abandoning the beginning of my career as a guerrilla, when the compañero approached me and offered me a cigarette. I refused with a shake of my head, not because I didn't want to talk but because I'd tried saying, "No thanks", and only a groan had come out. After a bit, taking advantage of the fact that the man in charge had gone off some distance to satisfy what is referred to as a basic biological need, I used the .20-calibre rifle that I was carrying more like a walking stick than a combat weapon, and pulled myself up as best I could. That was how I was able to see something from the top of that mountain that had a profound im-pact on me. No, I didn't look down. I didn't look towards the twisted scribble of the river, nor to the weak lights of the bonfires that dimly illuminated a distant hamlet, nor to the neighbouring mountains that painted the ravine, sprinkled with small villages, fields and pastures. I looked upward. I saw a sky that was a gift and a relief - no, more like a promise. The moon was like a smiling nocturnal swing, the stars sprinkling blue lights, and the ancient serpent of luminous wounds that you call the Milky Way seemed to be resting its head there, very far away. I stayed looking for a time, knowing I'd have to climb up that wretched hill to see this dawn, that the mud, the slips, the stones that hurt my flesh inside and out, the tired lungs incapable of pulling in the necessary air, the cramped legs, the anguished clinging to the rifle walking stick to free my boots from the imprisoning mud, the feeling of loneliness and desolation, the weight I was carrying on my back (which, I came to know later, was only a token, since in reality there would always be three times that or more), that all of that - and much more that would come later - is what had made it possible for that moon, those stars, and the Milky Way to be there and no other place. When I heard, from behind, the orders to renew the march, up in the sky a star, surely fed up by its subjugation to the black roof, managed to break away and, by falling, to leave a brief and fugitive trace on the nocturnal blackboard. "That's what we are," I said to myself, "fallen stars that barely scratch the sky of history with a scrawl." As far as I knew, I had only thought this, but apparently I had thought it aloud, because the compañero asked, "What did he say?" "I don't know," replied the man in charge. "Could be he's already got a fever. We have to hurry." What I'm telling you happened 15 years ago. Thirty years ago, a few people scratched history, and, knowing this, they began calling to many others so that, by dint of scribbling, scratching and scrawling, they would end up rending the veil of history, and so the light would finally be seen. That, and nothing else, is the struggle we are making. And so if you ask us what we want, we will unashamedly answer: "To open a crack in history." Perhaps you are asking what happened to my intention to turn back and abandon the guerrilla life, and you might suppose that the vision of that first dawn in the mountains made me abandon my idea of fleeing, lifted my morale and firmed my revolutionary conscience. Well, you are wrong. I put my plan into operation and went down the hill. What happened is I mistook which side to go down. Instead of going down the slope that would take me back to the road and from there to "civilisation", I went down the side that took me deeper into the rainforest and that led me to another hill, and another and another . . . That was 15 years ago. Since then, I have kept climbing hills and I have kept mistaking which side to go down, and every August 6 keeps giving birth to a special dawn, and all of us keep being falling stars barely scratching our history. Wait. What is that shining so bright in the distance? It looks like a crack . . . Opening remarks at the First Intercontinental Encuentro For Humanity and Against Neoliberalism, July 27, 1996 Chiapas, Mexico Brothers and sisters of Asia, Africa, Oceania, Europe and America, Welcome to the mountains of the Mexican Southeast. Let us introduce ourselves. We are the Zapatista National Liberation Army. For 10 years, we lived in these mountains, preparing to fight a war. In these mountains, we built an army. Below, in the cities and plantations, we did not exist. Our lives were worth less than those of machines or animals. We were like stones, like weeds in the road. We were silenced. We were faceless. We were nameless We had no future. We did not exist. For the powers that be, known internationally by the term "neoliberalism", we did not count, we did not produce, we did not buy, we did not sell. We were a cipher in the accounts of big capital. Then we went to the mountains to find ourselves and see if we could ease the pain of being forgotten like stones and weeds. Here, in the mountains of the Mexican Southeast, our dead live on. Our dead, who live in the mountains, know many things. They speak to us of their death, and we hear them. Coffins speak and tell us another story, that comes from yesterday and points to tomorrow. The mountains spoke to us, the Macehualob, we common and ordinary people. We are simple people, as Power tells us. The kaz-dzul , the false man, rules our lands and has giant war machines, like the boob, half-puma and half-horse, that spread pain and death among us. The trickster government sends us the aluxob , the liars who fool our people and make them forgetful. This is why we became soldiers. This is why we remain soldiers. Because we want no more death and trickery for our people, because we want no more forgetting. The mountain told us to take up arms so we would have a voice. It told us to cover our faces so we would have a face. It told us to forget our names so we could be named. It told us to protect our past so we would have a future. Brothers and sisters: We have invited you to this meeting to seek for and find yourselves and us. You have all touched our hearts, and you can see we are not special. You can see we are simple and ordinary men and women. You can see we are the rebellious mirror that wants to be a pane of glass and break. You can see we are who we are so we can stop being who we are to become the you, who we are. We are the Zapatistas. Letter to John Berger, Haute Savoy, France May 12, 1995 A cold dawn drags itself between the fog and the thatched roofs of the village. It is morning. The dawn leaves, the cold remains. The little streets of mud begin to fill with people and animals. The cold and a small bench accompany me in the reading of Boar Land. Heriberto and Eva (five and six years old, respectively) come and snatch the book. They look at the picture on the front cover (it is a Madrid edition from 1989). It is a copy of a painting by John Constable, an image of an English countryside. The drawing, Mr Berger, elicits from them a quick connection between image and reality. For Heriberto, for example, there is no doubt that the horse in the painting is La Muñeca [The Doll] - a mare that accompanied us in the long year when the indigenous rebellion governed southeastern Mexico, which no one could mount except Manuel, a playmate who was twice the age, size and weight of Heriberto. And what Constable called "a river" is really a stream that passes through "La Realidad". ("La Realidad" is the name of the reality of the village of La Realidad, which is the outer reaches of Heriberto's horizons.) The most distant place that Heriberto's trips and running around have taken him is "La Realidad". Constable's painting does not transport Heriberto and Eva to the English countryside. It does not take them outside the Lacandon Jungle. It leaves them here, or it brings them back. It brings them back to their land, their place, to their being children, to their being campesinos, to their being indigenous, to their being Mexicans and rebels. For Heriberto and Eva, Constable's painting is a coloured drawing of La Muñeca, and its title, Scene On A Navigable River, is not a valid argument: the river is the stream in "La Realidad," the horse is the mare La Muñeca, Manuel is riding it, and his hat has fallen off. That's it. On to another book. This time it is Van Gogh's turn, and for Eva and Heriberto, the Dutchman's paintings are scenes from their land, of their being indigenous and campesinos. After this, Heriberto tells his mother that he spent the morning with the Sup. "Reading grown-up books," says Heriberto, and believes that this earned him a free hand with a box of chocolate cookies. Eva is more farsighted, and asks me if I have a book about her doll with the little red bandanna. It Continues Raining Here September 8, 1998 I was with Pedrito one afternoon, both of us smoking (he a chocolate cigarette and I a pipe), when I wanted to be like Old Don Antonio, and so I began to lecture Pedrito (a Tojolabal and two years old) about life and other painful treasures. And I began to tell him: "Look, Pedrito, there are things you need to know about when you grow up. Important things like tying your boots, doing up your shirt without missing any buttons, getting comfortable in the hammock, lighting the pipe with the pot mouth down, and other etceteras that you will be learning about. But now we are going to talk about when a man loves a woman." Pedrito was looking at me seriously, and he continued sucking on his chocolate cigarette. I suppose that I had then, as they say, "captured" his imagination, and I continued: "Look, Pedrito, when a man loves a woman . . . because it's not the same as when a woman loves a man, or when a man loves another man, or when a woman loves another woman, because there is a bit of everything, and it's necessary to know and to understand it. Well, when a man loves a woman . . . well, it's not as easy to explain as, say, what you need to do so that you have no extra buttons when you've buttoned up your shirt, which can be a complicated thing if you don't pay attention. For example, I use a 'from the bottom up' technique, which, in addition to being a concept of political science, is very good for buttoning up. Look, you put on the shirt and look down to the bottom end of the shirt, seriously and with concentration." Pedrito frowned and looked at me seriously. "Like that! Good, then you line up the lower edges of the shirt, the right at the same level as the left, which is not as simple as the 'centrists' in politics make it appear. Here, if you aren't careful, the left side could be higher, which wouldn't be an issue; however, the right side could be higher, in which case it would be very regrettable indeed. The balance is very important; they must be even. Then you have to look for the bottom button on the shirt, but the bottom button isn't always the last one. You should know this, Pedrito, there are some evil shirt manufacturers who put on an extra button (to replace a button if you lose one, they say) for the obvious purpose of making this indispensable garment difficult to button. Good, now that you've found the last button, keep on looking for the corresponding buttonhole (double-entendre fanciers, refrain), something that is more difficult to find than any reference to Chiapas in a Zedillo report. As you will learn later on, you'll never lack a ripped seam for a buttonhole. That could be, but what is certain is that there are more buttons than buttonholes, as you will see when you skip buttons. "Certainly, there are other techniques for not missing buttons. There is, for example, the Sea's method, who puts on shirts as if they were T-shirts. That is, she does not undo the buttons. Ergo, there are no missing buttons. However, I do not recommend that technique because . . . Well, because the Sea and etceteras, and I was explaining to you that when a man loves a woman . . . So, you see now, Pedrito, that it is very difficult to explain how it is when a man loves a woman, but, nonetheless, it's very important to understand it, because . . ." He turned around and left. It's obvious that today's youth has no interest in important issues (sigh). Where was I? Ah, yes! When a man loves a woman . . . fields.trailText: This is altogether a superior thriller, surely the only one where a former FBI agent lured back from retirement to solve the case has had a heart transplant
fields.body: Hard-boiled Los Angeles detective Bosch is Harry to colleagues and chums. But his real first name turns out to be Hieronymous. So when a man is found strangled in exactly the contorted manner inflicted on one of the damned souls in a Bosch painting, guess who's prime suspect? This is altogether a superior thriller, surely the only one where a former FBI agent lured back from retirement to solve the case has had a heart transplant. The author capitalises on his former career as an ex- L A Times reporter to write convincing court scenes, a fiction rarity. Reader Michael Beck performs it well, modulating and characterising to an extent that British listeners appreciate but American audiobook readers don't often match.

fields.headline: Busted in New York [part II]
fields.body:
Jail was going to get me over my fear of saying the obvious, because there was no way to ignore all morning the fact that everyone in the cell was either black or Hispanic. The irony, for me, was that an all-black gathering usually meant a special event, a stirring occasion. I thought back to some black guys I used to know who enjoyed telling me that black guys like me ought to hang out with black groups like theirs. It flattered me to believe that I flattered them with my yearning for instruction in the art of how to be down with it. But this was not what they had in mind. The mood in the cell was like that of an emergency room in a city hospital: a mixture of squalor, panic, boredom, and resentment at the supposed randomness of bad luck.

Some guys, the Rasta youth among them, had elected to slip down on to the concrete floor. They were opting out of consciousness. Our cell had no television, no radio, no newspapers. There was a water fountain, a disgusting toilet, and two pay phones from which collect calls could be made. I don't know how those guys knew when the corrections officers had their backs turned, or how they'd held on to the contraband of drugs and matches they'd been thoroughly searched for, or how they knew who in which cell had what, but at one moment, as if by some secret signal, paraphernalia went flying through green bars from cell to cell. The next thing I knew, guys were taking turns smoking crack behind the waist-high partition of the raised open toilet. I'd switched seats and, as a result, was too near the burning funk. I saw my Hispanic comrade casually walk away from the hot spot, and soon I, too, got up and crossed the cell. His look of approval after I'd eased in somewhere else told me that I'd made the right move.

A black guy with broken teeth, dressed in a torn car coat, emerged from behind the toilet. He ambled around and then seized the floor. "You remember Lucky Lou Diamond? I had twenty thousand dollar over to Jersey City." I tuned in, eager for a jailhouse Richard Pryor who could turn the cell into something else. "Nineteen- seventy-five? Bunny hat on my head? Your honour. There's no mouth on the girl he touched." His free association promised much, but it gutter-balled into such incoherence that the black youth with break braids spoke for everyone when he barked, "Sit down."

It was quiet for a while, but then the Rasta youth snapped to attention. Something jerked him to his feet and set him standing squarely in front of the cell door, his right knee pounding out a steady rhythm. I thought: just when things were manageable, my brother in Selassie has to flip out. I braced myself for his rap. But he was ready for his lunch. He was first in the line we were commanded to make; first to march out of the cell towards stacks of chalk-coloured squares on long, low trolleys that looked like what bricks are transported on at a building site. We were to pick up a sandwich, turn, take a plastic cup of grape juice from another low trolley, and then march back to the cell.

A black guy in an orange jumpsuit - a trusty - called after me to let me know that I'd missed my allotted sandwich. Something about being urged to march rendered me unable to lift anything other than a cup of juice. Very soon the cell was strewn with sandwich remnants. Leaking sachets of mustard and mayonnaise found their way under the bench. A wedge of cheese crowned one of the pay phones. Lunch added to the odours of incarceration. However, there was still plenty of room, because some of the men whose size so alarmed me when I first entered the cell had dived to the floor. I counted nine guys asleep in the grime, six of them in the foetal position, their wrists between their knees. Heads had to loll down some broad shoulders before they could touch concrete. A young, crack-thin guy woke and, using his palms for locomotion, crawled along on his stomach to the trash can, where he reached up to extract sandwich remains.

I overheard some of the guys say a little while later that the police had arrested so many people in the sweep of the previous evening that two special night courts had been set up to process the haul. They would start to call names at four o'clock. Waiting might have been easier if there were no clock. At the appointed hour, the only official movement came from the black corrections officer who'd flipped out that morning. I'm sorry to report that he went through all the transparent manoeuvres of rubbing it in. He paraded by us on his way back to the oblong station desk, ostensibly laughing at himself for forgetting something. And just in case the black youth with break braids was pretending to take no notice of him, the corrections officer brought over a white officer holding a clipboard and pointed at the youth. His colleague tapped him a Have-a-good-night. "I told you when you got here not to give me problems." The black youth looked toward the bars at last, his arms hugging his chest. The black corrections officer flicked a salute.

'Y o, Pops," I heard the black youth say once the air had calmed down again around us. "Pops," he called again in my direction. I couldn't believe he was talking to me. Pops? Everybody in the cell who spoke to someone he didn't know said, "Yo, G." I pointed to myself. Who, me? "Mind me asking what you're in for?" I made a smoking gesture with two fingers of my right hand. "Uh-huh. You dress Italian. But." A neighbour of his wanted to give him five for that observation, but he just looked at him hard. It was true. The soundtrack of brotherhood in my head was nearly all Marvin Gaye. It had finally happened: I was older than a cartoon father on television. I was older than Homer Simpson.

I wasn't sure if Old Four Eyes in the Robert Hayden poem fled to "danger in the safety zones" or to "safety in the danger zones". It was important to me, sitting there in my concrete elsewhere, which seemed dirtier and dimmer the longer I had to wait.

As the cell emptied, it got eerier. The few new guys, dressed in their garrulous night selves, were out of sympathy with the general tone of exhaustion and passivity. One new guy ranted about calling his girlfriend to tell her to hook up a plane to Canada, because after he made bail, he was going to step off, boy. Another, the lone white, clung to a pay phone. He suggested to a friend that they deceive his brother-in-law. "Don't tell him it's for me." He could press telephone numbers with amazing speed. He insisted to the next friend that she had to get her bail money out of her mother, because he could not, he said, shooting his eyes across us, the non-white, do Riker's.

My name was called, the cell door gapped open, and I floated out. Neither my Hispanic comrade nor the Rasta youth followed. I regretted that I would not have the chance to thank the man who'd watched my back. Very soon I found myself upstairs in a new cell that had an iron-lattice screen. Beyond it was the outside world. I heard the voices of what I supposed were women corrections officers, and then over the walls I heard Billie and Rona in their interview cells. They heard me, we heard one another. The public defender on the free person's side of the barrier was a heavy-set white woman. She went from cubicle to cubicle, guiding us toward a plea: adjournment in contemplation of dismissal, or ACD. If we didn't get picked up for the same offence within a 12-month period, then the charge would be dropped. ACD.

I told the PD that I'd used the pay phones. I knew that that afternoon a friend of mine had come zooming down with news-papers and a criminal lawyer and had been denied access. She said they were entitled to hold us for 24 hours before they had to do anything with us. I said that being in custody was the punishment. I said prosecution of so-called quality-of-life crimes was a form of harassment. She explained that under the circumstances they didn't have to read us our rights. I was about to compare such offences to civil disobedience, but the last thing this calm and capable PD was interested in was anybody's vanity. She said that high arrest figures justified the large increase in the number of police on the streets. It was that simple.

In the courtroom, I felt as though we were guest speakers at a high school, the offenders with us behind the court recorder looked so tadpole, so young. We stood when the judge entered. "He's not that kind of judge," a black bailiff said. Maybe because I was minutes and a plea away from getting out, tenderness got the better of me. I thought of my older sister and her practice in defence of juvenile defenders valiantly conducted from files in shopping bags in the trunk of her car. Our case was called, and we sat some rows back from the attorneys' desks, where we were unable to hear the grim PD, even if we could have concentrated enough.

God bless the old-hippie souls who still believed in public life and social responsibility, I thought, but the PD had no time for effusive thanks. I'd been so hypnotised by green bars that the marble floor outside the courtroom was dazzling. The white clerks behind the counter in a payment-and-records office were accustomed to a stressed-out public and were rude back. Down in the lobby, Rona and Billie ran for the door marked "Women". I rushed over to a rickety booth for my fix of those former slave crops - tobacco, sugar, coffee.

Perhaps our elation on Rona's rooftop was unearned, but we felt like released hostages. We made jokes as soon as we had an audience of friends. Even the squalid bits, when told the right way, got laughs. Maybe we were defending ourselves against our deeper reactions to what had happened to us. Rona's husband said that now his little boy was old enough to play in the street he had had to tell him what to do should the police ever stop him. Don't move; do exactly what they say; take no chances; give no lip. We wondered how popular these sweeps would be after some more white people had been caught in the net.

We'd been abruptly deprived of our liberty, and that would always make for a chilling memory. And as I'd learned sitting in the cell with all those guys whose stories I didn't know and couldn't ask for: the system exists, the system - for the non-white youth, the poor - is real. New arrest records had been created, but we were out, and friends were standing in wreaths of smoke, savouring the night view of fire escapes, water tanks, and lights in distant windows. Six days after my release, I was back on the Lower East Side. I understood what Rona meant when she said that she fell in love with New York the day she realised that she could get a candy bar on every corner. But jail worked, it won. I thought, I'm not doing that again. The romance was over. For me, the changes in the streets went with everything else. Once upon a time, people moved to New York and thought it perfectly OK to remain themselves. Goodbye, Frank O'Hara.

"Yo, Papi," I heard. I was astonished. It was my Hispanic comrade. They'd given him five days on Riker's Island for possession of a crack pipe. He was selling vinyl records on the sidewalk before he got moved off that bit of Second Avenue. Could I help him out? It would be my privilege. He said he remembered what the black youth with break braids had said when they took him out of that cell in the Tombs. "Kidnapped by the mayor, y'all."
fields.bodyText: Jail was going to get me over my fear of saying the obvious, because there was no way to ignore all morning the fact that everyone in the cell was either black or Hispanic. The irony, for me, was that an all-black gathering usually meant a special event, a stirring occasion. I thought back to some black guys I used to know who enjoyed telling me that black guys like me ought to hang out with black groups like theirs. It flattered me to believe that I flattered them with my yearning for instruction in the art of how to be down with it. But this was not what they had in mind. The mood in the cell was like that of an emergency room in a city hospital: a mixture of squalor, panic, boredom, and resentment at the supposed randomness of bad luck. Some guys, the Rasta youth among them, had elected to slip down on to the concrete floor. They were opting out of consciousness. Our cell had no television, no radio, no newspapers. There was a water fountain, a disgusting toilet, and two pay phones from which collect calls could be made. I don't know how those guys knew when the corrections officers had their backs turned, or how they'd held on to the contraband of drugs and matches they'd been thoroughly searched for, or how they knew who in which cell had what, but at one moment, as if by some secret signal, paraphernalia went flying through green bars from cell to cell. The next thing I knew, guys were taking turns smoking crack behind the waist-high partition of the raised open toilet. I'd switched seats and, as a result, was too near the burning funk. I saw my Hispanic comrade casually walk away from the hot spot, and soon I, too, got up and crossed the cell. His look of approval after I'd eased in somewhere else told me that I'd made the right move. A black guy with broken teeth, dressed in a torn car coat, emerged from behind the toilet. He ambled around and then seized the floor. "You remember Lucky Lou Diamond? I had twenty thousand dollar over to Jersey City." I tuned in, eager for a jailhouse Richard Pryor who could turn the cell into something else. "Nineteen- seventy-five? Bunny hat on my head? Your honour. There's no mouth on the girl he touched." His free association promised much, but it gutter-balled into such incoherence that the black youth with break braids spoke for everyone when he barked, "Sit down." It was quiet for a while, but then the Rasta youth snapped to attention. Something jerked him to his feet and set him standing squarely in front of the cell door, his right knee pounding out a steady rhythm. I thought: just when things were manageable, my brother in Selassie has to flip out. I braced myself for his rap. But he was ready for his lunch. He was first in the line we were commanded to make; first to march out of the cell towards stacks of chalk-coloured squares on long, low trolleys that looked like what bricks are transported on at a building site. We were to pick up a sandwich, turn, take a plastic cup of grape juice from another low trolley, and then march back to the cell. A black guy in an orange jumpsuit - a trusty - called after me to let me know that I'd missed my allotted sandwich. Something about being urged to march rendered me unable to lift anything other than a cup of juice. Very soon the cell was strewn with sandwich remnants. Leaking sachets of mustard and mayonnaise found their way under the bench. A wedge of cheese crowned one of the pay phones. Lunch added to the odours of incarceration. However, there was still plenty of room, because some of the men whose size so alarmed me when I first entered the cell had dived to the floor. I counted nine guys asleep in the grime, six of them in the foetal position, their wrists between their knees. Heads had to loll down some broad shoulders before they could touch concrete. A young, crack-thin guy woke and, using his palms for locomotion, crawled along on his stomach to the trash can, where he reached up to extract sandwich remains. I overheard some of the guys say a little while later that the police had arrested so many people in the sweep of the previous evening that two special night courts had been set up to process the haul. They would start to call names at four o'clock. Waiting might have been easier if there were no clock. At the appointed hour, the only official movement came from the black corrections officer who'd flipped out that morning. I'm sorry to report that he went through all the transparent manoeuvres of rubbing it in. He paraded by us on his way back to the oblong station desk, ostensibly laughing at himself for forgetting something. And just in case the black youth with break braids was pretending to take no notice of him, the corrections officer brought over a white officer holding a clipboard and pointed at the youth. His colleague tapped him a Have-a-good-night. "I told you when you got here not to give me problems." The black youth looked toward the bars at last, his arms hugging his chest. The black corrections officer flicked a salute. 'Y o, Pops," I heard the black youth say once the air had calmed down again around us. "Pops," he called again in my direction. I couldn't believe he was talking to me. Pops? Everybody in the cell who spoke to someone he didn't know said, "Yo, G." I pointed to myself. Who, me? "Mind me asking what you're in for?" I made a smoking gesture with two fingers of my right hand. "Uh-huh. You dress Italian. But." A neighbour of his wanted to give him five for that observation, but he just looked at him hard. It was true. The soundtrack of brotherhood in my head was nearly all Marvin Gaye. It had finally happened: I was older than a cartoon father on television. I was older than Homer Simpson. I wasn't sure if Old Four Eyes in the Robert Hayden poem fled to "danger in the safety zones" or to "safety in the danger zones". It was important to me, sitting there in my concrete elsewhere, which seemed dirtier and dimmer the longer I had to wait. As the cell emptied, it got eerier. The few new guys, dressed in their garrulous night selves, were out of sympathy with the general tone of exhaustion and passivity. One new guy ranted about calling his girlfriend to tell her to hook up a plane to Canada, because after he made bail, he was going to step off, boy. Another, the lone white, clung to a pay phone. He suggested to a friend that they deceive his brother-in-law. "Don't tell him it's for me." He could press telephone numbers with amazing speed. He insisted to the next friend that she had to get her bail money out of her mother, because he could not, he said, shooting his eyes across us, the non-white, do Riker's. My name was called, the cell door gapped open, and I floated out. Neither my Hispanic comrade nor the Rasta youth followed. I regretted that I would not have the chance to thank the man who'd watched my back. Very soon I found myself upstairs in a new cell that had an iron-lattice screen. Beyond it was the outside world. I heard the voices of what I supposed were women corrections officers, and then over the walls I heard Billie and Rona in their interview cells. They heard me, we heard one another. The public defender on the free person's side of the barrier was a heavy-set white woman. She went from cubicle to cubicle, guiding us toward a plea: adjournment in contemplation of dismissal, or ACD. If we didn't get picked up for the same offence within a 12-month period, then the charge would be dropped. ACD. I told the PD that I'd used the pay phones. I knew that that afternoon a friend of mine had come zooming down with news-papers and a criminal lawyer and had been denied access. She said they were entitled to hold us for 24 hours before they had to do anything with us. I said that being in custody was the punishment. I said prosecution of so-called quality-of-life crimes was a form of harassment. She explained that under the circumstances they didn't have to read us our rights. I was about to compare such offences to civil disobedience, but the last thing this calm and capable PD was interested in was anybody's vanity. She said that high arrest figures justified the large increase in the number of police on the streets. It was that simple. In the courtroom, I felt as though we were guest speakers at a high school, the offenders with us behind the court recorder looked so tadpole, so young. We stood when the judge entered. "He's not that kind of judge," a black bailiff said. Maybe because I was minutes and a plea away from getting out, tenderness got the better of me. I thought of my older sister and her practice in defence of juvenile defenders valiantly conducted from files in shopping bags in the trunk of her car. Our case was called, and we sat some rows back from the attorneys' desks, where we were unable to hear the grim PD, even if we could have concentrated enough. God bless the old-hippie souls who still believed in public life and social responsibility, I thought, but the PD had no time for effusive thanks. I'd been so hypnotised by green bars that the marble floor outside the courtroom was dazzling. The white clerks behind the counter in a payment-and-records office were accustomed to a stressed-out public and were rude back. Down in the lobby, Rona and Billie ran for the door marked "Women". I rushed over to a rickety booth for my fix of those former slave crops - tobacco, sugar, coffee. Perhaps our elation on Rona's rooftop was unearned, but we felt like released hostages. We made jokes as soon as we had an audience of friends. Even the squalid bits, when told the right way, got laughs. fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on The Mirror: A History by Sabine Melchior-Bonnet,  Hildegard of Bingen by Fiona Maddocks, and The Hacker Ethic and the Spirit of the Information Age by Pekka Himanen
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on The Mirror: A History by Sabine Melchior-Bonnet, Hildegard of Bingen by Fiona Maddocks, and The Hacker Ethic and the Spirit of the Information Age by Pekka Himanen
fields.body:
The Mirror: A History
Sabine Melchior-Bonnet
(Routledge, £16.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

What is a mirror? A tool to know yourself, according to Socrates; a flattering liar, according to Shakespeare's Richard II; flatly uninhabitable, for Borges. Melchior-Bonnet's highly cultured reflections begin with a brief technical history, including the secret war of mirrors between the Venetians and the French in the 17th century, and then range over ancient myth, ecclesiastical history, literature and art - we observe Magritte wittily preserving the mystique of his subject in La Reproduction Interdite by painting a man looking into a mirror, in which is reflected the back of his head. Naturally there is much about Lacan's "mirror stage", and occasionally we may watch Melchior-Bonnet disappearing altogether through the looking-glass with passages such as this: "The fiction of the mirror refuses the rigid distinction between real and imaginary and allows a more subtle dialectic of the subject." The mirror was once thought of as a tool for summoning devils (splendidly called catoptromancy), so it is slightly disappointing not to find here any reference to Dracula . Is the fact that you cannot see him in a mirror not the vampire's most disturbing trait?

Hildegard of Bingen
Fiona Maddocks
(Headline, £15.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Everyone's favourite 12th-century abbess has long been reappropriated for the gender-studies and postmodern-theology generation, and her songs subjected to banging remixes for the discerning Ibizan hordes. Maddocks, though, aims to paint the woman in full: composer, theologian, pioneering sexologist. (Hildegard may have been a lesbian, and certainly took a more relaxed and inquiring attitude to sex than the rest of the church in her time.) As Maddocks's warm, scholarly story shows, her extraordinary life also encompassed reams of correspondence with popes and kings, and fat, surprisingly accurate treatises on natural history and medicine. Top tip: mashed-up earthworm paste is good for scrofula.

The Hacker Ethic and the Spirit of the Information Age
Pekka Himanen
(Secker & Warburg, £12)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Understand that the hackers in question are not those resourceful dudes in insect-eye shades and black trenchcoats who break into the Pentagon; those are crackers. Hackers are noble programmer geniuses who pose a "spiritual challenge" to the rest of society in this exciting new world of e. They earn huge amounts of money but don't really value it, see, except as a means to go snowboarding or build huge model train sets in their basements. Leisure and work blur into one another. It's "the hacker work ethic", which, unlike the Protestant work ethic, is, um, passionate . And joyful. And enthusiastic. "Hackers can do almost anything and be a hacker. You can be a hacker carpenter," says one hacker. Really? Can you be a hacker McDonald's burger flipper, or a hacker child worker in a Nike sweatshop? Have these people actually gone mad?

fields.headline: Sister act
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery looks at What Are You Like by Anne Enright, Century in Scarlet by Lajos Zilahy,  The Long Afternoon by Giles Waterfield, and The Friends Of Eddie Coyle by George V Higgins
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at What Are You Like by Anne Enright, Century in Scarlet by Lajos Zilahy, The Long Afternoon by Giles Waterfield, and The Friends Of Eddie Coyle by George V Higgins
fields.body:
What Are You Like
Anne Enright
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

No, no, no you want to shout when Dublin-born Maria, lounging post-coitally in a New York bed, sees a picture of a girl who looks just like her on the wall of her current mate's apartment. We know already know that Maria's mum died in childbirth and suspect, rightly, that What Are You Like will do the twins/nature-vs-nurture thing. It does, but in a very circuitous, incidental way. Enright chops and changes between Maria's dad, her step-mum, Maria and her sister through semi-independent chapters or loosely linked stories. Ireland, feminity, mothers and daughters, and fathers and daughters are as much the issues as the lightly drawn parallels between the two girls.

Century in Scarlet
Lajos Zilahy
(Prion, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Twin boys are born as the Congress of Vienna convenes to reapportion Europe in the aftermath of Napoleon: naturally, they are fated to embody their century's world order. "This century will be a long sunny Sunday, it be a giant merry-go-round . . . a gala century, a century in scarlet," says godfather Metternich over the heads of baby Counts Antal and Dali. Indeed it was, ending just before the 100 years are up in a shooting in Sarajevo that buries the Habsburg empire. Zilahy unabashedly followed Tolstoy in making history personal and though Century in Scarlet fails to reach the all-absorbing depths of War and Peace , it is far grander than most sweeps through the epochs.

The Long Afternoon
Giles Waterfield
(Review, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is easy to slide through Waterfield's debut without questioning whether what you are reading rises above a pastiche of a mannered between-the-wars novel written by, say, Rosamund Lehmann or Elizabeth Von Arnim. The subject matter - a portrait of a middle-class marriage, hemmed by genteel mental illness and played out on the Riviera from war to war - would have appealed to either, and the elegantly understated style suits. There may be much pleasure in reading a well-crafted period piece, but the nag remains - is this gentle and humane novel as necessary for the reader as (with the hindsight of the afterword) it clearly was for Waterfield?

The Friends Of Eddie Coyle
George V Higgins
(Robinson, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Norman Mailer loves the dialogue, people who make lists of their "best ever" include it in the post-war American fiction section, and Hollywood bought the script. Higgins was assistant DA in Boston before defending Watergate conspirator Gordon Liddy and Black Panther Eldridge Cleaver, then he took to writing full-time. "Jackie Brown, at twenty six, with no expression on his face said he could get some guns." A pretty good first sentence for a first novel: you see the signposts heading straight for the American dream's flipside. Picture Steve Buscemi in the remake with Alabama 3 on the soundtrack.

fields.headline: Queen of hearts
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale looks at Elizabeth by David Starkey, and Patrick O'Brian: A Life Revealed by Dean King
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at Elizabeth by David Starkey, and Patrick O'Brian: A Life Revealed by Dean King
fields.body:
Elizabeth
David Starkey
(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Fraudulently marketed as "the book of the TV series", Starkey's life of Elizabeth is no such thing: whereas his glorified lectures on Channel 4 covered the entire reign - so that viewers entertainingly saw one tetchy old queen beadily assessing another - the biography stops soon after her accession. Conceiving it as a "historical thriller", Starkey is transparently besotted with his heroine, sensitive and adroit in teasing out the subtexts of Tudor portraits or ceremonies, and virtually eschews academic bitchery. All of which makes you wonder what drugs they inject him with before he interrogates hapless bien pensants on The Moral Maze .

Patrick O'Brian: A Life Revealed
Dean King
(Sceptre, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Begun in 1969 on the suggestion of a US publisher looking for a successor to C S Forester, O'Brian's sequence of Napoleonic naval novels featuring Captain Jack Aubrey and ship's surgeon Stephen Maturin could scarcely be less like most 20th-century fiction - indeed, that was central to its attraction, you suspect, for such admirers as Tory ministers and newspaper editors. But O'Brian's own life was a novel by Graham Greene or Patricia Highsmith, in which a wartime intelligence officer called Richard Russ changed his name in 1945 and maintained the lie that he was an Irishman until his death last year.

webTitle: A life in writing: Edward Marriot

fields.headline: Swimming with the sharks
fields.standfirst: Edward Marriot tells Nicholas Wroe why he is an accidental travel writer
fields.trailText: A life in writing: Edward Marriot tells Nicholas Wroe why he is an accidental travel writer
fields.body:
In Edward Marriott's debut book, The Lost Tribe , he ventured to a remote jungle in Papua New Guinea, where he was accused of being responsible for a fatal lightning strike and had to flee for his life. In his second book, Wild Shore: Life and Death with Nicaragua's Last Shark Hunters , published in paperback this month, he finds himself in the squalid and menacing world of bull-shark fishermen in Nicaragua. It is daring stuff, stylishly written, with as sharp an eye on the history of these places as on their geography. One critic said that Marriott "plays his role as the linen-clad Brit in the jungle with superb nonchalance", but despite all this he claims: "The truth of it is, I don't really have a huge wanderlust."

He says he suffers from homesickness, and that the demands of his young family - his wife was pregnant with their now three-year-old son while he was in Nicaragua - mean he won't travel so much in the future. "My first book did turn into a dangerous expedition, but I didn't intend that," he recalls. "I'm really more interested in the story than the location. I nearly wrote a book about a vicar in Norfolk. There was this huge schism in his parish and it's not exaggerating too much to say there was a war going on. It was an excellent story, full of interesting, rich characters."

But while he adds to his parochial credentials by declaring that he always went to Scotland on holidays as a child and that his first trip abroad was on a French exchange at the age of 15, he also acknowledges that he finds it easier to describe places that are very rough and off the beaten track. "I do find they get my juices flowing more." It was a news story about the lost tribe in Papua New Guinea that first attracted his attention. "I had a cousin who lived there, so I went on a little recce. It wasn't that I wanted to go into the heart of darkness and all those other clichés. But having been there, it was such an interesting country and quite unlike anything I had known before."

He admits that as the situation worsened, his journalistic and survival instincts came into conflict. "I jotted down some impressions in my notebook, but I had no idea how I could make them into a book. As we were fleeing, I thought rather superstitiously: 'If I get out of this I promise not to exploit it in any way.' But on the other hand, part of me was thinking: 'This is great material and I want to get out of this so I can write about it.'"

Marriott was at university when he became aware of writing as something he wanted to do. He started a magazine, wrote some poetry and journalism and now writes for the Evening Standard . His writing is often praised for its literary qualities, and he has also made a couple of attempts at fiction. "I wrote a novel after Lost Tribes which is in a bottom drawer and is likely to remain there," he says. "It was a coming-of-age novel, which I think unless they are done incredibly well can be rather embarrassing." Another novel about an early underwater submersible was put on hold when he started Wild Shores . "I don't know whether I'll go back to it."

At 34, he says he was too young to be influenced by the Granta -inspired travel-writing boom of the 1980s, but was aware of Bruce Chatwin. "It wasn't until my mid-20s that I started reading travel writing seriously. I'm not one of those writers who was started off by discovering a shell in their grandfather's cabinet aged two."

Marriott considers the best travel writing to be a hybrid of genres. "The least interesting type is just a flat account of the journey. But someone like Jonathan Raban, one of the best exponents of travel writing, does all sorts of things, sometimes heavily disguised, that are wrapped up in this travel umbrella: bits of autobiography, historical reconstruction, fiction." The issue of truth and fiction in travel literature is a vexed one. That's where the truth comes in." He has been to north- west India to research it, but claims he hopes to remain more in the background than in his previous books.
