fields.headline: The Mule Duignan
fields.trailText:
Nowadays it always rains in Bristol,
and every night, trying to get to sleep...
fields.body:
Nowadays it always rains in Bristol,

and every night, trying to get to sleep,

I hear it, looking beyond to the lights

winking over the Clifden Bridge, like the lights

of the shoreline seen from the Irish mailboat.

It helps me to drop off if I go over

details from childhood, like the big key

of acrid cast-iron that shut and opened

the front door. I find it strange to still remember

that it opened clockwise, and locked the way

you'd expect that it would open. Most often

I think back to a December night

when my small sister crept into bed with me,

shivering. We listened to our father's voice,

emphatic and quiet:" if the cow does die tonight,

we'll have to sell up and go." We prayed ourselves

to sleep. In the morning the wind woke us

and we all went out together to the stall.

The cow was standing up, eating hay.

And then for the first and only time I saw

my parents embracing. I hate that country:

its poverties and embarrassments

too humbling to retell. I'll never ever

go back to offer it forgiveness.

When my father died at last, the place

was empty. I went back to bury him,

then turned the key in the lock and dropped it

in the estate-agent's letterbox

and turned my back for ever on it all.

webTitle: Review: Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture by Apostolos Doxiadis

fields.headline: Number crunching
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  luxuriates in his primes with Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture by Apostolos Doxiadis
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard luxuriates in his primes with Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture by Apostolos Doxiadis
fields.body:
Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture
Apostolos Doxiadis
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is a matter of some concern over and above the purely literary when a publisher, in whom the present reviewer has to declare an interest, announces that it is prepared to give away a cool $1 million. And all the more so when, in the last financial year, it made a profit of only £256,000, a sum I had thought perfectly respectable until announcement of this damn fool publicity stunt was made.

You are all presumably familiar with Goldbach's Conjecture. For those who are not, it is this: that every even number greater than two is the sum of two prime numbers. Now, while this conjecture has been painstakingly verified for all numbers up to a gadzillion, no one has supplied an actual proof for every number in the universe. And they've been trying since 1742.

So where mathematics flounders, literature steps in to lend a hand, and this is where Faber's publicity stunt comes in: tied to the hardback publication of this novel last April and still unclaimed. (One imagines listless coteries of mathematicians, preferring to work on anything on earth rather than Goldbach's Conjecture, until the Faber offer comes along. It is bankrolled, incidentally, by Bloomsbury US, so I suppose that, as their coffers are bursting with gold clawed from the pockets of Harry Potter fans, no one at Faber is really that worried.) By the way, Goldbach himself, and indeed this novel's narrator until about page 41, would be ineligible for the prize, being respectively non-US and non-UK citizens, and, in the latter case, under 18.

But that is nit-picking. For, when science meets art, the results are acclaimed around the world. I count 24 different encomia printed within and without the book itself, from George Steiner to the Morning Star . The book is manifestly readable, its scanty characterisation and liberal use of exclamation marks no bar to one's enjoyment; the mathematics has been made light and fluffy enough for ordinary people, and there is a cunning blend of fiction and reality (pen portraits of the Trinity trinity of mathematicians G H Hardy, JE Littlewood and Srinivasa Ramanjuan, with cameos from Alan Turing and Kurt Gödel). One imagines Doxiadis knows whereof he speaks: he was apparently admitted to Columbia University after presenting an original paper to the Department of Mathematics, has written at least four other novels, directed for the theatre, won a prize at the Berlin International Film Festival, and translated Hamlet and Mourning Becomes Electra , for crying out loud.

The story is poignant: the narrator (unnamed; it is possible he is a version of Doxiadis himself) has an Uncle, gifted but broken, presumably in the course of trying to solve this Conjecture; he makes his nephew promise that he will never pursue a career in mathematics. It is a portrait of mathematical genius, of relentless application and insanity; and it makes the character of the driven mathematician less of a mystery. To paraphrase more of the book would be to spoil its simple impact. As for Goldbach's Conjecture itself, I have discovered a most marvellous proof of this, only I do not have enough space in this review to . . . oh, wait, that's a Fermat's Last Theorem joke.

webTitle: Review: Ways of Hearing by Ben Thompson

fields.headline: So bogus, dude
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  discovers how to judge pop in Ways of Hearing by Ben Thompson
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard discovers how to judge pop in Ways of Hearing by Ben Thompson
fields.body:
Ways of Hearing: A User's Guide to the Pop Psyche, from Elvis to Eminem
Ben Thompson
327pp, Orion, £14.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In an exchange from a radio interview reproduced here, American hip-hop artist KRS-1 says that the word on the Brixton streets is that his interviewer, Tim Westwood, is uncool. Westwood, a white man in a predominantly black milieu, knows something about how to anticipate and possibly deal with slurs on his professionalism, and asks KRS-1 when he was last in the UK. The factually accurate answer to this question is "six years ago", but what KRS-1 chooses to say instead is: "I'm always here."

Ben Thompson glosses this with the stage direction: "An awkward silence as the awesome bogosity of these words sinks in." I cite this not as an example of Thompson's confidence with his subject, but as a good use of the word "bogosity", which also appeared in his last collection of writings on pop music, Seven Years of Plenty . There - and I don't even have to look this up, although I read the book nearly two-and-a-half years ago - he refers to the "inherent bogosity of MTV's Unplugged ", that part of the rock channel's schedule devoted to performers playing acoustic versions of their songs. (Or "acoustical", the term contemptuously coined by Colin B Morton and Chuck Death in their sublimely twisted cartoon history of rock'n'roll, Great Pop Things , which has a similar subtitle to that of Ways of Hearing . Unamplified music is simply not pop, rock or anything that the young of heart need bother with.)

The question of bogosity underlies almost all critical thinking - both public and private - about pop music. Is so-and-so fake? And if so, in what way, precisely? Thompson, in a hilarious piece on Beavis and Butthead , says that "their division of all artistic phenomena into two categories - 'stuff which is cool' and 'stuff which sucks' - bespeaks an evaluative aesthetic of inspirational directness". The joke lies in the use of language that would fly high over B & B's heads; but is there not, too, a note of wistfulness at their ease in making snap judgments? Punk rockers chose to tackle that particular argument by declaring that pretty much everything, punk itself possibly included, was bogus; at least they were frank about it. But it's a circular accusation that backfires on the accuser: the word "bogosity" is, in itself, bogus. That's why it's so much fun to use it. And it also hints at the essence of the pop performer, who has necessarily reinvented him- or herself to an extraordinary degree.

This notion of pop music as a matter of reinvention is the key to this book - not that it is exactly locked. It is, after all, a collection of pieces, many of which have been published previously: interviews with bands and stars from Air to Neil Young, their alphabetical arrangement here emphasising the randomness of the commissions (unless Thompson really wanted to have an interview with Eminem, and no one else, precede his interview with Brian Eno). It also offers amusing digressions and expanded versions of sleevenotes.

You can dip into it anywhere and take great pleasure from Thompson's wit and artfully constructed sentences, which at times have all the earthly grace and snap of a beautifully modulated chord change: "The most cherished image of a memorable evening is the hulking figure of [Einstürzende] Neubauten's mighty human talisman FM Einheit, advancing into the crowd in his blacksmith's apron brandishing a fully operational chainsaw. This action - long before the Archaos circus had made such antics a cabaret staple - sends the leather-clad cream of London's counterculture scurrying to the back of the hall, their faces struggling to convey the message: 'I just want to get a look at this from another perspective.'"

But even here, in this paragraph chosen more or less at random, you can see another skirmish in pop's battle between bogosity and sincerity: the above gig took place at the ICA, which over the years has trodden a very fine and wavering course in the mined borderlands between art, pop and outright pretension.

Which is almost what Ways of Hearing does, too. Its title is a deliberate nod to John Berger's Ways of Seeing , a book Thompson found "forbidding and arid". But he liked the idea of pinching and adapting the title, "thereby doing for music what you might imagine John Berger's Ways of Seeing did for the visual image, if you hadn't actually read it". The paragraph then rapidly tumbles through the following positions: an apology to John Berger, an apology-cum-justification to the reader for being so cheeky, and a perfectly gratuitous swipe at Jools Holland or, more specifically, "the plinky-plunk totalitarianism of Jools Holland's turn-of-the-century TV persona". (Not exactly the words I'd have chosen, but they still attest to something that needs to be said.)

Thompson uses puckishly flamboyant prose for a subject that, as he quotes Hanif Kureishi, is "crying out not to be written about". He raps Kureishi over the knuckles for saying this, particularly as it occurs in his introduction to the Faber Book of Pop , but, as with bogus words like bogosity, part of the thrill of writing so eloquently about pop, as Thompson emphatically does, is that it is transgressive in itself. This is why he persists in the technique, also used in Seven Years of Plenty , of the comedy index (not that his interviewees are incapable of speaking with surprising complexity and intelligence when the mood so takes them).

And as Thompson himself is fully aware, those searching for unsullied purity in the form are looking in the wrong place. As he says in his introduction, even such notionally cut-and-dried issues as the blackness or whiteness of one's skin begin to look ambiguous in pop music's supercharged atmosphere of re-creation and adulation: look at Mick Jagger, whom many have accused of appropriating blackness, in his voice and music if nothing else. Or think of "another, still more famous MJ", Michael Jackson, whose "terrible saga" is a kind of "minstrelsy in reverse".

Not that Thompson belabours the more serious points. He doesn't have to: his feel for the subject means that even bite-sized snippets dealing with wildly disparate artists reveal the same evaluative aesthetic at work. His critical ear is almost infallibly trustworthy; his writing, which both dances round the point and then gets straight to it, is a delight. When he writes that our ears "wax up protectively" when exposed to the worst excesses of one particular band, you can see both of these attributes in action. It is wit, in its 18th-century sense: an acuity of judgment that makes you laugh.

webTitle: Review:  The Cash Nexus by Niall Ferguson

fields.headline: Rich pickings
fields.standfirst: Hywel Williams  gets the hard sell from Niall Ferguson's  The Cash Nexus
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams gets the hard sell from Niall Ferguson's The Cash Nexus
fields.body:
The Cash Nexus: Money and Power in the Modern World, 1700-2000
Niall Ferguson
576pp, Allen Lane, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The "right-wing historian" has become an important figure in the republic of English letters. The proclaimed role is that of raging bull, pumped up with intellectual testosterone. He - for the milieu is a masculine one - is out to demolish the delicate china shop run by liberal rationalists, as well as the heavy-duty but rusty machinery of the Marxist determinists. The years of Conservative hegemony were a good time for this beast on the prowl: advances rolled in and the column spaces proved receptive. Niall Ferguson is the best of these beasts. Aggression, all chunky and spunky, stares out at us from the dust-jacket photograph. We are meant to be frightened: pack away those limping aperçus lest they attract the attentions of a Glasgow kiss.

The Cash Nexus is devoted to a single, if obvious, truth: economics inclines but does not determine the history of the world. Human beings are not rational agents. Who wants to be a millionaire? Well, most people think they do. But most people are also bad at assessing their own economic best interests. "Bounded rationality" locks us inside misleading preconceptions and emotions. In any case, Ferguson maintains, there are no objectively right answers on this syllabus that humanity pursues. All that exists is the irrational violence of the human fight for what it thinks is an appropriate existence.

There's fun to be had in this book's dismantling of illusions, but sometimes the candidates for dismissal are too predictable. There's the hypocrisy of those literary types ("conspicuously ungrateful") who bewailed mammon's rotten fruit but still found it tasty: Fontane and Dickens, Zola and Maupassant, as well as the prophet of dissolution himself - Marx speculated on American funds and on those English stocks that he eagerly noted were "springing up like mushrooms".

Sometimes there's a belaboured quality to Ferguson's enterprise, as graphs and tables grind the tired intuition into the dust. "Feelgood" comes in for a particular bashing. Its absence in 1992 and economic abundance in 1997 should have dictated a Labour victory in one election and a Conservative victory in the other, but voters' judgments proved to be impervious to economics. Judgments of political character were central. In the most recent election, morality too was a strong influence.

Despite its debunking of illusions, this is a book that sets out to explain why British was best for such a long time - and why, in its Anglo-American form at least, it remains so. The Cash Nexus is, in its way, as patriotic a tome as the works of those Whig historians whose innocent evolutionary assumptions it rightly dismisses.

Britain became a world power because it handled four institutions supremely well. It had a professional tax-gathering bureaucracy rather than private and venal "tax-farmers". Parliament enhanced the state's ability to raise taxes. National debt made for successful war by allowing for a sudden increase in costs, and a central bank managed the debt. Other European powers tried some or all of these components: only the Hanoverians got the balance right. The oligarchy promoted prosperity. Its success demonstrates that there's no automatic relationship between affluence and democracy, a pleasing fancy of our global times. Here Ferguson convinces.

But it is when we get to the 20th century and the American hegemony that we see some calculated frothing at the mouth. A book like this needs, after all, its USP to service the authorial cash nexus: a big idea to shock and earn a headline. Ferguson's is a central and western European perspective. He has always been a superb historian of Germany: nobody better understands the febrile insecurities behind the strutting will to power. In his conclusion he inspects the demilitarised west, which has travelled from warfare to welfare, and finds it vulnerable. Alert to rogue states, Ferguson is a missile-defence man ready to don a bomber jacket. But he goes further and castigates the United States for "imperial under-stretch". America needs to intervene more consistently and spend its money more abundantly on the spreading of the shining path. Yanks, though, are wimps, "unwilling to expend any American lives in foreign wars, no matter how noble the cause".

As a killer punch, this fails to convince. Of all the great empires in world history, the American version is the most capricious - its actions governed by ignorance, inconsistency and sanctimony. Marooned on a land mass, in the 20th century it has veered between equally disastrous extremes of isolationism and interventionism. Sharing a frontier only with Canada and Mexico, it is constitutionally incapable of understanding the balance of power that comes to great states and empires which have somehow to coexist. History man as raging bull has dropped something malodorous on his way to the bank. So virile, but oh so false.

webTitle: Review: SS-1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler by Hugh Thomas

fields.headline: Rebuilding the Reich
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey  examines the theory that Himmler cheated death in  SS-1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler by Hugh Thomas
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey examines the theory that Himmler cheated death in SS-1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler by Hugh Thomas
fields.body:
SS-1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler
Hugh Thomas
287pp, Fourth Estate, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Conspiracy theories concerning the fate of former Nazi German leaders are 10 a pfennig. Did Martin Bormann, Hitler's secretary, live to a ripe old age somewhere in South America? Are we sure it was the Führer's corpse that was burned by aides in the courtyard of the Reich Chancellory as the Red Army stormed Berlin in May 1945? And what about Himmler? Is it just possible that the scrawny middle-aged man in glasses who committed suicide at the British camp at Luneburg after capture that same month was in fact a stand-in for the feared SS Reichsführer? That Himmler himself - who as late as May 5 had claimed that he, for one, "would never commit suicide" - had somehow slipped out of the Fatherland and set out on some not-so-vainglorious quest to set up a secret Fourth Reich?

Well, maybe. Possibly. Perhaps. Anything is possible, after all, in the breathless aftermath of world war. Certain physical details of the dead man at Lüneburg do seem different from Himmler's: you can see them in the studious photos reproduced in this book. One nostril is larger than the other, whereas Himmler's were symmetrical. The corpse doesn't appear to sport a duelling scar, which means that unless the dead man was wearing make-up (popular among senior Nazis), he wasn't the son born to Anna and Dr Gebhard Himmler on October 7 1900.

Hugh Thomas is "a surgeon and forensic expert of international repute", says the blurb to this dense, fascinating yet ultimately bothersome book. "His first book, The Murder of Rudolf Hess , caused a worldwide furore. His second, Hess: A Tale of Two Murders , precipitated a six-month Scotland Yard inquiry that saw its report immediately suppressed." Thomas does have a scalpel-sharp eye for detail - as you would hope of a man of his profession. He also writes well when he allows himself to get beyond the weight of the obsessive detail that bogs parts of this book down like one of Panzer General Guderian's tanks attempting to advance on Moscow in December 1941. It was Guderian who commented that Himmler was "a man from another planet".

The central thesis of Thomas's book - and the evidence for it is vivid - is that Himmler was attempting to set up a Fourth Reich outside the boundaries of Hitler's Germany. Quite aware that Germany had effectively lost the war as early as 1943, Thomas's Himmler set about channelling the Croesan riches amassed by the SS and pro-Nazi German finance and industry into Swiss and South American bank accounts. An FBI/OSS report of November 1944, written by Senator Harley M Kilgore and backed by the US Treasury and State departments, noted: "The German aggressors have begun to pursue the strategy which they found successful a quarter of a century ago. They are already deploying their economic wares throughout the world in preparation for a third attempt at world domination." Which, of course, appeared to happen from the 1950s, when the Federal Republic's "economic miracle" astounded the nations that had borne the brunt of the fighting against Hitler, Himmler and the rest of their vile crew.

Thomas piles up a massively detailed case suggesting that Nazi money exported to safe financial havens in the late stages of the second world war was, to a previously underplayed extent, responsible for Germany's rise to economic power in the decade following Hitler's downfall. Well, maybe. Perhaps. Possibly. To his credit, Thomas uses these defusing words frequently in a book that might otherwise overstretch the imagination and, in turn, credit Himmler with too much intelligence and insight.

His portrait of Himmler is, in fact, the best part of SS-1 , which suffers from being three books in one. There's an excellent mini-biography of Himmler, a Byzantine analysis of the links between Nazi and international finance during the war, and a forensic examination of the corpse that may or may not have been that of the Reichsführer.

The description of Himmler's childhood and youth is compelling. This "man of quiet, unemotional gestures, a man without words" was fastidious and possessed of a phenomenal memory; he kept a daily diary recording everything that happened to him. He put these skills to chilling use when he began to wipe out Europe's Jews and gypsies, communists and homosexuals. Everything the SS did was planned and recorded fastidiously. No one escaped the Reichsführer's eyes, beady behind those infamous rimless glasses. Everyone needed to be watched, especially Paula Stolzle, his elder brother's pretty and flirtatious fiancée. Disapproving of sexy women, shortly before he joined the Nazi party the puritanical young Himmler employed a private detective to follow Stolzle; he made the couple's lives so fraught that the engagement was called off.

Himmler went on to become a lot creepier and a lot more dangerous, although he did marry, losing his virginity at the age of 28 to a nurse seven years his senior who thought those rimless glasses - she persuaded him to wear them - rather fetching. It's just this sort of near-forensic detail that makes Thomas's book worthwhile. Quick as a blitzkrieg, this bloodless young man is Reichsführer SS (in 1929, aged 28). The title SS-1 refers to Himmler's position as head of the Schutz Staffel; it was also the licence plate of his BMW staff car. According to Josef Goebbels, "except for Hitler, no one is entirely without fear of Himmler".

No one? German business certainly appears to have gone along with him. So too did business interests in Washington, London and Zurich. If there had been some shady Allied agreement to allow Himmler to escape the wrath of the Nuremberg trials and set up shop elsewhere while pretending that he had committed suicide, then it had surely been abandoned by May 1945. Himmler, the SS and German big business may well have been in cahoots with elements in Wall Street and the City of London; Britain's royal family, with its shareholding in German companies, was also that bit too close to him (Prince Christopher Mountbatten, says Thomas, was on Himmler's staff). Yet ultimately the SS Reichsführer was surely too ghastly to be acceptable to the international business and banking community.

It's true that the British dug up the corpse for reidentification, and it's true that several members of British intelligence, Kim Philby among them, were not immediately convinced that Himmler was dead. Yet if he weren't, we would surely have heard something about it by now. Wouldn't we?

webTitle: Review: All Bones and Lies by Anne Fine

fields.headline: Life in bad-sitcom land
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson  on  All Bones and Lies, a colourless comedy of cardigans by Anne Fine
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson on All Bones and Lies, a colourless comedy of cardigans by Anne Fine
fields.body:
All Bones and Lies
Anne Fine
238pp, Bantam, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Multiple award-winning children's writer Anne Fine is edgy, readable, and funny, and has even had Robin Williams star in the film of one of her books (no greater accolade is possible in our eight-year-old's eyes). Her last adult novel was a dark, intriguing piece about sisters; this, her fifth, concerns the misadventures of Colin, a bumbling middle-aged environmental-health officer who needs to get out more.

Colin is unmarried and unloved. His only pleasure is masturbating in his mother's woodshed, his only friend a three-year-old called Tammy (don't worry, the two don't seem to be connected). I'm not sure whether we're told that he wears a cardigan, but he's absolutely the kind of man - stalwart of many a grim 1970s farce - who would.

Colin's hen-pecked father killed himself long ago by driving into a wall (a blessed release, presumably, from being driven up one). Since his sister views their gruesome mother as "moral syphilis", it falls to Colin to visit and shop for this crabby, bitter-tongued old woman whose hobby is thinking the worst of everyone. Meanwhile, Colin's small friend Tammy belongs to Mel, a grounded trapeze artist and single mum who lives in a run-down block of flats and seems only to tolerate Colin's regular, doting visits. It's a sign of his intense loneliness and his passion for the child that, when Mel dumps Tammy on him so she can go off for a weekend's trapezing, he suddenly feels normal, happy, needed.

And if only All Bones and Lies were about that potentially touching emotional transformation. If only Fine had bothered to explore any of the quirky relationships that lurk beneath her oppressively knowing tone and unfunny, repetitive gags, this might be a readable novel. But she doesn't, and it isn't. Most of the time we're firmly pinioned in bad-sitcom land, a barren place where "comic" conversations end abruptly because if they were taken to a logical conclusion, either plot or gags would falter. It's a place where people make remarks and think thoughts that are grossly out of character, or fall into sudden, bumbling gaffes, again for the sake of the side-splitting comedy Fine clearly believes she's concocting.

Most of all it's the novel's sheer sameness that grates - the monotony, for instance, of having half its turgid conversations revolve around insurance forms. And then there's the small matter of the writing. This really is a terminally colourless piece of work, which sweats and shudders under the weight of an unwieldy, incoherent prose that would send a GCSE English teacher running for cover.

So what's gone wrong? Is it that, once Hollywood has called, no one dares edit you any more? Or, more depressingly, is it just that Fine has accurately tuned in to the current literary market for small, safe, complacent novels that take you nowhere very slowly? Whichever, it probably won't matter for a while. If you're as skilled, incisive and celebrated a writer as she is, I expect you can get away with this sort of drab, unfunny fable. Once.

fields.headline: Own goals
fields.trailText: As promised, the Loafer trotted along to the British Book Awards for roast peppers, tough venison and a few sour grapes
fields.body:
 As promised, the Loafer trotted along to the British Book Awards for roast peppers, tough venison and a few sour grapes. But amid the winners (Nigella, Zadie, Becks) and the losers (Nigella, Zadie, Becks), the most entertaining sight was the "guest presenters", aka celebs who are persuaded by their publishers that this is A Good Thing to Do. Thus we had Rolf Harris sketching away on stage; yachtswoman turned "motivational speaker" Tracy Edwards asking Jamie Oliver for the secret of good pastry ("cold hands, darling" - ugh); and Mr Sincere, Alan Titchmarsh, urging his fellow writers on to greater heights of humility. But best of all was Geoff Hurst, who announced an autobiography entitled 1966 and All That and got a standing ovation. Even in bookish circles, you can't beat football for stirring the troops.

 Interesting news from Stuart Rose, ex of Iceland/ Booker, whose acrimonious departure occurred days after last year's Booker. "It was like having a row with your wife before a dinner party," he says. "You still have to be nice to the guests, haven't you?" Which might account for the chilly atmosphere on the night.

 A glorious World Book Day is slightly overcast by a special survey of reading habits. The English are slackers when it comes to reading, spending only 4.6 hours a week reading "for pleasure", well behind the Scots, who get between the covers for 5.8 hours. Within England, Londoners and those in Yorkshire come joint top, but "the North" (excluding Yorkshire, presumably) really shows itself up: there you will find the highest percentage of people "not reading for pleasure at all"! But perhaps readers in "the North" are simply wondering what exactly defines "pleasure"?

 You really don't want to get on the wrong side of Dave Eggers, particularly not via email. Eggers has taken exception to a piece written by David Kirkpatrick for the New York Times to coincide with the paperback publication of A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. Eggers homes in on discussion of the legal dispute between him and his former agent, references to the multiple covers that adorn his paperback and a sprinkling of factual errors. But what really gets his goat is Kirkpatrick's liberal use of off-the-record comments resulting from their feverish emails. Now, as "clarification", Eggers has reproduced the whole correspondence on his McSweeney's website, www.mcsweeneys.net. Good bits include Kirkpatrick cajoling a reluctant Eggers into cooperating with the article by promising him copy approval; a fabulous cock-up that prevents the above from happening; Eggers going bonkers when the piece appears; and Kirkpatrick all but begging him not to go public. There's also much tedious "you said", "no I didn't" stuff. The Loafer suggests you read the first bit and then do a search for the words "bitter little bastard".

webTitle: Review: The Way Forward Is with a Broken Heart by Alice Walker

fields.headline: Broken-hearted nation
fields.standfirst: Kasia Boddy  on The Way Forward Is with a Broken Heart, Alice Walker's collection of poignant stories of race in America
fields.trailText: Kasia Boddy on The Way Forward Is with a Broken Heart, Alice Walker's collection of poignant stories of race in America
fields.body:
The Way Forward Is with a Broken Heart
Alice Walker
256pp, The Women's Press, £14.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

At the start of Alice Walker's new collection of short stories is a memoir of her 10-year "magical marriage", which ended 20 years ago. It is addressed "to my young husband", and asks him in turn to address the question of what happened to them. "We were good people . . . Too good to have those years stolen from us, even by our grief."

Walker's agenda is political as well as personal. Her divorce was not that of just any couple gone wrong, but of a union between a black woman and a white man in the "60s time of war". If they, inspired by Martin Luther King's vision, could fail, what hope has America, that "broken-hearted nation"? As the book progresses, however, through stories clustered around comparable couples, the possible "ways forward" become more optimistic. Love still may find a way. For those tempted by nostalgia, she contrasts women's lives in the 20th century with those possible in the 18th or 19th centuries. One narrator unthinkingly eats watermelon, but she can remember a time "in my lifetime, when black people were ashamed of watermelon". "We sure have come a long way," she concludes.

At times the plots seem designed to facilitate their morals, but the most politically direct stories are suffused with Walker's characteristic witty banter and sensual playfulness - we can almost believe, for a moment, that a white man massaging a black woman with olive oil is the ultimate political act. Self-love and an embracing of "the foreign" are still key issues, and Walker has always been an advocate of sexual healing.

The book is dedicated to "the American race", a phrase that Walker acknowledges comes from Jean Toomer, author of the 1923 modernist classic Cane . A strong believer in the unified national purpose of America, Toomer felt that race was a meaningless category and argued that interracial sex was the key to eradicate endemic racism. Ironically, however, his career proved the importance of race to "intermingled" Americans. When he refused to be published "as a black man", claiming, as Walker does, a multiracial heritage, he was no longer acceptable to those who had previously embraced him. Today Toomer features largely on courses on "black writing". Walker, too, is predominantly read, taught and even shelved as a "black writer" rather than as an "American" one. But what this says about the national "way forward" is something that she does not address.

webTitle: Review: From Dawn to Decadence by Jacques Barzun

fields.headline: The age of entropy
fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss  journeys from revolution to inertia with From Dawn to Decadence: 500 Years of Western Cultural Life by Jacques Barzun
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss journeys from revolution to inertia with From Dawn to Decadence: 500 Years of Western Cultural Life by Jacques Barzun
fields.body:
From Dawn to Decadence: 500 Years of Western Cultural Life
Jacques Barzun 877pp, HarperCollins, £25 Buy it at a discount at BOL

In assessing the French revolution, Jacques Barzun describes it as an upheaval that occurred "not so very long ago". For Barzun, who was born in France in 1907 and whose education was supervised by a great-grandmother born in the year of the final fall of the Bourbons, it is precisely that - an event of recent vintage - and it is one of the virtues of his vast, synoptic book that he makes the history of the past 500 years vivid and urgent. For a generation for whom history largely comprises BBC2 theme nights on the 1970s and 1980s, it is a salutary lesson.

Barzun's book, written in a light, lucid, epigrammatic style, reads like a set of notes drawn from a lifetime's contemplation of the route by which the US and Europe arrived at Eminem, George W Bush and the Millennium Dome. He offers a history of ideas, not a historical narrative; it is an interpretation, not a description, of what happened, which is why he gives parenthetical suggestions of other books to browse.

Barzun moved to the US in 1920 and, based at Columbia University, became one of its starriest and most combative academics, using his elegant pen in books such as The House of Intellect and Darwin Marx Wagner to oppose premature academic specialisation and defend the place of the humanities. He has been an emeritus professor since 1967, suggesting the need for some enhanced term of venerability. This book concludes his lifelong quest to relate historical events to cultural expression, and to understand the process of change. His question is nothing less than that which Tolstoy poses at the end of War and Peace : "What is the force that moves nations?"

Barzun arranges his answer by period. From 1500 to 1660 it was religion: the Protestant challenge to Catholicism that led men, suddenly given direct access to God, to redefine themselves and states. From 1660 to 1789 it was the pursuit of political freedom and individual rights, culminating in the French Revolution. From 1790 to 1920 it was the search for social and economic equality, exploding in the Russian Revolution. In the past century, it has been an uneasy amalgam of all three. Now, if his bleakest pronouncements are to be taken at face value, it is nothing at all: we are ruled by inertia. Entropy has replaced ideology.

The story starts with Luther because the religious revolution he began lit the fires of individualism that burned ever more brightly thereafter. Barzun sees the religious, monarchical, liberal and collectivist revolutions as a chain reaction triggered by increasing demands for individual rights. (It is a grim irony that the pursuit of equal rights for all should culminate in a collectivist revolution that sought to obliterate the individual: a nihilist's equality.) Luther said that every man was a priest; the monarchs who built the nations of the 17th and 18th centuries undermined the nobility and (inadvertently?) encouraged the notion of equal subjects. The revolutions of the late 18th century converted subjects into citizens, and Marx sought to turn political equality into economic equality.

That is the canopy that Barzun erects over his luxuriant garden of ideas and aphorisms. He shows his age in only one respect: like his fellow academic luminary Harold Bloom, he is anxious to judge, to draw moral lessons from the lives of figures such as Cromwell and Louis XIV. That is at best otiose and, when he dismisses the leading figures in the French Revolution as "men who lacked mature political talent", ludicrously banal. Most of all, Barzun wants to judge the present generation, and he finds us sadly lacking. "The forms of art as of life seem exhausted, the stages of development have been run through. Institutions function painfully. Repetition and frustration are the intolerable result. Boredom and fatigue are great historical forces."

This vision, outlined in the sketchiest section of the book, only appears persuasive because of a trick of perspective. The present cannot be judged in the same way as the past; 1517, 1649, 1789 and 1917 only make sense with hindsight. Similarly, greatness in art, itself a mutable designation, is determined by later generations. The present age, unquestionably suspicious of ideology, may appear bereft of genius and empty of meaning; but who knows, any day now another Luther may be posting a new set of incendiary propositions on the internet, making placemen and plutocrats quake.

fields.headline: Rough Trade at the Union Chapel
fields.standfirst:
Mark Mulcahy
Union Chapel
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Mark Mulcahy
Union Chapel
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Impressive though it is that the Rough Trade record shops have reached their 25th anniversary without stooping to selling major-label garbage such as Steps or S Club 7, it's hard to ignore the niggling sensation that what's really being celebrated here is wilful underachievement. It's stamped all over the acts playing at the fortnight of birthday gigs: Tindersticks, Evan Dando, the Sea and Cake, Nectarine No 9 and, at this show, Mark Eitzel and Mark Mulcahy. These acts haven't been unsuccessful: they each lay claim to a sizable cult following. But their music is so joyous, so rich, that it should be crashing out of the indie ghetto to reach a significantly larger audience.

So Eitzel and Mulcahy faced a Union Chapel only half full, but half full of devoted fans who hung on their every syllable, clung to each spirit-soaring note as it swelled beneath the church's domed roof. They made a superb pairing. Eitzel is a songwriter as acerbic as he is humane: his poignant tales are littered with remarkable details, such as the cat that couldn't resist becoming a Christian Scientist and the people dressed in moth outfits who collide beneath street lamps. Mulcahy's lyrics, too, offer delicious turns of phrase - "Do I enjoy a walk on your thin ice, or on your hot coals?" he muses of his lover's mood-swings in Hurry, Please Hurry - but in his case it's the voice that really thrills.

The wonderful thing about Mulcahy is that he knows he has an incredible voice, an instrument that can be sculpted like soft clay, and he isn't shy of using it. When he takes the stage he immediately starts humming; later he tries to encourage us all to sing along to his sequence of perfectly tuned "uh-uh-uh" sounds. When he repeats a verse of In the Afternoon, he sings it with new inflections that make the words appear fresh. Hurry, Please Hurry starts gently, the guitar barely there, the chorus taken slowly in a high-pitched voice like the sound of a finger running round the rim of a glass. But he grows more urgent by the minute, until he is panting, seducing. The song ends with funny little miaows of contentment.

You realise how this voice has developed in the second half of the set, when he moves on to songs by his old band, Miracle Legion, and sings them in a far straighter, less experimental manner. But there are still delightful quirks, such as the way he and his accompanist, Hefner's Jack Hayter, fade their guitars right down on The Backyard then bring the volume back up with a shoom. And he has his own cheeky analysis of the Rough Trade label's troubled history; introducing the song Heart Disease Called Love, he remarks: "I don't think Rough Trade ever put this song out. That's probably why they went bankrupt."

 Mark Mulcahy plays the Cube, Bristol (0117-907 4190), tonight, Toynbee Hall Arts Cafe, London E1 (020-7247 5681), tomorrow, then tours.

webTitle: Jazz review: Gary Crosby's Nu Troop II

fields.headline: Gary Crosby's Nu Troop II
fields.standfirst:
Bonington Theatre
Nottingham
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Bonington Theatre
Nottingham
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The original Nu Troop was a conscious attempt to imitate Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, with leader and bassist Gary Crosby (formerly of the Jazz Warriors) providing a nurturing environment for an ever-changing assembly of hot young players.

The hard bop quintet's second incarnation features some astonishingly young and vibrant talent. The impish Robert Michelle is quite simply a staggering pianist. He manages to roll the styles of Art Tatum, Franz Liszt and Nina Simone into one blistering bundle, yet still comes out sounding like himself. He enjoys a particular rapport with floppy-limbed drummer Rod Youngs, who doesn't so much hit his drums as massage them. Leaning forward sensually, then reclining back with an expression of orgasmic concentration, he makes his cymbal fizz like freshly poured lemonade.

The front-line duo provide a riveting dialogue. Saxophonist Soweto Kinch is the composer of much of the material played tonight, and he serenades us with mellifluous restraint, adopting an easy, conversational tone to tell us about life, the universe and everything.

By contrast, Sean Corby uses his trumpet to call on heaven, emitting great devotional shrieks that add lustre to his companion's quietly spoken wisdom. The pair spur each other on, and as sparks start flying, the rest of the band respond with the explosiveness of lit dynamite.

Yet amid all this phenomenal playing there lurks a sense of danger. There are moments when Michelle appears not to know which note he's going to hit in a thousandth of a second's time, and Youngs occasionally looks as if he's going to topple backwards off his drum stool. These musicians may have attained total mastery of their instruments, but that clearly is not stopping them pushing at the limits of their own talent and vision.

The screw is turned right until the last moment, the quintet riding the tidal wave of Chick Corea's Inner Space with apparently little concern for their own physical health. When the end comes, Michelle jerks back in his seat, appearing surprised that his fingers haven't fallen off, and Crosby thanks the shell-shocked audience with the warm-hearted modesty that has underpinned all of the extraordinary, white-hot performance.

webTitle: Homes fit for the lower paid

fields.headline: Homes fit for the lower paid
fields.standfirst: An investment plan which provides affordable housing for people like nurses and teachers is finally about to launch. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: An investment plan which provides affordable housing for people like nurses and teachers is finally about to launch.
fields.body:
An investment scheme which aims to provide affordable housing for average and lower-paid homeseekers looks like finally turning into reality nearly 13 years after it hit the statute book.

It could help alleviate teacher and nursing shortages caused by the lack of low-priced accommodation.

The plan - known as a housing investment trust - could also offer a low-hassle, lower-risk alternative to buy-to-let schemes. The scheme will also be attractive to income seekers - the aim is to produce 9% yearly income, net to basic rate taxpayers - competing head-on with riskier junk bond funds.

But to be more than a one-hit wonder, housing minister Nick Raynsford will have to persuade the Treasury to increase the property purchase limits laid down in the housing investment trust scheme.

The rules state that no property can be purchased worth more than £85,000 outside London or £125,000 in the capital. These ceilings were based on January 1988 figures.

But average UK house prices have increased from £48,875 to £86,196 in the ensuing years, while those in Greater London have soared by roughly the same ratio from £85,217 to £153,881 at the start of this year. The once generous limits will now buy little. The average three-bed semi is more expensive than £125,000 in all but two of London's 32 boroughs, according to the Land Registry.

However, the limits will not prevent the promoters of the new vehicle, the First Housing Investment Trust, from using the £32.6m they hope to raise for property purchase.

And although the official prospectus for this split-level investment trust has not yet been finalised, interest from investors and advisers has been large enough for promoters, stockbrokers Williams de Broe, to take on four temps to staff phones.

"People like this concept. It's the first time that it will prove to be feasible despite the idea being around for well over a decade. It is possible because of a partnership with a residential property management company," says trust analyst John Newlands at Williams de Broe.

"It's an investment that is literally as safe as houses. It is an alternative to buy-to-let. Both gain or suffer with housing market ups and downs, but investors in this fund cannot be stuck with unsellable properties, difficult tenants or negative equity."

The fund will concentrate on buying in cities such as Nottingham, Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool and Dundee, where prices are low but rents are high by comparison.

The aim is for the fund to yield 9% before expenses. Property management company Solitaire, which will buy, sell and control the homes, takes 10% of the rental income. Alternative Investment Market listed Solitaire already organises smaller buy-to-let portfolios for private investors.

Subtracting an allowance for "voids" - periods when a property remained unlet - and insurance against defaulting tenants leaves a real 7% return on rents. Solitaire managing director Harvey Shulman expects annual rent rises just over inflation.

But the income is pushed back up thanks to the split-level trust set-up. Investors can choose between income shares and capital shares. Seven income shares at 100p will be issued for each three capital shares at 100p. And during the 10-year life of the trust, the income holders will benefit from a gearing effect from the cash put up by the capital shareholders.

The arithmetic puts the gross yield back to 10% - 9% net to basic taxpayers and 6.35% to 40% payers. The income will be paid quarterly. When the trust is wound up in 2011 investors should receive their original stake.

Whatever is left goes to the capital shareholders, who benefit from any property price uplifts. Provided values move ahead by 1.5% a year, the lowest level recorded over any 10-year period since 1974, capital investors will get their cash back in 2011.

But if the average rises by 2.5%, they get 159p, equal to 4.7% a year, at 5% annual growth, the result is 334p or 12.6% annualised, while at 7.5%, the return per share will be 550p or 18.3% a year.

Information: 020-7898-2380.

webTitle: Pressure mounts to play  Footsie without sandals

fields.headline: Pressure mounts to play  Footsie without sandals
fields.standfirst: Socially responsible investments take centre stage, but new ethical indices will exclude half the big companies
fields.trailText: Socially responsible investments take centre stage, but new ethical indices will exclude half the big companies.
fields.body:
Half of Britain's biggest companies fail to meet ethical and environmental tests, according to the company which compiles the Footsie index.

This week, FTSE International launched a series of ethical indices, putting pressure on companies to behave in a more socially responsible manner, and giving investors a yardstick to measure their ethical investments. Backing the launch was actor Roger Moore on behalf of children's charity Unicef, which will receive a 40% share of the fees generated by the indices.

The FTSE4Good indices will only include companies that have a credible record on the environment, human rights, and social issues, resulting in the likely expulsion of firms involved in activities from weapons to cigarette manufacturing. "Research to date suggests that over 50% of the constituents for each region may fail to be included in the FTSE4Good indices," says FTSE International.

The launch of the indices, and a new ethical index-tracking fund for small in vestors, are more evidence that socially responsible investing, once derided by City institutions as the province of sandal-wearing vegans, has moved to centre stage.

Since 1984, when Friends Provident unveiled the first ethical fund in the UK, cash invested in socially responsible unit trusts has grown to more than £3bn. The past year alone has seen a raft of new ethical fund launches and the industry reckons that the total cash under management will hit £10bn in less than three years' time.

Last year, new legislation came into force requiring pension funds, the biggest investors in the stock market, to publicly disclose the extent to which they take into account environmental, social or ethical considerations.

As increasing numbers of pension funds choose to 'index' their investments, FTSE ethical indices are likely to appeal to pension fund trustees. Surveys show that three out of four pension contributors want their fund to have an ethical policy, and pick oppressive regimes, polluters and animal product testing companies as the main areas they want to avoid.

The FTSE4Good UK index will go live in June, and to tie in with the launch Close Fund Management will be offering a new fund which will track the index.

Close managing director Marc Gordon says: "There is a massive tide in favour of ethical investment. Unlike other ethical funds, which have tended to end up investing in smaller companies, this fund is going to be in vesting in some of the biggest companies in Britain, and is about engagement with companies to improve things rather than exclusion because they don't meet certain criteria."

However, this fund is not the first ethical index-tracker. Both Legal & General and NPI offer funds which track indices minus companies that are screened out on ethical grounds and in the US, Dow Jones launched an ethical index in September 1999.

Does it pay to go ethical? Like everything in investment, the answer is not clear-cut. A study by the Ethical Investment Research Service (Eiris) in 1999 found that annualised returns on ethical funds were a shade below those of other funds which are not ethically screened. However, it found that ethical funds enjoyed lower volatility and better consistency of returns than ordinary funds.

A separate study by Swiss bank Sarasin of 65 European shares concluded that returns from ethical investment were "at least comparable with those for more traditional equity investment".

Increasingly, ethical considerations by companies are considered to be good professional practice. "If companies are addressing issues about socially responsible investment, it tends to suggest that they are treating other areas professionally as well, which in turn suggests they are likely to be well-managed, which in turns suggests their share prices will outperform," says Close's Mr Gordon.

Small investors currently have a choice of around 50 ethical unit trusts, and from April 6 they should be able to opt for ethical investment within their stakeholder pensions.

The giant of the sector is Friends Provident Stewardship, which has £600m under management and a steady, if unspectacular, performance record. An investment of £1,000 in the fund five years ago would now be worth £1,644, which places it just above the average for all unit trusts of £1,639.

However, last year was a poor year for the stock market overall and for Friends Provident Stewardship. It slipped by 5.3% during 2000, compared to an average fall of 1.3% for all unit trusts.

The leader last year was Jupiter Ecology, which earned its investors a return of 13%, followed by Clerical Medical Evergreen, and another Jupiter fund, Environmental Opportunities. However, few ethical funds managed to make a positive return last year, with the worst producing losses of nearly 15%.

webTitle: Film review: Sound on Film Live

fields.headline: The Barbican's musical jellyfish
fields.standfirst:
Sound on Film Live
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Sound on Film Live
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
When film directors and composers get together, it's usually clear who calls the shots. The music does what the images demand, or that dazzling scherzo heads for the cutting-room floor. But collaborations designed as more equal encounters are riskier, especially when performed live. Are we there to watch or to listen?

The other distracting thing about the four BBC commissions opening the Barbican's Only Connect festival was that each was prefaced by an on-stage interview with the composer and/or director. It's hard to keep an open mind after hearing John Tavener and Werner Herzog announce that they were searching for "an ecstatic truth".

Their collaboration Pilgrimage suffered from an over-bearing sense of its own holiness. The piece was a repetitive alternation of two words, one in Greek, one in Sanskrit, in the rich, deep voice of Sufi singer Parvin Cox, with tolling bells to underline the numinousness of it all. Herzog's images were a loosely edited ragbag of footage of pilgrims in Mexico and Siberia, intercut with geyser-like waves on Christmas Island. The overall effect was of a National Geographic tribute to global spirituality.

Hal Hartley and composer Louis Andriessen had rather more fun. The composer's shrieky modernism - rendered on voice, violin, marimba and baroque flute by the Electra ensemble - was spiced up by Michel van der Aa' s electronics, creating an intriguing blur between the live music and the film's own sound. But the visuals, crammed with allusions to German Expressionist and Soviet cinema and martial arts movies, were more than a little arch in the way that only Hartley's work can be.

Nicolas Roeg and Portishead's Adrian Utley offered a digital FX extravaganza about music, memory and the unfathomable inner being of Claudia Schiffer. Utley provided a sometimes dizzying collage of music, phone calls and cosmic chirrups. But the bad-acid visuals - Schiffer's face exploding into a trillion electrons, white lace panties bobbing underwater intercut with a jellyfish - delved into hitherto uncharted realms of kitsch.

The night's one unqualified success was In Absentia, from the Brothers Quay and Karlheinz Stockhausen. Ostensibly, the visuals were typical Quay: a mix of animation, live action and shadow-show sketching out a vestigial narrative about a woman obsessively writing letters in an asylum. But the violence of the music - with harsh, intense swathes of synthesiser and screeching organ - brought out extreme new tonalities in the Quays' imagery, especially in the swells and blasts of white light, in retina-scorching digital projection. This dazzling piece of work, I suspect, was the only one of these collaborations that will have a life of its own outside the programme.

 The Sound on Film series screens on BBC2 from March 12 to March 15 at 11.20pm.

fields.headline: Buying Isas online saves time
fields.standfirst: This Isa season will be the true test of whether investors have woken up to the competitive deals available from a phenomenon imported from the US - the fund supermarket, writes Marianne Curphey
fields.trailText: This Isa season will be the true test of whether investors have woken up to the competitive deals available from a phenomenon imported from the US - the fund supermarket, writes Marianne Curphey
fields.body:
Fund supermarkets are financial services companies which allow you to mix and match your Isa funds. Most allow you to do this via the internet.

It can be cheaper and more flexible than buying directly from a fund management house and the fund supermarkets earn their commission from a portion of the management fee which the fund management company would have retained for itself.

If you were to buy direct from the fund management company it would not refund any commission to you. Independent financial advisers who sell products from fund supermarkets tend to waive or reduce the initial charge for setting up the fund via an agreement with the fund management company.

The true fund supermarkets allow you to buy funds from several different providers within one Isa without having to pay extra charges associated with self-select Isas. You could hold half of your Isa allowance in a Jupiter unit trust, and half in one from Framlington, without having to pay extra management charges for the Isa wrapper. The drawback is that you can only hold unit trusts or Oeics, so investors who want to hold a selection of individual shares or investment trusts still need to opt for the self-select option.

So are fund supermarkets as good as they sound? Jason Hollands of Bestinvest (Bestinvest), an independent financial adviser which deals with a number of funds supermarkets, believes they are. "The advantages of fund supermarkets are so strong that we cannot see any reason why an investor could possibly want to take out a stocks & shares Isas through a traditional plan if the same funds can be purchased within a supermarket," he says. "They offer more choice, more flexibility and more control over your investments."

Purists argue that only those websites which allow you to buy funds online are true fund supermarkets.

At present, the term is loosely used to describe a website that gives the user access to a range of funds.

Mr Hollands says the ideal online fund supermarket would provide the following:

 The ability to mix and match within one Isa without paying extra charges to a third party;

 The ability to deal online with a credit or debit card in real time and without having to download and print out an application form; and

 The ability to track the progress of your account and manage it online;

Discount brokers are sometimes also referred to as fund supermarkets, although they don't tend to offer the mix and match facility. They are not the best place for novice investors to start building up a long-term fund because they rarely provide advice to buyers and are run on a "execution only" basis.

At present three companies offer the true "mix and match" supermarket facility:

 Egg (egg) whose products are only available to Egg customers;

 FundsNetwork (Fundsnetwork)

 Cofunds (Cofunds) whose products are only available through independent financial advisers. It plans to launch an online buying facility later in the year.

Marianne Curphey is the author of E-cash, a step-by-step guide to managing your money online, and the editor of Money, the Guardian's personal finance website.

webTitle: How you can mix and match with a maxi

fields.headline: How you can mix and match with a maxi
fields.standfirst: Investment savings accounts are surprisingly flexible despite complex rules, says Ian Wylie
fields.trailText: The complex and confusing rules surrounding Isas are a good remedy for insomnia, so it's hardly surprising that so many investors sleepwalked into their first Isas, with a mini in stocks and shares, rather than a maxi, or vice versa. Savers who want to use up both their cash and stocks and shares allowances need to be particularly wide awake.
fields.body:
The complex and confusing rules surrounding Isas are a good remedy for insomnia, so it's hardly surprising that so many investors sleepwalked into their first Isas, with a mini in stocks and shares, rather than a maxi, or vice versa. Savers who want to use up both their cash and stocks and shares allowances need to be particularly wide awake.

Thanks to the generosity of the chancellor, savers can now salt away up to £3,000 tax-free in a cash mini-Isa this year and for the next four years.

Unfortunately, by buying cash mini-Isas, tax-efficient savers are prevented from buying maxi-Isas in the same tax year. Instead, if they wish to invest in shares or funds via the tax-free wrapper of an Isa, they have to opt for a stocks and shares mini-Isa, which limits them to investing just £3,000 - less than half the £7,000 permitted in a maxi-Isa.

For many, this is not a problem. The tax-break on cash mini-Isas will be more valuable than that on a stocks and shares Isa. Cash Isas give a complete exemption from income tax on the interest received, while stocks and shares Isas are still liable in effect for some income tax on dividends - although they have a complete exemption from capital gains tax, and no income tax is paid on bonds or bond funds within them.

The alternative is to buy a maxi-Isa with a provider who also offers a cash element. For example, if you are stock market-friendly, but feel that £5,000, say, is your maximum "inaccessible" investment, you can still put that £5,000 into a maxi plan, topping it up with a £2,000 cash holding. Buying two mini-Isas permits a total investment in equities and cash of £6,000 a year. Buying a single maxi-Isa enables the investor to bump up that total to £7,000, presuming he or she does not wish to use up the £1,000 insurance entitlement (which few do).

But savers should be aware that they are unlikely to get such good rates on the cash Isa element from plan managers, who are primarily interested in share-based investment.

Not surprisingly, the maxi-Isa providers paying the most generous rates on cash deposits are primarily the banks and building societies. Bristol & West pays tiered rates of interest on cash held in its maxi-Isa starting at 5.5% on deposits of just £10 rising to 6.4% on deposits of £3,000. Bradford & Bingley pays out 6.75% on cash held in the Capitalsaver part of its maxi-Isa, while Alliance & Leicester pays 7% on £3,000 deposits held in its maxi-Isa. Such rates compare favourably with the interest paid on cash mini-Isas. Rates paid by Bristol & West and Bradford & Bingley on cash held in either their mini- or maxi-Isas match up exactly, while the rate paid by Alliance & Leicester on its maxi-Isa actually exceeds the 6.15% it pays to mini-cash Isa savers with £3,000 to deposit.

The trouble is, if past performance figures are anything to go by, the banks and building societies are not the obvious places to go looking if you want to maximise the return on the stocks and shares component of your maxi-Isa. Seductive rates of interest on cash deposits are sometimes just a bait to draw inexperienced investors to a mediocre or poor-performing investment fund at the core of the maxi-Isa.

But there are a few investment houses paying decent if not outstanding interest on cash deposits in their maxi-Isas. Alliance, for example pays up to 5%, Gartmore pays a flat rate of 5.46%, Jupiter pays 4.30% while Legal & General is paying 4.75%.

The cash element of a maxi-Isa is probably the most undersold feature of Isas and is not very widely used,say investment experts. They conclude that the real benefit is flexibility. Putting just £1 in a cash mini-Isa whittles down your stocks and shares entitlement to just £3,000. By using the cash element of a maxi you can mop up an extra £1,000 in stocks and shares.

But advisers warn that the rules state investors cannot move money from the cash part of a maxi into the stocks and shares part. There are some plans which "phase in" cash to a stocks and shares maxi-Isa. In these cases, cash reserves must be used to buy shares. There will be a tax liability at a flat rate of 20% on interest if it exceeds £50 in any tax year.

fields.headline: Peter Grimes
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.body:
For many, Benjamin Britten's Peter Grimes is a national treasure: it is the British opera. On one level you can understand its wide appeal. The depiction of the sea in all its moods - from the magical to the terrifying - is wonderfully vivid. And Britten's compassionate, penetrating music brings the characters to life in ways only hinted at in the libretto.

But the message remains hard to fathom. Every character is deeply flawed. Grimes may have visionary qualities, but his treatment of his boy apprentices, emotionally and physically, is appalling. The widow Ellen Orford is hopelessly deluded about him, and her misguided attempts to help are partly responsible for one boy's death. Captain Balstrode may seem a relatively earthed character, but he's the one who sends Grimes to his wretched end at sea. The villagers are horrific as a mob, but are portrayed sympathetically as individuals. There are no heroes and no villains, only victims.

Britten's vision of humanity seems to be one of helplessness, the heartless sea making nonsense of human aspirations. Or at least, that was the feeling after this semi-staged concert performance.

There have been singers - Philip Langridge is a recent example - who have made the opera focus much more on Grimes himself. With Langridge, the drama of the sea was a reflection of Grimes's inner turbulence. There are qualities in John Daszak's voice that resemble Langridge. But moving as he was in the final mad scene, Daszak came nowhere near his great precursor in depth and power - nor was his intonation quite as steady. Yvonne Kenny's Ellen Orford too was only partially successful: tender in her scenes with the boy, but less involving as the mad scene approached, and with signs of strain at the top of her vocal register.

And yet the performances still packed a punch. This was partly due to excellent singing and characterisation in some of the lesser roles: Andrew Forbes-Lane as the deranged lay-preacher Bob Boles, Anne Wilkins as the brothel-keeper Auntie, and Jeremy Huw Williams as the apothecary Ned Keene. Leading them was Steven Page's Balstrode, arrogant one moment, understanding the next.

The City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus and Youth Chorus were splendid, as was the CBSO itself under Sakari Oramo. Details that get lost when the orchestra is placed in the theatre pit emerged with fresh clarity. Under Oramo's direction the pacing was compelling from the start, and got better as the evening progressed. Not a perfect Grimes, but one to leave you thinking.

This was partly due to excellent singing and characterisation in some of the lesser roles: Andrew Forbes-Lane as the deranged lay-preacher Bob Boles, Anne Wilkins as the brothel-keeper Auntie, and Jeremy Huw Williams as the apothecary Ned Keene. Leading them was Steven Page's Balstrode, arrogant one moment, understanding the next. The City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus and Youth Chorus were splendid, as was the CBSO itself under Sakari Oramo. Details that get lost when the orchestra is placed in the theatre pit emerged with fresh clarity. Under Oramo's direction the pacing was compelling from the start, and got better as the evening progressed. Not a perfect Grimes, but one to leave you thinking.

fields.body:
Tanika Gupta's salty new version of Brecht is both in yer face and on yer bike - it requires a hardy volunteer to ignite a pedal-powered lighting rig. Rarely has a staging of Brecht's difficult political parable generated such electricity. Stephen Powell, director of the National Theatre's tour for students, has turned this play into a theatre workshop that is also the show. The audience are not so much on the edge of their seats as hardly ever in them.

It's tricksy - and very Brechtian, of course - and turns the evening, as the author envisaged, into an interactive experience. Whether he had an earnest student union debate in mind is a moot point; but you have to admire anything that has a captive crowd with Setzuan on the syllabus shrieking their approval rather than politely sitting to attention.

There only remains to negotiate the technical difficulty of slipping under the radar of the Brecht estate. These hallowed guardians of the text, much like the executors of Beckett, do not take kindly to mucking about with Brecht: a rich concept given that Brecht enjoyed mucking about with any theatrical convention he could. Powell has come up with an ingenious ruse - a naked red light bulb suspended above the action that is lit when echt-Brecht is in progress and goes out when liberties are being taken. Needless to say, the fixture flickers so regularly that one hopes the on-stage electrician has several spare fuses handy.

Gupta's breezy colloquialism observes the spirit rather than the letter of the text, and is lustily put across by a versatile, multi-ethnic cast. The abstract problem of an allegorical society governed by gods is solved by suggesting that our new deities could be rock stars, supermodels and footballers. A sop to a youthful audience, perhaps, yet it seemed briefly that an obstreperous, dead German polemicist had somehow snuck into the pantheon.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 0161-274 0600. Then tours to London, Warwick, Harrogate, Norwich, Brecon, Worthing and Truro.
